HEADLINE: China Has Held American 18 Months Without Charges 

BYLINE:  By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 7 

 BODY:
A 66-year-old naturalized American citizen has been jailed here for 18 months on suspicion of gathering state secrets, his relatives and American officials revealed today.
 In violation of Chinese legal procedure, the man, Fuming Fong, an electrical engineer from West Orange, N.J., still has not been formally indicted. And for most of his detention, his family says, Mr. Fong has been subjected to a gratuitous torment: he has been deprived of his badly needed eyeglasses and hearing aid. 
 The jailing of Mr. Fong is the latest of several cases involving the arrest of Chinese-born Americans on vague security grounds. 
After one-and-a-half years of seeking his release quietly, Mr. Fong's wife and two sons are taking his case to Congress and the American public, and it threatens to become a new irritant in Chinese-American relations just as President Bush prepares for his first official visit here next month. Chinese leaders are eager to strengthen ties with the United States, which they see as vital to their country's modernization. 
Mr. Fong's relatives insist that he is innocent. The accusations against him center on technical documents that Mr. Fong had assembled in his laptop computer in his role as a consultant to American power companies. He was detained on Feb. 28, 2000, shortly after arriving in Beijing for a meeting with the American company Babcock & Wilcox, which was bidding for a contract for a power transmission project financed by the World Bank.
Mr. Fong never arrived at that meeting, but it appears that the authorities were more concerned about documents he had from earlier projects, his relatives said.
"The Chinese have blatantly violated their own criminal procedure law," said Jerome Cohen, a lawyer in New York who is advising Mr. Fong's family. Mr. Fong was formally arrested in September 2000 but not indicted on specific charges. Even with all allowable extensions, Mr. Cohen said, Mr. Fong should have been indicted or released within seven months after his formal arrest.
"They haven't been able to come up with any plausible rationale for holding him 18 months without an indictment," said Mr. Cohen, who has long experience in China and has advised several other Chinese-born American citizens and green-card holders who were arrested here.
On Thursday, Mr. Cohen and one of Mr. Fong's sons, an engineer who asked that his name be withheld, traveled to Washington, where they raised his case with members of Congress from New Jersey, hoping to build pressure for answers from the Chinese government.
In some well-publicized recent cases of American citizens or permanent residents arrested on security grounds, Chinese authorities convicted them, then deported them. 
The American Embassy confirmed today that Mr. Fong was in detention and had been visited numerous times by consular officers, who have recently been able to deliver needed medications. But officials said that, under American privacy law, they cannot discuss details of the case. 
Mr. Fong was a senior engineer and an electric-power official in Zhejiang Province before he moved to the United States in the late 1980's to become a private consultant. His wife, who was born in the United States while her parents were attending graduate school there in the 1930's, was already an American citizen, and Mr. Fong was naturalized as a citizen in 1994. 
Mr. Fong was initially accused of bribing Chinese officials to obtain confidential information. But security agents soon decided to treat the technical documents in his computer as state secrets, and Mr. Fong is being held in a Beijing detention center of the Ministry of State Security, which handles spy cases. 
According to a statement by his family, Mr. Fong told a lawyer that none of the documents had been marked as confidential. Most were from previous power projects, he said, and many had been provided to him by his multinational clients. 
As for the accusations of bribery, the authorities have not provided any details or evidence, the family said, nor is there any sign that any Chinese officials have been arrested for giving him secret documents.
Mr. Fong is extremely nearsighted and hard of hearing, his relatives said, but for most of the last year, for unexplained reasons, he was not allowed to wear his glasses, and he is still denied use of his hearing aid.
"Not being able to hear makes him feel helpless, and it's driving him crazy," one of his relatives said today.
Lately, he has been given his glasses when he needs to write documents, but for months he has been unable to read.
After nearly a year of being denied access to a lawyer "on the ground that the case involves state secrets," his family said, the authorities relented, and he has had five visits from a Chinese lawyer. But these visits have been of limited use, Mr. Cohen said, in part because Mr. Fong had trouble hearing the lawyer through the glass partition.
Though he lives in the United States, Mr. Fong works for a Hong Kong consulting firm. In his work, Mr. Fong has helped several American companies win power projects in China and Southeast Asia. The family, in its statement, said his work in China had involved only projects financed by international development institutions that "strictly adhere to international open-bidding practices."
On Aug. 15, the relatives filed a formal petition protesting Mr. Fong's prolonged detention without charges and asking for his release on bail. By law, they should have received an answer within seven days but have heard nothing.
Mr. Cohen said he had learned that state security and police officials had twice tried to present a case for prosecution, but that both times the prosecutors had sent it back for lack of convincing evidence.
Cases involving Americans may receive global publicity, but Mr. Fong's treatment also shows the general flaws in China's justice system. 
"This is one of tens of thousands of cases where the investigations exceed the time limits," Mr. Cohen said. "It happens all the time."
"The police just pay no attention to the rules," he said. "But now in this case they've run out of excuses."

HEADLINE: Lost Files Jeopardize Choices By Clinton for Kennedy Center 

BYLINE:  By DON VAN NATTA Jr. and ELAINE SCIOLINO 

 BODY:
It is not unusual for Washington's elite to jockey for the best seats in the house at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. But in an unusually bitter cultural contretemps, Clinton loyalists and the Bush White House are fighting over who should occupy seats on the center's socially and politically influential board of trustees. 
 A seat on the board of the Kennedy Center is one of the most prized plums a president can bestow, and former President Bill Clinton selected five lucky men for the honor as he was preparing to leave the White House. They expected six-year terms and special boxes at the center's concert halls. But there has been a hitch because the Bush administration says it cannot find the official records of Mr. Clinton's appointments, board members and administration officials said today. The official commission papers for the appointments, signed by Mr. Clinton in December, are missing and the appropriate filing procedure may not have been followed, officials said. 
 So the position of the Bush White House is: no papers, no appointments.
Among those caught in the cultural crossfire are two prominent Democratic fund-raisers, Smith Bagley, the grandson of the tobacco magnate R. J. Reynolds, and Mark S. Weiner, president of the Democratic Governors Association.
Scrambling to salvage the appointments, aides to Mr. Clinton are frantically searching for copies of the papers among the former president's archives of millions of White House documents at a warehouse in Little Rock, Ark., an aide to Mr. Clinton said. A search in August failed to turn up the papers. A second, more comprehensive search began last week, officials said.
A seat on the Kennedy Center's board of trustees is a prestigious political honor. It is like no other performing arts board in America. Thirty of its 47 trustees are appointed to six-year terms by the president, often as consolation prizes to friends and fund-raisers who do not get ambassadorships or who cannot move overseas. By law, among the other 17 members are 3 members of the cabinet, 10 members of Congress, the Washington mayor, the director of the National Park Service and the librarian of Congress.
Several trustees said the board, which is a fiercely nonpartisan group, is trying to resist getting caught in the middle of a contentious dispute between members of the Clinton and Bush administrations.
"It's astonishing; it's awful," said James D. Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank and a former chairman of the board of the Kennedy Center, in a telephone interview. Mr. Wolfensohn emphasized that he had heard only rumors of the appointment problem, but said, "It's clearly a sad state of affairs and doesn't help the institution because of the uncertainty it creates."
Tiki Davies, the Kennedy Center spokesman, said, "The Kennedy Center has no comment."
But a longtime board member said: "Everyone at the Kennedy Center is heartsick -- it's a great shame. It is a tremendous disappointment for the people who were appointed. They didn't do it. The papers fell through the cracks somewhere."
In addition to Mr. Bagley and Mr. Weiner, the trustees whose appointments are now in doubt are Frank H. Pearl, a lawyer and chairman of the venture capital firm Perseus Capital; William F. McSweeney, the emeritus chairman of Ford's Theater; and Thomas E. Wheeler, the president and chief executive officer of the Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association. 
Anne Womack, assistant White House press secretary, said the Bush administration had not threatened to block the five Clinton appointees if the commission records were not found. "We're working with the Kennedy Center," Ms. Womack said. "If they don't find them, we'll cross that bridge when we come to it."
Earlier this year, the executive clerk's office told officials in the White House personnel office that there were five vacancies on the Kennedy Center Board. But while the Bush officials began compiling a list of potential nominees, they learned from Kennedy Center officials that there were no openings on the board.
"That's when we discovered there was no paperwork backing up these five appointments," Ms. Womack said. "There is no official record of them ever being commissioned."
A Democratic strategist with knowledge of the dispute said, "The White House made it clear, if those records can't be found, they will block the appointments of the Clinton guys and go with their own people."
The five appointees, who first heard of the missing papers in July, have hired Robert A. Long of the powerful Washington law firm Covington & Burling. They have discussed filing a lawsuit against the Bush administration. The appointees either declined to comment or could not be reached for comment.
Behind the scenes, there have been bitter recriminations on both sides, and the dispute has inflamed political passions among some current Kennedy Center board members.
A Democrat who is a friend of Mr. Clinton speculated that the White House may have purposefully lost the documents so they could have the appointments for Mr. Bush. But a Republican supporter of the center scoffed at the notion and said: "Think of the last few weeks of that administration. It was chaos. It's hardly a surprise that these records were lost. If only this happened to the Marc Rich pardon."
Although their appointments might be challenged, the five men's names appear as presidential appointees on the Kennedy Center Web site. Their names are on the Kennedy Center stage bills that are distributed to audiences at every performance. And at least two of the trustees are committee chairmen. Mr. Pearl is chairman of the finance committee, and Mr. Wheeler is chairman of the personnel committee.
The appointment process is complicated. The documents that literally make the appointments, called commissions, should have gone from the White House personnel office to the White House executive clerk's office. From there, the papers should have been filed with the secretary of state's office, which usually makes an appointment of this sort official. In this case, the documents may have never left the White House, officials said.
News of the appointment problem has been closely held, and some of the trustees said this week they were unaware of it. Even James H. Billington, the librarian of Congress, who sits on the board's executive committee, said in a telephone interview today that he knew nothing about it.

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGNING FOR CITY HALL: THE RECORD; 
Bloomberg Philanthropy Cuts Two Ways as Campaign Issue

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

 BODY:
Last year, when Michael R. Bloomberg was consulting political advisers and gearing up for a bid for mayor, his charitable giving doubled from the year before. Compared with three years earlier, the increase was nearly fourfold, growing to $100.5 million from $26.6 million.
 In dispensing the enlarged bankroll last year, Mr. Bloomberg added nearly 200 new organizations, including 79 in New York City that covered a broad spectrum of causes he had not supported during the previous three years, according to four years of partial tax returns he made available to the news media. 
 It is not possible to determine how much money Mr. Bloomberg gave to the new charities because the tax information does not list the donations given to individual groups. The information does show that the number of New York City charities, as a proportion of the total, has remained more or less constant over the years. 
Some of the charities that have most recently been added to Mr. Bloomberg's list are the Tanenbaum Center for Interreligious Understanding on Fifth Avenue, which got a cash donation, as did the Staten Island Children's Museum and NYC2012, the committee that promotes the city's Olympic ambitions.
Also for the first time, Mr. Bloomberg bought tickets to fund-raisers for the Eye Bank for Sight Restoration on Wall Street and for the Grand Central Partnership, a business improvement district on East 42nd Street. Another newcomer was the Children's Health Fund on East 64th Street, which got money from Mr. Bloomberg to help pay for a "doctor's office on wheels" that serves poor children in the Bronx.
His opponent in the Republican primary, Herman Badillo, makes the argument that Mr. Bloomberg was looking to buy the good will of New Yorkers -- or perhaps exaggerate the scope and breadth of his generosity -- as a backdrop to his mayoral bid. 
"Last year, he gave twice as much money as he had in the previous year," Mr. Badillo said in an interview. "Clearly, it was all geared to his mayoral campaign. Clearly, his philanthropy has been used for political purposes."
A senior aide to Mr. Badillo, James S. Vlasto, suggested the surge in Mr. Bloomberg's giving separated him from other rich politicians like Nelson Rockefeller or Robert Kennedy.
"With other families of wealth over the years, the Rockefellers or the Kennedys, the giving was done quietly, effectively and consistently over a long period of time," he said. "For Mike Bloomberg, we do feel the jump was an appeal to try and gain some political edge."
Mr. Bloomberg's campaign bristles at the suggestion that any of his giving has been influenced by politics. A review of Mr. Bloomberg's philanthropy since 1997 shows no evidence of a broad pattern of political calculation leading up to his candidacy. 
"They are ridiculous allegations," said Patricia E. Harris, who oversees Mr. Bloomberg's philanthropic giving at his company, Bloomberg L.P., and who also works as an adviser on his mayoral campaign. "We are trying to make a difference and leave a legacy of people who get involved in their community."
Mr. Bloomberg is using some of the charities with which he is affiliated to promote his candidacy. 
A pamphlet mailed this week features Mr. Bloomberg's new sponsorship of the Bronx medical van under the general heading, "Protecting and preparing our children." The same contribution for the van is also mentioned in a 12-page biographical brochure, which has been among Mr. Bloomberg's most widely distributed campaign literature.
In most elections, philanthropy would be an odd bone of contention among candidates. But the motivations behind Mr. Bloomberg's charity have unusual relevance in this year's race because Mr. Bloomberg has made philanthropy a defining element of his public persona, featuring it in television advertisements, campaign literature and in his stump speeches.
Just as Mr. Badillo has emphasized his record as Bronx borough president, deputy mayor and congressman, Mr. Bloomberg, who has never before sought public office, has tried to distinguish himself through his experience as a successful businessman and as a serious doer of good. His record of charitable gifts is one of the few public windows Mr. Bloomberg has opened into his largely private world.
Typically, when asked on the campaign trail why he is running for mayor, Mr. Bloomberg cites his philanthropy and speaks of a burning desire to "give back" to New York.
"I am luckier than anyone has the right to be," he told a crowd last month on the Upper East Side.
A Bloomberg television advertisement shows him and some of his employees painting a run-down school with Publicolor, a charity he has supported. In a mailing last month to Jewish voters, he described himself as "one of the Jewish community's most dedicated volunteers and most generous donors." In a pamphlet sent this week to Hispanic voters, he boasted about his financial support of the United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce.
In an interview, Mr. Bloomberg said he made the decision at the beginning of the campaign to be open about his philanthropy -- to the point of providing the news media with the names of more than 1,000 organizations he has supported in recent years -- in part to counter any suspicions that he was secretly promoting his candidacy under the guise of charity.
"You had no choice," Mr. Bloomberg said. "Remember, there were issues before of other candidates trying to buy votes and I wanted to make sure that nobody thought we were doing that."
He added: "My personal philanthropy would stay totally private if it weren't for this campaign. I don't think it is anybody's business."
Mr. Bloomberg said he gave a lot of money to organizations in New York because his company is based here. Though his tax information did not include foreign giving, he said he also made major contributions to organizations in London, where his company has its European headquarters.
The level of his giving is almost always related to the profitability of his company, he said, and therefore rose markedly during the economic boom in the late 1990's. While his company may derive some tax benefits from its charitable donations, Mr. Bloomberg's personal tax returns show he is already in the highest tax bracket and his campaign said he derived no tax benefit from the additional giving. 
Dr. Alfred Sommer, dean of the Bloomberg School of Public Health at Johns Hopkins University, said Mr. Bloomberg began making more gifts anonymously once he became serious about running for mayor. He said Mr. Bloomberg actually reined in some of his high-profile philanthropy in anticipation of criticism like that leveled by the Badillo campaign. 
"I am a New Yorker, we are a cynical bunch and I know that rap is easy," said Dr. Sommer, whose school in Baltimore has been among the biggest recipients of Mr. Bloomberg's charity. "As it got closer to this mayoral race, his concern was that he didn't want it to be perceived he was giving for that reason. He saw a backlash effect."
Even with Mr. Bloomberg's emphasis on his philanthropy during the campaign, it is hard to substantiate the Badillo campaign's broader claim of political calculation, based on the tax information made available by the Bloomberg campaign.
The gift last year to the Children's Health Fund was a three-year commitment that was nearly 18 months in the making, according to Judith Jorrisch, vice president of development at the fund, a charitable organization. Ms. Jorrisch said her office approached Mr. Bloomberg in early 1999 about making the contribution, which she said exceeded $50,000 a year.
"We came to them cold and asked for the money," Ms. Jorrisch said. "In our quest for new supporters, we thought Mike Bloomberg and his company would be a perfect fit."
In 1997, well before Mr. Bloomberg nailed down his plans for seeking public office, he gave generously and much of the money went to charities in New York City. And the year before, he was ranked 13th on Fortune magazine's list of the country's most generous philanthropists.
While Mr. Bloomberg's giving grew substantially thereafter, most of the increase can be traced to the huge donations to Johns Hopkins, his alma mater. Johns Hopkins announced in May an anonymous pledge of $100 million to establish an institute devoted to the treatment of malaria. An official at the university, who declined to be identified, said this week that Mr. Bloomberg, who had publicly donated $100 million to the university, was the source of the anonymous pledge as well.
"He has been very well known in the world of philanthropy," said Stacy Palmer, editor of The Chronicle of Philanthropy, which published a profile of Mr. Bloomberg as philanthropist in May 1997. "It is not just the amount he donates. He is also quite a gifted fund-raiser from what we hear."
In the years leading up to his bid for mayor, Mr. Bloomberg's giving rose steadily in terms of the total number of recipients and those with operations based in New York City, according to an analysis of the tax information by The New York Times. Last year, 577 organizations received money from Mr. Bloomberg, compared with 425 in 1997. Of those on the list last year, 309 were based in the city. The corresponding number in 1997 was 228.
But the percentage of New York recipients was similarly proportionate over the four years. And since his campaign would not disclose the amount of money provided to individual organizations, it was impossible to gauge the significance of the New York component.
Ms. Harris said some contributions were as small as $500; the biggest donations, she said, have consistently gone to the 20 organizations where Mr. Bloomberg holds a position on the board. He has supported some of them, like the New York Police and Fire Widows' and Children's Benefit Fund, for more than a decade.
"I can only promise you that he has never asked for anything," said Rusty Staub, the fund's chairman, who appeared on a campaign advertisement for Mr. Bloomberg. "He has only asked how he can help."
Mr. Bloomberg has long offered an interpretation of philanthropy that emphasizes both giving and receiving. 
"The fact of the matter is it's very good for business," Mr. Bloomberg said in the article in The Chronicle of Philanthropy. "People respect you because of it. People talk about you because of it. You've got to believe when my company takes a table at a fund-raising dinner for 10 grand, we get our money's worth." 
Mr. Bloomberg devoted a chapter to his views about philanthropy in his autobiography, "Bloomberg by Bloomberg," which was published in 1997.
"It all helps the bottom line," he wrote. "Companies that don't understand that don't do as well as they could."
In the chapter about philanthropy he writes about the attraction of politics and mentions three jobs that might interest him: mayor, governor and president. At the time he was writing the book, Mr. Bloomberg was contemplating what he wanted to do with the rest of his life and with his money, a process that led to the decision last year to run for mayor, several associates said.
But like most things about Mr. Bloomberg and his enormous fortune -- according to Forbes magazine, his estimated worth of $4 billion last year made him the sixth richest man in New York City -- it is hard to separate the man, the media mogul and the candidate.
Alphabetical lists of charitable organizations included in the tax information made no distinction between personal gifts from Mr. Bloomberg and gifts from his privately held company or from a family foundation he established.
Ms. Harris said the source of the check was not important; it was all Mr. Bloomberg's money.
Should he be elected, Mr. Bloomberg said his commitment to philanthropy would not change, even with the heightened level of scrutiny it would undoubtedly receive. However, he is likely to make one change: he said he would erect a very high wall between his mayoral office and his philanthropy office.
"You can't put yourself in the place where, if the city budget can't do something, then every constituent group will say I should pay for it from my personal funds," Mr. Bloomberg said.

HEADLINE: Saying Too Many Are Losing Jobs, Bush Pushes His Policies 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 

 BODY:
President Bush said today that "too many people are losing their jobs," and he cast the surge in the unemployment rate as reason for Congress to advance his economic agenda by expanding trade agreements and reducing energy costs while holding down government spending.
 "The slowdown is real, and it's affecting too many lives, and we're concerned about it," Mr. Bush said. "Any American out of work is too many Americans out of work." 
 His hastily arranged appearance outside the Oval Office this afternoon reflected growing concern among his aides and officials of his party that the deteriorating economic and budget outlook could dearly cost the White House and Congressional Republicans politically.
Even as Republicans scrambled to contain the fallout from the unemployment figures, the White House budget director, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., told Republican leaders on Capitol Hill that the softening economy might bite more deeply into tax revenues in the current fiscal year than had been anticipated. Republican aides said Mr. Daniels suggested that Congress and the administration faced a greater likelihood of having to spend money generated by the Social Security system than the White House had acknowledged.
With Wall Street tumbling on word that the unemployment rate jumped last month to 4.9 percent, a full percentage point above where it was on Election Day 10 months ago, Mr. Bush spoke to reporters, with Vice President Dick Cheney and the leaders of his party in Congress at his side. The country, he said, needs a "growth plan" to reverse a downturn that he pointedly said started before he took office.
But Mr. Bush, the son of a president whose loss in 1992 was widely attributed to a failure to address the last recession more aggressively, seemed mostly intent on assuring voters that he was in touch with what the weakened economy meant to individuals.
"I want the American people to know we're deeply concerned about the unemployment rates and we intend to do something about it," he said.
He did not say, though, what he intended to do, beyond pushing for policies he had been pressing for all along and waiting for his tax cut to give the economy a kick. As he did in selling his tax cut, Mr. Bush used the changing economic situation as further justification for initiatives that he had proposed long before the downturn became apparent.
They included seeking authority from Congress to negotiate international trade agreements. Such a step might benefit the economy in the long run by increasing opportunities to sell American goods abroad, but would be unlikely to come in time to influence the current business cycle.
Mr. Bush also renewed his call for Congress to take steps, like opening up new areas to oil and gas drilling and reducing regulatory restrictions on energy companies to reduce energy costs. Energy prices, however, have already fallen in recent months without any major actions by the government, substantially reducing their drag on the economy.
Mr. Bush's aides said he was confident that the tax cut he signed into law three months ago, combined with the Federal Reserve's campaign of interest rate cuts, would lead the economy to start rebounding by the end of the year.
Today, the Treasury Department sent out the eighth of 10 batches of tax rebate checks of up to $300 for individuals and $600 for couples, money that the administration said should keep consumers spending and help the economy through a temporary rough patch.
Further cuts in income tax rates will take effect in January. 
The president spoke after Democrats stepped up their attacks on the administration's handling of the budget and the economy, saying Mr. Bush had squandered the surplus on an excessive tax cut, pushing up interest rates on Wall Street and undermining confidence among consumers.
"The unemployment level now is at the highest it has been in four years," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic majority leader. "We're at 4.9 percent, and that's intolerable. I think it's a reflection, unfortunately, of the Bush budget and the Bush economy."
Democrats have been working to link the shrinking budget surplus to questions about Mr. Bush's economic management, in part by arguing that Mr. Bush's tax cut is forcing the government to violate pledges by both parties not to use excess money generated by the Social Security tax for other government programs.
The issue became more complex for the White House and its allies in Congress when Mr. Daniels updated the administration's budget outlook for Republican leaders. Last month, the White House projected that the government would barely avoid spending any Social Security money for the fiscal year that ends Sept. 30.
A few Republicans, including Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, have suggested that using part of the retirement system's surplus would be an acceptable way to ease pressure on the economy and the budget. Mr. Bush and most Republican leaders, however, have stuck to their vows not to touch the Social Security money.
Some Republicans floated a plan today under which any further dissipation of the surplus next year that might force the budget to use Social Security money would lead to an automatic across-the-board spending cut.
The idea was discussed at the White House today by J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, the speaker of the House, and Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican minority leader in the Senate.
Republicans said the idea had considerable political appeal, but many practical problems. Among them, they said, was concern that cutting spending in response to a weakening economy would run counter to the traditional economic theory of what a government should do when confronted with a recession or the risk of one. 
Typically, governments have increased spending during economic slowdowns to give the economy a boost; cutting spending at such times would risk harming the economy, economists say.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush in Washington yesterday with Vice President Dick Cheney, left, Senator Trent Lott and House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Fox Urges Scrapping of 54-Year Treaty Between U.S. and Mexico 

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 

 BODY:
President Vicente Fox of Mexico called today for the dismantling of a 54-year-old defense treaty between the United States and Latin American nations that was aimed at protecting the hemisphere against Communism and replacing it with pacts that would combat widespread social ills and organized crime.
 Capping his visit to Washington, Mr. Fox said the Inter-American Reciprocal Assistance Treaty had become obsolete with the end of the cold war and that his government, after consulting with other Latin American nations, would decide within the next 60 days whether to withdraw from it. 
 In some ways, the break with a 1947 treaty that has been strongly supported by the United States seemed at odds with the new spirit of friendship between Mr. Fox and President Bush during the Mexican president's first state visit here. But experts said Mr. Fox wanted to send a strong message to the rest of Latin America that his celebrity reception north of the border had not blinded him to the importance of reaching south. 
With his rising international influence as the head of Mexico's most democratically elected government and with his close ties to Mr. Bush, President Fox seemed to be positioning Mexico as the broker for Latin America before the world. 
"Mexico is determined to play an active role in the work that will be required, by its nature and importance, by all the nations of the Americas," Mr. Fox said. "This is the moment to define the new rules and norms that should regulate the world community."
The Inter-American Reciprocal Assistance Treaty was invoked by President John F. Kennedy to persuade Latin American countries to back the blockade of Cuba during the 1962 missile crisis. 
But speaking to the Organization of American States today, Mr. Fox said Communism was no longer the principal threat to the region. And he urged the organization to begin work on the development of new regional strategies that would take on "the real threats that stalk us," including extreme poverty, human rights abuses, environmental degradation and natural disasters.
His speech laid out a broad vision for the economic and social development of the Americas that one foreign policy adviser to Mr. Fox called a "coming-out address."
At the end of his visit to Washington -- during which he urged new trust from the United States government and challenged Congress to adopt sweeping immigration changes -- Mr. Fox also made clear his position to campaign on behalf of Latin America.
He reminded the meeting of the Organization of American States that his first foreign trips as president were to Central and South America. One of his most sweeping promises is to raise international funds for development projects to spur industrial growth in eight southern Mexican states and the seven nations of Central America.
And although talks between his government and the Zapatista rebels of Chiapas in southern Mexico are in a stalemate, Mr. President Fox has sought ideas on resolving the civil conflict in Colombia.
At the O.A.S. meeting today, the president seemed to be positioning his government to serve as a mediator and advocate on behalf of Latin America. It is a role coveted, but never achieved, by his predecessors. But Mr. Fox does not carry the stigma of Mexico's past authoritarian governments, said Peter Hakim of the Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington research organization. 
"By the force of his election, he can achieve things his predecessors couldn't" Mr. Hakim said. "President Fox is the embodiment of democratic change."
Lorenzo Meyer, a historian and political analyst in Mexico, said, "Fox needs to show that, even now, as Mexico moves closer than ever to the United States, it will not forsake its independence, nor Latin America."
Mr. Fox also used his speech to make clear that he intends to scrap Mexico's traditional philosophy of nonintervention. He announced that he had sent several initiatives to the Mexican Congress that would, for the first time, commit his country to cooperate with and abide by the judgments of international human rights tribunals.
The measures are the focus of heated debate among Mexicans, some of whom say they are a threat to the country's sovereignty. The critics worry that by taking on a more activist role in international affairs, Mexico will open itself to intervention from abroad.
"The danger is that there are a few subterranean nationalists who will come out and critique President Fox," Mr. Hakim said. "But there is not much resonance anymore for such strident nationalism. I don't think it would go anywhere."

HEADLINE: Mexico's President Rewrites the Rules 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 

 BODY:
Rarely has a foreign leader shown up on the South Lawn of the White House and declared that he and the president of the United States "must" remake the fundamental rules that have governed his country's uneasy relationship with the United States -- and get it done in the next four months.
 Yet for President Vicente Fox of Mexico, that was just a start. On Thursday he used an address to Congress to insist on an end to the humiliating ritual of annually certifying that his country was cracking down on drug traffickers. And he argued that the lawmakers should immediately make good on their Nafta commitment to open American roads to Mexican trucks. Lastly, as he left town, he declared that the collective security pact that for half a century has cemented the military ties between Mexico, the United States and much of Latin America ought to be scrapped and that he might pull out of the pact. 
 Such assertiveness is especially notable because it did not come out of the mouth of the leader of a nuclear power or an economic juggernaut. Yet Mr. Fox seemed to pull it off with aplomb during his remarkable visit here, casting himself not only as a political equal of his friend the American president, but as the leader of Latin America. Often as Mr. Fox spoke, President Bush stood nodding at his side, endorsing his principles, even while fudging on the timetable and the politics of it all.
"In many ways this was the reversal of all the traditional roles between the United States and Mexico," said Robert A. Pastor, a professor at Emory University and a former National Security Council official in the Carter administration, who has long been involved in Mexican-American relations.
"In the past it has been the United States that made all the specific proposals," Mr. Pastor said, "and the Mexicans who said 'yes,' but never said when. This time, President Fox made all the proposals, and it was his good friend President Bush who had to say 'yes,' but couldn't say when."
White House officials said they were not surprised by any of Mr. Fox's proposals, all of which they said had been discussed since intensive talks began in February. But clearly, the two leaders' schedules for accomplishing it all are not in sync -- a reflection of the political pressure on Mr. Fox to move as fast as possible, and the pressure on Mr. Bush to shift into low gear.
If Mr. Fox played the role of equal, rather than junior partner this week, it was Mr. Bush who gave him the opportunity.
In the middle of the presidential campaign last year, Mr. Bush repeatedly heralded his friendship with Mr. Fox, who promised long-delayed economic and political changes. "He's a man I know from Mexico," Mr. Bush said in the presidential debates, when he was under pressure to show some familiarity with foreign affairs. Mr. Bush promised that the two leaders would remake the often strained and unequal relationship between the two countries.
Mr. Bush's first trip abroad was to Mr. Fox's ranch. Once there, he repeated his determination to make the United States-Mexican relationship his top foreign policy priority -- even if the British and the Japanese, not to mention the Russians and the Chinese, cringe every time he utters those words.
Mr. Bush, however, is also discovering that a personal friendship is not enough to create the political environment required to turn their broad, mutual agenda into action.
That is especially true when the subject turns to immigration, the most emotion-laden and complex problem facing the two countries -- and one that divides the Republican Party.
Both men learned how deeply that division runs today. Mr. Fox was received with polite enthusiasm in Congress and earned praise for his commitment to democracy.
But Mr. Fox's visit coincided with the news that unemployment in the United States rose to 4.9 percent in August. In back-room conversations with the White House this week many Republicans made it clear that the coming Congressional election year was not the time to legalize the status of nearly 3.5 million illegal Mexican workers in the United States, even if the effort was couched in neutral-sounding terms like "regularization" of migrants.
"It's going to be very, very difficult," said Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, who strongly supports immigration reform. He agrees with Mr. Fox and Mr. Bush that migrant workers are a critical part of the American economy.
But Mr. Hagel noted that on Thursday night it took enormous political lifting just to extend a modest provision allowing certain illegal immigrants with jobs or family sponsors to remain in the country while applying for a green card. 
"To get that done last night you would have thought it was a matter of declaring war," Mr. Hagel said. A broad program to allow millions of illegal immigrants to obtain legal status, he said, "is going to be very tough when all the marbles are on the table -- American jobs and the control of Congress."
Mr. Bush faces perhaps his staunchest opposition in the House, where the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, and the leader of the panel's immigration subcommittee, Representative George W. Gekas, Republican of Pennsylvania, oppose any legalization of undocumented immigrants.
In the Senate, Republican opponents include Senators Jon Kyl of Arizona and Phil Gramm of Texas, who view any legalization plan as a magnet for lawbreakers. "You earn your way to get here by applying legally and coming legally," Mr. Gramm said. "You don't reward people who violated the law in coming here."
The political pressures flow in the other direction as well. American businesses, a crucial Republican constituency, want access to low-wage migrant workers, and they endorse Mr. Fox's plan for a "guest worker" program. Mr. Bush talks constantly of finding a way for a "willing employer" to strike a deal with a "willing worker," but hedges on how broad an amnesty he might be willing to grant.
But on Thursday, Mr. Bush acknowledged that "to make matters even more complicated, we've got to work with the Congress, and we've got to come up with a solution that Congress can accept." His aides have made it clear that any such deal is not likely by Mr. Fox's deadline of the end of the year. 
In his seven and a half months in office, Mr. Bush has not gone as far out on a limb for any other foreign leader. Clearly he treasures his personal relationship with Mr. Fox -- the kind of leader-to-leader diplomacy that his father favored -- just as he thought it important to emphasize the bond he had created with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
But such friendship has its risks, because it associates Mr. Bush with almost all of Mr. Fox's agenda. For example, Mr. Fox was able to prompt Mr. Bush to say that he would veto legislation that kept Mexican trucks off American roads -- where they are entitled to drive under the Nafta treaty. 
"It was quite amazing to hear President Bush talk about how much he wanted to 'accommodate my friend,' " said Mr. Pastor, the Emory University professor. "But President Bush never came back with a specific vision of where he wanted to go that responded to Fox's vision. That was conspicuously missing."

HEADLINE: U.S. JOBLESS RATE IN A JUMP TO 4.9%; BUSH VOWS TO ACT 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The nation's unemployment rate jumped sharply in August to 4.9 percent from 4.5 percent in July, the biggest one-month rise since the spring of 1995, dashing hopes that the bleak economic climate was starting to improve.
 The 4.9 percent jobless rate in August, according to the government's Bureau of Labor Statistics, was the highest since mid-1997. Businesses eliminated more than 100,000 jobs last month, suggesting that the economy remained at risk of falling into a recession. And companies, in an effort to halt steep profit declines, made more cuts this summer in the hours their employees worked. 
 "The economy is facing bigger threats than we had thought," said Jim Glassman, a senior economist at J. P. Morgan Chase. "It's a very weak picture." 
The grim economic news prompted a hastily arranged appearance by President Bush on the White House grounds yesterday, where he sought to assure the public he was aware of the human toll the job losses were taking. Page A9. 
"I want the American people to know we're deeply concerned about the unemployment rates and we intend to do something about it," said Mr. Bush, who has long been aware that the nation's last recession at least in part caused his father to lose his 1992 bid for re-election. 
Mr. Bush called for a "growth plan" to reverse the downturn, but offered no specifics beyond pushing policies that he has advocated before. He urged Congress to move on his proposals for increased energy production and to give him more leeway in negotiating international trade agreements.
The job figures prompted a broad sell-off on Wall Street, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell to its lowest level in almost three years. The dollar also dropped against the euro, and economists said that the Federal Reserve was now likely to keep cutting interest rates until signs of a rebound emerge. Page C1. 
A month ago, the Labor Department had offered some reason for optimism, finding that manufacturers in July cut the fewest jobs in almost a year and reporting a rise in the number of people in the labor force -- those with a job or actively seeking one. But the August numbers erased nearly all of the hopeful signs.
"Today's unemployment numbers are obviously higher than expected," Elaine L. Chao, the secretary of labor, said. "It's disappointing and sobering."
Manufacturing companies -- hurt badly by the plunge in business investment and by the strong dollar, which makes it harder to compete against foreign goods -- accounted for the entire August decline in jobs.
Since early last summer, factories have cut more than one million jobs, or 5.4 percent of their payrolls, and fewer people now work in a manufacturing plant than at any time since 1964. The South and the Midwest have been hardest hit by the manufacturing slump.
Companies in the vast services sector continued to add workers, but at a much slower pace than in recent years. Businesses that are most affected by a slowdown, like restaurants, hotels and movie theaters, cut jobs in August, while doctors' offices, hospitals and other health-care companies added positions.
Most government and Wall Street economists still predict that a rebound is coming soon, though many concede that they have been overly optimistic so far this year. They now say that the $38 billion in tax rebates gives consumers more money to spend -- a point the White House sought to emphasize as well. They also say that the sharp decline in business inventories has set the stage for production increases and that a recent rise in manufacturing orders presages a turnaround.
But they acknowledged that risks remain, chief among them the continued decline in corporate profits that could cause companies to make even deeper jobs cuts. Last month, for example, the Ford Motor Company, in its second major cost-cutting attempt this year, said it would eliminate 5,000 of its 50,000 jobs.
More job reductions could cause consumers to spend less money and leave the economy in a more severe slump. Already, two-thirds of Americans believe that the economy is declining, and most say they plan to save their tax rebate or use it to pay off debt, according to the most recent consumer survey by the University of Michigan.
Even if a rebound does begin in coming weeks, joblessness is likely to continue rising for many months because companies usually do not start rebuilding their workforces until they are confident that business has picked up.
But the report offered little indication that the staff cuts companies have made have gone deep enough to match the declines in sales. The average workweek stayed at 34.1 hours, its lowest two-month average since the government began keeping the statistic almost 40 years ago.
"Companies that had been trying to avoid layoffs are doing it anyway," Mr. Glassman, the Morgan Chase analyst, said. "And despite the cutting they've done, they're not getting ahead of the curve."
The one aspect of the report that gave economists some comfort was the government's revision of its June and July payroll numbers. During those months, the economy was not as weak as the Labor Department had said in its initial estimates: companies and government offices eliminated 86,000 jobs, not 135,000.
In all, the private and public sectors accounted for 132.3 million jobs last month, down 113,000 from July and more than 300,000 from the March peak, according to the Labor Department's payroll survey. Its household survey -- which is used to measure the unemployment rate -- offered an even more pessimistic picture, indicating that 600,000 fewer people are working than at the start of the year.
In either case, the situation is far different from the previous five years, when the economy, on average, added 2.8 million jobs a year.
In the second half of 2000, manufacturers began to suffer as companies -- having decided many of their investments in new buildings, equipment and software would not be profitable -- cut back. With stocks falling and layoffs rising, consumer spending slowed somewhat but has remained strong enough so far to keep the economy barely growing.
By historical standards, unemployment is still relatively low, which has helped keep wages rising. Wages rose at a 3.4 percent annual rate last month, compared with the rise of 3.6 percent averaged over the last year.
In the second quarter, the United States economy grew at an annual rate of just 0.2 percent, according to the Commerce Department's most recent estimate. Many people consider a recession to consist of two consecutive quarters of contraction. Analysts said it was still too early to tell whether the second and third quarters of this year would fall into that category once the government updates its statistics, but yesterday's jobs report increased the chances of that.
The Federal Reserve has tried to revive the economy by repeatedly cutting short-term interest rates this year in an effort to bolster confidence and make it cheaper for businesses and consumers to borrow money. Investors now expect the Fed to reduce its benchmark short-term rate, now at 3.5 percent, by at least another quarter-point and perhaps even by a half-point, when it next meets in October.
Earlier in the week, after a survey of manufacturing executives hinted that industrial output might be on the verge of improving, most investors thought that even a quarter-point cut was unlikely. But yesterday the government said that factories cut another 141,000 jobs, their biggest reduction since July 1998.
Aggravating the weakness in the private sector, government agencies -- local, state and federal -- stopped adding to their payrolls in August. In the coming months, analysts said, government employment is unlikely to rise significantly because the slowdown has cut tax revenues, leaving less money for new programs.
Already, virtually every measure of the labor market has weakened. The average length of unemployment rose to 13.3 weeks, from 12.5 in July.
The unemployment rate for teenagers increased to 16.1 percent, from 14.8 percent in July. And the unemployment rates for blacks, 9.1 percent; Hispanics, 6.3 percent; and whites, 4.3 percent, all rose.
More people stopped looking for work last month than in July. Only those actively looking for a job count in the unemployment rate.

HEADLINE: CONTRIBUTORS 

 BODY:
 The Photographers

Alyson Aliano ("Driven," P. 159) photographed women and their cars this summer during a 3,700-mile cross-country move in an '89 Ford Taurus. Her work has appeared in a variety of magazines.

Tina Barney ("The Crew," P. 124) is known for her portraits of her family and its upper-class milieu, collected in "Tina Barney: Photographs: Theater of Manners" and "Friends and Relations."

Vanessa Beecroft ("Economy of Desire," P. 72) takes staged portraits of groups of women. Her next performance will take place in Paris in December.

Eve Fowler ("Great Expectations," P. 118) is an artist whose portraits of female wrestlers and football players are on display at the Smithsonian Institution this fall.

Nan Goldin ("Letting Go," P. 116) relocated this year from New York to Paris. She says that her photograph in this issue, of her close friend Valerie and Valerie's boyfriend, reflects a new direction for her work. "These images aren't about a photographer's vicarious thrill or the audience's voyeurism," Goldin says.
"I share a very strong intimacy with these friends." Goldin's latest series will be presented at the Pompidou Center in Paris in October, with original music by Bjork.

Katy Grannan ("Family Values," P. 54) has been photographing young Russian veterans of the war in Chechnya. A collection of her photos will be included in a show this fall at the Stedelijk Museum voor Actuele Kunst in Ghent, Belgium.

Lauren Greenfield ("Beheld," P. 132, and "Big Women on Campus," P. 148) is working on "Girl Culture," a book that will examine how young women express themselves by decorating their bodies.

Naomi Harris ("Knowing Her Place," P. 44) is chronicling the lives of senior citizens in the only residence hotel in her body-conscious neighborhood in South Beach in Miami.

Brenda Ann Kenneally ("Hard Time," P. 152) is the recipient of the 2000
W. Eugene Smith Award for Humanistic Photography. She has spent the last
five years shooting drug-dependent inner-city women in New York City.

Justine Kurland ("Portrait of the Artists," P. 39, and "Women Among Women," P. 96) is working on "Spirit West," a book of photos of groups of girls.

Gillian Laub ("In Sync," P. 110) studied at the International Center of Photography in New York.

Sally Mann (Cover and portrait on P. 93) has been photographing southern landscapes for the past nine years. Her portraits of her children are part of the permanent collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Whitney Museum. For this issue, Mann created two new self-portraits with her daughters, Jessie, now 19, and Virginia, now 16.

Malerie Marder (What They Were Thinking, P. 88) is a portraitist who lives in Venice, Calif. A solo show of her work will appear at Interim Art in London in December.

Mary Ellen Mark ("Keeper of the Flame," P. 126) has published 12 collections of her work during her 35-year career. This year she was presented with the Cornell Capa Infinity Award by the International Center of Photography.

Katie Murray ("Head of the Class," P. 52) was recently selected as one of Photo District News's 30 photographers under 30.

Lise Sarfati ("Interior Life," P. 142) is a Magnum photographer who lives in Paris and works mostly in Russia. Her book "Acta Est" was published last year by Phaidon.

Barbel Schmidt ("Walking Away," P. 180) is working on a series of photographs of elderly women in her native Germany wearing traditional attire.

Bastienne Schmidt ("Blood Sisters," P. 74) is a German photojournalist now living in New York. Her show "Vivir la Muerte" has traveled to Cologne, New Orleans and Stuttgart.

Zoe Selsky ("Force Majeure," P. 43) is a photojournalist in Bogota, Colombia.

Joyce Tenneson ("Generations," P. 138) has just completed a collection of portraits of women over the age of 65 for her next book, "Wise Women."

Diana Walker ("The Freshman," P. 104) spent the last 20 years covering the White House, beginning with the Reagan administration.

Ann Weathersby ("Stranger in the House," P. 84) begins her M.F.A. in photography at Yale University this fall. She is currently shooting photographs for a book on kinship adoption.

Jessica Wynne ("Garden Party," P. 108), a portrait artist, graduated from the Yale M.F.A. program in 1999. Her portraits are in the permanent collection of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.

The Writers

Diane Cardwell ("In Sync," P. 110) is a Metro reporter for The Times.

Lisa Carver ("Letting Go," P. 116) is a columnist for Nerve.com and the author of "Dancing Queen: The Lusty Adventures of Lisa Crystal Carver."

Ted Conover ("Hard Time," P. 152) is the author, most recently, of "Newjack: Guarding Sing Sing," an account of his experiences working inside a maximum-security prison.

Debra Dickerson ("Generations," P. 138), a senior fellow at the New America Foundation, is the author of "An American Story."

Doris Kearns Goodwin ("Garden Party," P. 108), is a Pulitzer Prize-winning historian and author. She is at work on a book about Abraham Lincoln.

Michael Ignatieff ("Blood Sisters," P. 74) is the director of the Carr Center for Human Rights Policy at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard and the co-author of the coming collection "Human Rights as Politics and Idolatry."

Robert Knafo ("Economy of Desire," P. 72) writes about the arts for Slate.

Sara Mosle ("Head of the Class," P. 52) is writing a book about East Texas in the 1930's.

Dee Dee Myers ("The Freshman," P. 104), a contributing editor for Vanity Fair, was the White House press secretary in 1993 and 1994.

William Norwich ("The Crew," P. 124) is the entertaining editor of the magazine.

Cynthia Ozick ("Interior Life," P. 142) is the author of "Quarrel & Quandary," a collection of essays to be published in paperback this fall.

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 91

LENGTH: 3029 words

HEADLINE: IN THE BALANCE; 
Women And Power In 2001.

BYLINE:  By Margaret Talbot 

 BODY:
The most powerful women in my life are my sister and my baby sitter. My sister is eight years older than I am, so when I was a child and she was a teenager, she enjoyed the status of a queen as far as I was concerned. She had waist-length blond hair, boyfriends, an abundance of purple garments, important moods -- and political beliefs that sometimes prevented her from going to school. (During the Vietnam War, she once persuaded my mother to write a note to her high-school principal that read: "Please excuse Cindy's absence yesterday. She was sick -- sick of war.") As we got older, the age gap between us seemed to narrow, and we grew steadily closer. But in the meantime, Cindy had become a doctor, adding a layer of professional expertise to her big-sisterly mystique, and I had become, among other things, a hypochondriac and a mother. Cindy is an uncannily good diagnostician, quick to piece together scattered clues and reveal truths about underlying ailments in a way that strikes me as magical, though I suppose it has as much to do with how attentively she listens as with any actual occult powers. 
 There is no one whose advice carries more weight for me. Often, her role is to reassure. Last spring, though, I called Cindy after my husband became suddenly and mysteriously ill. When I told her the diagnosis, she said, "I'm flying out there today," which meant leaving Portland, Ore., for Washington, D.C., and I knew instantly that my husband and I were in deep trouble. Part of me attributes his eventual recovery to Cindy's divinely nudgy presence, hovering over the doctors in charge of his case. Sometimes I think there is no power like the power of professional knowledge and competence, alloyed with emotional pull, that my sister has over me. 
 My baby sitter is a different matter. By most conventional measures, I realize, Maria Luisa would not be considered a powerful person. She is an immigrant; her English is a little shaky; she cannot lay claim to a great deal of professional status. But I am dependent on her to the point of fear -- and often, unhappiness. Without her, I could not work, meaning write, which I sometimes hate and sometimes love but in either case have to do, for reasons both economic and emotional. It is true, of course, that I could hire someone else. But losing her would be sort of like a divorce, something to be approached with foreboding and gravity and handled with delicacy; she has been an intimate part of my kids' lives, after all, for as long as they can remember. Recently, when she became convinced, for complicated reasons, that we were using one of those nanny-cams on her, a pall fell over our household. I was depressed that she would believe such a thing of us; she was chagrined that she had. We talked about this misapprehension for hours, first over the phone, then later standing in my kitchen with cold cups of coffee in our hands; for days, I could think of nothing else. 
Maria Luisa and I each have powers and privileges the other wants, at least some of the time. I am envious of her because she gets to bring her baby to work; she is envious of me because I get to go to an office. She worries that her American-born, almost-teenage daughter will be ashamed of her because she's a nanny; I worry that my children are spending too much time in somebody else's care. We step around each other with exaggerated politeness, carefully broaching subtle but loaded disagreements about how to treat a cold or a disciplinary crisis. Most days, I am convinced she doesn't like me, or at any rate, resents me in the way people resent their bosses. Yet I know she loves my children and they love her. When my 2-year-old pretends to talk on the phone, it is always to her. This is all familiar stuff to any working mother who depends, as so many of us do, on paid help. But I continue to marvel every day at a relationship that belongs so inextricably to both the marketplace and the heart. 
I know that when I think about women and power, I am not really supposed to think about relationships like these. The phrase is supposed to call to mind the sort of photo spreads you see in magazines from time to time -- female C.E.O.'s in fire-engine-red suits and Hollywood mogulettes in sunglasses. And in a vague, distant sort of way, I guess I'm glad that Carly Fiorina is the head of Hewlett-Packard and that actresses as young as Drew Barrymore can get their own production companies nowadays. But truthfully, the sort of power they wield doesn't impinge much on my life, or on the lives of many women I know, and it interests me less than maybe it should. Other sorts of female power -- complicated, quotidian, intimate, ambiguous -- do. And these, as it happens, are the kinds of female power this issue of the magazine explores: women finding fun and solace in one another's inspiriting company; women in moments of toughness and in mobility; women displaying beauty and brazenness; women reveling in motherhood or in the chance to shut out the social demands of femininity and concentrate on the work at hand.
When the editors here first started talking about a photo issue on women and power, though, even they were kind of dubious. It would be naive, they realized, to gin up something purely triumphalist about all the places women were that they once were not -- a glossy pageant of slick professionals with the occasional foxy female steelworker thrown in for good measure. But it would be naive in a different way to deny that the postfeminist world is a fundamentally different place, a place where women have more freedom, autonomy, sense of possibility and, yes, power, than at any other time in history. 
Once you give the slightest thought to the topic, after all, you find yourself tangled in contradictions. On the one hand, for example, there are 13 women in the U.S. Senate now, more than ever before, and only one of them got there through the once-traditional route of widowhood. And on the other hand, a female president still seems a misty prospect. There are more female doctors and lawyers, but comparatively few female media barons or dot-com entrepreneurs. There are more images of female derring-do for little girls to enjoy, but a lot of them are examples of ditz-power -- bubbleheads with fists of fury, like the Powerpuff Girls. There are certainly more female athletes than when I was growing up in the 60's and 70's, and they have fans and cultural cachet, too. But then again, maybe it really wasn't such a stretch to start celebrating another kind of female physicality, a different supremely beautiful body type. While American women enjoy the legal rights and cultural visibility that might be called, for short, power, there are places in the world where honor killings or female infanticide make womanhood seem like the very definition of powerlessness. And so on. Pick your own contradictions. 
Besides, power is an ineffable thing, forever on the move, forever changing form. A woman might be powerful in one context (say, her home) and a weakling in another (her place of employment). A woman can be, or at least feel, deliriously powerful for the very reasons -- youth, beauty -- that make her vulnerable to exploitation. (Personally, I have never felt more powerful than when I was 17 and cute and full of hope about who I might be.) A woman can be powerful by virtue of her personality, sexuality, professional expertise, class, religion, race -- or not, depending on any of those things. Even within feminism itself, there are bitter disagreements over what power actually means; to cite one random example, there are feminists who argue that when women get plastic surgery, they are exercising choice and, by extension, power, and there are those who argue that such women are abject victims of false consciousness. 
Still, as the feminist historian Sheila Rowbotham has put it, those sorts of contradictions make for "a much more muddled picture -- and a far more interesting history. . . . Women have experienced the fracturing of feminine identity in the course of this century and somehow accommodated to living the split." How they have done so is what fascinates. It certainly doesn't make sense to look at power as some monolithic entity -- like one of those mysterious energy sources in cartoons -- to which women do or do not have some precisely measurable access. But I think many of us still want to know how certain forms of power change women or themselves change when women are in possession of them. Women with real worldly power are still enough of a novelty that we are frankly curious about them and the way they resolve (or smooth over) the discontinuities between their public and private selves, discontinuities that seem more jarring, somehow, for women than for men. In magazine profiles of working-mom C.E.O.'s or politicians, there is often a moment when they point to the peanut-butter or grape-juice stain on their power suit, as if to show that they, too, had to fight their way out of the house that morning. It is no surprise that one of the most powerful women in America today, Martha Stewart, has built a media empire on the idea that messy domesticity can be tamed, aestheticized and handled with calm, craftsmanlike respect.
Maybe a certain amount of ambivalence, just natural emotional ambivalence, is the reason women in power sometimes seem to enjoy their power a little less than men do. It is hard to feel really jazzed about it when you feel torn -- and not necessarily guilty but truly and painfully and permanently undecided about where you belong. "It's not guilt, you fool," a working mother imagines telling her partner in "Getting a Life," Helen Simpson's excellent new short-story collection. "It's the unwelcome awareness that being daily ripped in half is not good, not even ultimately." Ambivalence of some kind is a natural condition of maturity, though, so most women simply go on living with it, knowing that they have no choice and that it is also a kind of gift. (We're ambivalent about ambivalence.) Every powerful woman I know looks tired most of the time, exhaustion being the natural concomitant of ambivalence, of combining at least two lives into one. Eavesdrop anywhere that, say, working mothers congregate in the morning (the subway, Starbucks, the entrance to the preschool), and you will hear them starting conversations about how tired they are and then dropping the subject -- what's the point, really? 
Maybe women with power seem a little grimmer about it than men, though, because it doesn't get them the goodies that it does for men. A woman with power in business or politics does not by dint of that particular form of power become a collector of young males. Indeed, there is something unthinkable, vaguely horrifying about the scenario of a sexually predatory female politician; whereas the sexually predatory male politician is merely embarrassing, maybe scandalous. Partly, this is because a woman who obtains power -- via something other than her beauty or sexuality, anyway -- usually obtains it at an age when she is no longer widely considered sexually attractive. (This chronology holds true for men, too, but age doesn't seem to limit their sexual possibilities in the same way.) Last year's movie "The Contender" was unusual in its portrayal of a female politician facing allegations about her randy past. But in the end, even it backed away from the idea of a mature woman with both political power and erotic license; the sexual innuendo about Joan Allen's character turned out to be a lie that she was too proud to refute. 
I have a friend who insists that in England things are rather different and that she knew men there who thought of Margaret Thatcher as a temptress. She says it is because of the royal tradition, a cultural memory of enormously powerful women who are also evidently sexual creatures. I don't know -- but at any rate, there doesn't seem to be much of an equivalent here. On the contrary, in Hillary Clinton we have a perfect example of the opposite phenomenon: the way in which humiliation at the hands of a philandering husband can "humanize" a woman who seems a little too powerful, making her more popular and ultimately more powerful, especially if she seems to weather the crisis with dignity. 
These days when we think about women and power, we are usually thinking about worldly, professional power. We tend to define power for women as admittance to a career or a position that men once dominated. But occasionally, this leads to some questionable assumptions. Is a woman working as a prison guard for male convicts -- a poorly paid, hazardous, often demeaning job for the men who do it -- really a powerful person? It also allows us to overlook the power in some traditionally feminine attributes and roles -- motherhood, for instance. This is not a cultural moment when we look on mothers as particularly powerful figures. It is not like, say, the 1950's, when the bad mother portrayed in best-selling advice books and magazines was a scarily potent character, capable of causing autism, homosexuality and the spread of Communism, while the good mother, like a domesticated superhero, upheld the American Way. Since comparatively few Americans today insist that only mothers ought to be taking care of children, it doesn't pay to make too strong a case for maternal influence. Moreover, we are no longer standing directly in the cultural shadow of psychoanalysis, in which mothers appeared as giants, responsible for fostering healthy sexuality and robust individuation in their children or for warping the whole process irrevocably. Today, when genes and brain chemistry loom larger than nurture, what mothers do seems a little less crucial, in some ways, to how in the end their children turn out. Which is a relief, but also a ceding of power. Around my house, where I am grateful to share most jobs with my husband, I can never be the domestic authority that my mother was and that I sometimes long to be. I am not the only one in my family who remembers when the kids need a checkup or what spices we have on hand. I am not the repository of all the critical bits of knowledge that keep a household going. 
There is another form of female power we don't seem to recognize much anymore, and that is the power of the civically virtuous volunteer, the tireless builder of social capital. A few weeks ago, I attended a memorial service for an elderly neighbor named Jane. I hadn't known Jane well, but she had always been sweet to us. Once she brought me an armful of pink-tinged white peonies from her garden, a few days after I mentioned that they were my favorite flower. Her memorial service gave me a whole different impression, of someone who might have seemed mild-mannered but who, in her community, had been an important, charismatic and much relied-upon person. The church was packed, though a noisy electrical storm raged outside, and person after person got up to testify about Jane's good works, her volunteering at the National Gallery of Art and for the homeless and the D.C. schools; to recall how she and her husband, who had raised two boys and taken various lost souls into their big old stone house, loved their neighborhood and their city and their church; about how she had sung in the same church choir every Sunday for 50 years. It struck me that few of us who work outside the home, whatever our career status, could claim to have touched as many lives. 
This issue of the magazine looks at power in some unexpected forms, partly, I think, because women are doing the looking. Feminists of the 70's and 80's used to talk a lot about the "male gaze." This issue is dominated by the female gaze: all of the photographs were taken by women. 
If image-making is a form of power, does it make us see women differently? I think so. The differences aren't huge, but then, despite what the Mars and Venus crowd might claim, neither are the differences between men and women. Indeed, some of the photographs are stylized, self-consciously formal, even rather frosty portraits -- see the images of women in groups, for example -- which do not reflect a particularly relaxed intimacy between female photographer and female subjects.
What you do see in many of these photographs, though, are women who look a little more serious-minded and less obligingly smiling than women are often pictured as being -- a little more self-contained and caught up in what they are doing. You see women who are not afraid of close-ups that show wrinkles and imperfections -- the sweet and exhausting toll even lives they recognize as impossibly rich can take on them. (See, for example, the tired and sober-looking lawyers on Page 118.) You see women who have grown accustomed to being in large groups of other women, whose enclosed societies remind you that even in our gender-integrated culture, there are times (the end of life) and places (sweatshops, the midday playground) in which women are almost exclusively in the company of other women. You see young women who are used to projecting their toughness and their independence from men, like some of those in the women-and-their-cars series. Finally, you see women who occupy positions of power without declaiming they do, women who are too busy living their full and contradictory and crazy-quilt lives to think much about being Powerful Women. 
It is a feeling similar to the one I get from my favorite picture of my sister. It is an old snapshot of Cindy at work in blue scrubs, helping a patient deliver a baby; for years, I kept it in a frame on my desk. Truth be told, I think it grossed my male colleagues out a bit -- there is a certain amount of blood in the picture -- but I just loved it. In it, Cindy is an emblem of pure concentration, her hands firmly cupping a baby with the umbilical cord still attached, her arms draped with some sort of plastic tubing, her eyes betraying no interest whatsoever in the camera. Nonetheless, you can't help but noticing the big silver earrings glinting behind her thick blond hair. She is totally immersed, yet she looks damn good. I like that, too.
