HEADLINE: Commercial Property/MacArthur Airport; 
Busy Runways Spur Development, and Vice Versa

BYLINE:  By CAROLE PAQUETTE 

 BODY:
PAUL T. FORTUNATO remembers driving his car to Long Island MacArthur Airport in Islip about 20 years ago and parking on the grass in front of the terminal to take a "little twin-prop Mohawk Airlines plane to Albany."
 Since then, that grassy area has been swallowed up by the parking lots for the airport, which now serves more than two million passengers a year. "Who would have ever thought the airport would grow up like this?" Mr. Fortunato asked. 
 Development around the airport, which is on Veterans Memorial Highway in central Suffolk County, has grown as well. Since the mid-1980's, when the town of Islip created its seven-mile industrial corridor district along the state highway, with the town-owned airport as its anchor, development has more than tripled. Planners credit the industrial district for the airport's growth. 
The industrial district is "one of the glowing successes on Long Island," said Lee Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board and a former Suffolk County planning director. 
"Thirty-five years ago," he said, "the Suffolk County Planning Department strongly recommended that the land around MacArthur not be zoned residential, but for industrial development -- all for uses related to the fact that there is an airport there. If it had been zoned residential, the airport wouldn't have succeeded, and as a job generator it is one of the strongest areas on Long Island." 
The district was set up to "minimalize retail and strip commercial development and to promote industrial and office development," said Daniel Gulizio, Islip's planning commissioner. "Because of the convenience of the airport, it has encouraged businesses to locate along the highway."
The number of passengers using the airport rose to 2.3 million last year, from 115,000 in 1980, spurred by Southwest Airlines' arrival at MacArthur in 1999. The passenger numbers rose to to 1.9 million that year from 905,000 in 1998.
The airport, which is on 1,300 acres, completed a $13 million renovation last year, expanding its terminal to 63,300 square feet from 45,300 and doubling the ticket centers and baggage claim areas. This year, Southwest, a highly successful discount airline, proposed a $35 million terminal for its own use that would include building additional runways. The airport now has four runways ranging from 3,275 feet to 7,000 feet.
The industrial corridor district includes property within 300 feet of both sides of Veterans Memorial Highway beginning at the Long Island Expressway and running southeast to Sunrise Highway. Growth in the district -- which runs through Bohemia, Ronkonkoma and Holbrook -- peaked between 1979 and 1991, according to Roy Fedelem, principal planner at the Suffolk County Planning Department. In 1979 there were 1,568 vacant acres and 463 developed for industry. By 1991, there were 823 vacant acres, and the rest had been developed. The industrial corridor was set up in 1985 in "the midst of the growth period" when development came close to 200 acres a year, Mr. Fedelem said. 
Some parcels are still left, the largest being 135 acres in the Holbrook section of the district owned by Serota Properties of Syosset, which has submitted preliminary plans for developing the site. 
Before the district was created, the area had been zoned for light industry and manufacturing. Building was permitted on a minimum lot of a half acre and a width of 100 feet, according to Thomas A. Isles, director of planning for Suffolk County and former Islip planning commissioner. The new district, he said, "upgraded the quality of development to minimum lots of three acres and a width of 300 feet and increased the landscaping standards." 
SINCE then, the 60-year-old airport has played a major role in the construction and real estate business of the Fortunato family, which was founded by Bernard R. Fortunato in the 1940's. 
Its development company, Fortunato Sons Inc., which is operated by Bernard R. Fortunato Jr., built the new 18,000-square-foot extension to MacArthur's terminal and more than 20 industrial and office buildings in the corridor. These included 70,000 square feet of renovations and additions at the Federal Aviation Administration complex at the airport's entrance and the 95,000-square-foot world headquarters for Selchow & Righter, the board game manufacturer. 
Fortunato's offices, along with those of its real estate business, Fortunato Development Inc., headed by Paul T. Fortunato, are in the Airport Corporate Center, which includes five buildings on 25 acres across the highway from the airport. 
A major property owner in the corridor is the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, a publicly traded real estate investment trust, which owns approximately 4.6 million square feet of office buildings in Nassau and Suffolk. Reckson owns 25 buildings across from the airport, totaling 1.3 million square feet, and has room for an additional 74,000 square feet of buildings, said Kathleen Giamo, senior vice president and director of corporate development for Reckson.
"The airport now plays a big part, as it makes it easier for business people to commute," Ms. Giamo said. "It is becoming a major corporate commuter-type place that makes it more attractive on a national corporate level."
Mr. Isles said: "There are still traffic issues in terms of Vets Highway to handle the increased growth. It has to catch up at some point."
If the entire corridor is built out, "there will be deterioration of some service, such as transportation." he said. "There are two solutions: the state has to do something, and private developers have to help by upgrading their property with turning lanes."
According to Ms. Giamo, Reckson dedicated land to the state and built a third lane for traffic to its newest group of buildings, which are across the highway from the airport. The 442,000-square-foot complex, completed in 1999, is the second phase of Reckson's Airport International Plaza. It includes four buildings on 39 acres one block east of its first industrial park in the corridor, which was built in the late 1970's.
That complex had 33 buildings -- more than one million square feet -- on 200 acres. While some of the buildings have been sold, Reckson continues to own 21 buildings in the first Airport International Plaza complex.
Early this year, Fortunato opened a 60,000-square-foot new building at its 15-year-old Airport Corporate Center complex, across the highway from the airport entrance. With nine acres remaining on the property, the company has plans to expand further, Bernard Fortunato Jr. said. "At this time we have half a million square feet of buildings," he said. "We may expand to close to a million."
The growth of Islip's Veterans Highway industrial district has those in the commercial real estate business looking at it as an alternative to the 14-million-square-foot Hauppauge Industrial Park, which is five miles north on 1,400 acres.
There is a lack of available space in western Suffolk and the Hauppauge Industrial Park is built up, Ms. Giamo said. "This location is a natural place to go," she said. 
"The airport is definitely a benefit, opening up a whole new area for companies to do business with us."
Mr. Fortunato said: "In the last 10 years, this area had been a submarket to Hauppauge. Now we have grown up to be our own market."

HEADLINE: At Odds With Affluent Neighbor 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT WORTH 

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON 

 BODY:
MOST of the time, Mayor Ernest D. Davis is affable and easygoing, given to philosophical musings about his city and its people. But when his dispute with the neighboring village of Pelham comes up, his patience evaporates. 
 The mayor has talked for years about a plan to build a sprawling $50 million mall along Sandford Boulevard, just across the Hutchinson River Parkway from Pelham. The city now has commitments from several major retailers, including Target and TJ Maxx, and if the final approvals go through, the developer could break ground as early as next month, said Gerrie Post, the city's planning commissioner. 
 But residents and officials in the more affluent town of Pelham are bent on stopping the project.
They say it would endanger children as they cross Sandford Boulevard from Pelham's middle and high schools to the district's playing fields, next to the mall site. And it would worsen traffic on the Hutchinson River Parkway. The town and village of Pelham have filed suit to block the project, along with the village of Pelham Manor and the school board.
Mr. Davis has a word for his opponents: racist. "You don't have to be a rocket scientist to see it," he said. "It's a group of white folks getting together to deny darker folks their just due."
He conceded that the mall would bring more traffic but he said it could be managed effectively. The main issue, he said, is economic justice: Mount Vernon needs the jobs and sales tax revenue the mall would provide. The city has rezoned the property and partnered with the developer, G&S Investors of Old Bethpage, N.Y. It has also transferred a $10 million loan for a hotel project to the mall.
Some Pelham residents say Mr. Davis has made things worse by accusing them of racism and refusing to compromise. 
"If Ernie wanted to be more than a visionary and actually find a way to reach a compromise to get this thing built," said Michael Volpe, a Pelham Town Council member, "he could approach that with us right now." 
But Mr. Davis has made clear that he is willing to use his considerable political influence to get what he wants. 
"Mount Vernon is the most predictable Democratic vote in the county," he said. "If I don't get that project I'll campaign against you."

HEADLINE: Environment Bucks Stop Here 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
VENTURING more deeply into local politics than ever before, the New York League of Conservation Voters, an influential statewide environmental group, has gone beyond endorsements to recruit and campaign for environmentally minded local candidates on the East End.
 A key test of the league's assertive new strategy will come on Tuesday in the Republican primary for supervisor in Riverhead, now the fastest-developing of the five East End towns. In the closely watched race, the candidate backed by the league, Judi Pitsiokos, a lawyer in Wading River, is challenging Robert Kozakiewicz, the first-term supervisor. 
 Mr. Kozakiewicz, also a lawyer, has across-the-board support from the local Republican Party and from federal, state and local Republican elected officials. But the league and other environmental groups say that he is a willing supporter of development and that he has thwarted preservation efforts. 
Mrs. Pitsiokos has promised to advance an environmental agenda that would include a one-year moratorium on development while the town makes plans to control growth. 
Unlike nearly all other environmental groups, the league, which is based in Manhattan and which refers to itself the political arm of the state's formidable network of environmental groups, has a tax status that allows it to endorse political candidates and to contribute to their campaigns. It has singled out the East End towns because it says that elected officials there will soon be making crucial decisions about land and groundwater preservation.
Since those decisions will likely determine the fate of the remaining open land on the East End, which is still semirural, the league is putting a high priority on the election of candidates committed to environmental programs. 
The league said that it expects to raise up to $100,000 to support selected candidates for town offices in primaries and the general election in November. It is placing emphasis on the Towns of Riverhead and Southampton, where the pace of development has been the most intense.
That amount would be a pittance in a national campaign and a fraction of the money spent for major Long Island political contests like those for county executive. But it is substantial for town-level races.
Because towns hold zoning and planning powers, the winners in these local elections will play central roles in making land-use decisions that may include rezoning, building moratoriums, and the use of public money for open-space preservation and groundwater protection.
This has not been lost on the league and other environmental groups. 
"We have become more and more convinced that the best place to effect changes is on the local level," said Marcia Bystryn, the league's executive director who lives in Manhattan and has a second home in Remsenburg. "And we decided that strategically investing our resources on the East End offers the best opportunity to do that. There is a very narrow window of opportunity here to protect open space on the East End. To be effective we have to be effective political players. The developers have known that for a long time." 
She said the league was paying particular attention to the East End because "it's where the stakes are highest and the chances of success greatest." But she acknowledged that efforts in recent months to recruit candidates had been only partly successful. "A campaign is a major investment in an individual's time, particularly when you don't have the support of the party," she said. 
In Riverhead, Mrs. Pitsiokos, a former school board chairwoman, has been the exception. She said that in door-to-door canvassing she found preservation sentiment and distress over the pace of development running high among Republican voters.
"I am not looking at this as a long shot," she said. "I expect to win. The Republican leaders have underestimated the intelligence of the Republican voters of Riverhead. They are not stupid. They see what is happening."
She said the 2,700 houses currently proposed in Riverhead were more than the combined total for the other four East End towns: Southampton, East Hampton, Shelter Island and Southold. 
Mrs. Pitsiokos has been aided by advertising on her behalf placed and paid for by the league. The ads say that under Mr. Kozakiewicz the town has compiled "the worst record on the East End for open-space and farmland preservation." The league also contends that developers are prominent among contributors to the Kozakiewicz campaign.
Mr. Kozakiewicz said the league was distorting his record and blamed much of current development on the prior town administration. He also charged that Richard L. Amper Jr., the executive director of the Long Island Pine Barrens Society, a nonprofit Riverhead group whose tax status does not allow it to be involved in political campaigns, was masterminding the campaign against him. Mr. Amper is a board member of the league and a well-known environmental leader.
"I believe he is very much behind my opponent's campaign," Mr. Kozakiewicz said. He said he had displeased Mr. Amper because "I have not jumped on board and followed his every whim."
Mr. Amper said he was not involved in running the Pitsiokos campaign. "He is trying to make an issue out of an individual instead of facing the recognition of the people of his town that development is out of control," he said. 
Mr. Kozakiewicz and other Republicans in the town said the league had no business in Riverhead. "I question their motivation to come out here and become involved in a local election," he said.
The chairman of the Riverhead Republican Committee, Bruce Stuke, said Mrs. Pitsiokos was among 11 people the committee screened for council seats but was not selected. He described the league as an out-of-town group.
"The Town of Riverhead can handle preservation and farm programs on its own," said Mr. Stuke, who is in his third term as a member of the town's Zoning Board of Appeals. "There is an awful lot of development in the town, but most of it is good growth."
The league, which contends that current development is destroying the town's environmental and economic base, plans to support the Democratic candidate for supervisor, Anne Moroh, if Mrs. Pitsiokos loses the Republican primary. But the league has not yet decided which of the women it would back in November if Mrs. Pitsiokos wins.
The league's strategy in Southampton went awry when the candidate it was backing in the Republican primary for town council, Alexander D. Gregor of Hampton Bays, was knocked off the ballot by the courts after town Republican leaders accused him of having some invalid signatures on his nominating petitions. 
The league had hoped that Mr. Gregor, an environmental contractor and the owner of a well-drilling company, would defeat one of two candidates supported by the Republican Party, Ann LaWall and Linda Kabot, whom it regards as development supporters. Mr. Gregor's victory in the November election would, in the league's view, have added a third environmentally minded member to the five-member town board.
Both women said they were environmentalists and attacked the league for backing a Democratic candidate for Town Council, Dennis A. Suskind of Bridgehampton, who they said was a land developer. Mr. Suskind, a retired partner in Goldman, Sachs, the investment bank, said there was "absolutely no truth" to the assertion.
Amie Hamlin, the director of the league's Long Island chapter, said the league thoroughly investigated candidates before supporting them and firmly backed Mr. Suskind. 
"All candidates say they are environmentalists but their opponents aren't," said Ms. Hamlin, who lives in Brookhaven. "It is our job to distinguish, and that's what we have done."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Judi Pitsiokos, a Republican candidate for Riverhead town supervisor, campaigning at a Polish festival. (Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/The Financial District; 
In Wall Street's Canyons, Cliff Dwellers

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
IN "The Death and Life of Great American Cities," her famous treatise on the liveliness of city neighborhoods, Jane Jacobs deplored central business districts that were not also used for residential or cultural purposes. As the primary example of one such neighborhood, she described downtown New York, noting the restaurants there that were mobbed at lunch but did not offer dinner at all.
 "To see what is wrong," she wrote, "it is only necessary to observe the deathlike stillness that settles on the district after 5:30 and all day Saturday and Sunday." 
 That was 1961. Forty years later, things have changed in the section of the city that contains the New York Stock Exchange, the World Trade Center and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Evening in the financial district offers a sight that would have been a rarity four years ago, unthinkable 40 years ago: side by side with the idling black Lincoln Town Cars waiting for their Wall Street fares are casually dressed men and women leisurely returning home from restaurants and grocery stores and walking their dogs. 
"The transformation has been dramatic," said Francis Greenburger, chief executive of Time Equities Inc., which owns half a dozen residential buildings in the area. "Not that it's thriving at night, but now there's a background to the area, a more 24-hour feeling."
New museums and hotels in the area -- there are 10 hotels and 13 major museums in the area and more on the way -- partly account for that. So does Battery Park City, with more museums and residential and commercial buildings, to the west. But the main engine driving the changes is thousands of new residents who have poured in in the last five years.
After the recession of 1990-1991, office vacancy rates downtown were persistently high, with some buildings standing empty. City officials and neighborhood boosters adapted by encouraging office buildings to convert to residential use. "Jane Jacobs has really stood the test of time," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the Alliance for Downtown New York, the city's largest business improvement district in terms of area and budget.
IN 1995, the city began offering tax incentives to owners who converted downtown commercial properties to residential use under the Lower Manhattan Revitalization Plan. Since then, according to the Alliance, more than 5,000 apartments have been created in 51 formerly commercial buildings.
"In 1997 the financial district was a very speculative area," said Andrew S. Heiberger, chief executive of Citi Habitats, the large rental broker. "It was certainly known as a secondary neighborhood and by all the other words that real estate people don't like to hear like 'transitional' and 'alternative,' " Now, he said, it is now a strong market in its own right.
The vast majority of the recent conversions created rental apartments. "Any time you have a new neighborhood, generally the first people who move in are renters," said Brian G. Edwards, director of leasing for the Halstead Property Company. "Then conversions to home ownership begin as the neighborhood becomes more stable."
Because the area was not an established residential neighborhood, building owners invested heavily in amenities to make the converted structures attractive as apartment buildings. "At first they were concerned about attracting tenants," Mr. Heiberger said, "so they went over the top with kitchens and granite countertops and marble baths, which are standard in the area."
In addition, most buildings have fitness centers and laundries, as well as concierge service and roof access, and they allow pets. The apartments are larger and have higher ceilings than those uptown, and the conversion from office space to apartments has frequently meant offbeat layouts.
"It seemed like they'd do anything to get you to move down here," said Nikki Loffredo, 32, an administrative assistant who works in Midtown and has lived at 75 West Street, one of the early rental conversions, for a year and a half.
Ms. Loffredo, who had lived in Greenwich Village, said she was attracted to the idea of having a newer and bigger apartment. "My old apartment had like 100 coats of paint," she said. "It was old and rickety. I wanted a nice apartment in an O.K. neighborhood."
Since the stock market downturn last year, rental prices are off 10 to 15 percent, real estate agents say. "The financial district has felt the brunt of the downturn more quickly than the neighborhoods uptown," Mr. Edwards said. "And we're seeing concessions for the first time. New tenants often sign a 13-month lease in which they typically get the first or 13th month free."
A low-floor studio without a view rents for $1,800 a month while a larger one with a terrace can rent for $2,500 a month, said Arnon Barzilai, a Citi Habitats rental agent who specializes in the financial district. One-bedroom apartments rent for $2,300 to $3,200 and two-bedroom apartments for $2,800 to $4,500. "The top ones could usually be converted to three-bedrooms," he said.
With zoning that is unique in New York City, the financial district is home to breathtaking artificial canyons created when streets barely wide enough for a single lane of traffic are bordered on both sides by some of the tallest buildings in the city.
Most of the area's apartments can be found in recently converted skyscrapers, some of which once housed the headquarters of leading American companies. The three rental buildings with the most units are 200 Water Street, with 576 apartments; 17 Battery Place, a mixed-use building with 496 apartments; and 99 John Street, with 442. The John Street building also houses the new Jubilee Market grocery store.
Real estate brokers and developers speculate that buildings will begin to convert from rentals to co-ops or condominiums. Some of the better-known existing co-ops are at 3 Hanover Square, 176 Broadway and 55 Liberty Street. Condominiums are scattered throughout the area, for example at 33 Rector Street, with 14 apartments; at 25 Ann Street, with 9; and 130 Beekman Street, with 18. A 2,200-square-foot condominium loft could sell for $950,000 to $1.2 million, depending on the size, the floor and maintenance costs, said Katharine Vaccaro, a broker with Douglas Elliman. Similarly sized co-op apartments, lofts or two-bedroom apartments would sell for $480,000 to $1.2 million. An apartment might have a spectacular river or cityscape view or nothing more than the sight of a solid wall of the building across the street, a factor that influences price. "Light is always very important," Ms. Vaccaro said.
BUT small-scale buildings are also to be found, including a row of a dozen three-story Federal and Greek Revival-style town houses on Stone Street, built soon after a fire in 1835 leveled most of the area. These contain full-floor two-bedroom lofts that rent for about $3,500 a month, said Joey Goldman, a partner of Goldman Properties, which owns five of the buildings.
The district contains three areas with concentrations of residential buildings: the financial district proper, especially along John Street; the handful of blocks south of the World Trade Center along Greenwich, Washington and West Streets, and the seaport district, which is another area with century-old low-rise buildings.
"The financial district and the seaport are in character two completely different areas," said Felicia De Chabris, a sales associate with the Halstead Property Company who lived on Nassau Street for five years but has since moved uptown. "The seaport is quiet, residential, and has an old world charm," she said. "It just sits in a period of time, and it doesn't move."
Every working day 375,000 workers flood downtown New York, the third-largest central business district in the country. But its burgeoning residential character is more of a return to the past than an innovation, said Edwin G. Burrows, professor of history at Brooklyn College and author with Mike Wallace of "Gotham: A History of New York City to 1898" (Oxford University Press, 1998). "If you were to walk down Wall Street in the decade before the American Revolution," he said, "you would find plenty of residences."
The area was the first in the city to be settled by Europeans, in 1626. It was not until the 1840's and 50's, as the city's population swelled and the neighborhood took on an increasingly commercial character, that most residents moved uptown. "There are old stories of people's houses being surrounded by the clamor of business and trade and the owners complaining that they can't get anything done," Dr. Burrows said. "That's a big story of the first few decades of the 19th century."
Despite the recent influx of residents, the area is still quiet at night, when steam from underground pipes wafts upward in narrow canyons populated by grinding sanitation trucks but not a single pedestrian.
The nighttime peace is a big draw for some, said Bruce Menin, a residential developer downtown. "I think a lot of people who live here really like the fact that they are not assaulted by throngs of tourist strangers that they don't know," he said. But others, who go to SoHo, Union Square or TriBeCa for restaurants and night life, said they would like to see a little more activity.
Mr. Menin, managing principal of Crescent Heights Realty, was the first residential developer to convert a building to residential use under the revitalization plan, turning 25 Broad Street into 345 apartments of one, two and three bedrooms.
As a young lawyer for Sullivan & Cromwell at 125 Broad Street in 1989, Mr. Menin lived near the intersection of 89th Street and Third Avenue. He said he remembered a difficult commute and thought people might like to avoid it. "I believed there would be people who would see the dual benefit of avoiding the commute and living in a building they can be proud of when they have visitors," he said, noting that he aimed to provide all the amenities of a Fifth Avenue luxury building.
The financial area is populated to a large degree by young men and women fresh out of college who move to the area shortly after landing a job with long hours at a Wall Street firm. "For anybody who's starting out in banking or some kind of job that is downtown that has very work-intensive hours, it's good place to be," said Josh Goldin, 24, a financial analyst with Lehman Brothers who has lived for 14 months at 99 John Street. "The convenience thing is great for someone who works a lot of hours."
Still, many others, like Ms. Loffredo, commute to Midtown or elsewhere. With 14 of the city's 22 subway lines going through the area, residents say a reverse commute in the city is easy. "There are so many subways down here," Ms. Loffredo said. "You can easily get anywhere in the city."
Relatively few families with children live in the area, though their number is growing. Children who live south of Cortlandt Street and west of Broadway attend Public School 89. Those who live elsewhere in the area attend P.S. 234. Both schools, in TriBeCa, perform well above the citywide average. There are no private schools in the area, but a leading educational presence is Stuyvesant High School, one of the city's premier public schools, which is at the northern end of Battery Park City. 
There are no schools in the district itself, but with so many new residential conversions, hotels and museums opening in the area, the diversity that Jane Jacobs wrote about is at last coming to the southern tip of Manhattan. But that does not mean that people will stop calling it the financial capital of the world.
"It will become a more and more integrated area that people will enjoy living in," said Mr. Greenburger, the developer. "But it's always going to be a mixture of a business district and a residential one, with the business dominating by a vast majority."

MAKING DO BEFORE THE CONVERSIONS: By the 1850's, Wall Street had been more or less purely commercial for about 30 years. But Herman Melville's short story "Bartleby, the Scrivener" revolves around a character who decides to live in the area. In the story, Bartleby is described as an oddball legal clerk who refuses to do work because he "prefers not to." Eventually, he starts to make his home in the office where he supposedly works. Exasperated, the lawyer who hired him decides to relocate the office when he realizes that Bartleby might "perhaps outlive me, and claim possession of my office by right of his perpetual occupancy." Melville, born at 6 Pearl Street, has the lawyer say of the area: "Of a Sunday, Wall-street is deserted as Petra, and every night of every day it is an emptiness. This building too, which of week-days hums with industry and life, at nightfall echoes with sheer vacancy, and all through Sunday is forlorn. And here Bartleby makes his home; sole spectator of a solitude which he has seen all populous."

HEADLINE: Avoiding Pitfalls in Buying Raw Land 

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
WHEN David Wade bought an acre of land near Rochester in Victor, N.Y., about three years ago, one of the most appealing features of the property was its location on a hill overlooking a golf course. The site would be perfect, Mr. Wade thought, for the 4,700-square-foot house he and his wife dreamed of building. 
 After buying the land and starting construction, however, Mr. Wade says, he made a surprising discovery. "I figured that hill the property was on had been there for hundreds of years," he said. "But as it turns out, that particular part of the ridge was, for all intents and purposes, man-made land that was just bulldozed in. It ended up costing us about $40,000 in excavation costs to find solid ground." 
 Although Mr. Wade was ultimately able to build his house, he is now engaged in litigation with the seller -- whose lawyer says that Mr. Wade knew about the soil conditions before making the purchase -- to recover the extra excavation costs he incurred. 
"Just because a piece of property looks like it may have been there forever," he said, "doesn't necessarily mean you can build on it."
The problem encountered by Mr. and Mrs. Wade is relatively unusual; most land that looks as if it has been around for hundreds or thousands of years probably has been. What is not unusual, however, is for people who are unfamiliar with the intricacies of buying raw land to discover that a property that appears perfectly located and priced just right may be costly, difficult or even impossible to develop.
"Buying undeveloped land is an entirely different experience than buying a lot with a house already on it," said Les Scher, a Garberville, Calif., real estate lawyer who, with his wife, Carol, wrote "Finding and Buying Your Place In The Country" (Dearborn). Mr. Scher explained that when a person is buying an existing house on a lot in a city or a suburb, it is reasonable to assume, for example, that the house can legally remain where it is situated on the lot, that it can continue to be used as a home and that basic utilities -- like water, sewer, electricity and telephone lines -- are readily available. 
"When you're buying rural land, though," Mr. Scher said, "you can make no assumptions whatsoever." 
For example, Mr. Scher said, the most basic thing a buyer needs to know is whether there is a proven source of water on the property. 
"Your land can have the most beautiful view in the world," he said. "But without water it is useless."
Just knowing that a property has water, however, is not enough. The buyer must also know how wastewater will be removed from the property. With country property, this usually means that the property must be able to support a septic system. But even if a septic system can be installed without much trouble, he said, a buyer should also ensure that it can be installed in a location that makes it possible to build the house in the most desirable spot, yet far enough away from the well to prevent contamination of drinking water.
"In short, you have to make sure that your land is going to be able to legally, geographically and geologically support the type of house you ultimately want to build," he said. He added that prospective land owners should also know where the property's boundary lines are, whether adjoining property owners have easements or rights of way over the property being purchased and how much it will cost to run utilities and possibly even a new road to the future dream house.
"I tell people that their lack of caution regarding any of these issues is going to help put my kids through college,"' Mr. Scher said.
Most specialists interviewed for this article agreed with Mr. Scher's observation that one of the most important matters to be addressed when purchasing raw land is the availability of water.
Charles W. Crover, vice president of Roarke Well Drilling in Harriman, N.Y., said that while most land has water somewhere under the surface, locating and tapping into that water source can be expensive. 
"Wells are usually priced by the foot," he said, adding that the price per foot of depth can range anywhere from $8 to $30, depending on the material being drilled through. Drilling through sandy soil, for example, is going to be easier and less expensive than drilling through rock. And since the total price of the well is largely determined by its depth, Mr. Crover said, there is generally no way of knowing how much a well will ultimately cost until the well digger locates a source that can produce an adequate supply of clean, usable water.
"Here in Orange County, wells range anywhere from 80 feet to 1,000 feet," Mr. Crover said, adding that the physical location of a piece of property is not necessarily indicative of the ease with which water may be found.
"It doesn't matter whether you're on top of a mountain or in a valley," he said. "All that matters is where Mother Nature put the water."
ONCE it has been established that a property contains an adequate supply of water, a prospective purchaser must determine if the land will support a system that will allow for the disposal of the water after it has been used.
"When buying undeveloped land, one of the basic questions to ask is if the site has been evaluated for an on-lot wastewater treatment system," said Gil Longwell, administrator of the Pennsylvania Association of Sewage Enforcement Officers, a trade organization based in Mechanicsburg. "And if the answer is yes, the questions that follow should be: What type of system will the land support? How much will it cost? And where does it have to be located?"
Mr. Longwell explained that an on-lot wastewater treatment system -- commonly referred to as a septic system -- is "soil sensitive," meaning that the system can be installed only in an area that will allow for percolation of liquid effluent into the ground. And while some properties may allow for the installation of a septic system just about anywhere, others may have only small areas -- or no area at all -- that will support the leach field, which is the portion of the system that distributes liquid waste after the solids have been captured by the septic tank. As a result, Mr. Longwell said, it is necessary for a buyer of raw land to determine not just whether the land will support a septic system, but where the system must be located.
"You might get the land tested and find out that the most beautiful spot on the property, the perfect place to build your house, is the same place that the sewage enforcement officer has planted his orange flags," he said. Buyers should also understand that there are different types of sewage disposal systems that can be installed. 
For example, Mr. Longwell said, if the top layer of soil on a property is not deep enough to support a septic system, it may be necessary to construct what is basically an aboveground leach field. With such a system -- commonly referred to as a sand mound -- the required amount of porous soil is obtained by adding it to the surface, and the leach field is then installed aboveground in the sand mound.
Since the system is basically a large, unadorned mound that stands out noticeably from the surrounding terrain, it is typically considered an eyesore. A sand mound for a three-bedroom house, for example, could be 30 feet wide by 70 feet long or even larger and as much as 5 feet high. "But if that piece of property is your dream property," Mr. Longwell said, "you might be happy you can install a sand mound because without it, you may not be able to use the land for anything at all."
He pointed out that in addition to the potential aesthetic objections to sand mounds, there are some economic disincentives to them as well. 
"The cost of a typical system with a subsurface absorption area would probably be in the $5,000 range," Mr. Longwell said, adding that a sand-mound system, which requires trucking in as much as 100 tons of special sand, could cost five times that amount. As a result, he said, anyone contemplating buying undeveloped land should check with the local sewage enforcement officer to determine what type of system is likely to be necessary. 
At least as important as knowing that a property has good water and the ability to support a septic system is knowing that the property can be used for the type of structure the buyer intends to build on it.
James S. Grossman, a Rochester lawyer who is the immediate past chairman of the state bar association's real estate section, said that while most areas are zoned to permit residential construction, local zoning laws often differ with respect to the maximum allowable percentage of the property that can be used for buildings and the required setbacks from property lines.
"And you can't just assume that because the next-door neighbor has built something on his property that you can build the same thing," Mr. Grossman said, explaining that a structure on an adjoining property may be permitted only because it existed before the adoption of the zoning law.
Another matter that buyers of undeveloped land should investigate is the quality of the land itself.
"Soil conditions are extraordinarily important in raw land sales," Mr. Grossman said, pointing out, for example, that building on lakefront property may require the use of stilts or pilings. Even land that was once used for farming could prove problematic. 
"You may have pesticides sitting in the soil," Mr. Grossman said. "Or there may be leaking fuel storage tanks buried underground that you may end up having to remove."
In fact, Mr. Grossman, who represented Mr. and Mrs. Wade in the purchase of their property from Vicwil Associates, a local developer, said that the presence of organic fill on the site was the cause of his clients' problems and the reason for filing the suit to recover damages from the seller. Francis L. Gorman III, a lawyer for Vicwil, said the company maintains it is not liable for any additional excavation costs because the Wades conducted soil tests of the property prior to the closing and were aware of the presence of the fill but chose to purchase the property anyway. 
Christopher J. LaMonica, a real estate lawyer in Brick Township, N.J., said that land use issues become even more complicated when property is on or near a river, a bay or the ocean.
"The basic rule is that any development on a beach or dune or within 150 feet of the mean high water line of a tidal water body in New Jersey must meet the requirements of the state's Coastal Area Facility Review Act," Mr. LaMonica said. He explained that under the law, which covers more than 880,000 acres of the state's coastline and inland areas, any development in the designated area is subject to review and approval by the state.
Moreover, he said, those who buy waterfront property -- whether on the ocean itself, on an inlet or on an inland waterway like Barnegat Bay -- will have to obtain a waterfront development permit and a tidelands license to erect or repair a dock or bulkhead on the property.
"The best advice I can give someone buying near water is to have an attorney or an engineer who is familiar with all of the regulations determine the conditions and limitations of development," he said.
Phyllis Simpson, director of marketing for LTS Builders in East Stroudsburg, Pa., said her company was frequently asked to build houses by people who had purchased land themselves.
"One of the things we see is that people go out and buy property without first knowing what kind of home they want to build," she said. "And we've found that most people don't really have an eye for evaluating the topography accurately for siting a home."
Moreover, she said, when buyers accustomed to New York City-area prices see land for sale for a fraction of what a studio apartment would cost in Manhattan, they tend to become a bit too eager to become land owners.
"We have people come here from the New York City metropolitan area who have fallen in love with the beauty and peace and quiet up here," Ms. Simpson said. "But they're really not terribly equipped to make the right decisions when they're making a land selection. We've seen people who have paid 30 to 40 percent more for a property than they should have paid, and they may not even be able to build what they want to build on it."
One way to avoid paying more for land than it is worth -- and to avoid buying property that will not support the kind of house one wants to build -- is to buy a "land and house" package from a reputable builder. In this kind of arrangement, Ms. Simpson said, the builder ensures that water and sewer service have been provided for and that the house ultimately built on the property meets local building and zoning requirements. 
One of the most common mistakes people make when buying rural land -- particularly large, multiacre parcels -- is failing to ascertain where the boundary lines are.
"Most people who come from the city think that property lines always run at a 90 degree angle to the road and that stone walls are a property's boundary lines," said Sal Santo, a principal of Santo Associates, a surveying company in Catskill, N.Y. "Unfortunately, neither assumption is necessarily going to be true."
Mr. Santo explained that unlike property in populated areas, where it is likely that larger parcels have already been subdivided into developable lots with easily identifiable boundary lines, rural property is often irregularly shaped and described by words alone.
"It's not unusual to see a deed describe the boundaries of a property by making reference to natural landmarks like trees, rocks and the banks of streams," Mr. Santo said. The only problem with that, he added, is that trees can die, rocks can be moved and streams can change course or dry up. 
Accordingly, he said, the first thing that a prospective purchaser of rural land should do is ask the seller for a survey. If the seller doesn't have one, he said, it would be wise for the purchaser to hire his own surveyor to identify and mark the property boundaries.
"You also want to walk the boundaries with the surveyor if possible," Mr. Santo said, explaining that by doing so, a buyer can determine whether there are any structures on the property -- or the property next door -- that extend across the property line. 
W ALKING the boundaries also makes it possible to determine whether there are any roads that other property owners are using to gain access to their property or that the buyer will have to use to get to the property being purchased. And precisely locating the boundary lines also makes it possible for the surveyor to calculate exactly how much property is being sold.
"If the seller says he's selling you 100 acres and the survey shows that he only owns 90 acres, it's good to know ahead of time so you can adjust the purchase price," Mr. Santo said. 
In fact, when buying rural property -- or any developable land -- knowing as much as possible about the property ahead of time can be a valuable negotiating tool.
Phil King, a real estate broker at Valley View Realty in Sharon Springs, N.Y., said it might be worthwhile, for example, to obtain a satellite photo of property being considered.
"A satellite photo can show you how much of the land is open, how much is wooded, the position of buildings with respect to the roads and what other kind of properties are next door," Mr. King said. (United States Geological Survey satellite photos of most of the country are available on the Internet. A quick way to find photos of specific areas is to go to www.terraserver.microsoft.com.). 
It is also important, Mr. King said, for those who are buying rural land to consider how much it will cost to have utilities connected to the home.
For example, he said, while power companies in New York do not charge for the first 500 feet of service to the property from the nearest power source, the cost beyond that first 500 feet can be anywhere from $6 to $10 a foot.
"If you're a mile in from the nearest utility pole, you've got a real item on your hands," he said.
Finally, Mr. King said, buyers of land -- regardless of where the land is and how beautiful it may seem -- should follow a simple rule they probably learned in childhood. "If a deal sounds too good to be true," he said, "it probably is too good to be true."

HEADLINE: Call It E-ZPass The Hard Way 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
Jeffrey M. Zupan has studied highways for more than 30 years, and he loves the E-ZPass automated toll system.
 Mr. Zupan can speak in rapture about the shorter lines, the savings in gasoline and the lower fares later in the evening. He says the electronic gadgets are a "tremendous improvement" over the manned toll booths in which drivers have to hunt for their money and then often wait for change while the cars back up. 
 But there is the matter of those 15 tickets. 
Mr. Zupan, like many other law-abiding drivers, has received violation notices since he began using New Jersey's E-ZPass early this year, lots of them. On one memorable day, he got 11.
Most are for running an E-ZPass gate without a pass. But Mr. Zupan, a transportation expert with the Regional Plan Association, is probably the last person who would zip through without a valid E-ZPass, so he contested the fines.
"I had to send back a separate form for each one," he said, 15 stamps, 15 envelopes and 15 chances for more aggravation.
"I was very conflicted," Mr. Zupan said. "On one hand, I am all for the tolls. On the other hand, this was driving me nuts."
Mr. Zupan is not alone. For years, New Jersey motorists looked with envy at New York and Pennsylvania, where drivers zipped through the automated toll lanes with barely a glance. After repeated delays, New Jersey's toll roads finally unveiled their own version of E-ZPass last year, and drivers signed up by the millions.
But along with the popularity came a flood of complaints.
Indeed, Edward Gross, director of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority and the state's E-ZPass program, acknowledged in a recent interview that the system had suffered through technical problems as well as financial miscalculations. Nonetheless, Mr. Gross said New Jersey was working its way through these "growing pains," and for the majority of the six million users who drive on the state's highways, E-ZPass had worked flawlessly. 
"No system of this size is going to start without some hiccups," he said.
Still, in what is arguably the most auto-dependent state in the nation, New Jersey's attempt to automate its highway tolls has been at best a mixed bag. Although it has been adopted enthusiastically by drivers, the system was late and cost millions more than expected. The cost of construction and operation is expected to reach $488 million. Trucking companies have had to hire clerks to deal with E-ZPass billing errors. Others, like Mr. Zupan, have to deal with the bureaucracy on their own.
"I am thankful it is there, but I am disturbed by some of the operational problems and the financing," said Martin Robins, director of the Transportation Policy Institute at Rutgers University. "Over all, on a scale of 1 to 10, I would give it about a 6."
Although highway officials say the worst of the growing pains are over, critics say there are several problems that must still be ironed out:
*Failure to read vehicles' electronic registers leads to fines for legitimate customers; other times, motorists are charged a maximum fee for using a highway because the system cannot tell where they entered the road.
*The customer service center has not kept pace with the thousands of calls. One Delaware official complained, "If you call the customer service lines, chances are you will not get through."
*The system is supposed to pay for itself over 10 years, mainly through the collection of fines from toll jumpers. But over the last year, only $7 million was collected, far short of the $106 million expected.
Any time a project as large and expensive as New Jersey's E-ZPass -- encompassing more than 700 tollbooths on three state highways -- some degree of controversy is expected. But this has been a particularly bad year for bureaucrats who manage large and unwieldy state contracts as well as for the motorists who are at their mercy.
The State Legislature and the Commission of Investigation have already been investigating the unpopular and costly auto inspection program. That $500 million contract, which stranded motorists in endless lines, was fraught with delay and technical mishaps. Moreover, witnesses who testified before the commission this spring said the company that won the contract, Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group, had been given advance information during the bidding.
Leading Democratic legislators did not waste any time drawing parallels between the problem-plagued inspection system and the E-ZPass contract. Assemblyman John S. Wisniewski of Sayreville, called E-ZPass "a maddening experience," and Senator Joseph F. Vitale of Woodbridge said some of the decisions taken by administrators had been "ridiculous."
Senate Minority Leader Richard J. Codey, a longtime E-ZPass critic, said that the system had jolted from one mishap to another.
"It is like you are in a bad marriage," said Mr. Codey. "It was a disaster to put into place, and it does not work that well right now."
Mr. Codey has called for Acting Governor DiFrancesco to reactivate a Senate task force originally charged with investigating both the inspection contract and E-ZPass. The task force, which only met once, was disbanded so its work would not interfere with the Commission of Investigation's examination. And though the commission was looking into the inspection contract, Mr. Codey said E-ZPass had never been examined.
"We want the Senate task force to look at both situations," he said.
At this point, Mr. DiFrancesco does not plan to reopen the issue. Rae Hutton, a spokeswoman for the governor, said the E-ZPass operators had fixed most of the problems that cropped up when the system opened.
"At the time the task force was commissioned, there were a lot of problems as far as construction and getting it set up," Ms. Hutton said. "It has been installed, it is working, and except for the motorist violations, everything else seems to be being ironed out."
SUPPORTERS and critics can argue over the merits of New Jersey's toll collection, but it is a given that the implementation of E-ZPass was anything but easy. The effort began with accusations of corruption, became stalled with a legal challenge, struggled through several changes in the primary contractor and finished with a compromise. 
Highway experts said that it was not unusual for electronic toll systems to have problems initially. Joseph L. Schofer, a professor of engineering at Northwestern University, said that in Illinois, for example, E-ZPASS had trouble attracting users because of the way it was marketed.
"They made you put down a substantial deposit," Dr. Schofer said. "It made it more difficult than it had to be."
But he said that New Jersey's plan to have fines pay for the implemention of E-ZPass was troubling.
"Using enforcement as a fund-raising strategy is really the wrong incentive," he said. "It is a speed trap."
It all began in the early 1990's, when New Jersey joined other Northeastern states in debating whether computers and cameras could replace human toll collectors. After testing competing technologies, the states agreed on a device that used small radio transmitters mounted on car windshields.
The New York Thruway quickly adopted the system, and in 1993 it installed E-ZPass booths on some portions. By 1995, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority of New York City followed suit, installing E-ZPass at the entrances to the city's nine bridges and tunnels.
But in New Jersey, proposals to adopt the system lagged. When Frank J. Wilson was appointed transportation commissioner in 1994, planning for E-ZPass was "going on at a low level," he recalled.
Part of the problem was disagreements between officials from the various toll roads. Tom Margro, who was chief engineer for the Turnpike, said that different agencies viewed E-ZPass according to their own priorities. The turnpike, for instance, saw it as a way to speed toll collections, while officials for the Garden State Parkway viewed it as a costly replacement for their token machines.
"The parkway's basic objection was that they were already doing a very efficient collection," Mr. Margro said. "We had a real rough time with the Garden State Parkway. They just did not want to change this, and in my mind, they were not looking at the bigger picture."
As Mr. Wilson now sees it, state officials became concerned that New Jersey was falling behind neighboring states, which were fast installing the technology. With a long-range plan for a seamless toll system stretching from Maine to Delaware, New Jersey's failure to begin work looked like an embarrassment. As a result, the governor instructed Mr. Wilson to move the project along.
Experts from the state's three toll roads -- the Turnpike, the Parkway and the Atlantic City Expressway -- who were tapped by Mr. Wilson to come up with a plan, quickly recognized the enormity of the job. Nothing the size of the system envisioned in New Jersey had ever been attempted. After all, more than a million drivers -- who pay more than 40 percent of the nation's tolls each year -- use the state's toll roads each day.
After months of discussion, New Jersey asked contractors for proposals but offered few specifications. New Jersey wanted all lanes equipped with E-Z Pass, and it wanted the job completed by the end of 1998. "No one had ever put a job like this into the marketplace," Mr. Wilson said.
Although several companies were interested, only two submitted proposals. Lockheed Martin IMS, which had designed E-ZPass systems in other states, offered a traditional bid and said it would install and operate the system for a set amount of money.
But its rival bidder, an MCI Worldcom subsidiary called MFS Network Technologies, presented a different strategy. Instead of requiring the state to pay, MFS said the system could support itself by fining toll jumpers and leasing rights to fiber optic lines the company would build to support the E-ZPass computers.
"You had a stark choice economically," Mr. Wilson said.
After the bids were opened, Lockheed protested, claiming it had not been given the same information about the contract as MFS -- specifically the fiber optic network, which it insisted unfairly favored its rival.
In a more explosive move, Lockheed also levied personal charges against Mr. Wilson, accusing him of discussing future employment with companies connected with the E-ZPass contract. Lockheed contended that Mr. Wilson's actions tainted the entire bid and demanded its dismissal. (A Lockheed spokesman declined to talk about the contract for this article, saying the company considered the matter closed.)
At the time, Mr. Wilson denied that he had violated any rules, since he did not have a direct role in awarding the E-ZPass contract or in recommending bidders. He also said he had informed the governor about the conversations before the bidding had started.
In the fall of 1996, the highway consortium announced its intention to award the contract to MFS. Nonetheless, Lockheed's complaint stalled the job. After several hearings, Mr. Gross rejected the protest, saying there was no evidence of unfair advantage. He even went so far as to rebuke Lockheed for accusing Mr. Wilson of unethical behavior, calling the charges "baseless."
Lockheed appealed to the Superior Court's appellate division, but its complaint was dismissed in June 1997. The court also rejected the claim against Mr. Wilson, saying there was no evidence that his talks with potential employers had any effect on the E-ZPass contract.
For his part, Mr. Wilson left the Department of Transportation before the judge's decision was handed up. In a recent interview Mr. Wilson said he probably would not have supported the version of the contract awarded to MFS, since under the current plan, the company would be paid regardless of whether fines from toll jumpers generate enough revenue to finance the system. Mr. Wilson said he would have required the company to take the risk.
"We never intended for the government to pay a penny for that project," he said.
Nevertheless, the charges about his behavior continued to haunt Mr. Wilson. Eventually, he settled claims filed with the state's Executive Commission on Ethical Standards, agreeing to pay $1,200 without admitting any wrongdoing.
"I think the record, if anyone would care to take the time to look at it, shows that what the judge said was actually correct," he said.
THE E-ZPass construction contract, hundreds of pages of minutiae, took about a year to draw up. John Haley, who was appointed to succeed Mr. Wilson as transportation commissioner, had barely approved the document when there was a major change. MFS announced it had been sold to a company called Able Telecom.
"The biggest breath-holder was whether they could demonstrate that financially they could support the project," Mr. Haley said recently.
MFS finally began work late in the summer of 1998. Construction involved parallel projects: one was the installation of E-ZPass equipment at tollbooths, and the other was building a 400-mile-long fiber optic network to connect the system.
Mr. Haley said the company used equipment and technology that had been working for years on other roads, so there was little question about the hardware. The question was whether MFS could handle the project organizationally.
"From a technical perspective, this was not hard," he said. "The concern was, given the enormous size of the project, was the company big enough to do it."
Problems quickly began to crop up, particularly in the area of nabbing toll jumpers. The company had a falling out with the subcontractor that was designing computer software to process violations, and an arbitrator ordered MFS to pay off the firm while it continued the work on its own.
MFS soon began to miss deadlines, and Mr. Gross began imposing penalties after the company failed to install the violations processing center on time -- with the fine eventually growing to more than $4 million.
The company changed hands once again, creating what Mr. Gross called "some new learning curves and some concern on our part."
The company declined to answer specific questions for this article, but did issue a written statement:
Throughout the project, MFS and its subsequent owners "have devoted significant resources to assure the successful completion of the E-ZPass system," wrote Robert Sommerfeld, president of the company, which was later renamed Adesta as a Bracknell Corporation of Canada. "Bottom line, the system is a success despite its growing pains."
At the beginning of the new company's foray into New Jersey's tangle of toll roads, Carol-Ann Hollows, who supervised the E-ZPass project for the Department of Transportation, said the company seemed to have trouble juggling several projects at once. Part of the problem was getting enough people who were technically adept to make the endless decisions about equipment and software.
In addition, Ms. Hollows said MFS was also installing electronic tolls for a highway outside Denver, and that the job seemed to divert the company's attention. Eventually, MFS and the Denver Highway Authority agreed to cancel their contract.
"There were times we needed people out here and we could not get them," she said. "There was a lot of turnover."
By 1999, the state began to open E-ZPass tollbooths on the Garden State Parkway. The work was on schedule according to the contract, but behind the state's original projections. Starting at the southern end, a new plaza opened every few days in what Ms. Hollows called "the glory days," when each opening was a small triumph.
But in a decision that would generate more controversy than any other, Mr. Gross decided on a quick opening for E-ZPass on the turnpike as well. Rather than equip all lanes with the devices, exclusive E-ZPass lanes were mixed with cash lanes. Mr. Gross said that studies showed that drivers on other roads tended to use E-ZPass-only lanes more than 90 percent of the time, so that equipping all lanes was unnecessary. 
Critics did not agree. They denounced the plan, claiming that the turnpike had scaled back on the project.
"It was like the end of the world," Mr. Gross said.
Ultimately, the protests led to yet another reversal, and all lanes are now expected to be equipped for E-ZPass next month.
IF E-Zpass is going to work through its growing pains, it will have to satisfy people like Denise Ciok, a vice president with Port Jersey Transportation, a trucking company, who was an early supporter of E-ZPass and still says electronic tolls "are a great thing to keep people moving."
But Ms. Ciok said she soon began to notice glitches in her company's bills. Sometimes drivers were charged a maximum fare when the company knew they had not traveled the entire highway, and at other times trucks with valid passes were charged with running the tollbooths.
"We were getting a lot of violations," she said. "We would have to pull out a clerk and have them research who was driving which trailer on which particular day."
The problem is a serious one for trucking companies. Gail Toth, executive director of the New Jersey Motor Truck Association, which represents about 1,000 companies, says some of the larger companies have been receiving $15,000 in excess charges a month.
"The problems you read about with cars, we are having with trucks, but 10 times worse," Ms. Toth said. "It seemed like they were in a hurry to get E-ZPass in the state and they did not think about it."
Mr. Gross said the E-ZPass consortium was working to fix the problems, and that many had already been addressed. In addition, he said that new software was expected to eliminate the problem of maximum charges for short trips by analyzing the driving patterns of highway users. And additional cameras are being installed to avoid misidentifying trucks.
What's more, Mr. Gross said that the consortium had hired a collection agency to track down people who did not pay their fines. Once the agency is working, he said, revenue should begin to move closer to expectations -- though he acknowledged that the system probably would still fall about $65 million short of paying for itself this year. Critics insisted the gap would be far greater.
"When the bill comes due, who is going to pay it?" Assemblyman Wisniewski said. "E-Zpass is not an isolated problem that got screwed up, it is a way of doing business."
Despite the criticism -- and there has been much -- Mr. Gross insists E-ZPass has been very successful. He said that while about 30 percent of the state's drivers were expected to subscribe to the system, the actual number has been more than 50 percent.
And according to a study recently made public by the turnpike, the system has decreased congestion at five of six toll plazas and has cut overtime by $10 million each year.
"Even if we are short, you should pat us on the back -- 75 percent of the system will be paid for by cheaters rather than 100 percent by toll revenues," Mr. Gross said. "I find it a little baffling that we have been criticized."

HEADLINE: Is the Field Getting Too Crowded? 

BYLINE:  By SOPHIA HOLLANDER 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
Larry Berger stood in the deserted parking lot conjuring images of urban renewal and soccer innovation with the skill of a magician and the conviction of a visionary. 
 Mr. Berger and his partner, Paul Oliu, were at the Roebling Complex, an abandoned factory site in downtown Trenton, where their group, NTC Partners, proposes to build a $31 million soccer stadium where they hope to land one of two Major League Soccer expansion teams scheduled to join the league in 2003. 
 For now, the two men envision a team called the Union FC, which would be named in honor of Trenton's history as a union town and for the city's contribution to the Union forces in the Civil War.
Across the street loomed the newest sports venue here, the Sovereign Bank Arena, tall and stark against the city's underdeveloped skyline. 
With a wave of his hands and a few words, Mr. Berger -- who runs a venture capital company in Princeton -- turned historic brick warehouses, now abandoned and with broad windows stained by age, into a stately stadium facade.
Faded streets with bargain-basement shops became opportunities to turn the ragged downtown into a community of artists' lofts and restaurants.
In their vision -- some would say pipe dream -- soccer would be transformed into an instrument of international healing as Mr. Berger and Mr. Oliu -- who works for Merrill Lynch -- propose bringing Palestinian and Israeli youths together to participate in soccer camps.
Later, as the men drove from the squalid site, speeding past small, colorful houses with peeling paint, Mr. Berger pointed to abandoned storefronts as more evidence of the city's potential. Suddenly a voice piped up from the back seat.
"Dad," the voice said skeptically, "isn't Trenton mostly boarded up houses?"
Mr. Berger admitted that was largely true.
Aaron, age 9, digested this. "So," said Mr. Berger's son, "why would you want to build it here then?"
It is a question many people are asking. 
No one involved with Major League Soccer disputes the need for new stadiums as the sport matures in this country. And the emphasis by NTC Partners on youth development, education and community involvement are also important components. But there are several concerns among soccer fans, and two of them involve the MetroStars, a Major League Soccer team that has been playing at the Meadowlands sports complex for about six years:
*Can the city sustain a major league team when it has often struggled to support a minor league sports franchise?
*Can soccer supply enough fans for three teams in such close proximity -- assuming that the owners of the MetroStars exercised their option to start an additional team in New York City? And would the MetroStars allow that to happen?
*Why wouldn't a franchise go to a nearby city like Philadelphia, which has a strong soccer community?
"If you were to go into Philadelphia and play in a big football stadium, then it doesn't have that feel that this is the best show in town to me," said Jeff Bradley, a writer for ESPN Magazine and an ESPN.com soccer columnist. "You're dealing with what almost every other M.L.S. team deals with -- being a second- or third-class citizen. I think the league could break new ground by going into areas that are known for soccer."
But Nick Sakiewicz, general manager of the MetroStars, has said that he would block any effort to bring a team to Trenton because it would infringe on the 75-mile competition-free zone guaranteed by the league.
Mr. Sakiewicz estimated that about 10 percent of the team's fans came from central and southern New Jersey, a number that could increase if the MetroStars left the Meadowlands and moved to a new stadium it envisioned in Harrison, outside of Newark.
"Certainly having a soccer stadium in Trenton is a great idea," he said. "Trenton is our territory under our agreement with Major League Soccer. We would certainly prevent a major league team from going there."
So far, the league has been noncommittal.
"The MetroStars certainly would have the right to express themselves if there was going to be a potential for infringement of their boundaries," said Nelson Rodriguez, assistant to the commissioner. "Ultimately a decision would be taken in concert with them and the owners."
A week after visiting the site, Mr. Berger's voice, usually calm and confident, sounded strained over the telephone. He said he had been told by Major League Soccer that the MetroStars were its priority.
"There is this view out there that we're doing all of this to make the MetroStars look bad," he said with a touch of exasperation in his voice. "One of the things we decided to do was be very affirmative. We have these emerging transportation, education projects and yet we've somehow been pulled back into 'Are we polluting the waters of somebody else's effort?' "
The MetroStars are seeking to have their new stadium financed entirely by public money, even exploring the possibility of getting in on the proposal to build a new arena in Newark, which has been described by Bret D. Schundler, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, as a "Christmas tree" because of the various projects added to gain legislative support.
In contrast, NTC Partners has proposed financing the stadium without help from the taxpayers, though Mr. Berger said that their bid would be more attractive to the league if the state could contribute about a third of the price tag. Mr. Berger has offered to put up almost $10 million.
Assuming the league, the MetroStars, and NTC partners can smooth over matters, the question remains whether the market will be oversaturated.
When Ken Samu, the minority owner of the Trenton Lightning, an indoor football team that played in the Sovereign Bank Arena, read about the proposed stadium, he said he was astonished. 
"Are they nuts?" Mr. Samu said he remembered thinking.
In July, six games into the Lightning's inaugural season, the team folded. It was the second team in six weeks to fail at the arena; the Trenton Shooting Stars, a minor league basketball team that also played there, met a similar fate.
To be sure, each team had its own reason for failing. Both, said the arena's general manager, Michael Scanlon, were mismanaged and overly optimistic. In addition to the arena's operating costs, which are running about $575,000 a year higher than projected, the state has had to contribute an additional $7 million over the last two years.
In contrast, the Trenton Titans, a minor league hockey team that also plays at the arena, and the Trenton Thunder, a minor league baseball that plays at Waterfront Park, are both considered highly successful.
"Now it's two and two," said Herb Greenfield, owner of the Shooting Stars, when asked if he thought professional soccer could be successful in Trenton. "What do you think?"
But even the Titans and the Thunder each average fewer than 7,000 fans a game. The Lightning averaged 3,000, and the Shooting Stars 1,000. For the soccer stadium to succeed, it would have to keep pace with the Major League Soccer average of 14,000 tickets sold for each game.
Mr. Berger and Mr. Oliu know these numbers well. But they have some of their own. According to the New Jersey Interscholastic Athletic Association, 26,946 high school students play organized soccer. New Jersey Youth Soccer has even more impressive numbers: 160,053 children from the ages of 3 to 19 were participating in soccer leagues as of last month.
To doubters who claim that Pennsylvanians will never cross the bridge to attend sporting events, the Titans and the Thunder offer contradictory evidence. Based on fan surveys and season ticket sales, the Thunder estimate that 40 percent of their fans are from Pennsylvania, though the team's general manager, Rick Brenner, conceded that most came from neighboring Bucks County, not Philadelphia.
Richard Lisk, vice president for marketing and the Titans' assistant general manager, said that from 11 percent to 15 percent of his team's fans were from Pennsylvania.
But even beyond these statistics, argued Mr. Oliu, soccer fans are a "unique breed."
"Soccer fans are so starved for their own experience," he said. "They are tremendously loyal and they hunt out their games as best they can."
This city has also planned improvements, to be completed by 2004, to make Union FC's position more attractive. For instance, a train line is being built between Camden and Trenton that would stop directly in front of the stadium. The Trenton train station -- connected to Philadelphia by mass transit and a short walk from the arena district, will be undergoing a $30 million renovation; the blocks separating them will be will transformed into a promenade.
Mayor Douglas Palmer and Mercer County Executive Robert Prunetti said they were convinced the city could benefit from the proposed improvements.
"We're willing to talk about ways that we can be helpful and supportive," Mr. Palmer said. "We believe we could be the next Green Bay. We could be what Green Bay is to the Packers."
As for Mr. Prunetti: "I was impressed. I was a little skeptical going into the meeting. But they seem to have a pretty good strategy and some clear objectives."
