HEADLINE: CAMPAIGNING FOR CITY HALL; 
In Their Own Words

 BODY:
FERNANDO FERRER
Speaking yesterday at the National Action Network in Harlem:
 "There is a very interesting expectation in this election, that the policies of the last eight years must define the agenda for the next four. . . . If someone else believes that Rudy Giuliani is the personification of a New York resurgent, and all those policies are terrific and must continue, you need to vote for somebody else. Not me. Because I acknowledge what has not gone right. Somebody asked me about crime: 'You want to see crime back?' Oh, come on. You're going to give me a lecture on crime? Listen, I didn't grow up in a suburb of Boston. I grew up on Fox Street in the South Bronx, when it was the South Bronx." 

MARK GREEN
Remarks made yesterday during the Labor Day Parade.
 "No one stood up to Rudy Giuliani more over the past seven and a half years than I have. After a decade of divisiveness, I'm now the Democrat who is going to take on problems, not rivals, not their endorsers, not their surrogates, and I feel confident that I have enormous support in the black community and the Latino community."
"Franklin Roosevelt understood poverty better than Newt Gingrich. Our former president didn't grow up in poverty, and Newt Gingrich did. Whether or not you understand poverty is not your ZIP code or where you were brought up. It's your courage to take on hard fights and win. I don't know anyone who's done more for communities of color in the last seven and a half years than I have."

PETER F. VALLONE
Remarks made during the Labor Day Parade yesterday.
 "My whole political life has been underestimated. They said I couldn't do "Safe Streets/Safe City." When I cut a budget by $2 billion in one month, that's when I was underestimated. I've been underestimated and I'm certainly underestimated in these polls. I've been underestimated by a minimum of 20 points. I'm concerned about people in New York City who vote, not pollsters. The major thing that separates me from the other candidates is the fact that I have not only done things like "Safe Streets/Safe City," campaign finance, reducing class size; I don't have to talk about it, I've done those things and I think people are beginning to understand that."

ALAN G. HEVESI
Speaking yesterday in Union Square Park:
 "I am the manager of the comptroller's office, and we are the managers. We are the ones who audit all city agencies. We did the Y2K to make sure there was no trouble. The city is the center of the global economy. I am the representative, in effect, of the city in the global economy. We do yen deals, we do trade deals with South Africa, we do euro deals. Education is the No. 1 issue. I'm the educator. I have a Ph.D. I've been in the classroom for 27 years. None of my opponents have been in the classroom. And I've been endorsed by the United Federation of Teachers. You've got to be a fiscal expert -- that's my official designation -- as the fiscal monitor. And finally, you've got to have the best relationship with the governor and the Legislature, regardless of party, because they have to approve 75 or 80 percent of any initiative or innovation that we make. I have the best relationship coming out of the Legislature, as a member of the Assembly for 22 years."

MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG
Speaking at Frank Golden Memorial Park in College Point, Queens, and addressing a Little League picnic.
 "My No. 1 priority is education. The city already spent $12 billion out of a $40-billion budget and it looks like tax revenues are going to come down as the economy softens. And also, everybody agrees, for example, that teachers need raises."
"What Rudy did for education was he brought crime down so dramatically that the next mayor has the luxury of focusing on education. Rudy eight years ago did not have that -- you know you couldn't walk the streets. Today you can. You might not like Rudy; whether you like Rudy or not, crime is way down. It can go further, so the next mayor really has an opportunity, and if they don't focus on education it will be a terrible waste."

HERMAN BADILLO
Remarks made yesterday at the Labor Day Parade.
 "As the campaign winds down, we're beginning to find the real character of Mr. Bloomberg and that is that he is the kind of personality that cannot be trusted and should not be mayor of New York because of the remarks that he has made, but also because of his unwillingness to respond to the press . . . We all know that if you're not prepared to answer question after question after question ad infinitum from reporters, you're certainly not qualified to be mayor."
"My campaign is very simple. I have credentials and he has commercials. I have experience, he has no experience. I have been scrutinized all my life in every way for the past 40 years. He has never been held up to scrutiny and now we find out why. Because he cannot stand scrutiny. And I'm going and saying to people that they should not elect a $30-million commercial as mayor. That they should elect a real person and they should, for that reason, elect Herman Badillo."

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
U.S. vs. Microsoft: Going Back to Square One

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IT was a jarring juxtaposition. As the Bush administration decided last week to abandon the government's plan to break up Microsoft for a raft of antitrust violations, Bill Gates, the company's co-founder and chairman, was saying that the case had had no impact over the way the company designed its products or conducted its affairs.
 "There's been no interference from the lawsuit in terms of Microsoft pushing its innovation forward," Mr. Gates told The Washington Post. "I doubt there will be that interference because the laws do and should encourage innovation." 
 Indeed, the company is preparing to launch a new operating system that includes the kinds of features that have been at issue in the antitrust case.
The Justice Department's retrenchment seems to epitomize the Bush administration's belief that government should not play a decisive role in business affairs, and that, by and large, market forces should dictate how companies compete.
This conviction could also be seen in the administration's recently announced intention to relax or eliminate a host of decades-old regulations that have prevented the nation's largest broadcasters, cable companies and media conglomerates from growing bigger. The rules have kept conglomerates like AOL Time Warner from owning a television network, and big newspaper chains and cable companies from also owning local broadcasting stations. 
Until last Thursday, the Justice Department and most of the 18 states involved in the latest round of litigation had concluded that a consent decree limiting Microsoft's conduct would never be enough to restore competition to the software market. 
They saw Microsoft as an antitrust recidivist, an aggressive monopolist that two federal courts had said had bullied its rivals and abused its monopoly position in the industry. Indeed, Microsoft spent years developing its new operating system, Windows XP, which some antitrust experts say poses even more anticompetitive problems than the older systems at the center of the lawsuit. In addition to bolting in the latest version of Microsoft's Internet Explorer, Windows XP also integrates applications for processing digital photographs, instant messaging, and video and audio players. 
Nonetheless, a Republican administration that never really cared for the breakup order, and a president who has voiced impatience over protracted lawsuits, have decided on a more conciliatory course of action. 
Senior officials say that by narrowing the case and dropping the breakup request, they will shave many months off the proceedings. And they add that they are only following the guidance of a unanimous appeals court that three months ago voiced skepticism about any breakup order. 
To some who have followed the Dickensian twists and turns of the long-running case, events last week seemed eerily familiar. 
Six years ago, Federal District Judge Stanley Sporkin rejected a consent decree filed by the Justice Department and Microsoft, finding that it wouldn't work.
"The picture that emerges from these proceedings," Judge Sporkin wrote in his opinion in 1995, "is that the U.S. government is either incapable or unwilling to deal effectively with a potential threat to this nation's economic well-being." 
If he were to approve the deal, he wrote, "the message will be that Microsoft is so powerful that neither the market nor the government is capable of dealing with all of its monopolistic practices."
Accepting the proposed consent decree, the judge concluded, "would almost be the equivalent of a court accepting a probationary plea from a defendant who has told the court he will go out and again engage in inappropriate conduct."
The government and the company responded by getting Judge Sporkin thrown off the case and found a new judge to approve the decree, which, indeed, proved ineffective. 
"Microsoft has flaunted conduct remedies for years," said Mark N. Cooper, research director of the Consumer Federation of America. "The decision to take a structural remedy off the table puts the Department of Justice and the state attorneys general in the position of having to fashion an extremely aggressive set of behavioral controls that will have to be followed up vigorously."
Some antitrust experts and some state officials wonder whether, in fact, it will prove possible to curb a pervasive corporate culture through a consent decree. In any case, it will require years of close and onerous supervision by the judiciary and law enforcement, an outcome the Clinton administration and the states rejected last year in favor of a breakup.
"Judge Jackson repeatedly made clear that he did not want to be another Harold Greene," said Stephen D. Houk, a lawyer who has represented the states in the Microsoft case, referring to the judge who spent more than a decade supervising every facet of operations of AT&T after its complex consent decree was approved.
"THERE are problems with the large obstinate corporation but the judge in this situation has an awful lot of power," said John Shepard Wiley Jr., an antitrust professor at the University of California in Los Angeles who has used the Microsoft proceeding as a case study in his classes. "She has enough tools to discipline an unruly litigant. It's not an ideal world and these cases represent a genuine challenge to the judiciary. The conduct remedy may be a blunt instrument but it's certainly not impotent." 
Now in private practice, Judge Sporkin says he believes a consent decree can be fashioned to fix the problems identified by the case, particularly if it includes some tough enforcement mechanisms.
Judge Sporkin added that he is not at all troubled by the prospect of a court's spending years overseeing the company, as Judge Greene did in the AT&T case.
For their part, some prosecutors say they have taken a lesson from the government's experience with the earlier consent decree that Judge Sporkin tried to reject.
"We can learn from our experiences with the consent decrees on how to frame them and how to monitor them," said Richard Blumenthal, the attorney general in Connecticut. 
But some state prosecutors said they were concerned that the new leadership at the Justice Department would be more forgiving of the company, and they vowed to press any remedy to also include restrictions on Windows XP.
"We look forward to continuing to work with the Department of Justice in the proceedings that are about to begin before the trial court," said Eliot Spitzer, the attorney general of New York. "But we will, if necessary to protect the public, press for remedies that go beyond those requested by the Department of Justice."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Face Off; 
Which Way to Win Control of Congress?

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
TALK about shark season. Congress came back into session last week and the Democrats were circling, sensing blood in the political waters. The Republicans had an air of panic.
 Only last spring, the Democrats were unable to stop President Bush's $1.35 trillion, ten-year tax cut. But with the economy slowing, the budget surplus shrinking and President Bush in danger of having to break his pledge not to dip into the Social Security surplus, Democrats have returned to Washington crowing, "I told you so." 
 "This is the Bush budget and the Bush tax cut," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader. And Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York compared the changing fiscal climate to a bad summer movie titled "Honey, I Shrunk The Surplus." 
The "Bush budget, Bush tax cut, Bush economy" refrain will go hand-in-hand with a concerted Democratic campaign this fall to force Mr. Bush to submit a new budget -- one that reflects the new economic projections and details the politically painful choices he may have to make in response to them. 
How, for example, will he will pay for the military buildup, or expand tax breaks for health insurance, or provide a Medicare prescription drug benefit or increase education spending if the economy continues to deteriorate?
Democrats hope that raising these questions will let them seize the initiative in the autumn budget fight that is expected to set the framework for the 2002 battle for control of Congress. Nor do they plan to offer the president their own plan or answers any time soon. 
"It's really best to let him stew," said one senior Democratic Senate strategist. "And it's frankly only fair. Most of us voted against this budget and this tax cut and now we're going to come riding over the hill to save him?"
To make maximum use of their advantages, however, Democrats will need unity, a consistent message, party discipline and no missteps. 
"The Democrats have a way of stealing defeat from the jaws of victory," insists Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster. "They don't know when to shut up."
And the economy could turn around sooner than most people expect. 
"We're all speculating at this point that it's going to be a long-term downturn," said Marshall Wittmann, a Congressional analyst at the conservative Hudson Institute. "If we're on the cusp of a recovery that begins early next year, Bush will be able to sing the praises of his tax cut and the Democrats will have egg on their face."
So as both parties hold their breath and watch the economic indicators, strategists are plotting out all the political scenarios. And there are still a number of ways that Democrats might squander their advantage. Here are a few.

1. What happened to the party of public investment?
When President Clinton said "Save Social Security First" and railroaded both parties into pledging not to use Social Security taxes for anything other than paying down debt, it was a strategy designed in part to keep Republicans from passing large tax cuts. 
Now that Mr. Bush has won his tax cut and the economy is weakening, however, the inviolability of the Social Security trust fund is a brake on spending. And it is the Democrats who want a more robust Medicare prescription drug benefit than Mr. Bush does, the Democrats who are pushing for billions of dollars more for education, the Democrats who are more likely to want money for child care and health care programs.
On such issues Democrats retain the upper hand. But will they continue to do so if they can't actually get anything done? Even if they take control of Congress in 2002, will they find themselves neutered, without the cash to enact their programs?

2. Calvin Coolidge Democrats?
The Democrats' conundrum becomes worse if the country goes into a recession. Some party dissidents are already arguing that an obsession with debt relief and the Social Security trust fund during bad times risks making the Democrats look more like the party of Calvin Coolidge than of Franklin D. Roosevelt.
"I think they are building a box that could be very damaging," said Robert L. Borosage, the co-director of the Campaign for America's Future, a liberal public policy group. "If the economy continues to decline," he said, "Democrats should be arguing about unemployment insurance, about special assistance to older workers thrown out of the manufacturing sector, programs for welfare mothers who will be the first ones laid off. Instead what they are arguing is that the president should cut more money out of the budget."

3. Where's the beef?
While they can get away with blaming Mr. Bush for the budget straitjacket for a while, Democrats will eventually have to make their own proposals or else risk looking like mere partisan complainers.
Congressional Republicans want a cut in the capital gains tax rate, hoping that will stimulate the economy. What are the Democrats offering? No wonder that Mr. Daschle on Friday began speaking of the plight of the unemployed.
"They're just flapping their gums," said Representative Thomas M. Davis 3rd of Virginia, who is in charge of the House Republicans' re-election effort. "What's their answer? Their answer is to call on Bush to come up with an answer. They have some responsibility too. They control the Senate."
But it is far easier to blame Mr. Bush than to unite Democrats around a program of their own. If liberal Democrats push to switch money from the military to domestic programs, the party's southern defense hawks are likely to bolt for fear that Democrats will end up looking like McGovernites.
Similarly, if Democrats push to roll back some part of Mr. Bush's tax cut, they would need the support of the conservatives and moderates who voted with Mr. Bush in favor of the $1.35 trillion reduction. But not all of them will go along. Senator Zel Miller of Georgia was already scoffing last week at all the talk of a budget crisis and deriding government bureaucrats and spending sprees.
"We're in a good spot to start out," said Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York. "But if we fracture and everyone comes out with his own plan, that's our greatest danger."

4. Tax and spend Democrats?
Even the suggestion that the tax cut should be rescinded could open the Democrats up to the charge that they just want to tax and spend. President Clinton erased this vulnerability for his party by advocating a balanced budget and speaking of fiscal responsibility and debt reduction. But during the presidential campaign Mr. Bush effectively lampooned Al Gore as the candidate of big government. 
So Mr. Daschle said there was no point in talking about reducing the tax cut since Mr. Bush would never support the move. And Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, went through all kinds of linguistic gymnastics at a news conference last week. 
He challenged Mr. Bush to submit a new budget, pointing out that Democrats had come up with their own in the spring that called for a smaller tax cut than the president's. Yet he repeatedly dodged questions about whether Democrats wanted to rescind part of the Bush tax cut.
Asked for the umpteenth time whether he wanted to roll back the tax cut, he told reporters: "I'll get you a copy of our budget. Read it. It is a good budget. It has the right priorities."
By Friday, Mr. Bush was already accusing the Democrats of being big taxers. "Tax relief is just now making its way in the economy, and there are some, it seems like, who are beginning to say, maybe we ought to raise taxes," he said at the White House, vowing he would not "let anybody pick the pockets of the American taxpayer."
Still, at least in Washington right now, everyone thinks it is the Republicans who are in peril, including the Republicans. Witness the Oval Office huddle between Mr. Bush and leaders of his party Friday as unemployment figures surged and Wall Street tumbled.
Well aware that his father lost an election because he seemed oblivious to bad times, Mr. Bush took time to step out of the Oval Office and proclaim, "The slowdown is real and it's affecting too many lives and I'm concerned about it." His father might have said it differently: "Message: I care."
"Clearly people see the economy in trouble," said Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut. "And the president is sitting there and he's the guy they look to to lead on these matters." 
Mr. Bush's biggest problem, and the Democrats' biggest advantage, may be Social Security. Polls show that Americans overwhelmingly want surplus Social Security funds to be kept off-limits, and Democrats believe that uncertainty over whether Mr. Bush will leave them alone may eat away at his image, much as his father was hurt when he backed away from his "no new taxes" pledge during his own struggle over deficit reduction.
MR. BUSH pledged in the campaign and again in his first address to Congress in February that he would preserve the Social Security surplus "for Social Security and Social Security alone." But he has already abandoned a campaign promise on carbon dioxide emissions and changed his position on stem cell research. Might he -- or his party -- risk doing so on Social Security? 
The Democrats will try to exploit such vulnerabilities to take full control of the House and Senate in 2002, and they believe that history and circumstance are on their side. The president's party traditionally loses seats in off years and suffers during economic downturns, and in the Senate, more Republicans than Democrats are likely to retire before the next elections.
Of course, these scenarios are all hypothetical. This is likely to be a long drawn out budget fight, and its political consequences could surprise everybody.
"President Bush dug the hole that we're in, but we're in the hole too," Mr. Schumer admits.

 Late Edition - Final

HEADLINE: BUSH'S AIDES SEEK TO FOCUS EFFORTS ON THE ECONOMY 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE and DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 

 BODY:
As White House officials move to refocus President Bush's energies on the precarious economy, they are working to present him as a more commanding leader in what may be the most treacherous stretch of his first year in the White House.
 The economic and political challenges facing Mr. Bush were underscored earlier this week when his senior adviser, Karl Rove, joined more than a dozen prominent Republicans for a private dinner and heard an unvarnished critique of Mr. Bush's style and strategy. 
 The message, delivered on Tuesday in a dark-paneled room at the Metropolitan Club, two blocks from the White House, was urgent and unambiguous: If Mr. Bush did not take more forceful steps to resuscitate the economy, he would risk repeating the mistake that brought an early end to his father's presidency. He needed to talk about economic issues differently, they said, and to spur the economy with new measures that went well beyond the recent tax cut. 
"You didn't get the sense that anyone was holding back," recalled Mark McKinnon, a Bush campaign adviser who attended the dinner.
Even before the dinner -- and before the ominous news on Friday that the unemployment rate had risen to 4.9 percent -- Mr. Bush's aides were already recalibrating his fall agenda. There will be more and more economic prescriptions, they said, diluting what was initially planned as a season devoted largely to his education agenda and talk about values under the banner of what Mr. Bush calls "communities of character."
As Mr. Bush faces narrowing economic options at home and rising challenges abroad, some of his advisers said they feared he still did not project the image of a commanding leader. These advisers cite polls showing that many people still view Mr. Bush not as decisive but as tentative and perhaps overly scripted. They say that polishing the president's performance skills is an urgent political task.
From the size of the index cards he reads from to the size of the lecterns he stands behind, Mr. Bush's handlers are seeking to make him appear as comfortable in the formal settings of the presidency as he clearly was last month at a news conference in a small community center near his ranch in Crawford, Tex.
That will become all the more critical in the next three months, his aides say, because of the politically tough choices ahead. 
"We're in the Chinese box phase" of the presidency, one of his closest advisers said.
For example, Mr. Bush seems all but certain to have to choose between scaling back some of his defense and education priorities and acknowledging the virtual inevitability of tapping into the Social Security surplus. By November or December, he must decide whether to enrage United States allies and abandon the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty -- or accept delays in his missile shield program. He must bridge a rift in his own administration over dealing with China before visiting Beijing in five weeks.

Beyond the Rebate Check
Looming over all these concerns is the sluggish economy, which has necessitated a reshaping of Mr. Bush's fall agenda. Rather than focusing on issues he most enjoys -- family values, the importance of education, personal responsibility -- Mr. Bush will concentrate on the country's economic problems. 
"Karen had a whole fall offensive lined up -- all this character and values stuff," one Bush adviser said, referring to Karen P. Hughes, Mr. Bush's counselor. "That, I think is pretty irrelevant now," the adviser said. "We're in the process of switching the game plan."
While she disputed that she was switching signals, Ms. Hughes acknowledged, "We are maintaining some flexibility in October."
Other advisers said privately that there would be a much sharper focus than initially planned for Mr. Bush to talk about prescriptions for economic recovery, to turn the debate from the question of whether to tap into the Social Security surplus to the question of who has the best, most comprehensive plan to save the economy.
"We're aware," one senior economic adviser said, "that after this month, he can't simply keep saying, 'Did you get your $600 check in the mail?' "
Mr. Bush is driven by his determination not to repeat the mistake his father made: failing to leap ahead of sour economic news, failing to sound sophisticated and in command of the problem.
At the dinner on Tuesday -- attended by conservative stalwarts including David Keene, Haley Barbour, Kenneth M. Duberstein, Vin Weber, Charles Black, Linda DiVall, Bill Paxon, and Ed Gillespie -- several participants said they pressed Mr. Rove to get the president to act assertively. One suggestion was to cut the capital gains tax -- a step that might generate some income for the government by spurring stock sales but that would be seized on by Democrats as a tax cut for the wealthy.
They said Mr. Rove was sympathetic but noncommittal, as were two other administration officials in the room, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., who heads the Office of Management and Budget, and Nicholas Calio, the chief White House Congressional liaison.
"My job at these dinners is to take it all in," Mr. Rove said in an interview. "It's not to immediately react to everything. A number of people in the room had suggestions about things they said needed to be done for the economic growth package."
Mr. Rove disputed that Mr. Bush was entering the most challenging phase of his presidency thus far.
"I've heard that continually when he faced the cell decision, when he faced the tax cut decision, when he faced the education bill," Mr. Rove said. "A lot of people in Washington are trying to dismiss the success of the president by raising the bar higher on the next thing down the pike."
But even some Republicans have lingering concerns that on the stump with steelworkers in Pittsburgh or at Labor Day events in Michigan and Wisconsin, the president's economic prescriptions sounded simplistic, and that he lacked President Bill Clinton's well-honed skill at explaining how individual American workers can benefit from a changing world economy.
Mr. Bush has the compassion part down well. Ms. Hughes said, "He called me right after the picnic at the steel plant and said that the effects of the downturn are beginning to show up in factories and workplaces."
But in his public discourse about the economy, Mr. Bush sometimes sounds disjointed; he has trouble moving beyond a few set sentences about the relationship between free trade and the creation (not to mention the loss) of jobs in the United States. And so far, he has not developed many skills in talking to players in the financial markets, something Mr. Clinton learned from his treasury secretary, Robert E. Rubin. (Mr. Bush's treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, is also viewed widely in the administration and Congress as a poor communicator of economic strategy.)
"Like most Republicans," said Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, "Bush is pretty free market, so he's working his way toward talking about the economy, and he's discovering it's quite a balancing act. If you describe the problems in the economy too bluntly, you run the risk of having people lose confidence. And yet he knows he can't understate it either."
The problem is only compounded by the Bush administration's central dilemma. With the tax cut already passed, the president is essentially out of economic ammunition. He can talk about winning authority to negotiate new trade agreements, but the economic benefits would be years away. And the traditional stimulaters available to politicians -- more government spending or more tax cuts -- would require dipping deep into the Social Security surplus.

Beyond These Shores
At the height of the October budget battles, Mr. Bush will spend 10 days in Asia visiting Japan as it faces economic crisis, South Korea as it struggles with Washington over how to talk to the Communist North Koreans, and China. The last stop, one of Mr. Bush's close Republican foreign policy advisers said the other day, "is where we'll learn how well he plays three-dimensional chess."
Mr. Bush's own party is deeply split on how to approach China, with the business community urging more and more engagement and the conservative, pro-Taiwan faction warning that China could well become the next great military challenge for the United States. That division also runs through his administration: just listen to Secretary of State Colin L. Powell wax on about the benefits of a smart political and economic engagement with China, while Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld regularly briefs the press on how a rising Chinese threat requires a greater focus on security in the Pacific.
White House insiders differ on which man has the president's ear. But they agree on one thing: Mr. Bush cannot declare, as he did the first time he met President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, that he has looked into the souls of his Chinese hosts and seen men he trusts. 
With regard to Russia, administration officials had hoped this summer to hold a quick "consultation" that would pave the way for abandoning the treaty limiting missile defenses and allow Mr. Bush to test a missile shield. By now it is clear that Mr. Putin plans to take his time, insisting that Mr. Bush first reveal how deeply he is willing to cut American nuclear forces. Around the time the two men meet at Mr. Bush's ranch in Texas, the administration will have to choose its course.
"What worries me is that they are not yet treating this issue as a foreign policy problem but rather as a missile defense issue," said Senator Hagel, a missile defense proponent. "People from the administration come up here to testify and we hear all kinds of things, but you have the sense there is no clear definition of where they are going with these big relationships, that maybe they haven't thought out all the consequences yet."
Mr. Bush is also under pressure to once again put the United States in the midst of the Middle East talks, which until now he has kept at arm's length. That risks spending a lot of energy for a potentially small reward.

Behind the Lectern
A nagging concern at the highest levels of the White House staff is Mr. Bush's communications skills, with new debate over how he can project himself as a leader while also capitalizing on his ability to charm people in smaller group settings.
Some advisers said Mr. Bush would have a more dominant public profile if he appeared at more majestic, White House-style events with the trappings of his office behind him. Others have countered that Mr. Bush would get swallowed up -- and look out of his element -- in such settings.
Ms. Hughes said that this fall the White House will continue to carry out a strategy that she, Mr. Bush and Mr. Rove devised early in the summer to be more deliberate about staging presidential events. She said there had been too many medium-sized events that did not always generate favorable coverage for the president or put him in the best light.
As an example, some White House officials cited a trip by Mr. Bush in late June to Oak Mountain State Park in Alabama, near the foothills of the Appalachian Mountains, in which he promoted conservation. Some complained that Mr. Bush appeared too scripted and that the event did not give him an opportunity to mingle with people.
By contrast, Ms. Hughes said she was pleased in August with the small events in Texas where Mr. Bush appeared in informal settings relating to ordinary Americans. From now on, she said, there will be more of a blend of those events as well as grander appearances, like his first state dinner this week, that show Mr. Bush in more of a presidential mode.
"You always work for a balance," Ms. Hughes said, "and there was a conclusion that we need to focus on bigger presidential events as well as smaller events where he focused more directly on people."
Part of the problem White House officials face, however, is that Mr. Bush appears far more relaxed and comfortable when he is in settings outside Washington, particularly at his ranch. In addition, officials said, Mr. Bush scoffs at the notion that he is stage-managed and sometimes resists efforts that could improve his performance, like practicing more with a teleprompter.
"You cannot force it," one White House official said of Mr. Bush's reluctance to use the prompter. "The bottom line is he does not want to do it every time with the teleprompter."
Another Bush adviser said, "He hates the idea of being coached and handled, just like his father did."
Senator Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee, said he has seen a marked improvement in Mr. Bush's public appearances. "He is evolving into the presidential mode very comfortably. It's been an evolution, but the comfort level seems to me to increase every day."

HEADLINE: The Cost of Doing Business 

BYLINE:  By Maurice Isserman; Maurice Isserman is the William R. Kenan professor of history at Hamilton College. His most recent book is "The Other American: The Life of Michael Harrington."

 BODY:
 OUT OF THE JUNGLE
Jimmy Hoffa and the Remaking
of the American Working Class.
By Thaddeus Russell.
Illustrated. 272 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $26.
 Here's my favorite Jimmy Hoffa story: In early September 1972, The Detroit News reported that Hoffa would be leaving imminently for Hanoi to secure the release of American prisoners held by the North Vietnamese. Two of Hoffa's associates from the Teamsters union had met earlier that summer with Richard Nixon's national security adviser, Henry Kissinger, and proposed the idea. They struck some kind of deal, because Hoffa faced no difficulty from the State Department in getting his passport validated for travel to North Vietnam, a country supposedly off limits to all but officially sanctioned American visitors. 
Perhaps the Nixon administration reasoned that Hoffa, with years of experience under his belt as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, would prove a hard-nosed negotiator. Still, it was an unusual assignment for a private citizen -- not to mention a recently paroled felon. Barely six months earlier, Hoffa had walked out of Lewisburg Federal Penitentiary in Pennsylvania, freed by President Nixon's executive grant of clemency after serving four years and nine months of his original 13-year sentence for jury tampering and pension-fund fraud. Critics of the administration suggested that Hoffa's travel plans might be part of an election-year payoff to the Teamsters (the one major union endorsing the president's re-election) and prelude to a full presidential pardon that would allow Hoffa to return to the Teamster presidency.
In any event, when the story broke prematurely, Hoffa quickly canceled his plane reservations, and the State Department disavowed his passport validation. This was followed by a flurry of official denials in Washington -- from Kissinger, who said that he had opposed the idea of using Hoffa as a negotiator from the start; from Attorney General Richard Kleindienst, who denied reports that he had interceded with Hoffa's parole board to win its permission for the trip; and from the White House press secretary, Ron Ziegler, who denied that President Nixon knew anything at all about the arrangement. (Ziegler would get a lot of practice over the next several years offering similar denials on his president's behalf.) Hoffa never got his full pardon. 
Overlooking the moral squalor, what a splendid comic spectacle. Were there an Olympic competition for cynicism, could one imagine a dream team more formidable than that gathered on this occasion: Nixon, Kissinger, Kleindienst, Ziegler -- and Hoffa?
You will not find my favorite Hoffa story in Thaddeus Russell's new work of biography and labor history, "Out of the Jungle: Jimmy Hoffa and the Remaking of the American Working Class." Nor, in a more substantial omission, will you learn about the tens of millions of dollars in Teamster pension funds that flowed during the Hoffa years into mob-controlled casinos in Nevada and similar ventures in Florida and California -- a financial collaboration that, in the words of the labor historian Robert Zieger, "helped make the very name 'Teamsters' anathema to labor activists and union critics alike." What you will find is a historian's equivalent of the full presidential pardon Hoffa hoped to get from President Nixon.
Russell, who teaches American history at Barnard College, initially wrote "Out of the Jungle" as a doctoral dissertation at Columbia University. Like many such endeavors by young scholars, this book sets out to overthrow the dominant orthodoxy in its field, in this case interpretations put forward since the 1960's in the name of the "new labor history." The new labor historians, favoring a history-from-the-bottom-up approach to their subject, have been drawn to eras of intense conflict between workers and employers like the the 1930's, and have emphasized working class "agency" -- that is, the ability of ordinary workers at certain junctures in American history to change society through their own actions. 
Russell believes that these historians have skewed the actual history of the American labor movement to the left -- or, in his terminology, toward a "corporatist" bias, overemphasizing the importance of the big industrial unions like the United Auto Workers, which sought social power for the workers in order to do good in and for society. The more traditionally oriented "pure and simple" trade unionists, who could be found in craft unions like the carpenters or the Teamsters, have been slighted by comparison. 
"The practitioners of the new labor history," Russell writes, "have produced countless studies of the unions of the Congress of Industrial Organizations (C.I.O.), which emerged out of the American Federation of Labor (A.F.L.) in 1935, but only a pitiful few on the affiliates of the A.F.L. after the split. . . . This disparity is particularly curious when one considers that even at the height of the C.I.O.'s growth, the A.F.L. was three times larger in membership, and that on its own terms the A.F.L. could be considered the most successful working-class organization in American history."
Whether the anti-A.F.L. bias among labor historians is as pronounced as Russell suggests seems questionable; in a footnote to this passage he lists a half-dozen substantial works on A.F.L. unions or leaders published in recent years (while omitting some others he might have included, like Zieger's study of the Pulp and Paper Workers Union in the 1930's). But it is certainly true that the Teamsters, the largest A.F.L. affiliate (and, by the time Hoffa was preparing to set off for Hanoi, the largest union in the United States), has been understudied -- except by journalists and other critics more interested in its criminal record than its history as a labor organization. Russell's motives in seeking to redress this imbalance are certainly commendable.
The history of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters predates Hoffa's personal involvement by 40 years. It was founded as an A.F.L. affiliate in 1899, when most of its members were driving horse-drawn milk, bakery, coal and ice trucks. When Hoffa was hired on as an organizer in Detroit in the early 1930's, the union itself was still very much a horse-and-buggy operation. Unlike industries such as autos and steel, where unions struggled against a few huge national corporations, trucking was a fiercely competitive, decentralized industry. Local Teamsters leaders were pretty much left to their own devices by the national union in recruiting workers and winning contracts. 
Hoffa made it his life's mission to banish chaos from the trucking industry. His ambition was to organize everything on wheels (and a good deal more) by building a centrally organized union, one that was powerful enough to impose standard national contracts on thousands of local employers. And he was none too scrupulous about the means by which he would reach this goal.
One of the main things that truckers hauled out of Detroit was, of course, automobiles. Hoffa's Local 299 set out to organize the car-haul trucking companies in the mid-1930's. As Russell describes the process:
"Rather than devoting their time to signing up workers and petitioning for representation elections," the Teamsters "preferred a two-step strategy that was far more effective against the small and scattered car-haul companies. The local's business agents first approached the owner of a firm and told him that if he did not enroll his employees with the union his trucks would be bombed. Next, if the employer refused to capitulate, they bombed his trucks." 
The result, according to Russell, was that the Teamsters "gained a reputation as the most violent, lawless union in an unusually violent, lawless city." The union's reputation for favoring violent tactics (against rival unions as well as employers), and for fostering an internal culture of corruption, kickbacks, sweetheart contracts and dealings with the underworld, would only grow in the years to come as Hoffa continued his rise through Teamsters ranks, finally securing election as president of the union in 1957. 
Although he plays down accounts of Hoffa's "clandestine dealings with Mafia godfathers," regards him as the victim of "demonization" at the hands of government investigators and dismisses previous biographies as conspiracy-mongering tracts by anti-Hoffa partisans motivated chiefly by a "fanatical hatred" of their subject, Russell does not pretend that Jimmy Hoffa was an angel. The man who emerges from the pages of "Out of the Jungle" was simply no better and no worse than he needed to be to accomplish his twin goals of enriching himself and improving the wages and conditions of the rank and file of the Teamsters union. Russell approvingly quotes one teamster's reaction to Hoffa's conviction for plundering union pension funds: "Hoffa did steal from us, but he also gave us a hell of a lot. For what he did for the driver, I'd take a chance on him again. If he robbed a little, what the hell."
For a book that promises in its subtitle to discuss the "remaking of the American working class," it's disappointing that all we learn about that working class -- insofar as it was represented by members of the Teamsters union -- is that they admired Jimmy Hoffa. Rank-and-file teamsters are nearly invisible in this account, as they were during the Hoffa years in running their autocratic union. The question of union democracy does not engage Russell, who writes, on slender evidence, that Teamsters members "happily declined to share in the management of the union." Teamsters solidarity "came not from devotion to a cause greater than the union, but from the benefits they received from it."
Labor leaders -- and the historians who write about them -- neglect the bread-and-butter concerns of ordinary workers at their peril. But Russell constructs a misleading dichotomy in his defense of Hoffa. He writes as if the choice facing American workers was between unions led by pragmatic thugs on the one hand and otherworldly saints on the other. Walter Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers in the years Hoffa led the Teamsters, is Russell's prime example of the latter, a dyed-in-the-wool "corporatist" who nattered on endlessly about irrelevant concepts like industrial democracy. 
"According to Reuther," Russell declares, "unions should not be considered as vehicles for material gain. 'If the labor movement is not an instrument of social change, it is nothing,' he said in an attack on union leaders who shared Jimmy Hoffa's economistic philosophy." 
If Reuther had truly believed that "material gain" was unimportant, he would not have long remained leader of one million-plus members of the United Automobile Workers -- a union that, unlike the Teamsters, preserved a strong tradition of internal dissent and rank-and-file democracy from the heady days of 1930's organizing. From 1947 through 1960, under Reuther's leadership, average wages for a member of the union climbed dramatically, while the fringe benefits enjoyed by auto workers, including health insurance and pensions, were the envy of other unions (including the Teamsters).
The goals of social change and material gain do not require an either-or choice by the labor movement and its leaders. That Hoffa thought otherwise was just another of his flaws. He wasn't worthy of Nixon's presidential pardon in 1971; he isn't worthy of Russell's historical pardon in 2001.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
The Wonder Years: Homework Is Free Online

BYLINE:  By LAURIE J. FLYNN 

 BODY:
With summer over and school in full swing, Kenneth Sahr is finding the faltering economy is having little impact on demand for his service.
 More than 10,000 people visit his site each day, and many come back several times a week. Page views have reached two million a month, with demand for this site rising at an annual rate of 10 percent. And if he was not already notorious enough, late last month Mr. Sahr embarked on a publicity campaign to attract even more attention to his Web site. 
 Mr. Sahr runs schoolsucks.com, a Web site for students that for the last five years has offered essays, book reports, term papers and even doctoral dissertations for easy downloading. Some 5,000 pieces of homework posted directly on the site are available free, but the site also links to other term paper sites that charge as much as $8.95 a page. (Custom paper sites charge as much as $20 a page.) 
Since the site went into operation in 1996, Mr. Sahr has become perhaps the most public -- and in some quarters, most reviled -- symbol of the online homework industry, aggressively promoting his venture while the educational community bemoans the growing problem of plagiarism. One of the site's mottos is "Where the men are men and the teachers are nervous."
Critics point to statistics that indicate plagiarism is on the rise, abetted by Web sites like Mr. Sahr's. 
One watchdog group, Plagiarism .org, has a service called TurnItIn .com, which enables teachers to submit student papers to check for evidence of cribbing. The group, based in Berkeley, Calif., estimates that fully one-third of the high-school papers it examines contain at least some material copied from Internet pages. 
Donald McCabe, a professor at Rutgers University and founder of the Center for Academic Integrity, says plagiarism from the Web is most rampant in high school. In a recent survey he conducted, nearly half of high school students admitted to having plagiarized from an online source to some extent. 
Mr. Sahr said his customers ranged in age from about 12 to 25, most of them middle-school and high-school students. Of the 10,000 visitors to his site every day on average, he said, 8,000 are from the United States, 1,000 are Canadian and the remainder are from other countries. Anyone can log onto schoolsucks .com and download any of 5,000 free research papers on topics as diverse as the Magna Carta and encephalitis, sometimes even in Hebrew or French. 
Rather than plagiarism, Mr. Sahr argues, what his site really offers students is a mixture of research and inspiration. The site helps intimidated students "get their feet wet," he said, providing bibliographies and research material. Besides, he insists, students would not use his Web site to plagiarize material because it would be too easy for teachers and professors to check the site themselves. 
Mr. Sahr even offers a public-service defense of his business. The generally poor quality of the homework available for free on his site, he said, should send a red flag to educators that something is seriously wrong with today's schools.
"We're the connection," Mr. Sahr said. "This is the end result of our educational system." 
Mr. Sahr said that he and his two partners, Yasha Harari and Nimrod Carmi, did not exercise quality control. Anything and everything gets posted, he said, except for the occasional violent essay or anything that proselytizes for a political cause. As a result, a student downloading an essay has no way of knowing if the paper received an A or an F. "We tell people, 'You could be downloading garbage, and you probably are,' " Mr. Sahr said. 
The Sahr site is only one of dozens of so-called digital term paper mills. But its database of free papers is widely considered one of the largest online, with students submitting 50 to 100 new ones each month. Cheater .com and Cheathouse.com (which also calls itself the "Evil House of Cheat") offer both free and for-pay papers, while most other sites charge by the page, in addition to accepting advertising.
The Sahr site features a dozen or so advertisers, including for-pay term paper sites, an online gambling business and eBay. Mr. Sahr says the site has been profitable, in part, because it incurs very few expenses. He said he and his partners were the sole investors and intend to remain so. 
The idea for the site came to Mr. Sahr when he was a journalism student at Miami International University, he said, and saw firsthand the "mediocrity" of the educational system. Mr. Sahr, who is 30 and holds dual American and Israeli citizenship, divides his time between Tel Aviv and Miami. The company was founded in Florida, but is now run from Israel, where it has developed a Hebrew language site of its own. 
For Mr. Sahr and his partners, the question now is just how to capitalize on the current popularity of their brand. They are considering expanding the site to pick up the audience of some teen portal sites that have gone out of business, presumably by adding more youth-oriented material and community features. 
"Students will listen to school sucks.com, more than they will their parents," he said. "They feel free communicating here."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The site's owners, Kenneth Sahr, right, and Yasha Harari, hold a business meeting on a Tel Aviv beach. Their site, which warns of the quality of the homework up for grabs, still draws two million page views a month. (Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times); An advertiser on Mr. Sahr's site sells research papers.

HEADLINE: E-Commerce Report; 
The possible sale of Blue Mountain Arts could lead to the end of the free online greeting card.

BYLINE:  By Bob Tedeschi 

 BODY:
IS Blue Mountain Arts up for sale? 
 Now that Excite@Home is entertaining any and all serious offers for its media properties in an effort to keep bankruptcy lawyers at bay, the future of Blue Mountain Arts, the electronic greeting card service it bought for $780 million in 1999, is very much in question. 
 Consistently one of the World Wide Web's most highly visited sites, Blue Mountain has generated a huge following among those who regularly send free animated missives to friends and family members. 
The "free" designation was, of course, meaningless to Excite or anyone else in 1999. The stock price of the company, formally the At Home Corporation, soared amid speculation that online advertising would continue to grow. As long as Excite added so-called sticky features, meant to keep people on the Web site long enough to bombard them with advertisements, the business's fiscal health was seen as virtually assured. 
Or so the thinking went, as Excite acquired Blue Mountain in a deal that included $350 million in cash. (Incidentally, that figure is roughly twice the amount of Excite's market value as of late last week.) Since then, the "sticky" strategy has backfired, with many online media companies stuck paying millions for editorial and technology teams to pump information out to the public, while advertisers stand by with checkbooks closed. 
Still, Blue Mountain has value, analysts said, particularly to other electronic greeting card companies. Echoing a well-circulated rumor, Jeffrey Stein, a managing director at McDonald Investments, a financial firm based in Cleveland, said he "wouldn't be shocked to see American Greetings buy Blue Mountain and try to consolidate that market." 
Neither At Home nor American Greetings would comment on the possibility of such a deal, although Charles Fink, president of AmericanGreetings.com, said last week that the company was on the verge of making a "pretty dramatic announcement" -- the details of which he would not discuss. 
American Greetings, with annual sales of $2.5 billion, is the second-largest greeting card company, behind Hallmark. The company has already acted as consolidator this year. In March, American Greetings paid about $28 million to buy eGreetings.com, which at one time was the fourth-most visited electronic greeting cards site, according to Net Ratings, an Internet tracking firm. 
If American Greetings does acquire Blue Mountain, its total online audience for greeting cards would more than double that of its nearest competitor -- eUniverse's Flow go.com, which also offers free online cards. 
Given such a position of dominance, Mr. Stein, of McDonald Investments, said American Greetings could hasten the end of free online cards for consumers. Mr. Stein said the company had an "extremely profitable online greeting card business three years ago, where consumers paid as much as $19 for six months of unlimited access to the e-cards." 
"They were getting a very high renewal rate, too," Mr. Stein added, "but they were forced into the free model when Blue Mountain came along and gave the product away. If they could stick it out, it would eventually be a profit center for them." 
Hallmark.com, too, charged for each e-card sent before Blue Mountain came along. Since then, the company has given away its cards, as well. Hallmark has indicated that it is not currently interested in bidding for Blue Mountain. 
While Blue Mountain led the market toward the advertising model, the e-card industry has not necessarily relied solely on advertising revenue. To help replace revenue lost from user fees, most of the online greeting card sites in recent months have begun selling gifts to go with the cards.
For instance, on BlueMountain.com, users can send a $20 box of Dan's chocolates or a $3,200 Sharper Image recliner, among the selections, to punctuate an e-mailed card with a singing rabbit or a dancing flower. The undisclosed commissions Blue Mountain extracts from each sale have turned into a "significant revenue stream" for the company, according to Londonne Corder, an Excite@Home spokeswoman. 
Hallmark.com has a similar program in place, in which online customers buy gift certificates from the Gift Certificate Center, a company Hallmark acquired last year. It sells gift certificates redeemable at more than 400 retailers.
But even those sources of revenue are not nearly enough to make a standalone e-card venture profitable, analysts said. In the case of Blue Mountain, simply the cost of keeping the site running would be huge, said Sean Kaldor, an analyst with Net Ratings. 
In July, Mr. Kaldor said, 11.5 million people visited the site, viewing 218 million Web pages. "So if you add up the cost of the servers and everything you need to make sure the site's reliable, the cost has to be quite oppressive," he said. 
Adding to that the design and production costs for the cards, and the salaries of the advertising and marketing staff, the economics of an entirely free site did not look viable in the long term, analysts said.
Mr. Fink, of AmericanGreetings.com, does not necessarily agree with the speculation that his site will return to an all-paid model. He said the site already included a paid service called the Platinum Club, in which members pay $20 for, among other things, six months of access to exclusive e-cards. 
"That's been a robust revenue stream for us," Mr. Fink said, "and we'll continue to explore ways to enhance our subscription program. But a large portion of our cards will always be free." 
But John Sullivan, of Hallmark.com, said he could envision an environment in which consumers would again pay for the privilege of sending e-cards. "It's not viable in the near future," Mr. Sullivan said. "But as time goes on, and as some people aren't able to make money from this and others fall away, that's a possibility." 
For now, Mr. Sullivan said, the company has various reasons to stay out of the bidding for Blue Mountain Arts -- not the least of which is the possibility that Blue Mountain's inventory of e-cards may not be worth much a year from now.
"They have thousands of e-cards that are great today, but a year from now, that library will be meaningless," Mr. Sullivan said. "With so many broadband users coming on, those cards will look like the old Pong game."
And though he acknowledged the value of the Blue Mountain brand, Mr. Sullivan said, "Eventually, the good content will win." 
Meanwhile, Mr. Sullivan said Hallmark was content to use its e-cards as a supporting player in the overall business, which itself is diversifying beyond cards to include gifts. Analysts said such a move was necessary, because the greeting card industry has been consistently shrinking in recent years, as e-mail, cell phones and higher prices have pushed many consumers away from paper greeting cards.
The same is true for American Greetings, analysts said, as it searches for revenues from products like calendars, designer stationery and business cards. Consumers who come to the site for free e-cards are prime targets for such goods. 
And given the price Excite might be willing to sell Blue Mountain for, such a strategy could pay off, if the buyer can run the site at a reduced cost. Given the advertising contracts Blue Mountain is committed to, and the cost of running the site now, "Excite might get to the stage where they'd pay someone to take it off their hands," said Doug Shapiro, an analyst with Banc of America Securities. 
"I don't think it's going to happen," he said, "but it could be like, 'Please take Blue Mountain Arts, and by the way, here's 10 bucks.' "

HEADLINE: U.S. Companies Sharply Reduce Orders for Tools 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 

 BODY:
Orders by American companies for machine tools fell in July to levels comparable with the recession years 1980 and 1981, two trade groups said today. 
 Bookings for such power-driven equipment as lathes and mills dropped 18.7 percent in July, to $191.9 million, from June, according to the Association for Manufacturing Technology and the American Machine Tool Distributors' Association. 
 The 13-month slump in manufacturing "has slowed real investment in new manufacturing technology to the lowest point in decades," said Don Carlson, president of the technology association. 
"The current low level of spending," Mr. Carlson said, on new, productivity-enhancing technology is jeopardizing America's economic growth." 
Compared with the first seven months of last year, orders were down 29.3 percent, to $1.67 billion. 
The trade groups estimated that orders have fallen below levels seen in 1980 and 1981, based on numbers collected using a different method. The associations began using a new survey in 1997. 
The United States economy went through a six-month recession in 1980 and began a 16-month contraction in July 1981. 
By region, orders fell 52.7 percent in the central United States, to $27.4 million; 41 percent in the Northeast, to $23.4 million; and 9.5 percent in the West, to $26 million. Orders increased 12.8 percent in the Midwest, to $81.2 million. 
Machine tools are used to make parts, from tractor hoods to airplane wings. Analysts watch the tools report to help gauge production. The report looks at orders for domestic and foreign-produced machine tools.

HEADLINE: In Oregon, a City Provides Public Land for Homeless 

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 6 

 BODY:
As one who calls himself both homeless and a resident of the tent city known as Dignity Village, Ibrahim Mubarak has gotten used to moving along.
 Six times in the last 10 months, Mr. Mubarak and his fellow urban campers have been ordered to pack up their dirt-streaked tents and tarpaulins, shopping carts, portable stoves and ramshackle furniture and move off the public land in Portland where they had set up quarters illegally. 
 Each time, they moved to a new spot and broke the law again. It was a risk Mr. Mubarak and 70 or so other campers were willing to take to avoid what he called the "oppressive, depressive, repressive environment" of public shelters. 
Now, though, as they erect their camp with its large yellow Dignity Village flag yet again, they are doing so with official sanction. In an unusual move that has stretched the definition of public services for the homeless, Portland has provided a patch of land for the tent city and put in a water hookup and portable toilets.
The site is no paradise. The new Dignity Village is a fenced-in block of asphalt in a corner of the city's leaf composting operation, just a few hundred yards from a runway at the Portland International Airport. On the other side of the tents is a state prison.
It is almost two miles to the nearest convenience store, and a 40-minute bus ride to downtown Portland.
While some homeless men and women have refused to move to the new site, which one of them called a "concentration camp," about 40 have taken the city up on the offer. Some said they much prefer it to the most recent location under an interstate highway bridge in northwest Portland. They were ordered off that spot by the state Transportation Department, which owns the land.
Abram Atwood, 31, an unemployed construction worker who lived under the bridge before moving to the current tent city, said the traffic noise there was worse than the sound of jets.
"It's actually quieter out here," he yelled, as a United jet roared overhead. "It was so quiet after the planes stopped for the night last night, I could hardly get to sleep."
The new site, known as Sunderland Yard, is only temporary, and the campers may well not find it so appealing in few weeks, when the city's leaf collection resumes. Officially, the residents of the tent village will be allowed to stay for 60 days, while the city explores other locations for a more permanent site.
In some cities, the very idea of negotiating with the homeless and accommodating their settlements would seem counterproductive. Public sympathy for homeless people might have been scant. And as officials elsewhere have sometimes learned, the more welcoming a city is, particularly if it is a desirable place to live, the more homeless people migrate there.
In Portland, the tent city has attracted a fair amount of support, and with few officials wishing to appear unsympathetic or unwilling to compromise, there has been reluctance to shut the tent city entirely.
Last week, the City Council voted 4 to 1 to negotiate with the homeless on a one-year project that would allow the tent city to continue at a still undetermined site as long as the encampment demonstrated that it could "meet the needs of homeless people and help them move to more appropriate housing."
That move, while not directly sanctioning a permanent homeless campground, could pave the way for a resident-run tent city to remain in place. While other cities have informally tolerated encampments of the homeless and have even sanctioned temporary tent cities, Portland could be setting the stage for sanctioning a permanent arrangement.
"We begin something very different in Portland today," the mayor, Vera Katz, said. "It's a risk that all of us are taking."
Dignity Village consists mainly of homeless single men, though a few women and couples live in the tents. Most speak of being down on their luck or unable to find or keep a job, and some are "trying to move away from crime or drugs or prostitution," said Mr. Mubarak, 45, who has emerged as a spokesman for the group, often conducting business from a used office chair outside his tent. Mr. Mubarak said he had been homeless for 11 years, living here and in Chicago; Gary, Ind.; Nashville; Atlanta; Billings, Mont.; Iowa; and Oklahoma.
Most residents said they preferred tents to the crowded shelters, which they said forced people into regimented schedules, and did not allow pets.
"I'd rather live this way," said Jeff Roderick, 39, who said he lived with his girlfriend, a cook at a fast-food restaurant, and a tabby kitten.
Although the Dignity Village residents had voted among themselves not to leave the site under the interstate bridge, creating fears of a confrontation, most moved without incident when the deadline arrived on Wednesday. Some of those who did not move to the new site right away went back to shelters or the streets.
But even they now seem to be gravitating to Dignity Village, where a handmade sign under the flag says: "Foxes have lairs, birds have nests, but the son of man has no place to make his home."
The camp has already received several loads of donated food, and residents are hoping to secure a trailer with pay phones. Still, the site is temporary, and no one is sure where Dignity Village will wind up next.
"There are people who just won't go to the shelters, and this is about the only place left to go," said a man who gave his name as Minnesota Mike and his age as 60, and said he was homeless because he could not find a place to live on his monthly $557 disability check. "So we'll have to be somewhere, whether people like it or not."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
 A.I.G. Settles Dispute Over Korean Investment
The American International Group has resolved a dispute with Hyundai Securities that appears to remove a major obstacle to the $850 million takeover of the financial units of the Hyundai Group. The investment would be the largest investment ever by a foreign company in Korea's financial sector. Page C2.

Editor's Letter Raises Questions
In mid-August, when it was unclear which news organizations would get interviews with the embattled California congressman, Gary A. Condit, The San Francisco Chronicle, like many others, was pitching itself as the best place for Mr. Condit to break his silence. But its pitch has raised ethical questions about the separation of The Chronicle's newsroom from its editorial department. C2.

Trying to Rationalize a Merger
Forget about personalization, portals and push. Today's mantra in information technology is services. Most analysts have been skeptical about the proposed merger of Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer. But those who see value in it base their assessment on the prospect that the merged company will build up its business in providing information technology services. New Economy. C4.

Product Use for Accuracy's Sake
At first glance, it looks to be the most elaborate product-placement deal since Madison Avenue was a dirt road. In the World War II mini-series "Band of Brothers," there are so many scenes featuring the vehicles now sold under the Jeep name that no one seemed to have an exact count.
 Although estimates range from 600 to more than 1,000 -- none, it turns out, are the result of product placement. The jeeps are there for historical verisimilitude, representing the myriad vehicles built in the 1940's. Stuart Elliot: Advertising C8. 

Homework Is Free Online
More than 10,000 people visit the Web site of Kenneth Sahr each day, and many come back several times a week. And if Mr. Sahr was not already notorious enough, he has embarked on a campaign to attract even more attention to his Web site, which offers essays, book reports, term papers and even doctoral dissertations for easy downloading. C4.

Uncertain Future for Online Cards
Now that Excite@Home is entertaining any and all offers for its media properties, the future of Blue Mountain Arts, the online greeting card service, is in question. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report C6.

Video Heroines With Personality
In Kenneth Perlin's vision of the future, video game heroines will be endowed with the psychological complexity of Emma Bovary, the nuanced physicality of Juliette Binoche, or the social cunning of Alice Roosevelt. And though the characters will be the creations of human programmers, they will also have a certain amount of ersatz free will to act and interact in their own virtual universes. Patents C2.

Foreign Buyers for German Cable
In back-to-back deals, one announced last week and one that could be announced today, two companies are paying about $7 billion to buy 80 percent of the cable systems in Germany. Liberty Media, headed by John C. Malone, will have 10 million of the 17 million cable subscribers in Germany. C7.

PERSON: Robert R. Nathan 

HEADLINE: Robert R. Nathan, 92, Dies; Set Factory Goals in War 

BYLINE:  By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Robert R. Nathan, an economist who helped lead the nation's industrial mobilization in World War II, died on Sept. 4 at a group home in Bethesda, Md. He was 92 and lived in Bethesda.
 Mr. Nathan spent most of the 1930's with the Commerce Department before becoming chairman of the War Production Board's planning committee in 1942 at age 33. 
 In the years before the United States entered World War II, Mr. Nathan often criticized what he called the nation's lackadaisical approach to increasing production.
Mr. Nathan was often thought to resemble the fighter Primo Carnera, and he had a pugnacious personality to match his appearance. During the war, Mr. Nathan not only set production goals but helped achieve them by finding ways to increase factory production.
In a four-page article on Mr. Nathan in 1942, Life magazine wrote: "His greatest usefulness is as a 'needler.' He goes prowling through a great bureaucratic organization, looking for sour spots and needling the individuals responsible. For instance he may find, as he recently did, that the refrigerator manufacturers had been given several months leeway to keep on making electric refrigerators. To Nathan this means not only waste of steel but waste of production facilities which might be turning out searchlights and gun mounts."
The Life article said that Mr. Nathan enjoyed spending Sunday afternoons driving around the Washington area in his red Pontiac convertible, heckling slow-moving truck drivers.
Raised in Dayton, Ohio, Mr. Nathan worked his way through the University of Pennsylvania by selling silk stockings and telephone memo pads and by working in a factory at night. After receiving a master's degree in 1933, he joined the Commerce Department, working on studies of national income.
In 1946, Mr. Nathan left government service and started an economic consulting firm, Robert R. Nathan Associates, where he served as chairman until last month. Mr. Nathan's firm has conducted studies for industry associations and federal agencies and has had as clients the governments of several countries, including El Salvador, Israel and Vietnam.
For a time in the 1950's, Mr. Nathan served as chairman of Americans for Democratic Action, a liberal advocacy group. In that position, he often criticized the Eisenhower administration for its conservative policy making and supported a more liberal approach. In 1959, for instance, the group called for undiminished contributions to the United Nations, an expanded foreign aid program, a Congressional pledge of full employment and a 67 percent increase in the minimum wage.
In 1968, Mr. Nathan served as an adviser to Hubert H. Humphrey's presidential campaign.
Mr. Nathan is survived by his wife, Mary T. Nathan of Bethesda; three children, Richard A. Nathan of Burbank, Calif., Ann L. Nathan of Clarksburg, Md., and David A. Nathan of Coatesville, Pa.; and a granddaughter.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert R. Nathan (Paul Conklin)

HEADLINE: Essay; 
Jimmy That 'Lockbox'

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
In the fog of economic war, one incontrovertible truth is clear: the budget projections of Congress and the White House will continue to be horrendously out of whack.
 A decade ago, huge deficits were predicted "as far as the eye could see"; never happened. A few months ago, the same savants saw huge surpluses far into the baby boomers' geezerhood; now their surplus prediction is in free fall. Lesson in humility: The economic eye cannot see that far. 
 Here is a bedrock principle about the role of government in the economy: When prosperity booms, the government should apply a brake by running a surplus. Conversely, when recession looms, the government should press the accelerator by running a deficit. That subtraction or addition to aggregate demand is called "raising Keynes." 
Thus, when happy days are here, government should surely slow the growth of spending; when harder times are on the way, the feds should spend more and tax less. 
Will this enable Washington to tootle a fine tune of steady, full-employment growth without inflation? No; the feds control only a fifth of the nation's product and can only lean against the changing wind. That's because the business cycle's lungs need to exhale from time to time, blowing out the inefficient producers and the foolhardy investors. The hot breath of recession usefully reminds those who serve and sell to be more eager to please customers.
Here we are today with unemployment rising smartly and consumer and investor confidence falling intelligently. By those measures, it's safe to say a downturn is upon us -- signaling the moment for government to spend more and tax less. 
Why aren't we doing that? Why isn't the government getting out of the restraining posture of surplus and getting into the stimulating business of deficit? 
The reason that good Keynesian sense is not prevailing is that Bill Clinton, eager to find a way to avoid tax reduction, spooked the nation with his phony notion of a "lockbox" on revenues coming in from the payroll tax. 
It's phony because no such vault exists; no fund containing cash or gold is set aside for future retirees. The notion of an uncrackable safe containing untouchable security is a fraud. The only thing in the "lockbox" is government paper, which is a promise to pay from the Treasury in the future. 
By striking fear into oldsters with his demagogic "save Social Security" slogan, he joined conservatives in making "deficit" a dirty word. But only in boom times is "deficit" a dirty word; when air is hissing out of the balloon and a deficit becomes temporarily desirable, "surplus" becomes the dirty word.
The Bush administration and Republicans in Congress were snookered by the "lockbox" oratory and now are stuck with a foolish promise. Democrats in Congress would rather see Bush wriggle than let him off that hook; obsessed with the success of their lockbox ploy, they are hinting that the way to preserve the counterproductive surplus is to repeal the Bush tax reduction. The Senate leader, Tom Daschle, forgets that the last president to answer a downturn with a tax increase was Herbert Hoover.
The only way out the new president left himself was "in case of war or recession." The time has come for using the second part of that out. My plan: Increase federal spending on education and missile defense; as the slump deepens, fold in a prescription drug benefit for seniors. At the same time, double the summertime tax cut, reducing taxes on average families again in time for Christmas purchasing, to which no liberal could object; add in a capital gains cut to move the markets and bestir optimism. 
This mild fiscal stimulus may not turn us around, but it surely wouldn't hurt. Accompanied by a further reduction in interest rates by the Federal Reserve, which are justified by increases in productivity that hold down inflation, such a fiscal-monetary combination is sensible and timely. It beats watching Democrats drag their feet, pretending the surplus goes into some vault or mattress, and silently hoping for hard times so they can win the House next year. 
Break out of the depressive lockbox mentality. In economic buoyancy lies the only social security. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
