HEADLINE: ON HORSE RACING; 
The Title Roads All Lead to Belmont

BYLINE:  By Joe Drape 

 BODY:
Chris McCarron ticked off his impressions to Michael Cooper and Jay Robbins, the owner and trainer of Tiznow, at the edge of the track. The winning jockey Jerry Bailey, holding his son Justin's hand, disappeared in the paddock breezeway.
 The trainer Nick Zito, a sour look on his face, and the jockey Jorge Chavez, head craned up to Zito's, talked about Albert the Great's trip. On one side of the rail, a raucous bunch of horseplayers chided ChopChop, as Chavez is known, for taking his colt too wide off the turn. An equally boisterous crew across from them got on Zito. "He rode him good, Nicky; it's not Jorgie's fault," a baritone in island rhythms offered. 
 At the same time in the Bronx, the Yankees blasted the Red Sox; in Queens, the United States Open was reaching a climax; and on televisions across the region, college football games flickered.
Here at Belmont Park on Saturday, a countdown to racing's biggest day began in earnest. Three Grade I stakes, prep races for the Breeders' Cup World Thoroughbred Championships here on Oct. 27, attracted horses from Germany, Britain and Japan, as well as intercontinental stars from California and Kentucky.
The headline race was the $500,000 Woodward Stakes, which Bailey won aboard the Chilean-bred Lido Palace, as Chavez and Albert the Great finished second, and McCarron and Tiznow, the 2000 Horse of the Year, ran a close third.
It was the first of six weekend afternoons of high-caliber racing leading to the world championships.
Already, top jockeys and trainers from California like Gary Stevens and Neil Drysdale have moved their bases here for the fall. In Ireland on Saturday, the connections for Europe's two brightest equine stars spoke of coming to the United States.
After Fantastic Light edged Galileo in the Irish Champion Stakes on Saturday, avenging a July loss and handing the 3-year-old colt Galileo his first defeat in seven starts, the winner's owner, Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum of Dubai's royal family, told reporters: "This is what racing is all about. I will speak to my older brother Sheikh Maktoum, but I think we will go for the Breeders' Cup Classic."
The trainer of Galileo, Aidan O'Brien, also indicated that the English and Irish Derby winner had the mile-and-a-quarter Classic on his calendar. "I wouldn't see any reason why he wouldn't go to America," he said.
The trick for the thoroughbred industry is getting America, especially sports-saturated New Yorkers, to show up at the eight Breeders' Cup races worth a combined $13 million.
There was a solid crowd of more than 12,000 Saturday at Belmont. But over the next seven weeks, racing officials must make the general public take the event as seriously as the world's finest horsemen do.
Economically, the game is thriving. Last year, more than $14.2 billion was bet in the United States, according to the Jockey Club. Now it's up to the racing industry to transform a centuries-old sport into a modern spectator event. It has improved ratings for the Triple Crown -- ratings this year rose 49 percent from last year and the highest since 1992. But the industry suffered a blow when Point Given, a burgeoning attraction, was retired with an injury.
To that end, the National Thoroughbred Racing Association recently added World Thoroughbred Championships to what had been called simply the Breeders' Cup and bought many hours of television time. It also began an aggressive advertising campaign.
It calls the initiative re-branding, which makes sense after market research showed that casual fans had no idea what an afternoon of eight races featuring the world's best horses was all about.
As the countdown to what is essentially racing's Super Bowl continues, the immediate challenge is to get people to Belmont. 
As Saturday demonstrated, racing competes with a number of other sports here. So what do you sell? The same thing Nascar pushes: immediacy, intimacy and accessibility. As the Greek chorus of railbirds who serenaded Zito and Chavez proved, fans are often an arm length's from the sport's major figures. It may mean letting them in free or booking top musical performers. Once at Belmont, fans will see a Hall of Fame trainer like Allen Jerkens watching the races, horses like Lido Palace trotting 10 feet away and riders within speaking distance.
After Pat Day brought home With Anticipation in Saturday's $500,000 Man o'War, one horseplayer brought a smile to his face when he invoked a pejorative nickname for the extremely patient Day. "Pat can wait all day when a half-million dollars is on the line," the man said.
In seven weeks, horse racing will have far more than that at stake. The exchange between rider and railbird is a frequent and natural occurrence at the track. It is also a window into racing in all its majesty. One way or another, racing needs to open it, as well as others, to the public.

HEADLINE: ON PRO FOOTBALL; 
Thunder Expected at the Broncos' Lavish New Citadel in the Sky

BYLINE:  By Thomas George 

DATELINE: DENVER 

 BODY:
Fans in two preseason games here walked through the new $400 million Invesco Field at Mile High and gawked, paying more attention to the stadium than they did to the games. The Broncos' players have any number of amenities -- the splendid grass field, the spacious locker rooms, their spiffy hot and cold tubs -- that make the old Mile High Stadium next door seem like an old, worn shoe.
 Yes, the Denver Broncos are all dressed up with someplace to go. 
 How about another Super Bowl?
"We always have big expectations, and with this new stadium, people are even more excited," said Mike Shanahan, the Broncos' coach. "But personally, as long as it's 100 yards, I could play on a parking lot -- just bring the crowd and a lot of noise." 
What the Giants will find here tonight is a frenzied crowd proud to show the nation watching on television its latest civic treasure. That and a Broncos team that insists on returning to the top of the league after consecutive Super Bowl titles, followed by 6-10 and 11-5 seasons.
"We have the talent, coaching and ability to get back to the Super Bowl and win it," Broncos receiver Ed McCaffrey said. "If we come out and play together as a team, stay healthy and play our best football at the end, we have a chance."
A chance to go where the Giants have recently been.
The Broncos like the measuring stick the Giants will provide, because the Giants are the defending National Football Conference champions. This is a nifty chance for the Broncos, especially since the last time they saw the Giants up close, it was deflating.
Denver had a 13-0 record on Dec. 13, 1998, when the Giants (5-8) upset them, 20-16, at Giants Stadium. Denver would go on to win the Super Bowl, but the Broncos have not forgotten that loss. Especially Shanahan, the most successful coach in the N.F.L. during his six seasons in Denver, with 71 victories (he was 39-9 in the old Mile High).
But he has not beaten the Giants.
"That game helped bring us back down to earth, but the thing I remember most is we had a third-and-1 late in the game and didn't convert that," Shanahan said. "If we had, we could have run out the clock. They had the top rushing defense in the N.F.C. last year and they only gave up 244 yards in the Super Bowl even though the final score was lopsided. They're sound."
Not only have the Broncos built a new stadium, they have also built a new defense, one that is led by Ray Rhodes, their new defensive coordinator. The defense and stadium have the Broncos' owner, Pat Bowlen, full of optimism.
"Going back to when we won the referendum to build the stadium in November '98 up to Monday night, I can say all the stars lined up for us," Bowlen said. "The vote came at a time where the year before we had won a Super Bowl and then were 9-0; that had a great impact on the six counties of Denver to vote for it. We were able to sell all of our seats and suites at time when the economy was strong; I don't know the way the market is now if that would have happened so smoothly."
The community is paying $265 million for the stadium through taxes, the Broncos the remaining $135 million. Bowlen is proud that the sight lines for the stadium are good, that the fans are close to the field and that the bowl of the stadium is made of steel.
The idea was to increase crowd noise, which was a staple of the old Mile High. Fans here like to refer to it as Rocky Mountain Thunder.
The Denver players say the old field was more dirt than grass, but this one provides soft and sure footing. "You used to run on the old field and might see chunks of turf fly up in your face," said McCaffrey. "The jumbo screens, the bronze horse statues outside, it's just a wonderful place."
Now to get the crowd back into the games instead of simply showing up.
Now to stake their claim as the American Football Conference team to beat.
Now to christen the place with the Giants.
"For the Broncos, this stadium will provide us with the revenue to compete in the free-agency market, and that's very important not only in our game but in all sports," Bowlen said. "For Denver and for Colorado, this stadium is going to be a landmark. We've already got 100 major events planned here, so the stadium will have multiple use. Denver now has new baseball, football and hockey stadiums. Of course, I'm biased, but this is the best stadium ever built in the National Football League."

HEADLINE: Black Families Resist Mississippi Land Push 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: CANTON, Miss., Sept. 7 

 BODY:
Like the bulldozers now flattening several square miles of central Mississippi, this state has allowed nothing to stop its effort to acquire a huge Nissan truck factory and finally take its place in the international economy.
 It outbid every other competing state for the plant with the largest package of tax-financed incentives ever offered to an automaker in the United States, estimated at more than $400 million in spending and tax rebates. As part of the package, Mississippi agreed to pay for an $80 million job-training program for Nissan workers and to build the factory's $17 million vehicle-preparation building. It promised $60 million in new and improved roads, to be built far faster than most state roads. It even allowed Nissan executives to use a state plane for several months. 
 Most significant, it agreed to acquire more than 1,500 acres Nissan wanted -- nearly 2.5 square miles -- using the state's power of eminent domain, if necessary, to move out homeowners living on the site near this small town of 10,000, about 15 miles north of Jackson. 
And that is when the high-revving engine of Mississippi's new economy ran directly into the Archie and Bouldin families, a small but unyielding pocket of an older Mississippi that is not quite as impressed by the rush to join the global economy. These related black families, who for 60 years have owned an isolated green enclave where Nissan wants to put a parking lot and an access road, have spurned the state's offer of more than a half-million dollars for their land, and have gone to court to challenge the condemnation procedure.
The families have charged that the state acted in a racially biased manner by treating white and black landowners differently, and while Nissan has begun construction next to their property, they have become the most prominent obstacles to the fulfillment of the state's promise to the company. Although many white landowners received less money per acre than the state is offering the black families, the dispute makes it clear that Mississippi can never entirely escape the effects of its past, even at the precise moment that it is moving a great deal of earth to do so.
"My grandfather bought this land in 1941," said Lonzo Archie, 45, a welder who lives with his family of five in a modest brick house on the south edge of the Nissan project. "There's 15 of our families right around here, and none of them want to live anywhere else. But then the state comes in and pushes us around and tells us they're going to turn our land over to a private company. It's not right."
State officials said the families were simply holding out for more money, and produced extensive figures to show that black and white landowners in the area were not being treated differently. But even though the family owns just 23 acres of the land sought for the project, officials at the state's economic development agency said they must seize those acres because of a larger principle: the need to demonstrate to businesses around the country that they are utterly serious about attracting big corporate investments.
"It's not that Nissan is going to leave if we don't get that land," said James C. Burns Jr., the executive director of the Mississippi Development Authority. "What's important is the message it would send to other companies if we are unable to do what we said we would do. If you make a promise to a company like Nissan, you have to be able to follow through."
Regularly derided as the nation's poorest state with the least educated population, and mired in a largely agricultural economy, Mississippi spent years watching with increasing frustration as foreign automakers placed their high-wage jobs and high-tech factories in other Southern states, like Alabama, Tennessee and South Carolina. Mr. Burns acknowledged that Mercedes-Benz and Honda never seriously considered Mississippi before choosing sites for large factories in the 1990's.
"There was this perception out there that we just couldn't do what it takes, either financially or physically," said Mr. Burns, a former banker appointed to the job last year by Gov. Ronnie Musgrove. "What we had to do was show companies what we were capable of."
When Nissan quietly informed Mississippi and several other states of its interest in the spring of last year, the Musgrove administration quickly mobilized, determined to come up with a more generous incentive package than its neighbors. 
While Alabama had offered $253 million to Mercedes-Benz in 1993, Mississippi spent four months preparing a $295 million package for Nissan, an amount that did not include the $5,000-a-worker tax credit and the rollbacks of county property taxes.
In a one-day special session last November, the Legislature unanimously passed a 30,000-word bill granting a variety of privileges to the project and specifically granting the state the power to take whatever land it deemed necessary to turn over to Nissan. Alabama, Mississippi's main competitor for the project, had never used its eminent domain power for its auto plants.
"They were just way more generous than we were," said Keivan Deravi, an economics professor at Auburn University, who works with Alabama in preparing its incentive offers to automakers and other industries. "Despite a great deal of effort, we couldn't match it, I guess because they were trying to break into the market and willing to go further."
But Mississippi decided the cost was worth it. The $930 million plant, scheduled to open in 2003, will eventually employ 4,000 people and produce about 250,000 pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and minivans every year. State officials predict thousands more jobs will be created by suppliers and related businesses.
To convince Nissan of its seriousness, the state decided to acquire options on about half the land at the core of the site last summer, long before the public knew the company was coming and before the Legislature had granted the use of eminent domain for the project. 
The state's real estate agents struck deals with various landowners at a variety of prices, from $7,500 to $60,000 an acre, depending on the tenacity of the owner.
But last fall, after the use of eminent domain was authorized, the state was not as flexible when it began negotiating with the Archies, the Bouldins and other owners of land on the edges of the project. It has offered the families $24,500 an acre, plus the cost of their homes -- higher than the average price it paid of $18,000 an acre but not as high as the $60,000 paid to one white landowner -- and it has threatened to seize the land and pay less if the offer is not accepted. The amount the state is offering is about 10 times the appraised value of the land before Nissan disclosed its interest. 
It is the manner in which the state dealt with the families, as much as the price itself, that led to the current dispute. Lonzo Archie said his family wanted the right to negotiate freely with the state, and not under threat of seizure, in the manner of the earlier landowners. The family asked for help from the state chapter of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, which has in turn brought in the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Martin Luther King III to urge fairness in the negotiations.
"It's not about the money -- it's about the state understanding the true value of this land to these families," said Stephanie Parker-Weaver, the executive secretary of the state chapter of the Christian group. "They have treated these families very condescendingly. If they're going to force these families off their land, they're going to have to offer them a better quality of life than they are now."
In July, a state judge allowed the state to acquire part of the Archies' land that Nissan wants for its access road, but the ultimate disposition of the property is likely to be settled by the Mississippi Supreme Court. 
State officials said they had no doubt that the court would see the wisdom of Mississippi's efforts on behalf of the automaker.
"How can you imagine this as anything but a public good?" Mr. Burns said. "This project gives us an opportunity to change the destiny of this state."

(The New York Times); A Nissan truck factory is rising near Canton, Miss., beside Interstate 55, which will get a new interchange. Several acres of the site are in dispute. (Photographs by Hubert Worley for The New York Times) Map of Mississippi highlighting the area of the Nissan project.

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section B; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 3690 words

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGNING FOR MAYOR; 
In Double-Header Debates, the Politics of School Finance and Racism

 BODY:
 Following are excerpts from two debates yesterday by Democratic candidates for mayor, as recorded by The New York Times. The first, featuring the four major candidates, was broadcast on WNBC, Channel 4, and was moderated by Gabe Pressman. The second debate was administered by the New York City Campaign Finance Board and included five Democratic candidates. It was broadcast on WABC, Channel 7, and was moderated by Diana Williams.

Q. Major polls this morning, Mr. Vallone, show that this is a race between Mark Green and Fernando Ferrer. The Daily News says 27 to 26 in favor of Green. Are the polls right or wrong?

PETER F. VALLONE -- I've kind of made a career of being underestimated in terms of the polls. You might recall three years ago when I ran in the Democratic primary for governor, the very same polls, pollsters, underestimated me by 20 points. . . . But they also said I couldn't make the city safe 10 years ago, you might recall that, too. And they underestimated me then, too.

Q. What about you, Mr. Hevesi?

ALAN G. HEVESI -- All I can definitively say as an academician that the polls are either right or wrong and we'll know on September the 12th. Understand that these polls reflect the view of the pollee at the moment that the question is asked. . . . And half the voters who said they're leaning for one candidate or another also indicated they were willing to switch. So I assert this is soft, and I wouldn't write the final story of this campaign until the polls close. . . .

Q. Let's take education. You've all promised to build more schools, cut the sizes of classes and give teachers more money so they don't move to the suburbs. Where do you get the money without cutting other services? Mr. Hevesi?

HEVESI -- . . . It's still a $40 billion budget. So if you make education a priority, there's money there. Two, the Campaign for Fiscal Equity court case, which already has gone through the first stage, State Supreme Court, has determined that the State of New York has systematically cheated New York City out of substantial amounts of state aid. We will win that case after the appeal, so there'll be more money coming from the state. . . . And third, I have said that -- and maybe that's not good politics but I think it's good governance -- that if we have to as a last resort, I would restore the 12 1/2 percent surcharge on the income tax ----

Q. You'd raise taxes, in other words?

HEVESI -- Well, as a last resort, restore that surcharge that Mr. Vallone and Mr. Dinkins put into place for Safe Streets/Safe City to increase the number of cops. It worked then, and I would do it for education if we had to.

Q. Would you raise taxes for education, Mr. Green?

GREEN -- If necessary, absolutely. If we raise taxes as a last resort to hire a quarter more cops and crime fell by half, that was a good bargain. But before then, there's a billion-and-a-half dollars in the federal government that we could get under the Johnson-Rangel bill. There's a majority in the House for it. All four of us agree with the Campaign for Fiscal Equity case. Should that prevail, that could be $1 to $2 billion a year more from the state. . . . I intend, should I be the mayor, to pay teachers more as a base and then have bonus or incentive pay for teachers who do more: go to lower performing schools, tutor younger colleagues. My No. 1 reason for running for mayor is to fix the broken school system.

Q. Would you raise taxes, Mr. Ferrer, to pay for schools?

FERRER -- A mayor's got to make choices, and those choices sometimes are tough, especially in a declining economy. And that's why I pointed out months ago the pennies-a-day tax cut that Mayor Giuliani and the City Council enacted and approved that would put four cents a day in the pocket of the average working New Yorker would be better spent on keeping every one of the 200 middle schools in our city, in every neighborhood of New York, open from 3 p.m. to 6 p.m. and on the weekends to keep our kids out of harm's way and to keep them learning more. Those are choices you make. . . .

Q. As a last result would you raise taxes?

FERRER -- I might.

Q. Mr. Vallone?

VALLONE -- Absolutely not. And that's the difference between me and the other candidates. You know, I've worked alongside three different mayors. For 12 years now I've had balanced budgets. When I put that surtax in, that was at the same time we were cutting a budget by $2 billion. And I asked the people to put their trust in me, and I worked it out with Mayor Dinkins. And I said that was a temporary surtax until we made this city safe, until we balanced a budget, until we took this city out of the red, until we for 12 years in a row have never spent a penny more than we had. I said the days of taxing and spending are over, and they should be over.

Q. What about for the kids for education?

VALLONE -- Well, for education, I came up with a plan, a detailed plan, to show where every penny would come from the $5 billion that I'm willing to put in to education, without raising a tax, to insure that we reduce class size, to insure that the money goes in to help the kids, to insure that the bureaucracy is cut. . . .If you start talking about taxing and spending again, you're going to drive the last of the middle class out of the city.

HEVESI -- Well, first of all, let's be very clear. Peter Vallone increased taxes for Safe Streets, Safe Cities. . . . He will not do the same for the public schools if we had to as a last resort. Secondly, his comment about the $5 billion plan he has -- I've heard this many, many times, and so have we all, the $5 billion for education he's talking about is from residential property taxes that are already being collected and have already been spent. You cannot spend the same $5 billion twice. That's already in the budget, it is not new money.

VALLONE -- That's just not so, Alan.

HEVESI -- It is new money, Peter?

VALLONE -- Absolutely.

HEVESI -- Well, tell us how it's new money without raising taxes.

VALLONE -- How do you think I've been doing it, Alan?

HEVESI -- I don't know, I'm asking you a question.

VALLONE -- I've demonstrated where that $500 million comes from. I've demonstrated where $300 million comes from police overtime. I've demonstrated where every single penny has come from. It's a detailed financial plan. That was the same argument that was used when they said I couldn't put Safe Streets, Safe City in effect. They said the money was already used.

HEVESI -- Peter, Peter, Peter, Peter, Peter, come on. You have said you're going to take $5 billion from the residential real property taxes. Now you're talking about overtime and other issues. It can't be both.

VALLONE -- I'm saying that's where the money's coming from.

GREEN -- Ralph and Alice, listen, let me just get a word in here edgewise.

Q. Go ahead, Mr. Green.

GREEN -- Citizens Budget Commission has found $800 million in savings, before we touch taxes.

Q. That's a private, outside agency, right?

GREEN -- A half a billion as senior teachers leave at $70,000, regrettably, they're replaced by teachers earning $31,000, which is too little. I have $200 million in procurement savings at the school construction authority and elsewhere we could save. But at the end of the day, if someone in four years, should I be mayor, said, if we tax pennies a day per person to invest in classes no greater than 20, K to 3, with a proven result, test scores go up, children have the information technology and citizenship skills so they prosper as citizens and our companies prosper, that's an investment, it's not wasteful. We invest in bridges, we invest in health care. We should also invest in children. . . .

Q. The majority of the people who are stopped and frisked were absolutely guiltless of any wrongdoing, although there's a great incentive in this town to bring crime statistics down. If you're elected mayor, will you make sure, will you order the people in charge of your police force, the commissioner and the others, not to engage in unreasonable searches, which are prohibited by the Fourth Amendment to the Constitution?

GREEN -- Absolutely. . . . Racial profiling is wrong, it's illegal, it exists. You don't need a law to stop it, you need a mayor and a commissioner to say no. . . .

Q. Mr. Ferrer, you think that legislation is necessary?

FERRER -- I believed it was necessary 15 years ago when I introduced the first law that created the first Civilian Complaint Review Board in 1986. I believe if law is a reflection of the values of the community, racial profiling, stopping and frisking someone simply because of race and ethnicity, offends our values. You not only -- and this is where I disagree with Mark -- you need a law to stop it. You also need a mayor and a police commissioner to enforce the law. It's as simple as that.

Q. Do you favor a law, Mr. Hevesi?

HEVESI -- I support Mr. Ferrer's law, and prior to that, I supported the legislation introduced in the New York Assembly by Speaker Silver and other members of the Assembly. But the point is that the enforcement of the law is critical, and it goes beyond the mayor giving cues. The mayor must give cues that there will be no tolerance for misconduct, but you have to put into effect programs that hold precinct commanders accountable. . . .

Q. Now, Mr. Ferrer, Mr. Green has raised questions about Sonny Carson, the community activist who reportedly made anti-Semitic and anti-white statements, and he's endorsed you. Do you repudiate his endorsement?

FERRER -- First of all, I rejected a phony endorsement that I didn't ask for. And I rejected it pretty unequivocally. I reject it today. I didn't ask for it. This is a man I don't even know. But let's get real about this. Sonny Carson isn't even important enough to occupy the time of people who are talking about the serious future of this city. . . .

Q. Mr. Green, is it not a fact that you took the endorsement of the Independence Party when you ran for public advocate in '97? A prime mover in that party is Lenora Fulani, who has been associated with Louis Farrakhan, who's made anti-Semitic statements, and with Pat Buchanan, denounced as an anti-Semite by no less than Bill Buckley.

GREEN -- . . . The Independence Party, I can recall, endorsed me. It wasn't then controlled by Lenora Fulani, who I regard as racially divisive and an anti-Semite. This year, now that she's taken over that party, I didn't seek, I didn't want, I didn't get the support of the Independence Party. . . .

HEVESI -- May I respond, please? Just to get the record straight, in 1997 I, too, was running for re-election and had weak opposition and was offered the Independence Party nomination. I turned it down because of the involvement of Lenora Fulani. Mr. Green accepted it, apparently. But my understanding was, Mark, that in 1998 when you ran for the United States Senate you solicited the endorsement of Lenora Fulani's faction in order to get on the ballot to challenge Chuck Schumer, who was going to be the nominee of the party. If that's incorrect, please correct the record now. Here's what's dangerous ----

GREEN -- By the way -- please go ahead.

HEVESI -- ---- We're now getting into very sensitive issues, and all of us ought to be alert to the fact that what we say has meaning and has power and that we ought to be very careful not to aggravate any racial divisiveness or ethnic divisiveness that's a potential in this city at every moment because we're the most ethnically diverse city in the history of cities. And it means we have to be very careful about this. And one way for that is for all of us to pledge that whenever we confront any bigot, whether it's Sonny Carson or Louis Farrakhan or whoever it is, white or black, or the Ku Klux Klan that came to New York to picket where we all went to confront them, that we are standing together with no tolerance for bigotry . . .

VALLONE -- I just want to correct Freddy. I think, how could you not know Sonny Carson? This is a man who's not only a racist, but he says he's not a racist because he's just anti-white. And I think that's the problem. I think the problem here, while I know it's not intentional on Freddy's part, when you're talking about a divided city suddenly it becomes us against them. When you're talking about two cities, that's what happens. You encourage these kind of divisive lunatics to come out and act as if that that's the problem of our city.

GREEN -- I agree with Freddy on this. When I was first asked about Sonny Carson's endorsement of Freddy, I said it is wrong to impute the views of some guy who, unsolicited, endorses a candidate, to the candidate. That's guilt by association. I'm sure the comptroller doesn't mean to implicitly criticize Senator Schumer, who accepted the endorsement in 1998. I agree with Alan's conclusion. You don't have guilt by association. And in a racially divided city, you have to denounce bigots whether they're for you or against you. . . .

FERRER -- Let's be really honest here. The addressing of these issues is not meant to unite. It's really meant to inflame divisions in this city, to exploit them. And let me help you, Peter and Mark, with one little perception. You know that I don't talk to this man. And he is completely marginal to this conversation. To raise him in this issue, to raise him in this debate, inflames and divides. Let's get real about the issues that do confront this city and confront them boldly. This stuff is marginal.

VALLONE -- You don't think that the two cities' division doesn't encourage these kind of kooks to come out? . . .

FERRER -- To acknowledge that there are problems in housing and health care and education and after-school programs ----

VALLONE -- It's still one city, Freddy.

FERRER ---- is not divisive.

Campaign Finance Board Debate

Q. In Brooklyn, during the first six months of the year, noise complaints made up the No. 1 complaint on the mayor's quality of life hot line. If elected mayor, what will you do to bring down the noise? . . .

HEVESI -- The quality of life initiatives of the mayor have been very appropriate in most arenas, although I would eliminate the Decency Commission. And that includes dealing with the issues of fare jumping and graffiti with quality of life disturbances. Among these is the issue of noise. There are noise ceilings that are in codes that have to be enforced, and this is a question of emphasis that I would place with my law enforcement to make sure that people are first warned and then fined for any disturbances that really cause a disturbance in any neighborhood.

VALLONE -- We have a noise control bureau which is one that all you have to do is call the hot line and people would come over and do what has to be done. But we have an environmental code that we have passed in the City Council which determines the noise decibels and the noise levels that can be utilized in the city of New York. So what I would do is make sure of the enforcement mechanism of this particular very aggravating situation. For instance, we have cars that roam around the city. With a law in effect that says when you have this unbearable noise level coming from a particular automobile, the police officers have the power to impound that automobile and to take that radio out of the car. That's a question of enforcement. I passed that law. . . .

GREEN -- If elected mayor, I will eliminate noise in New York City. general laughter . . . I saw a segment on NY1 about a year ago where La Guardia initiated a campaign against noise. This is like shouting at the tides. You've got to keep doing it because it keeps coming at you, because we are a city, uniquely, that's congested. . . . Our noise code is decades out of date. I want to take a fresh look at it because about half of the noise that's generated now is not included and not prohibited by the noise code. And again, I'm very interested in technology. There's new technology that cops on the beat can have detectors which immediately can count the decibel levels and impose tickets to stop it on the spot.

FERRER -- You know, as a kid growing up on Fox Street, you could hear the planes coming by. We lived in the flight path. . . . Noise has been around a long long time, especially with those cars that are attached to rolling speakers or the truck traffic or the car traffic or the boom boxes that get walked down the block. Better enforcement is absolutely essential. But more than that, we have to get serious about the issues that degrade the quality of life of any neighborhood in this city. And getting serious about it is enforcing the laws that already exist.

Q. Mr. Ferrer, earlier this morning you all had a debate, and Mr. Vallone went hard after you on the notion that your campaign theme, the other New York, is racially divisive. Could you pick that up for our viewers and tell them why is the idea of one New York and another New York not a divisive one in your opinion?

FERRER -- You know, when too many New Yorkers find the pursuit of decent housing at a price that they can afford a crisis in their lives, they live in the other New York. Affordable rents, they live in the other New York. When too many New Yorkers don't have health insurance and they're standing right next to another New Yorker who's one pink slip away from losing health insurance, they live in the other New York. When working parents worry that they can't be home for their child after the dismissal bell rings . . . and they want their children to learn more, they live in the other New York. To confront those questions and those crises in people's lives is a unifying issue.

Q. Mr. Spitz.

GEORGE N. SPITZ -- Well, a lot of people in this city do not realize there is a lot of discrimination. Every salesperson at the Wiz store at 87th Street, people of color, has been stopped. These are respectable people. The mosque, Muslim mosque in Bay Ridge, is not allowed to call the faithful to prayer. I will put a stop to this. I will support Borough President Ferrer's bill to end racial profiling, but there'll be an administrative order ending it for blacks, Hispanics and Arab Americans.

Q. Mr. Hevesi.

HEVESI -- It is appropriate for us to suggest with sensitive language that while the city is moving in the right direction in many ways, lots of people have been left behind. And in the effort to make sure no one is left behind, that everyone is included, every candidate for mayor and the mayor himself has to be an absolute militant against any form of bigotry or racism or homophobia or anti-Semitism, whether it comes from the left or from the right, whether the bigot is white or black or any other ethnicity, that is our obligation.

Q. Mr. Vallone, earlier this morning you said one city, not two.

VALLONE -- Absolutely, and I've been saying it from the first. I head Freddy say this in over a hundred debates in over a hundred different corners of this city. This is not two cities, it's one city. And even though it may not be intentional -- it is not intentional on Freddy's part -- what you're doing is racially dividing this city. You are encouraging bigots like Sonny Carson to come out of holes and start talking about, he's not racist, he's just anti-white. It's incurring division. What we should be doing is talking about one city. There are people in this city who are seeking to divide this city. But it's one city and it has to stay one city.

Q. Mr. Green.

GREEN -- I don't think there are two cities. There are 200 cities in a sense, given the number of ethnicities, nationalities and religions. But we have so much more in common than what divides us. The ethic of my public life is those less favored in life should be more favored in law. That's why I exposed that a third of black and Latino children don't have health insurance. . . . We have helped 5,000 children, largely minority, navigate the welfare system. I want to help all the families of this city who have education and protection in common.

Q. This week in the news, we saw an 8-year-old charged with the death of a 4-year-old child. Given the current law, this child could only serve perhaps a year, year-and-a-half in a juvenile detention center for what many would regard as a very serious crime. How would you deal with this situation?

FERRER -- This is truly heinous. I can't imagine being the parent of that child who was stabbed through the neck just for taking out the garbage one night on the floor. But I'll tell you this, while we're all arguing about this one specific case of crime and punishment, we'd better get serious about after-school programs, about education ----

Q. But how would you deal with that 8-year-old?

FERRER -- Let me tell you something, it's hard to say that 8-year-old should be treated like a felon and like an adult.

Q. Mr. Spitz?

SPITZ -- I like to set an example. I'm an advocate of nonviolence. I'm a vegetarian for humanitarian reasons, though I've got considerable health benefits out of it. I'm opposed to bombing innocent civilians. I'm opposed to the death penalty. I'm opposed to the whole death culture. That is why ----

Q. O.K. Let's go on to Mr. Hevesi.

HEVESI -- You have to say that when it comes to an 8-year-old, presuming he is guilty of this heinous crime, that he comes from some dysfunctional family. . . . It's up to a court to determine the competency of the child involved. If the 8-year-old knew what he was doing, then he should be punished to the full extent of the law.

Q. O.K. Mr. Green?

GREEN -- You can't treat an 8-year-old like an adult. The don't have mens rea, as the legal justice system says. But that's why you invest as I will in early education programs, after-school programs to try to avoid tragedies like this.

Q. When voters go into the voting booth on Tuesday to make their choice what is the one word that you want them to associate with your name on the ballot? Mr. Spitz, let's begin with you. One word.

SPITZ -- Uh.

Q. Your time's up. Mr. Hevesi, one word.

HEVESI -- Most experienced, best qualified.

Q. That's not one word. Mr. Vallone?

VALLONE -- Qualifications.

Q. Mr. Green?

GREEN -- Integrity.

Q. Mr. Ferrer?

FERRER -- Commitment.

Q. And Mr. Spitz, I'll give you one last chance?

SPITZ -- Age.

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-10

Tough U.S. Visa Rules Anger Chinese Scholars
In a year in which record numbers of Chinese have applied for visas -- and been rejected -- the American Embassy visa section in Beijing has become a focal point of anti-American resentment, its decisions derided as arbitrary and unfair. From the Chinese perspective, the issue is simple: on the basis of interviews lasting under five minutes, tens of thousands of Chinese have found their plans for study, travel or work jettisoned. A1

Pilot Under Investigation
Two weeks after engine failure caused a plane's dramatic landing in the Azores, the pilot, copilot and the airline -- a Montreal-based charter company -- are all under investigation about decisions made before and during the drama. One of the questions concerns the captain transferring fuel from the one working engine into the other failing engine. A1

Terrorism Flares in Israel
Israel suffered several terrorist blows on the West Bank, the Gaza Strip and in a northern Israeli town. The authorities said one of the incidents was the first suicide bombing ever committed by an Arab who was an Israeli citizen. A3

Victory, of a Sort, in Belarus
The president apparently won the country's first presidential election in seven years. But the government's actions in the final hours of campaigning -- harassment of opponents and refusal to issue detailed vote counts -- seemed to belie any notion that it was confident of support. A8

NATIONAL A12-26

Both Parties Talk Tax Cuts As Economy Remains Weak
The Democrats and the Republicans, as the economy takes on a recessionary tone and the political stakes rise, are scrambling to come up with proposals to rekindle prosperity, with both parties saying that further tax cuts are possible if the deterioration continues. The politics of handling the economy have shifted rapidly since Friday, when the government reported that unemployment last month surged to 4.9 percent from 4.5 percent in July. A1

State Is Accused of Racial Bias
Two black families have accused Mississippi of acting in a racially biased manner by treating white and black landowners differently as it acquires land for a truck plant. A20

Campground for the Homeless
Portland, Ore., has provided land for a tent city and put in a water hookup and portable toilets, a move that has stretched the definition of public services for the homeless. A12

SCIENCE/HEALTH

Malpractice Premiums Soar
Medical malpractice insurance premiums are climbing at the highest rate since the mid-1980's, adding to already rising health care costs. Insurers say that the increases, typically in the double digits, result mainly from a rise in jury awards, now averaging $3.49 million. Some of the biggest insurers are raising rates more than 30 percent. A1

NEW YORK/REGION B1-7

Mayoral Candidates Trade Charges of Being Divisive
Peter F. Vallone used the televised stage of the final two Democratic mayoral debates to charge that Fernando Ferrer was "racially dividing the city" by campaigning on a theme that New York had become two cities. Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, countered that his promise to represent the "other New York" was an appeal to voters who had not benefited from the economic boom. He accused Mr. Vallone, the City Council speaker, of trying to "inflame divisions." A1

Newborn Found in Central Park
A baby girl found just before dawn, left on the ground and wrapped in a blanket, was in stable condition. B3

Common Approach to Schools
The six men hoping to succeed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani all vow to rehabilitate the New York City public schools. All have a plan for shrinking class size and speeding up the process for firing bad teachers. All but one want to increase the mayor's power over the school system. A1

ARTS E1-8

Spotlight on Creature Comforts
Animals have been part of the movie business from the beginning, even before Rin Tin Tin first fetched the sheriff. But never has there been such a demand for them. There were more than 10 films this summer that starred animals or had significant sequences involving them. This trend has squeezed the resources of those trying to safeguard the animals, pushed some producers into taking their projects overseas where there is little or no oversight and inflamed the passions of activists uncomfortable with animals being trained to entertain humans. HEADLINE: Resuscitating the Newark Arena 

 BODY:
A promising plan to aid Newark's downtown revival with a state-assisted sports arena fell victim to New Jersey's election-year politics last week, and there seems no chance of resuscitating the project until after the November election. The YankeeNets, which own the two teams looking for a new home, the New Jersey Nets and the New Jersey Devils, are now threatening to leave the region altogether. We hope the YankeeNets refrain from packing their bags until a new governor has been selected and calmer, less greedy heads prevail in Trenton. 
 The original idea was to relocate the teams from their money-losing arena in the Meadowlands to downtown Newark, near the New Jersey Performing Arts Center and other redevelopment projects. Under a plan sponsored by Acting Gov. Donald DiFrancesco, more than half the $355 million cost of the arena was to have been financed through state-issued revenue bonds, to be paid off through sales and hotel taxes from a special development district in Newark. Additional revenue bonds would have paid to redevelop the Meadowlands arena site. Relocating the teams would have helped make downtown Newark an evening entertainment district and relieved New Jersey of the subsidies it pays for the teams' current venue. 
 But the proposal quickly got caught up in gubernatorial politics. The Republican nominee, Bret Schundler, who is feuding with Mr. DiFrancesco, denounced the plan as an unjustified public handout to the private owners of the YankeeNets. He claimed that if the special tax districts did not yield enough revenue to pay off the bonds, taxpayers statewide would eventually inherit the debt. That seems unlikely. But even if Mr. Schundler turns out to be right, any modest shortfall would be a reasonable public investment in the economic revival of New Jersey's largest city.
In an effort to rally flagging support in the legislature, Mr. DiFrancesco unwisely allowed the arena financing bill to include far more questionable projects, like a rowing center and the redevelopment of a ski resort that could damage an environmentally sensitive region. Some of the new add-ons would have been directly financed from the state treasury. With overall costs soaring toward $1 billion, the bill eventually sank of its own weight. Even the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, Jim McGreevey, a longtime supporter of the arena, turned against the overloaded legislation, though he still supports the Newark arena component.
New Jersey's next governor, whether it is Mr. Schundler or Mr. McGreevey, should quickly craft a new plan to revive the Newark arena project.

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGNING FOR MAYOR: THE DEMOCRATS; 
VALLONE ASSERTS FERRER'S CAMPAIGN IS POLARIZING CITY

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Peter F. Vallone accused Fernando Ferrer yesterday of running an "us against them" campaign for mayor, using the televised stage of the final two Democratic mayoral debates to charge that Mr. Ferrer was "racially dividing the city" by campaigning on a theme that New York had become two cities under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
 Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, stiffened with anger, asserting that his promise to represent the "other New York" was an appeal to voters who had not benefited from the economic boom of the past several years. He accused Mr. Vallone of trying to "inflame divisions" with his assertion. Excerpts, Page B4. 
 Mr. Vallone, in an attack that began at a 9 a.m. debate on WNBC and spilled over at a second televised debate on WABC two hours later, pointed to an endorsement of Mr. Ferrer by Sonny Carson, a black political organizer who describes himself as "antiwhite," as evidence that Mr. Ferrer's campaign was racially polarizing. 
"I think the problem here, while I know it's not intentional on Freddy's part, when you're talking about a divided city, suddenly it becomes us against them," Mr. Vallone said. "When you're talking about two cities, that's what happens: you encourage these kind of divisive lunatics to come out."
Mr. Ferrer said it was Mr. Vallone who was stirring tensions by invoking Mr. Carson's name. "Let us be really honest here," Mr. Ferrer said. "The addressing of these issues is not meant to unite. It's really meant to inflame divisions in this city, to exploit them."
The confrontation between Mr. Vallone and Mr. Ferrer provided what was, at least by the standards of this campaign, an uncharacteristically sharp edge to the contest as it headed into its final hours. It was unusual because it involved a topic that the candidates had largely avoided, the ethnic appeal that some Democrats view as part of Mr. Ferrer's campaign. And it was notable because it was initiated by Mr. Vallone, the City Council speaker and a figure who is not generally known for having sharp elbows.
The forceful attack came as a series of public polls have shown Mr. Vallone and the fourth major Democratic mayoral candidate, Alan G. Hevesi, trailing Mr. Green and Mr. Ferrer in tomorrow's Democratic primary. Aides to some of Mr. Vallone's rivals suggested that he was trying to rally white and moderate voters behind him, in the hopes of slipping into at least second place. If no candidate wins over 40 percent, there will be a runoff between the top two vote-getters on Sept. 25.
Mr. Vallone's aides denied that there was any political calculation to the attack.
The skirmish came on a bright Sunday morning on which the candidates headed first to the studios of WNBC, Channel 4, for a debate moderated by Gabe Pressman. Then they packed up and scurried over to WABC, Channel 2, for a debate mandated by the city's Campaign Finance Board. It was the last debate of the race. From there, the candidates set out across the city for a final weekend day of campaigning. 
By Mr. Green's count, the second debate yesterday was the 100th appearance by the candidates at some sort of forum since they first began traveling around the city last winter. And there was a sense of familiarity to what they were saying; by this point, the candidates are almost able to finish one another's sentences.
That said, these final 120 minutes of discussion served to further define some differences, if slight ones, among the candidates on a few issues.
On taxes, for example, Mr. Hevesi, Mr. Green and Mr. Ferrer all said they were prepared, if necessary, to raise taxes to finance the public school system. "If necessary, absolutely," Mr. Green said.
Mr. Hevesi, reiterating a position he took early in the campaign to distinguish himself from his rivals, said he would support an income-tax surcharge, similar to one that Mayor David N. Dinkins and Mr. Vallone passed to pay for hiring more police officers, to pay for the public school system, if it proved necessary. "It worked then and I would do it for education if we had to," Mr. Hevesi said.
Mr. Vallone, though, said he would "absolutely not" support a tax increase. "And that's the difference between me and the other candidates," he said, adding, "The days of taxing and spending are over, and they should be over."
Mr. Ferrer called for legislation barring racial profiling by police officers, and Mr. Hevesi said at the debate that he considered that a good idea. But both Mr. Green and Mr. Vallone described such legislation as unnecessary and impractical. "You don't need a law to stop it, you need a mayor and a commissioner to say no," Mr. Green said.
The debate was marked by the exchanges over race between Mr. Ferrer and Mr. Vallone and also by squabbling between Mr. Vallone and Mr. Hevesi, two moderate Democrats from Queens who are competing for some of the same voters. At Mr. Pressman's debate, Mr. Hevesi strongly criticized Mr. Vallone for broadcasting a commercial that notes that Mr. Vallone had been endorsed by New York's police officers, while the others "haven't earned their trust."
"It's an ugly ad at the end of a campaign, and it shouldn't have been put on the air," Mr. Hevesi said. Mr. Vallone ignored him.
By contrast, Mr. Green, once again, stayed on the sidelines, offering joking asides about the fights going on around him, in the latest indication of just how confident he is about his position. 
At one point, Mr. Vallone and Mr. Hevesi carried out a dry though heated exchange about how Mr. Vallone would pay for improvements in education. "Peter, Peter, Peter, Peter, Peter, come on,"' Mr. Hevesi said sternly. "You have said you're going to take $5 billion from the residential real property taxes. Now you're talking about overtime and other issues. It can't be both."
Mr. Green interjected: "Ralph and Alice: Listen, let me just get a word in here edgewise."
At the WABC debate, a fifth candidate in the race, George N. Spitz, a retired civil servant, noted that Mr. Green's brother, Stephen L. Green, a large real estate owner, had hired a lobbyist, at $2,500 a month, to represent him before agencies in City Hall. When the moderator gave Mr. Green an opportunity to respond to Mr. Spitz, Mr. Green quipped: "My brother will not have to spend money to speak to me, should I be mayor."
The attacks by Mr. Vallone on Mr. Ferrer's campaign came as Mr. Ferrer has been trying to assemble the support of blacks and Latinos behind his effort to become New York's first Puerto Rican mayor. Mr. Ferrer has avoided any direct racial or ethnic appeals in his campaign speeches, and his aides have been concerned that the effort might be perceived as being exclusionary of white voters. Yesterday, in the midst of this criticism, Mr. Ferrer's campaign announced that it was broadcasting a new television advertisement featuring Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the former New York senator.
Mr. Ferrer, in the WABC debate, disputed the notion that his "other New York" argument was a racial or ethnic appeal. 
"When too many New Yorkers find the pursuit of decent housing at a price that they can afford a crisis in their lives, they live in the other New York," he said, adding, "When too many New Yorkers don't have health insurance and they're standing right next to another New Yorker who's one pink slip away from losing health insurance, they live in the other New York."
Listing several other examples, he concluded, "To confront those questions and those crises in people's lives is a unifying issue."
In attacking the "other New York" appeal, Mr. Vallone made note of the fact that his rival had been endorsed by Mr. Carson, the organizer of a boycott of Korean grocers in the early 1990's, and said that Mr. Carson had been responding to the kind of appeal Mr. Ferrer had been making. Mr. Green, in response to a question last week, suggested that Mr. Ferrer had not been forceful enough in disassociating himself from Mr. Carson. 
But Mr. Ferrer said he did not know Mr. Carson, and yesterday disavowed his support as a "phony endorsement I didn't ask for."
"Let me help you, Peter and Mark, with one little perception," Mr. Ferrer said. "You know that I don't talk to this man. And he is completely marginal to this conversation. To raise him in this issue, to raise him in this debate, inflames and divides. Let's get real about the issues that do confront this city and confront them boldly. This stuff is marginal." 
Mr. Vallone suggested that he did not believe Mr. Ferrer's claim of ignorance. "How could you not know Sonny Carson?" Mr. Vallone said, looking over at Mr. Ferrer on the set at WNBC studios at Rockefeller Center. "This is a man who's not only a racist, but says he's not a racist because he's just antiwhite."
Mr. Vallone continued his criticism of Mr. Ferrer after the debate. "What else does two cities mean?" he said. "You're dividing something. What does that mean? The average person is going to say if there are two cities, I belong in one or the other. It's us against them. Well, who is us and who is them?"
Mr. Green also said he did not agree with Mr. Ferrer's view of New York, although he was not as critical as Mr. Vallone. "I don't think there are two cities," Mr. Green said. "There are 200 cities in a sense, given the number of ethnicities, nationalities and religions. But we have so much more in common than what divides us."
Mr. Hevesi said he had no quarrel with the argument Mr. Ferrer had raised. "It is appropriate for us to suggest with sensitive language that while the city is moving in the right direction in many ways, lots of people have been left behind," Mr. Hevesi said.
As Mr. Ferrer sought to disavow his relationship with Mr. Carson, Mr. Green found himself pressed to explain his own decision in 1997 to accept the endorsement of the Independence Party, whose leaders include Lenora Fulani, who has been accused of making anti-Semitic remarks. 
Mr. Green said that when he was dealing with the party then, Ms. Fulani was not one of its official leaders. "Now that she's taken over the party, I didn't seek, I didn't want, I didn't get the support of the Independence Party," he said.
Mr. Hevesi, observing this exchange, noted that Mr. Green had unsuccessfully sought the party's support when he ran for the United States Senate in 1998.

HEADLINE: Malpractice Rates Are Rising Sharply; Health Costs Follow 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Medical malpractice insurance premiums are soaring at the highest rate since the mid-1980's, adding to rising health care costs.
 Insurers say the increases, typically in the double digits, result mainly from a rise in jury awards, now averaging $3.49 million. 
 Some of the biggest insurers are raising rates in many states more than 30 percent. Even insurers owned by doctors and hospitals, which strive to keep rates low, are increasing prices 10 percent to 18 percent. 
Insurers began raising rates last year, after several years of price-cutting competition that left premiums trailing inflation. A 4 percent rise in premiums last year was the largest since 1994, and insurers say the increases are accelerating greatly this year. 
In New York, where rates are already among the highest, and in New Jersey, insurers say they do not expect any big jumps this year. But some of Connecticut's largest malpractice insurers are raising prices sharply, and New York insurers say they are nervous about increasing costs. One New York insurer, its finances deteriorating, was taken over by state regulators last month.
Malpractice coverage is already one of the most expensive kinds of insurance. The latest increases put further pressure on doctors' and hospitals' earnings, which have been shrinking under managed care. While doctors and hospitals say they must absorb much of the added cost, analysts say they are able to pass some of it along to health care insurers and patients who have traditional medical insurance or pay directly.
Health care costs are expected to increase about 10 percent this year. And rising malpractice premiums account for about one-tenth of the increase, Dr. William F. Jessee, chief executive of the Medical Group Management Association, estimated. His group represents 188,000 doctors, or nearly half of those who buy the coverage.
Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a managing director at the Carlyle Group, a New York investment firm, who specializes in the health care industry, said: "The rising cost of malpractice coverage is becoming one of the most important factors driving inflation for physicians' services, particularly for high-priced specialists in surgery and obstetrics."
Dr. Yank D. Coble Jr., the president-elect of the American Medical Association, said the insurance jolt was one of his members' greatest worries. "This is creating a great deal of alarm and concern," he said.
The price increases are highest for obstetricians, gynecologists and surgeons, the doctors who are sued the most frequently. In New York and Florida, these doctors pay more than $100,000 a year for $1 million in coverage. The Clarendon Insurance Group, one of the market leaders in Florida, has raised its prices for obstetricians and gynecologists in the southeastern part of the state to more than $200,000, up from about $158,000 last year, said Carol Brierly Golin, editor of the Medical Liability Monitor, an industry newsletter.
For many hospitals, insurers are not only increasing premiums but are also sharply reducing amounts of coverage and raising deductibles. One hospital in Chicago, for example, paid the St. Paul Companies $1 million for $40 million in coverage last year with a deductible of $15 million. This year, the insurer raised the premium for the hospital, which it would not identify, to $1.8 million, but cut the coverage to $10 million and more than doubled the deductible.
Rising medical malpractice premiums are also adding to medical costs in another way: Doctors are practicing more defensively, ordering extra tests and choosing procedures that limit their risks. Dr. Nigel Spier, an obstetrician-gynecologist in Hollywood, Fla., said doctors were performing more Caesarean deliveries, for example, which are more costly than vaginal deliveries.
Insurers put most of the blame for the increases on a jump in big awards by juries and large settlements. While the number of malpractice suits has been holding steady, the average jury award rose to $3.49 million in 1999, up 79 percent from $1.95 million in 1993, according to the latest compilation by Jury Verdict Research of Horsham, Pa. 
But industry experts point to another reason for the price shock: a grave miscalculation by insurers. For several years, they kept prices artificially low while competing for market share and new revenue to invest in a booming stock market.
As the bull market surged, stock investments by these historically conservative insurers rose to 10.6 percent in 1999, up from a more typical 3 percent in 1992, said Geri Riley, an analyst at Conning & Company, an insurance research firm. That was nearly four times the percentage increase in stock market investments by the entire property and casualty insurance industry over that period.
With the market now in a slump, the insurers can no longer use stock market gains to subsidize low rates. The industry reported realized capital gains of $381 million last year, down 30 percent from the high point in 1998, according to the A. M. Best Company, one of the most comprehensive sources of insurance industry data. A decline in investment earnings has also helped drive up the prices of automobile and homeowners insurance.
About 60 percent of the malpractice insurance is provided by mutual companies, owned by doctors and hospitals that are inclined to err on the side of keeping rates low. Commercial insurers, battling for market share, also restrained their prices.
But now, industry experts say, the insurers must sharply increase their premiums to avoid collapse. One of the largest companies, Phico, which sells insurance nationally but concentrates on New Jersey and Pennsylvania, was taken over in August by regulators in Pennsylvania, where it is based, when claims threatened to outrun the company's ability to pay.
Later in the month, another big company, the Frontier Insurance Group, based in Rock Hills, N.Y., was taken over by New York regulators.
Ms. Brierly Golin, the newsletter editor, blames a lack of foresight for the plight of Frontier and others in the industry. "The insurance companies wouldn't be in this position if they hadn't been been so hungry for investment profits and had priced their product appropriately," she said.
Insurers now acknowledge their miscalculations. "We should have raised prices sooner," said Mike Miller, the senior executive in charge of malpractice coverage at the St. Paul Companies.
But no one wanted to go first, said Larry Smarr, the president of the Physician Insurers Association of America, which represents many of the companies doctors own. "If you're the first guy to raise your rates, you'll lose market share," he said. "So they all played a game of chicken for a long time."
Because dozens of companies are raising rates state by state, there is no centralized tally of the changes. Companies say their rates vary by state, city, doctor and medical speciality, with the largest increases where the gap between premiums and costs is greatest. 
St. Paul, the second-largest malpractice insurer, has raised rates for doctors an average of 24 percent this year in 25 states, with rates jumping 65 percent in Ohio and Mississippi. Scpie Companies is raising rates an average of 30 percent to 50 percent in a dozen states, including Florida and Texas. A few of the insurers owned by doctors and hospitals are raising rates more than 55 percent. 
In New York, one of the most litigious states, where neurosurgeons on Long Island pay $155,000 a year for $1 million in coverage, insurance executives say they are seeing rising costs that could soon result in still higher premiums. Donald J. Fager, who is in charge of daily operations for the Mlmic Group, the state's largest malpractice insurer, said that by midyear, claims costs were running $21 million, or 12 percent, ahead of last year. "I'm nervous about what's going to happen," he said.
In New Jersey, insurers do not expect the market leaders to make sharp increases this year. In Connecticut, one of the leading companies, the Connecticut Medical Insurance Company, has raised its rates 16 percent this year. State regulators said the company also cut dividends to doctors, who are both customers and owners, effectively raising its rates another 33 percent. Scpie, one of the smaller companies in the state, has raised its rates 35 percent.
Many insurers say the higher jury awards are at least partly a backlash against managed care. "You have a jury pool today made up of people who are not happy with their doctor and their managed care provider," said Mr. Miller of the St. Paul Companies. "When they're told about this poor person that was killed or injured, they're in a position to relate."
The physician insurers association, based in Washington, has been lobbying Congress to include in the Patients' Bill of Rights a limit of $250,000 on jury awards for pain and suffering in medical malpractice suits. But even in California, where this limit applies, juries keep awarding more for other damages, like medical expenses and lost wages. 
Last year, in California, juries awarded more than $1 million in 39 malpractice lawsuits, up from 28 seven years earlier, according to Medical Underwriters of California. The average award rose to $2.9 million from $2 million. 
In about a dozen states, there have been no rate increases so far this year. But experts say they will probably spread. Now that the leading malpractice insurers have raised rates, their competitors are expected to match or nearly match them. 
"There's no end in sight to this," said Mr. Smarr, of the physician insurers group. "The companies will have to take some very large rate increases to sustain their viability."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
New York Jobs Cut By Interpublic Unit

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
The New York office of Foote, Cone & Belding, part of the FCB Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is laying off an estimated 50 to 75 employees, which could end up being more than 10 percent of its staff.
 The agency, in a statement on Friday, described the dismissals as part of "an alignment of agency resources to meet the challenges experienced by many clients across the board" because of "the softening of the economy and reduction in ad spending." 
 The New York office works on accounts that include Compaq Computer, PepsiCo and Philip Morris. These are the first significant layoffs at the office, coming after large cutbacks in the staffs of offices in Chicago; El Segundo, Calif.; and San Francisco.

HEADLINE: Tough U.S. Visa Policy Riles Shut-Out Scholars in China 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 9 

 BODY:
Yu Jie had surmounted so many obstacles en route to attending business school in the United States. Born in a small coastal city, he accumulated a degree in international finance and a decade of prestigious work experience, as a business consultant and later as a journalist.
 He learned English and got high marks on the proficiency exam as well as on the standardized test for graduate school. He got family members to lend him tuition and was accepted by Purdue University, his first choice, in February. 
 But as Purdue begins classes, Mr. Yu remains here -- having crashed into a final barrier: the American Embassy repeatedly refused to grant him a visa, saying officials believed that he really wanted to get to the United States and stay there. 
"They only talked to me for a few minutes," said Mr. Yu, a gregarious, clean-cut 29-year-old, from the offices of the influential policy journal where he remains a top editor. "I think there's no way to judge, especially in such a short time. It seems like a snap decision."
In a year in which record numbers of Chinese have applied for visas -- and been rejected -- the American Embassy visa section here has suddenly become a focal point of anti-American resentment, its decisions derided as arbitrary and unfair.
Chinese newspapers have been running editorials and multipart series criticizing its performance. 
Internet chat rooms devoted to the visa section are filled with students' battle tales and analysis of the personality and foibles of each visa officer. "The inscrutable beings behind the glass are rejecting an unprecedented number of applicants, with full or nearly full scholarships," read one article in a series currently running in the popular Beijing Youth Daily, one of many Chinese publications to report the issue.
From the Chinese perspective, the issue is simple: on the basis of interviews lasting less than five minutes, thousands of Chinese this year have found their longstanding plans for study, travel or work jettisoned. Those denied visas include students with full scholarships to Ivy League schools and grandparents wanting to see a first grandchild.
While such cases are not unique to China, the numbers here have become huge and the aftermath especially far-reaching. There now are more students at American universities from China than from any other country, more than 50,000 last year, and a number of universities have complained that they are being denied valued students and teaching assistants. 
More important, those denials disproportionately affect young, highly educated students and professionals, seeding resentment in a group that has played an important role in improving ties between the countries.
But American Embassy officials are inclined to be suspicious: historically, a majority of Chinese students have indeed remained in the United States after graduation, although most did so legally, and the Chinese government says that the number returning home is now growing by more than 10 percent a year. 
Large numbers of Chinese have faced rejections this year, embassy officials acknowledge, and the rejection rate has been high compared with last year. But they deny that the proportion of applications turned down is an all time high -- although they refused to release statistics for fear they would be "misleading."
The embassy only tallies the percentage of applications that are successful and, since many Chinese apply several times before succeeding or giving up, it is hard to know how many individuals are turned down.
However, the United States government did release figures for the six weeks between May 15 and June 20, which showed that 41 percent of student applications were rejected during that time, up from 27 percent over the same period a year earlier.
The statistics also showed that just over half of applications from research scholars and professionals were rejected, up from 38 percent in 2000, although Chinese note that the odds seem to have become somewhat better recently.
An American diplomat said that one reason more people are being rejected is that more high school students are applying. Another is that the total number of applications is growing so fast -- up 17 percent, to more than 400,000 last year.
A vast majority of Chinese, like Mr. Yu, are rejected because a visa officer makes what is often a highly subjective determination: that the applicant harbors intentions of staying on in the United States -- whether legally or illegally -- which disqualifies the applicant for a visa under United States law. 
The interviewers, often first- or second-year Foreign Service officers, see well over 100 people a day on summer months, spending only minutes with each one. No wonder, then, that visa interview consulting booths are flourishing across from the American Embassy and Internet chat rooms are filled with hints on interview strategies. 
Given handles like "Glassboy" and "Big Taiwan Mama," visa officers have become minor celebrities to desperate students, who sometimes apply more than half a dozen times. The cost is $55 a try, a standard fee that is equivalent to about a month's salary in much of China.
"Taiwan Big Ma likes short answers and transcripts," said one successful applicant, identified only as Egirl to the chat room.
An American diplomat here acknowledged that getting a visa has become "the most stressful part" of applying for study in the United States -- by far the preferred destination of students. "We realize we are making life-altering decisions," he said. "But I think our people do a wonderful job given the tools we have."
If the Chinese are unhappy with high rejection rates, he said, they should not blame the visa officers, but the 50-year-old American immigration law.
Most Chinese are rejected under section 214-B of the code, which states that applicants should be denied a visa if they have "intent to immigrate," by legal means or not.
According to the law, every applicant is presumed to have "immigrant intent" until the candidate can convince an interviewer otherwise. It is a presumption that many Chinese find particularly galling. Although "innocent until proven guilty" is a basic presumption of American law, noted the article in the Beijing Youth Daily, "the applicant is assumed to be guilty of harboring a secret wish to stay in America." 
But the law is also "contradictory," acknowledged the American diplomat, because it presents numerous means for students to stay on legally in the United States after their visas expire. In fact, most Chinese students who stay on in the United States do so legally, he said, by going to work for an American company or university that sponsors them. "They are people who become very productive members of the U.S. economy -- it's not a drain on the U.S. at all," he added.
Mr. Yu, the editor who was denied a visa, insists that he wants to return, but in three different visa interviews, he failed to make his case.
On June 14, his first try, questions focused on his career. He said he wanted to return to get a job with a bank in Hong Kong, Shanghai or Beijing. Result: a 214-B rejection.
On July 10, he was assigned to "the woman officer whom everyone is afraid of for her high rejection rates." She told him that, as an M.B.A., "he would have more opportunities in the U.S. than in China." 214-B again.
On Aug. 9, three days after he was to have registered at Purdue, he tried again -- this time armed even with letters of support from American diplomats in Beijing. He said the visa officer asked him outright, four times, to prove he would return.
He did not quite know what to say. He mentioned friends and family in China, his goal of a bank job, and the career he has already made for himself here. "He said you have still not convinced us," recalled Mr. Yu. By then, time had run out.
The American Embassy says it tries to take into account many factors in trying to determine who might -- or might not -- return.
They are favorably disposed to people who have previously traveled to other countries and have returned.
Also, they look for ties that bind to China -- a successful family business, a home, a car, a job already offered for their return, a spouse or child left behind.
The evaluation is not high science. Anyway, critics say, it is impossible to sort out by these crude tests which applicants intend to return.
Fang Lin, a doctor specializing in rehabilitating people who have suffered traumas like strokes or heart attacks, was invited to present a paper last December at a conference sponsored by Baylor Medical College, in Texas. Her specialty is a fledgling field in China, and she looked forward to learning from American colleagues.
Dr. Fang, 30, has worked at one of Beijing's most upscale clinics, The Friendship Hospital, since 1993. She and her husband -- a successful executive -- own an apartment and two cars and have traveled to Hong Kong and South Korea as tourists. He was not planning to accompany her.
Still, she was turned down twice late last year, both times for "immigrant intent;" after that, it was too late to apply again. Of the five doctors from her hospital invited to the conference, only two were approved.
"I never dreamed it would be such trouble -- I was just going to a conference," she said, adding, "They think that everyone wants to leave."
