HEADLINE: FEAR OF RECESSION IGNITES DISCUSSION OF MORE TAX CUTS 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 

 BODY:
As the economy takes on a recessionary tone and the political stakes rise, the two parties are scrambling to come up with proposals to rekindle prosperity, with Democrats and Republicans alike saying today that further tax cuts are possible if the deterioration continues.
 Urged on by Republicans in Congress who are nervous that an extended downturn could harm their election prospects in 2002, President Bush is considering such responses as cutting spending to keep the budget balanced or cutting capital gains taxes to give Wall Street a lift. 
 Administration officials said the president had not decided to back any particular proposal. They said he believed that previous steps, including the tax cut he signed in June, should spark a recovery before long. If it does not, they said, he might eventually seek further actions. 
"We need to let the president's tax cut, as well as the Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts, take full effect," said Jennifer Millerwise, a White House spokeswoman. "But the president also hasn't closed the door on any further tax cuts."
The politics of handling the economy have shifted rapidly just since Friday, when the government reported that unemployment last month surged to 4.9 percent from 4.5 percent in July.
Democrats are seeking to pin the blame for the economy on Mr. Bush. They are linking the slowdown in growth and the rise in unemployment to their argument that Mr. Bush squandered the federal budget surplus by pushing through an irresponsible tax cut.
"It's his budget, it's his economy, it's his tax cut, it's his solution," Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, said today on ABC's "This Week."
But a number of Democrats said today that they, too, might support further economic stimulus, especially as part of a deal to scale back the longer-term components of Mr. Bush's tax cut. One idea mentioned by several Democrats was an immediate tax cut that would extend even to people who do not make enough money to pay federal income taxes.
One such measure would temporarily reduce the payroll tax that finances Social Security. This would reduce the current surplus in the retirement trust fund, but would not divert the trust fund into government spending, or concentrate another round of tax cuts on the wealthy.
"We'd want to do something to put money in people's pockets quickly," Senator Kent Conrad, the North Dakota Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said on "Fox News Sunday."
Any agreement could be hampered by the partisanship that has surrounded the budget, and by the pledges of both parties to avoid spending any portion of the budget surplus generated by Social Security.
To a large degree, the political decisions in the weeks ahead will be driven by the economy. Economists have lacked success in predicting downturns or calling the moment at which a weakened economy starts to recover, and there is considerable debate right now about just where in the cycle this economy is.
But economists and other analysts said the nation appeared to have reached something of a turning point, if only psychologically. The risks of protracted economic weakness, they said, are beginning to weigh more heavily on consumers, investors and politicians, all of whom had grown optimistic and perhaps complacent with prosperity.
"I don't know whether we're in a recession or not, but people are looking around and getting scared," said Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., president of the Economic Strategy Institute, a research group in Washington. "That in itself can be a negative factor."
One result has been to focus new scrutiny on the limited policy choices available. The Federal Reserve has already cut interest rates seven times this year. Although the Fed is likely to continue doing so, at this point it is mostly waiting for past rate cuts to be felt, a process that usually takes six to nine months.
For the administration and Congress, the question is how to reconcile their growing interest in tax cuts or spending increases -- the traditional fiscal responses to a flagging economy -- with their pledge not to touch the portion of the budget surplus generated by Social Security.
Mr. Bush has said he would put aside his pledge not to dip into Social Security money if the economy went into a recession. But for now the White House and both parties in Congress are assuming that is not an option.
Although the economy still seems to be moving ahead, it has decelerated so sharply that businesses and individuals might feel like they have hit a wall, analysts said.
The economy's growth rate has dropped from a robust 5.7 percent during the spring of last year to just two-tenths of one percent in the same period this year, its weakest performance in eight years. Typically, a drop-off of that magnitude would mean a swing from an expanding economy to a shrinking one, the primary attribute of a recession.
Moreover, the indicator that more than any other brings economic difficulty home -- joblessness -- has now shot up by a full percentage point in 10 months, from 3.9 percent last October to 4.9 percent in August.
"It's a very powerful policy and psychological point, because it feels like you've fallen off a cliff," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, a research group in Washington.
The prevailing view among economists has been that the economy would begin to recover by the end of the year, and there is still considerable evidence to support that outlook. 
The tax cut is putting $38 billion worth of rebate checks into the hands of consumers in a 10-week period. The sharp slide in manufacturing seems to be leveling off. New claims for unemployment insurance may have peaked. 
But there are considerable risks, including the spread of economic weakness around the world, especially in Japan. 
White House officials and Republicans from Capitol Hill who have recently met together said there was broad agreement not to rush into any decisions. Mr. Bush and his team especially counseled patience, participants in the meetings said.
But Republican leaders including Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the minority leader, and J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, the speaker of the House, made clear to Mr. Bush that their colleagues in Congress did not want to have to run next year under the cloud of a recession.
Although Mr. Bush has been noncommittal about cutting the capital gains tax, Republicans said that Mr. Hastert is likely to bring a bill to the floor of the House within the next month or so. Conveniently, such a change might actually raise more money for the government in the first year or two by encouraging investors to sell stocks they might otherwise hold on to. In that way, the tax cut would not force Congress to break its Social Security pledge.
Even as they talk about fiscal stimulus, House Republicans are also pressing for an automatic, across-the-board cut in government spending in the coming fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1. The cuts would be equal to the amount of the Social Security surplus the government is spending this year, allowing Congress to say it has paid back any money taken from Social Security.
The Congressional Budget Office projected last month that the budget would dip into Social Security by $9 billion this year, an estimate the White House no longer disputes.
But neither party in the Senate is enthusiastic about trying to cut spending across the board. In addition to being hard to carry out, cutting spending in the face of a recession might actually slow the economy further.

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGNING FOR MAYOR; 
Confronting the Economy's Future and Media Rumors

 BODY:
 Following are excerpts from yesterday's debate between the Republican candidates for mayor, as recorded by The New York Times. The debate was broadcast on WNBC, Channel 4, and was moderated by Gabe Pressman.

Q. Mr. Bloomberg, your opponent here says you're trying to buy this election. You're a billionaire, he barely has enough money to buy postage. Do you agree that this is far from a level playing field?

MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG -- Well, money can get your message out. I do not have a long record in public service. My record is in private service, so I've got to use whatever resources I have to explain to the people who I am. But you can't buy the public, you can't buy their votes, you can't buy The Daily News endorsement, you can't buy the endorsement of the largest Spanish language daily. . . .

Q. Mr. Badillo, you've barely raised any money, as I pointed out. People say your time has passed. You've been very low in the polls. Why do you persist in running?

HERMAN BADILLO -- Well, I've been trying to expand the base of the Republican Party for the past eight years in order to make it the majority and responsible party in New York City. I joined Rudy Giuliani in 1993, and I ran for comptroller with him, and I brought in a large number of Hispanics and other Republicans that enabled Rudy to be elected. And then I supported Rudy in 1997. That is the reason that we had a tremendous reduction in crime. That's the reason that we've proven that the City of New York is governable. And now the Republican Party, with Mr. Bloomberg, is trying to go back to the old days of being the party of money. . . . And I expect that the Republican Party voters . . . will vote for me and not for the fellow who has not one day of experience at all.

Q. Now, you're both self-defrocked Democrats. Do you have an identity crisis about whether you're Democrats or Republicans?

BADILLO -- Not me. I endorsed Rudy Giuliani way back in 1993, as I said, because I wanted to have a mayor who would agree that the city is manageable. And prior to that, you may remember under Mayor Dinkins there were policies that allowed 2,100 murders a year.

Q. What about you Mr. Bloomberg? Did you become a Republican because it was the easy way to get elected mayor?

BLOOMBERG -- Well, the Republican Party called me, asked me to run. I've been endorsed by almost all local Republican government officials and party leaders. And I agree with the Republican values of those inclusive Republicans like the mayor, like the governor. And I'm very comfortable in running as a Republican, and I will stay a Republican long after this election. . . .

BADILLO -- He has not been endorsed by the largest Republican leaders. Neither the mayor nor the governor has taken a stand. The senator, Guy J. Velella, and the entire Bronx Republicans have endorsed me. Senator Frank Padavan has endorsed me. Assemblyman Robert A. Straniere has endorsed me. . . . The largest Hispanic papers, El Diario, La Prensa, and they endorse me.

Q. Mr. Bloomberg, something that's come up in the last few days is the New York magazine article by Michael Wolff, in which he refers to a book of quotations supposedly said in jest by you, presented to you as a booklet at a party. Among them are that, if women wanted to be appreciated for their brains, and I quote, they'd go to the library instead of to Bloomingdale's. Did you say that?

BLOOMBERG -- I don't remember ever saying that. This was a book that was given to me as a joke 10 years ago at a party. I probably never saw it after that. It's a bunch of borscht belt jokes that somebody had put together. It does not reflect my views back then, or now. And the fact that it comes up three days before a primary -- come on, that's just normal politics, so I'm told. I'm not a politician and I don't want to get involved in it . . . It doesn't reflect me. I apologize if anybody's offended by it. But I didn't say those things. I didn't write the book.

Q. What about, I make it a rule never to go to Queens, and since that eliminates both airports I don't travel a great deal. Did you say that?

BLOOMBERG -- Well, the fact of the matter is, I'm a pilot and I fly out of both of those airports. So that shows you how ridiculous it is.

Q. But Queens is a hotbed of registered Republicans.

BLOOMBERG -- I've spent an enormous amount of time in Queens, thank you very much. I was there yesterday. I'll be there today.

Q. What about, if Jesus were a Jew, why does he have a Puerto Rican first name?

BLOOMBERG -- I never heard that joke before. But I'm -- one of the comedians, one of the columnists on television said they'd heard that joke 40 years earlier.

Q. I thought you had said that you hadn't said that. But in any event ----

BLOOMBERG -- I certainly don't think I said that.

Q. It seems to be a pattern of humor. If you believe at all in Freud, all jokes are based on truth, on real feelings. Could some of these jests represent your real feelings?

BLOOMBERG -- I haven't even bothered to read the stories about it or read the book. It was something handed to me, written by somebody else 10 years ago, at a party. They handed it to me, I'm sure I handed it to one of the staff people. And I never saw it again. So I just don't know. . . .

BADILLO -- I have to comment on this, because I don't believe that anyone in his right mind would believe that Mr. Bloomberg would forget about 32 pages in a book which has remarks that he has made and the introduction says that these are some of the gentlest things that he has said. Now, the reality is that he was given a bound copy of this book. He -- if these remarks were made by any politician, he'd be driven out of office. What these remarks indicate is the real Michael Bloomberg. Because he has been hiding behind $30 million of commercials. This is really the first debate we've had a chance to have on television. I've been debating with the four Democrats and an empty chair for months because he doesn't want people to know who the real Bloomberg is. These 32 pages bring out who the real person is. . . .

BLOOMBERG -- Nobody alleges that I said this. It was in a book written by somebody else. Let's go on to the issues. Come on. . . .

Q. The stock market has been faltering. The economy seems to be in very poor shape. Now the independent budget office says that there's a $3 billion shortfall. What will you do to address this if you're elected mayor?

BADILLO -- Well, we had that problem when I was deputy mayor in 1978 because we had the New York City fiscal crisis, which was even worse than the projected amount of a deficit now. . . . And we dealt with it by cutting the budget in a sensible way, cutting departments in such a way that we would not destroy the capacity of the department to perform until the economy was restored. That's the way to do it. Not by increasing taxes. Because if you increase taxes, as Mayor Dinkins did, you will find that you're going to lose jobs and you're going to lose the middle class.

BLOOMBERG -- Well, my recollection is that back then there were some elected officials that even recommended New York City go bankrupt. Fortunately Hugh Carey kept us from doing that. I think what you have to do is you cannot raise taxes under any circumstances. And what I promise I will not do is I won't fudge the accounting, which is typically done. I won't borrow, which commits our kids to a terrible future of debt service. And I won't postpone maintenance. What you have to do is you have to set some priorities. My priorities are: No. 1, keep the streets safe, no matter what it costs; No. 2, focus on education, or we will never have a good economy again and we'll never have jobs coming here; and then No. 3, you sit there with every single other department and say, I want to know what would happen if I had to cut 2 percent, 5 percent, 7 percent. . . .

Q. What about the fence around City Hall, which some people regard as symbolic of a lack of information coming out of this administration. Will you tear down the fence? And will you open up the agencies? And will you allow your commissioners to speak freely?

BLOOMBERG -- Yes, yes and yes. Get rid of the fence. I would do that the first day I am in office. The second thing is, I think the mayor is going in the right direction of trying to have all the agencies that report to him put every bit of information possible on the Internet so that everybody can see. And three, I've just always run a business, and my theory has always been: get all the information out there. If you don't know what's going on, you can't fix the problem.

BADILLO -- My public record shows that I've always believed in open government. I would tear down the fence. But more than that, I would meet with the people who are my opponents. I did that, as you know, when I was chairman of the City University, and I restored standards. And I was criticized. I was called a racist; I was called an ethnic cleanser. But I met with my opponents. I met with the students. I debated the head of the faculty senate. I called public hearings because I want people to know exactly what I am proposing and why I'm proposing it. And I believe in facing my opponents. That's why I believe in debate. That's why I wanted to have debates with Mr. Bloomberg for every week for the past two months. . . .

Q. Mr. Bloomberg, Mr. Badillo, it's time now for your closing statements. The order was determined by a coin toss.

BLOOMBERG -- Well, this election is about three things: it is about leadership, it is about accountability, and it is about independence. I've shown that I know how to lead. I've built a worldwide company, 8,000 employees. We've been a big success thanks to those people. And I can do the same thing in managing this city's $40 billion, 250,000 employee company -- budget. I can -- I am accountable. I've been accountable every day. I know exactly what it means to make a payroll. I know what it means to provide health care. I know what it means to look people in the eye and bring them together rather than make them divisive. And in terms of independence, I don't think that anybody expects anybody to buy me. The fact of the matter is, what I can do here is I can bring jobs and I can bring housing and I can help the school system.

BADILLO -- Mr. Bloomberg has been hiding behind $30 million of commercials. And now that the booklet reveals who the real Bloomberg is, The Daily News reports today that Mr. Bloomberg's lawyers, Willkie Farr & Gallagher, have threatened her and told her not to open her mouth to let people know that in fact everything that is in that book is the truth and that there is more behind it. I call upon Mr. Bloomberg to call his lawyers off. Let the woman who wrote the book tell the public who you really are. And if that happens, people are not going to vote for a $30 million commercial. They're going to vote for a real person with experience. They're going to vote for my candidacy.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael R. Bloomberg and Herman Badillo, the Republicans running for mayor, touched on topics yesterday from Mr. Bloomberg's self-financed campaign to the faltering economy. (James Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In America; 
Obscuring The Real Issues

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
All four candidates in the Democratic primary will tell you that the last thing they want is an ethnically polarized race for their party's mayoral nomination.
 But despite the civil tone of this year's campaign, and the best stated intentions of Mark Green, Fernando Ferrer, Alan Hevesi and Peter Vallone, the politics of polarization are threatening to take center stage yet again. 
 In a televised debate yesterday, Mr. Vallone, the City Council speaker, accused Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, of using tactics that were racially divisive. 
A little background.
Of all the candidates running in this mayoral season, Mr. Green, the city's public advocate, appeared to be gathering the most diverse group of supporters. Polls showed him doing especially well among black voters. But a recent surge by Mr. Ferrer, fueled in part by the endorsement of the Rev. Al Sharpton, appears to be eroding Mr. Green's black support. 
A month ago, a poll by the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion showed Mr. Green favored by 48 percent of black voters and Mr. Ferrer by 14 percent. But a new Marist poll, released last Friday, showed Mr. Ferrer outpolling Mr. Green among blacks by 47 to 30 percent.
Mr. Ferrer has tried mightily from the beginning to forge a coalition of black and Hispanic voters. And while he has said repeatedly that he never intended to exclude white voters, several aspects of his campaign have combined to make non-Hispanic whites wary.
Mr. Ferrer has been the candidate most critical of the policies of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. He has anointed himself the champion of the "other New York," which is made up, he says, of residents who have not done well during the Giuliani years. He made it clear for months that he craved the endorsement of Mr. Sharpton, who is still seen by many whites as a symbol of divisiveness. And he has recently been sharply critical of former Police Commissioner William Bratton, an early architect of Mr. Giuliani's crime-fighting strategies who is now a staunch Green ally.
The polls have shown Mr. Ferrer stuck in single digits among white voters. Last week's Marist poll showed him favored by just 9 percent of whites, and just 6 percent of Jewish voters.
For several months the polls showed Mr. Ferrer, Mr. Vallone and Mr. Hevesi all lagging behind Mr. Green, with no clear indication of who was running second. But recent polls, taken in the aftermath of Mr. Sharpton's endorsement, have shown Mr. Ferrer in a statistical dead heat for first place with Mr. Green.
Mr. Vallone, running well behind in the latest polls, said during the debate that Mr. Ferrer's repeated references to the "other New York" encouraged racial polarization. "While I know it's not done intentionally on Freddy's part," said Mr. Vallone, using Mr. Ferrer's nickname, "when you are talking about a divided city, suddenly it becomes us against them." 
Later, as if for emphasis, Mr. Vallone said, "What you're doing is dividing the city."
Mr. Ferrer again denied that his tactics were divisive, and he angrily accused Mr. Vallone of trying to "inflame divisions."
However the election goes tomorrow -- keeping in mind that Mr. Vallone and Mr. Hevesi still have a shot at a runoff -- it would be a shame if ethnic politics, a dominant and corrosive force in so many recent elections, trumped the important issues currently facing the city.
Above all, the next mayor will almost certainly have to deal with tough fiscal and economic conditions. The Wall Street bubble that gave the Giuliani administration such a fun ride is history. Unemployment is rising. Budget gaps are looming. And big municipal unions -- think cops, think teachers -- are clamoring for raises.
A report on the city's budget from Comptroller Hevesi's office two months ago said, "In the last few years the city has used its record budget surpluses to address short-term budget problems, thereby leaving long-term (structural) budget imbalances unaddressed. Once the surplus disappears, the city will be forced to address out-year gaps by cutting vital services."
The polarizing issues are the easiest to talk and write about. But it's the other issues -- like the budget, and schools, and safe neighborhoods and affordable housing -- that get to the heart and soul of day-to-day life in a great city.

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGNING FOR MAYOR: THE REPUBLICANS; 
Joke Book Proves Bloomberg Is Unfit, Badillo Says in Debate

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

 BODY:
With the campaign drawing to a close and no money for television advertisements, Herman Badillo yesterday used the only televised debate of the Republican primary to try to cast doubt on the character of his opponent, Michael R. Bloomberg.
 Mr. Badillo suggested that his rival was not fit to be mayor because of off-color remarks attributed to Mr. Bloomberg that are included in a booklet of quotations compiled 11 years ago. 
 Mr. Bloomberg answered questions about the booklet -- a birthday gift from some employees at his communications company in 1990 -- that were posed by the moderator, Gabe Pressman of WNBC-TV. But Mr. Bloomberg would not be drawn into a direct exchange about the booklet's contents with Mr. Badillo, who devoted his entire closing statement to the subject. 
"It doesn't reflect me," Mr. Bloomberg said of the assortment of jokes and aphorisms, many of them crude and insulting to women, Jews and gays. "I apologize if anybody's offended by it. But I didn't say those things. I didn't write the book."
Mr. Badillo described the items in the booklet as unforgivable and said that Mr. Bloomberg should pay the highest political price for them.
"If these remarks were made by any politician, he'd be driven out of office," Mr. Badillo said.
Given another opportunity by Mr. Pressman to respond, Mr. Bloomberg said: "It was in a book written by somebody else. Let's go on to the issues. Come on."
The offensive by Mr. Badillo came in the final 48 hours of a Republican contest between one of New York City's most veteran politicians and its biggest-name political newcomer. Mr. Bloomberg, a billionaire businessman running for office for the first time, has swamped Mr. Badillo, a former Bronx borough president and congressman making his fourth bid for mayor. 
Mr. Bloomberg's fortune has enabled him to run a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign that has dominated the television and radio airwaves.
Mr. Bloomberg also agreed to only two face-to-face encounters with Mr. Badillo, giving Mr. Badillo a small window of opportunity to challenge his opponent in person. 
In yesterday's 30-minute debate, Mr. Pressman posed a broad range of questions about topics other than the birthday booklet, including education, the economy, housing and the Republican Party. 
Responding to a query about open government, both candidates said they would remove the fence around City Hall. Mr. Bloomberg pledged to tear it down on his first day in office.
In the event of a worsening economic downturn, Mr. Bloomberg said that "you cannot raise taxes under any circumstances," a statement that goes beyond what he said in the only other Republican debate, an Aug. 31 exchange that was broadcast on WNYC-AM. In that debate, Mr. Bloomberg said that raising taxes would be bad economic policy but that he could not "prudently promise" not to do so.
Mr. Badillo repeated his pledge not to raise taxes and suggested that he would be the better of the two candidates in managing the city's economic problems because of his experience as deputy mayor in the 1970's, when the city endured its worst fiscal crisis. Mr. Bloomberg, who insisted that he was a superior manager, drew attention to Mr. Badillo's onetime support for a bankruptcy strategy.
"My recollection is that back then there were some elected officials that even recommended New York City go bankrupt," Mr. Bloomberg said. 
Seated side by side in dark suits in the WNBC studio at Rockefeller Center, the two candidates appeared formal and cool during the live broadcast, only occasionally picking up on each other's remarks and rarely catching each other's gaze. At the end, they briefly shook hands before going their separate ways to speak with reporters.
In his closing statement, Mr. Bloomberg said the election was about three things: leadership, accountability and independence.
"The fact of the matter is, what I can do here is I can bring jobs and I can bring housing and I can help the school system," Mr. Bloomberg said.
In his final remarks, Mr. Badillo referred to an article in yesterday's Daily News and called on Mr. Bloomberg to allow the editor of the booklet, Elisabeth DeMarse, to come forward and clear the air about its origin and contents.
The Daily News reported that Ms. DeMarse, a former employee of Bloomberg L.P., had been contacted by lawyers for the company and reminded that she had signed a confidentiality agreement when she accepted a severance package.
Reached late last night at a hotel near Palm Beach, Fla., Ms. DeMarse said, "I cannot answer any questions or comment on Bloomberg, the man or the company. I'm sorry and good luck." She then hung up.
Ms. DeMarse is quoted in an article about the booklet in the current issue of New York magazine, but she has declined requests for an interview from other publications.
"Let the woman who wrote the book tell the public who you really are," Mr. Badillo said. "And if that happens, people are not going to vote for a $30 million commercial. They're going to vote for a real person with experience."
In speaking to reporters, Mr. Bloomberg said the severance agreement with Ms. DeMarse was a standard practice at many companies. He said that he did not ask the lawyers to contact Ms. DeMarse, but in doing so, they were doing "what they're supposed to do." 
"We have an agreement with former employees: we can't talk about them and they don't talk about the company," he said. "And that's the agreement. And we'll stick by our agreement. We certainly are not going to talk about anybody." 
The Bloomberg campaign has cast the last-minute surfacing of the booklet as a political cheap shot and has sought to distance Mr. Bloomberg from it. He has for the most part stayed above the fray, even declining to pick up on a suggestion by Mr. Pressman that he may have been the victim of a dirty trick.
"I don't want to characterize things," Mr. Bloomberg said.
The 32-page booklet purports to be an "unauthorized collection of unauthorized sayings" by Mr. Bloomberg. It was compiled by Ms. DeMarse and other employees at Bloomberg L.P., apparently as a gag gift for his birthday in 1990. 
The booklet came to light last week because of an article in The New York Post that quoted an advance copy of the New York magazine article.
Mr. Badillo insisted that Mr. Bloomberg was guilty of sexual harassment because of the demeaning references to women in the booklet.
"These 32 pages bring out who the real person is," Mr. Badillo said. "And that real person, as a matter of fact, as a lawyer, I am telling you, is guilty of sexual harassment because the remarks he made about women would be considered sexual harassment in any company."
For Mr. Badillo, whose campaign was last week denied $1 million in campaign matching funds it intended to use for advertisements, the birthday booklet is being embraced as a great hope for defeating Mr. Bloomberg. 
"It is never too late for people to change their minds," Mr. Badillo told reporters after the debate.
Speaking later to reporters during a campaign stop at the Third Avenue Fair on the Upper East Side, Mr. Bloomberg defended his company's record on sexual harassment, which included several lawsuits by women that have been settled, withdrawn or dismissed, according to court records. 
"I don't know what these guys are talking about," Mr. Bloomberg said. "We take it phenomenally seriously. And we have a stellar record for 20 years with 8,000 employees."
Mr. Bloomberg went on to Brooklyn and Queens later in the day, where his stops included the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society Celebration in Asser Levy Seaside Park and the Great Irish Fair in Coney Island, which Gov. George E. Pataki also visited. A spokeswoman for the governor said it was a coincidence that he was there at the same time as Mr. Bloomberg.
Mr. Badillo spent most of the afternoon meeting voters and handing out literature at the Third Avenue Fair.

HEADLINE: MEDIA; 
80% of Germany's Cable Systems Selling Abroad

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Sept. 9 

 BODY:
In back-to-back transactions, one announced last week and one that could be announced as early as Monday, two Denver-based dealmakers are paying about $7 billion to control 80 percent of the cable television systems in Germany.
 On Tuesday, Liberty Media announced an agreement to buy six regional cable systems from Deutsche Telekom for about 5.5 billion euros ($5 million). Liberty, headed by John C. Malone and based in Denver, will have 10 million cable subscribers in Germany and become the biggest cable operator in Europe. 
 Deutsche Telekom also plans to sell one of its biggest systems for about $2.7 billion to partnerships headed by Richard Callahan, a former executive at US West and a longtime cable investor in Europe who already owns one system in Germany and others in Spain and Belgium. Mr. Callahan heads Callahan Associates International, based in London, but spends much time in Denver. 
The two deals come after tortuous negotiations with Deutsche Telekom, which had been talking with bidders for more than two years but which became a desperate seller after stock prices for telephone and cable companies crashed.
Between them, the companies will have 14 million of Germany's 17 million cable subscribers, making them the dominant cable providers in the country. They will also have more control than the German telephone company originally planned to surrender, and some analysts say the price was low.
The risks are high. The two companies will have to spend more than $1 billion each to modernize the German networks, many of which are more than 20 years old and offer little more than about 30 channels. Both Mr. Malone and Mr. Callahan think they can make their real money by using the networks to offer telephone service, high-speed Internet access and a broader selection of channels.
 But even if that plan is valid, Germany presents some singular headaches. Unlike cable operators in most other countries, Deutsche Telekom had direct connections to only about one-third of its customers. For the rest, it supplied its basic package of services to scores of local distributors and housing associations, which in turn control the cables that reach into homes.
Both Liberty and Callahan are on the prowl to buy up the local operators, or at least to cut new deals with them. But even so, the average German subscriber pays less than $15 a month for cable services and, thus far at least, pays for few frills.
 "To offer attractive new services to the customer base, all of these companies have to go through quite a challenging and expensive upgrade," said Frank Knowles, a high-yield bond analyst who follows European cable companies at Merrill Lynch. "It is a huge project."
 Mr. Callahan, in a telephone interview from Denver, said the German market had ample room to grow. "There is great potential to bring in new programming," he said. And Germany has a big domestic television and film production business that can be tapped for added material, he said. Beyond that, he is counting on telephone and high-speed Internet services to provide important revenue. "Germany is getting pretty close to hypergrowth in the Internet," he said.
Liberty, which was controlled by AT&T but separated from it last month, owns more than $50 billion in shares of media and telecommunication companies.
On Friday, in a meeting with analysts in New York, company executives said they might finance their expansion in Europe by selling billions of dollars' worth of shares in Cendant, Motorola, Sprint PCS and Viacom. 
 "Cash is king and we think there are a number of opportunities to add to our assets," said Robert Bennett, the chief executive of Liberty. Mr. Malone told the group that Liberty might create a separate tracking stock for its international holdings.
 Until recently, Deutsche Telekom wanted to keep a considerable amount of control. It wanted to retain 45 percent of the stock in its cable systems and apparently hoped to cash in if the buyers ever took their systems public. But the crash in telecommunication and cable stocks -- including Deutsche Telecom shares, which on Friday dropped below their original offering price back in 1996 -- forced the German company into concessions.
 As a result, Liberty is acquiring 100 percent of six systems, including ones that serve Berlin, Hamburg and the affluent state of Bavaria. But most of the systems are in Eastern Germany, which is poorer than the west and is mired in double-digit unemployment. 
Callahan will acquire 60 percent of one system and 55 percent of another. But in contrast to Deutsche Telekom's initial demands, Callahan received an option to buy out the remaining Telekom stakes as well.
 Both companies have a lot of work to do. Besides upgrading the old networks, analysts say, the purchase of or the cutting of new deals with scores of local operators is essential for making a profit.
 That is not an insurmountable problem. Liberty effectively controls another European cable operator, United Pan-European Communications, which is the local provider in several areas it serves. Another big local operator, Tele-Columbus, is for sale and will probably end up being divided by Callahan and Liberty. 
 But the costs will be high. Mr. Callahan says that upgrading systems will take about 350 euros, or $318, per household. That would add up to $1.5 billion over the next several years, though Mr. Callahan said the company may decide not to upgrade all the neighborhoods.
 To finance all that, Mr. Callahan has lined up a group of private equity investors that include Blackstone Capital Partners and Bank of America. But it is also relying heavily on high-yield junk bonds and credit lines.

LENGTH: 838 words

HEADLINE: Power Politics in the Senate 

 BODY:
This has not been a good year for clear thinking about energy. First came the Cheney-Bush "national energy strategy," which presupposed that the country was in the grips of a terrible energy shortage and that the only sure way to address it was to drill aggressively for more oil and gas, remove various regulatory impediments to the burning of coal and build 1,300 new power plants. The House of Representatives swallowed the Cheney-Bush scenario whole and produced an alarmingly unbalanced energy bill with $33 billion in tax breaks -- $27 billion for traditional energy producers, only $6 billion for conservation.
 The Senate must now set things right, presumably at lower cost; even the Bush administration was appalled by the House's price tag. What this country wants is an energy policy that encourages oil and gas exploration without corrupting the environment, finds more efficient ways to use the energy we have and begins planning for the day when the fossil fuels we take for granted are less abundant at home or abroad. This will not be an easy task; energy politics gets nasty (and local) in a hurry. In the House, for example, many normally reliable friends of the environment voted in favor of opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to the oil companies and against increasing fuel economy standards because they were terrified of retaliation from organized labor if they did otherwise. 
 This is a rare chance for the Senate to exercise statesmanship while reaping political rewards as well. Polls show that the two issues on which President Bush is most vulnerable are energy and the environment. The Senate cannot lose if it produces a plan more balanced and enlightened than his. It will be up to Jeff Bingaman, the chairman of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, to devise such a plan. Then Tom Daschle, the Senate majority leader, must sell it to his colleagues.
There are three areas where the House bill requires complete overhaul.
Improving Efficiency: The House bill dedicates $5.9 billion in various subsidies for energy efficiency and renewable energy, versus about $27 billion for the coal, oil and gas industries. It creates modest tax credits for people who buy hybrid cars, for builders of more energy-efficient homes and for manufacturers of some energy-saving appliances. But it does nothing to improve the efficiency of one of the biggest energy users of all, air-conditioners, and it is here that the Senate could usefully resurrect the tough standards imposed by the Clinton administration that President Bush is trying to roll back.
The most important and courageous step, however, and one the House refused to take, would be to close the so-called S.U.V. loophole, under which large vehicles like sport utility vehicles and minivans are classified as light trucks and thus escape the 27.5-mile-per-gallon standard required of ordinary cars. Closing that loophole, which Detroit is perfectly capable of doing, would result in oil savings of one million barrels a day by 2015, more than the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge could be expected to yield in the same time frame. 
Increasing Supply: At the heart of the House bill is a proposal to open up the refuge's coastal plain to oil exploration. That would yield only six months' to a year's worth of oil, even at favorable prices, while disrupting an ecological treasure. Industry assertions that drilling would create 750,000 new jobs have been widely discredited.
There are other steps the committee can take to increase supply. One is to see whether there is an environmentally safe way of tapping and transporting the vast supplies of natural gas at Alaska's Prudhoe Bay, where the oil industry is already firmly ensconced. Such a scheme would be expensive, and in some quarters controversial, but it makes a lot more sense than invading the refuge, the national forests, the Rocky Mountain Front and other sensitive areas on which the oil industry and the Cheney task force have cast a covetous eye. 
Improving Reliability: The House was so fixated on subsidizing traditional energy producers, including the coal-fired utilities, that it paid no attention to the way electricity is regulated and transported. That was a huge oversight that Mr. Bingaman says he intends to remedy. As the now-receding California crisis demonstrated, electricity deregulation has not gone smoothly. There are transmission problems in the West and Northeast. Power does not move easily from one region to another, and the system is full of disincentives that discourage smaller -- and potentially more efficient -- producers of power from entering the market.
None of this will come easy for Mr. Bingaman and Mr. Daschle. They must resist President Bush's seductive and specious argument that opening up new areas for oil and gas drilling and easing environmental regulations will provide an immediate economic boost. And powerful corporate and labor forces are arrayed against them. But the nation would like them to give it their best shot.

HEADLINE: A CONVERSATION WITH/Larry Gilbert; 
Plotting an Aerial Attack On Marauding Fire Ants

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA DREIFUS 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex. 

 BODY:
On a recent morning, Dr. Lawrence E. Gilbert, a professor of integrative biology at the University of Texas and director of its Brackenridge Field Laboratory, was standing over a glass tank at in his office, watching a swarm of Brazilian phorid flies make buzzing attacks on some very unhappy South American fire ants.
 "The flies are really cool, being able to fly backward, flying rings around these ants," Dr. Gilbert said with enthusiasm. "They are wonderful acrobats -- just torturing those ants! You feel sorry for the ants when you see the flies attack them. Or at least, I do. But not too sorry." 
 Larry Gilbert, 59, is a great fan of the phorid fly, a tiny gray insect more formally called Pseudacteon tricuspis, because he believes that it and its kin may be an answer to one of the most troubling pest infestations in American environmental history. 
For at least 60 years, an aggressive red fire ant, originally from Brazil, has been thriving in the American South, spreading through Texas, and attacking indigenous birds, lizards and other small animals.
Dr. Gilbert was among the first to notice that phorids appeared to keep fire ants in check in South America, and he is hoping that they will do the same in the United States.
So he has been importing phorids from Brazil and Argentina and breeding them in his laboratory, then releasing them in tests. He has also been singing their praises to all who will listen.
When not on the fire ant trail, Dr. Gilbert is one of the world's experts on the passion vine butterfly. 

Q. Why should the ordinary American give any thought to a red fire ant indigenous to Brazil and Argentina?

A. Because they are here. They can be found from Florida to California, from the East Coast to the Mexican border of Texas.
Red imported fire ants are able to consume or outcompete many organisms. When fire ants are dense in pastures and cows are dropping new calves, some of these are just going to be covered with stinging workers, even blinded.
Quail and duck hatchlings and even young alligators in their nests are vulnerable to death by fire ant. It is widely thought that the endangered horned lizard has declined because of fire ants.
In addition to reducing biodiversity and injuring livestock, these fire ants damage electrical systems and incite increased use of pesticides. The economic cost of them in Texas last year exceeded $300 million.

Q. How did the fire ants get to these shores, anyway?

A. They were probably on board a ship that came from South America in the 1920's and docked in Mobile, Ala. They may have entered in the soil of a potted palm. Nobody really knows. It was Prof. Edward O. Wilson of Harvard, as a high school student in Alabama, who discovered the invasion.
Now, fire ants in their native ecosystem are not a bad thing. Indeed, in South America, these very same red fire ants are thought of as nothing more than a nuisance.
In Brazil, the attitude is, Why do you consider these a major pest?

Q. Are the fire ants native to Texas more docile than the South American kind?

A. They are not more docile, but they are no problem -- unless you are silly enough to stand on one of their mounds. In that case, they'll sting. During the 1970's, when the South American species moved into areas of Texas I knew well, my first thought was, Why is this new fire ant, which looks virtually the same as the native variety, such a pest?

Q. When people first noticed the invasion of fire ants, pesticides were used against them. You have said that this early chemical approach was a mistake. Why?

A. For one thing, no one was thinking about what broad-spectrum pesticides would do to native ants. An infected area would just be blasted. And guess which resurged better, native ants or these South American ones? The imported fire ants did.

Q. How exactly did fire ants become your passion?

A. They are not my passion; solving the fire ant problem ecologically is. And my involvement with that was a gradual process.
In 1972, after graduate school at Stanford, I returned to the University of Texas. I took a field course into East Texas, where I was immediately struck by the density of the imported fire ants' mounds in rights of way through the pine forests.
So I had my class do a survey of ants. We baited them with pieces of tuna and found that imported fire ants were virtually the only ants exploiting the food.
In the early 1980's, I became responsible for the Brackenridge Field Laboratory of the University of Texas -- 90 acres in Austin -- which at the time harbored over 50 ant species. 
A year later, imported fire ants invaded the field station. As a project, a student began mapping the invasion. We expected to see scattered hot spots among the native species where winged queens came in and set up shop.
But, instead, we saw a solid front of fire ants spread over the area like a tank invasion, replacing the native system. This observation led to the question, Why doesn't the native fire ant do this? Which ultimately led to research comparing the native fire ants with the non-native ones, and an interest in how the imported fire ant gets along in Brazil.

Q. Did you go to Brazil to see how fire ants get along there?

A. Yes. In Brazil, it wasn't easy to find fire ant mounds. Plus, if you kicked a mound there, lots of tiny flies -- phorid flies -- showed up to attack the ants.
So in 1994, we asked the question, What happens if you put some food on the ground in Brazil -- who gets it? The answer is, It's not fire ants, if phorid flies show up to attack them.
Then, with Brazilian colleagues, we did the experiment of putting out food, then removing the phorid flies as they arrived; fire ants would dominate the food as they do in in Texas. And if you didn't remove the flies, other native Brazilian ants usually won.
That got us thinking, What might happen if we introduced Brazilian phorid flies in Texas? Would that impose the same stress on the imported ants here and make them less of a pest?

Q. Will just one species of the phorid flies solve the imported fire ant problem in North America?

A. We'll probably need a suite of them to do the job. We saw in South America there were about 15 to 16 species of these flies that may be appropriate to our problem here.
They all disrupt the behavior of those worker fire ants responsible for bringing food and protecting the colony. Late in '94, we got permission from the U.S. Department of Agriculture to bring some of the flies back, and we started testing to see which of them would discriminate between the native and the imported fire ants.
We have been mass-rearing one phorid species that we've been releasing in Texas. But since 1996, we've had four years of very harsh drought here in Texas. Even the fire ants have suffered, making life doubly difficult for the fly that depends entirely on its host ant.
Nevertheless, phorid populations are established in the field in several Texas locations.
It's going to take a break from drought for them to build up. The U.S.D.A. is releasing the same phorid in Florida and the Southeast, and that looks promising -- it's spreading. But we've just released one species. Locally in Brazil, there are five, six species of flies attacking fire ants. So I don't think this one species is the ticket.

Q. Are you worried about turning another foreign creature loose in the North American environment? Things could go wrong.

A. One of the nightmares is that you might introduce something that will create more problems than you're going to solve, which has happened in some situations and has given the field of biological control some black eyes.
The thing about fire ants is that they are moving across the country and knocking out a lot of native species. They are a big mortality factor for endangered birds around here. So biological control with phorid flies seems worth trying, given that the greatest risk of these specialized flies might be that they will attack native fire ants.
But those local ants are going extinct anyway as the imported ones move in.

Q. Did you ever see "Them," the 1954 Warner Brothers science fiction thriller? In it, giant ants, mutated by nuclear testing, take over New Mexico and come to their final end in the sewers of Los Angeles. The film closes with the suggestion that there may be further insect horrors lurking out there. Were they thinking of imported red fire ants?

A. (Laughing.) Well, I saw that as a kid. Those ants were 10 feet tall, weren't they? I guess that's how a fire ant invasion looks to small animals in the ecosystem. But in terms of their menace to humans -- let's not exaggerate.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Lawrence E. Gilbert says red imported fire ants can "consume or outcompete many organisms," and he is studying ways to combat them. (George Brainard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Protect Sharks? Attacks Fuel Old Argument 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
To hear commercial fishermen tell it, fishing curbs are leaving sharks free to prey on bathers.
 Scientists see things another way. They now wonder if overfishing of prized shark species is letting unwanted killers like bull sharks, implicated in several recent attacks, thrive as never before. 
 Neither theory rules out the other. If both are right, it is possible that federal rules and commercial fishing practices are interacting in unexpected ways to create new dangers in coastal waters. Scientists and federal agencies are preparing to study the potential risk. 
Among other things, the new debate highlights a longstanding dilemma of marine science: the possibility that changes in one part of an ecosystem can have profound, often unanticipated effects elsewhere.
The main restrictions on shark fishing date from 1993, when the federal government began an aggressive program to protect dwindling Atlantic populations from commercial and recreational fishermen. It set stiff quotas and ruled out catches altogether for 19 species, including the great white, a ruthless predator often blamed in human attacks.
But after sharks killed a 10-year-old boy in Virginia Beach and a 28-year-old man in North Carolina over Labor Day weekend, fishing groups have renewed their war against the restrictions, arguing that myopic state and federal officials are fostering the attacks.
"They've set up a bait-fish preserve and a sanctuary for sharks," said Bob Jones, executive director of the Southeastern Fisheries Association, an advocacy group for commercial fishermen based in Tallahassee, Fla. "I've never been as frightened of going in the water as I am now."
Most marine biologists dismiss such fears. Attacks are down in number globally this year, they say, and rising human populations account for most historical increases. They add that sharks are still so overfished that many populations are in danger of collapse or facing extinction.
"Fishermen are playing upon public fear to make an economic argument," said Sonja V. Fordhman, a shark fisheries expert at the Ocean Conservancy, a private group in Washington.
If anyone is to blame, the scientists say, it may be the commercial fishermen who may be altering things for the worse.
Heavy fishing of commercially attractive shark species like sandbars and blacktips, marine biologists argue, could have the unintended side effect of helping bull sharks, which are cited in many attacks. In theory, declines of prized species could free ocean resources for killers like bulls, expanding their ranks.
"Sharks are key parts of ocean ecology," said Dr. Ellen K. Pikitch, a shark expert at the Wildlife Conservation Society, based at the Bronx Zoo. "If you mess around with some parts, you're going to have consequences in others."
Dr. Robert E. Hueter, director of the Center for Shark Research at the Mote Marine Laboratory in Sarasota, Fla., agreed, saying he worried that fishery disruptions could endanger people. 
"The fishery has severely depleted the sandbar, but not the bull," he said. "Pound for pound, the bull is the most aggressive. The question is whether we have been culling our populations, removing the less aggressive for the most."
Last year, bull sharks were suspected of killing a man in shallow waters near St. Petersburg, Fla., and attacking a swimmer in Gulf Shores, Ala., tearing off his arm. This July at a beach in Pensacola, Fla., a bull attacked an 8-year-old boy, severing his arm before the boy's uncle dragged him to shore. Scientists also suspect bull sharks in the recent attacks that killed the boy in Virginia and the man in North Carolina.
Bull sharks worry scientists because they are especially vicious. Unlike some sharks that bite humans by mistake and quickly let go, bulls target people as food. And unlike most other sharks, they thrive in fresh and brackish water, swimming into rivers, shallows and coastal estuaries -- closer to people.
Alarms are also ringing because some of the attacks this summer occurred along the Gulf Coast and mid-Atlantic states, places usually at relatively low risk of shark attack.
William Hogarth, director of the National Marine Fisheries Service, which assesses fish stocks and regulates fishermen, said his agency was concerned about the strikes. "There's a lot of possible factors at work that we have to look into," he said.
He noted, though, that large coastal sharks in Atlantic waters were still declining in number or stabilizing overall at levels only a quarter to a half of what they were as recently as the 1970's. The populations still vulnerable to collapse, experts said, include whites, duskies and hammerheads.
Dr. Pikitch, of the Wildlife Conservation Society, and Dr. Hueter, of the Mote Marine Laboratory, have teamed up to study whether fishery upsets are favoring bulls around Florida, whose beaches and waterways have long seen the greatest number of shark attacks on people. There were 37 attacks last year, a record. So far this year there have been 29 attacks in Florida.
Experts agree that the main factor behind the rising number of assaults is the growing human populations and the increasing use of beaches and coastal areas for swimming and water sports, including surfing.
Dr. George H. Burgess, a shark biologist at the University of Florida, has analyzed how Florida's skyrocketing human population during the 20th century, to 16 million people, closely matches rising shark attack rates. From a low of two to five attacks in Florida per decade, assaults soared to 180 in the 1990's.
At the same time, the global market for some sharks has exploded, driven by a developing taste for shark steaks and Asia's love of shark-fin soup. Experts say fins can bring fishermen $100 a pound or more.
"We saw immediate reductions in the numbers of sharks on the East Coast," said Dr. Carl Safina, author of "Song for the Blue Ocean," a 1997 book about global fisheries. "By the early 90's, they were down 80 to 90 percent."
Florida took the lead in establishing curbs. In 1992, it set a limit of one shark per person, or two per boat, for shark fishermen in state waters. These areas extend three miles out on the state's Atlantic side and nine miles on the Gulf side.
Alarmed at dwindling stocks, the federal government in 1993 imposed rules on the whole East Coast shark fishery, cutting the take in half, to 8.5 million pounds in 1999 from an estimated 17.2 million pounds in 1989. Last year, it expanded the restrictions to put 19 species off limits entirely, including whites, sand tigers and longfin makos.
Infuriated, commercial fishermen have sued successfully to stop further cuts, and ocean conservationists have countersued, unsuccessfully so far, to let federal cutbacks proceed.
In the glare of publicity over recent shark attacks, the fishermen gained an ally in Sean Paige, a fellow at the Competitive Enterprise Institute. Last month in an article titled "The Jaws of Government" in The National Review Online, he argued that state and federal curbs had inadvertently created a sanctuary for deadly predators in coastal waters.
Although many scientists have publicly questioned that theory, a few have voiced support. "In my opinion," said Dr. Michael L. Parrack, a research biologist in Miami for the National Marine Fisheries Service, "a refuge has been recently created off the east coast of Florida and large fish are stacking up, sharks included."
The alternative theory of marine biologists points a finger at the commercial fisherman, arguing that heavy fishing of sandbars and blacktips, the top market sharks, could be having unforeseen repercussions in ocean ecology that favor bulls, which most fishermen scorn. 
The problem is, neither side can now produce good data to back its case. It is notoriously difficult to measure changes in fish populations over time, much less the subtleties of their interactions with other species and the complex cycles of marine food chains. So scientists acknowledge that proving their overfishing theory will take hard work.
Dr. Pikitch, of the Wildlife Conservation Society, said that adult sandbars might feed on young bulls and that sandbar declines might thus have the "unintended consequence" of benefiting bulls.
Dr. Hueter said blacktips overlapped bulls ecologically because both were comfortable in warm, shallow waters. Young bulls, he said, may gain from blacktip declines by having less competition for prey fish like mullet, ladyfish and sea trout. He said he was searching for historical records on bull populations, looking for an upturn. Studies of current populations also help, he said.
Helping drive the inquiry, Dr. Hueter said, is anecdotal information on rising numbers of bulls. Tarpon fishermen, he said, are "experiencing a tremendous loss of fish because the bulls are attacking."
Russell H. Hudson, a spokesman for the commercial shark industry, belittled the bull theory. "It's a false argument," he said. "These academics don't know doodah and want to study this stuff forever. They're anti-commercial and pro getting all these federal grants."
Dr. Burgess of the University of Florida, who runs a database known as the International Shark Attack File, said his information suggested that identifiable bull attacks on people during the 1990's had risen annually from one to three. But he cautioned that such small numbers were statistically insignificant and that only further study could establish any real trend.
Jack Musick, head of shark research for the State of Virginia, said the Labor Day killings in Virginia Beach and North Carolina both appeared to be the work of bulls. But he, too, urged caution about the idea that commercial hunting was unintentionally letting the killers thrive.
"It may be that populations of bulls are not as depressed as much as other sharks," he said. "That doesn't mean they've exploded."
Dr. Safina, founder of the Living Oceans marine conservation program of the National Audubon Society, said the bull thesis was plausible and testable. But even if true, he added, any trend in attacks paled in comparison with the tens of thousands of deaths every year from car accidents and handguns.
When it comes to shark attacks, he said, "Your chances of being bitten are still about one in a million -- it's still very much a freak accident."

HEADLINE: Times Names Andrew Rosenthal As Assistant Managing Editor 

 BODY:
The appointment of Andrew Rosenthal as an assistant managing editor of The New York Times was announced yesterday by Howell Raines, the executive editor. Mr. Rosenthal, who was the paper's foreign editor, will coordinate daily coverage by the paper's principal news desks.
 Roger Cohen, a foreign correspondent who moved into editing last month as Mr. Rosenthal's deputy, will now head the foreign desk as acting editor, Mr. Raines said. 
 Mr. Rosenthal, 45, joined The Times in 1987 from The Associated Press, where he had been a Denver correspondent, a foreign desk editor in New York and eventually Moscow bureau chief. 
At The Times, he began as a Washington correspondent covering the political role of media and advertising and then the 1988 presidential campaign of Michael S. Dukakis. He later covered the Pentagon and the White House. He became Washington editor in 1992, directing coverage of the 1994 and 1996 elections, and foreign editor in 1997. 
A graduate of the University of Denver, Mr. Rosenthal was born in New Delhi, when his father, A. M. Rosenthal -- later executive editor of The Times -- was bureau chief there. 
Mr. Cohen, 46, joined The Times in 1990 as a reporter and became a foreign correspondent in 1991. He has served as European economic correspondent, Balkan bureau chief during the Bosnian war, a Paris correspondent and, most recently, chief Berlin correspondent. 
Earlier, Mr. Cohen reported for The Wall Street Journal from Rome, Beirut, Miami and Rio de Janeiro. He has also worked for Reuters as a correspondent in Brussels and Rome.
A graduate of Oxford University, Mr. Cohen is the author of "Hearts Grown Brutal: Sagas of Sarajevo," an account of the violent break-up of Yugoslavia, and the co-author of "In the Eye of the Storm," a biography of Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf.

HEADLINE: Review/Fashion; 
Nilsson, New at Blass, Shows Talent, Not Ego

BYLINE:  By GINIA BELLAFANTE 

 BODY:
For the most part, fashion isn't the place to turn for life lessons a great-grandmother could impart -- you will find no one handing out the manual on the virtues of humility, civility or largesse. But every now and then from the world of the mink purse some wisdom manages to leak. Fashion is just the place to learn, or be reminded, that those in possession of the most prodigious egos are generally those in possession of the fewest actual gifts. The designers who truly merit the name genius, the Hussein Chalayans, say, are never the ones who turn up in movie cameos or channeling George Clooney in ads for Absolut.
 Judging from how hesitantly he approached the runway at the finale of his first show for Bill Blass yesterday, it seems that Lars Nilsson belongs to the school of the unassuming. Just before his quietly exquisite 52 looks were presented at the Celeste Bartos Forum of the New York Public Library, a socialite seated in the front row leaned over to a neighbor and remarked, "You know, he's the only guy in fashion whose modesty is disproportionate to his talent." 
 Mr. Nilsson is in fact so skilled with a needle and thread that few would fault him if he chose to cultivate a greater sense of self-regard. A native of Orebro, a small city in Sweden, Mr. Nilsson, 35, studied sewing and patternmaking in Stockholm before moving to Paris in 1986 to study at the Ecole de la Chambre Syndicale de la Couture. That training was followed by a decade more in the haute couture ateliers of Christian Lacroix and Dior. Two years ago, he moved to New York to work as a design director at Ralph Lauren.
The career path could not have been better laid out for steering the ship at Blass. What Mr. Nilsson clearly absorbed from the universe of the $50,000 suit is the appeal of tailoring so trenchant and precise that the garments themselves look as though they could cut through a roll of cloth. 
This was exactly the effect rendered when Mr. Nilsson sent a series of wide-leg pinstriped pantsuits down the runway, which seemed to elongate the towering models wearing them into ambulating skyscrapers.
Apparently not a scene maker, Mr. Nilsson, a guy who looks like a physicist in his own well-fitting suit, hasn't spent all that much time in New York, but he has figured out that it isn't Los Angeles. His embellishments appeared economical even if in some instances the embroidery came from Lesage. He turned out evening dresses and ball skirts in pinstriped cotton, one featuring back pockets that called to mind a Claire McCardell kitchen dress. Here we were not looking at what Angelina Jolie might call in for the next Golden Globe Awards.
Mr. Nilsson's clothes suggest that he isn't all that interested in dressing stars or trophy girlfriends with pounds of pave diamonds. Ostensibly, conventional fashion wisdom has it, Carolina Herrera is also too grand for such slumming. But her show yesterday left one wondering just what kind of well-bred Vassar girl at the intersection of youth and middle age was going to sprint over strollers up Madison Avenue to get ahold of tight pants with embroidery blossoming from the crotch.
The real problem with Ms. Herrera's show was evening gowns that gaped, bunched, constricted or in some other way didn't quite manage the proper hug. One exception came in the form of a circle-neck beaded minidress that looked as though it could flatter women who don't look like Sarah Jessica Parker. But when a crepe gown came down the runway on the person of Mini Anden, leaving her backside looking considerably larger than the microscopic reality, one simply left wondering what would happen when it met the body of a fun-loving 36-year-old who missed yoga last week. It would go back on the rack.

(Photographs by Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Economists Lower Forecasts But Do Not Expect a Recession 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Business economists lowered their forecasts for growth for 2001 and 2002 but most say the economy will not slide into recession and should start recovering by the end of the year, a survey showed yesterday.
 A separate report from the Federal Reserve showed that the level of consumer credit outstanding unexpectedly held steady in July after a drop the month before, which had fanned worries that consumers were beginning to rein in their purchases. 
 A panel of 31 professional forecasters sponsored by the National Association for Business Economics cut expectations for business investment and profits, but, highlighting the resilience of consumers, raised 2001 estimates for consumer spending. 
The survey was conducted in the last two weeks of August, before last week's report of a surprising jump in unemployment. The government reported last week that the jobless rate surged to 4.9 percent in August, its highest rate in four years, raising concern that the sharp increase might deal a crushing blow to consumers, whose spending has held up the anemic economy.
The association's panel cut its median forecast for real gross domestic product growth year to year to 1.6 percent from 2 percent in the May forecast. 
The economy slowed to its softest pace in eight years in the second quarter when G.D.P. eased to an annual growth rate of 0.2 percent, down from 5.7 percent growth in the period a year earlier.
The panelists also lowered their estimates for 2002 G.D.P. growth to 2.7 percent, down from the median 3.1 percent growth forecast in May.
The pessimism was driven by the struggles occurring in the business sector, where investment is forecast to contract 2 percent in 2001, a sharp contrast to earlier forecasts of 2.4 percent growth. In 2002, business investment is now expected to grow a modest 1 percent, well below previous estimates for an increase of 4.9 percent.
After-tax corporate profits are now expected to contract 12 percent in 2001 compared with previous estimates of a 3.5 percent decrease. Profits are expected to rise 5 percent next year, compared with earlier expectations of a 6 percent increase.
But the association sounded optimistic about consumption, which makes up two-thirds of the economy. Real consumption expenditures are expected to grow 3 percent in 2001, compared with the 2.7 percent gain estimated earlier. The association still expects 2002 consumption growth of 2.9 percent. 
The Fed report said credit outstanding was virtually unchanged at a seasonally adjusted $1.589 trillion in July.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
A Surprisingly Steady Day for the Major U.S. Markets

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The stock market was a surprise yesterday, rallying from early losses to finish the day little changed.
 The steady performance -- instead of the feared continuation of the sharp declines at the end of last week -- was enough to help European stock markets rebound from their early losses. And longer-term bond prices fell and yields rose as investors saw stocks hold the line and, maybe, thought that the pessimism about the economic outlook might be a little overdone. 
 "Maybe people thought there would be more of a follow-through on equities, and we didn't get it," said Robert V. DiClemente, chief United States economist at Salomon Smith Barney. "The worst hasn't happened yet." 
The Dow Jones industrial average, which plunged 3.5 percent last week, was off just 0.34 point yesterday, after beginning the day down as much as 112 points. It ended the day at 9,605.51.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 7.68 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,695.38, after falling almost 18 points in the morning. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks climbed 6.76 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,092.54, after dropping more than 12 points at the opening of trading. On Friday, the S.& P. 500 became the first major stock index to fall below the lows reached this spring.
The Financial Times stock index in London was off 0.7 percent after rebounding from a 3.4 percent decline before stocks on Wall Street began their own about-face. The CAC 40 index in Paris was also down 0.7 percent, after falling 3.7 percent earlier. And the DAX index in Frankfurt was down 1.3 percent, after coming back from a 4.3 percent decline.
In the American bond market, the price of the Treasury's 10-year note fell 15/32, to 10 18/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 4.84 percent, from 4.78 percent Friday. The yield on the Treasury's two-year note, which had plunged to a record low of 3.49 percent Friday, was unchanged.
The talk from Washington over the weekend of new tax cuts to stimulate the economy may have made some investors worry more about the government surplus shrinking even further and added some to the selling pressure yesterday, analysts said.
But the data that sent the pessimism barometer higher last week was the report Thursday that the nonmanufacturing index of the National Association of Purchasing Management had fallen sharply, indicating that this sector was beginning to feel the brunt of the economic slowdown. That was followed Friday by the news that the unemployment rate in August jumped to 4.9 percent, from 4.5 percent in July. Analysts were expecting that the unemployment rate would just inch up to 4.6 percent.
But Louis Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, said that while the job data got the big headline, the report earlier last week that the purchasing manager's manufacturing index had shot sharply higher was more important. The manufacturing sector, he said in his report to clients this week, is the one that has dragged the economy down and the new data suggests "that the worst is past for much of the factory sector."
On the New York Stock Exchange, the trading volume was a little above average at 1.28 billion. Eastman Kodak, down $1.94, to $43.23; Boeing, off $1.72, to $43.46;, and Alcoa, down $1.65, to $33.80, led the Dow lower. But the declines were all but offset by jumps in other Dow stocks, including SBC Communications, up $2.43, to $43.43; Microsoft, up $2.18, to $57.58; and Merck & Company, up $1.80, to $66.10. The Nasdaq was led higher by Microsoft; Qualcomm, up $1.36, to $50.54; and Dell Computer, up $1.02, to $22.57.
Christine A. Callies, the chief United States investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, said she believed that this sell-off was the "final capitulation" of stocks before they turn around. "I hope today means that people came back from vacation and are taking a more dispassionate view of what is in the economic data," she said. "Because I think the economy is turning."

HEADLINE: Tunnel Vision; 
Plumbing a City's Curiosities in the Name of Art

BYLINE:  By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Like most New Yorkers, Jerome Fortin goes to work on the subway.
 The difference is that from day to day, Mr. Fortin never quite knows which subway line he will ride. Or even which stop might take him closest to his job. 
 One day, it could be the F to Coney Island, where his mission is to track down elusive metallic ice-cream cup lids. (No luck.) Another day, it could be the M to Chinatown to hunt for red plastic bags. (No luck again.) Or the No. 1 to Greenwich Village for phone books. (Jackpot.) Or maybe the L to Williamsburg, where he went one day just to wander, but ended up finding another jackpot: a bin full of leather doodads discarded by a leather belt factory. "They were shaped like stars and hearts," he said.
"It was, to me," he added, "like a treasure."
Mr. Fortin, 29, is not hearing voices that tell him to go find these things. He is not a strange kind of thief or a recycling fanatic. He is not even in waste management, exactly, though that could be one way of describing what he does.
He is an artist from Montreal who moved to New York temporarily at the end of July to work on a project that will appear as part of "Quebec New York 2001," a huge exhibit of the province's culture taking place around New York City beginning this Thursday and continuing through Oct. 7. (Mr. Fortin's art will be on display at the World Financial Center Courtyard Gallery beginning this Friday.)
While he is an artist by profession, what Mr. Fortin has become over the last months is more of a professional subway rider. There are other in the city: motormen, conductors, battery salesmen, buskers, police officers and homeless people, all of whom must ride the subway for their livelihoods.
But Mr. Fortin (pronounced for-TAN) may be one of the only professionals who rides for art.
His sculptures are based around the old European concept of the Wunderkammer, or cabinet of curiosities, a collection of objects, both exotic and mundane, selected according to the tastes and fortunes of their owners, and often cited as a forerunner of modern museums.
But where a 16th-century cabinet might have contained a stuffed iguana next to a Chinese water clock, Mr. Fortin's objects are a little more urban. Matchbooks, cigarette butts, wine corks, beer bottle caps, motor oil jugs, phone books -- and yes, if he could get someone to give him a few dozen, those ubiquitous red Chinatown shopping bags.
He takes these decidedly worthless objects and, spending long days and nights in his studio in Brooklyn, he makes them into objects that appear to be things of great worth. Phone books are made into origami. Bottle caps and MetroCards are made into rings. Plastic oil jugs are sliced and arranged on a board like an Op Art painting.
For the show, all of these painstakingly transformed objects will be stacked on the kind of portable table that street vendors use to sell incense and handbags.
"The more I work until the opening, the more high it will be," said Mr. Fortin, whose French-accented English is good but also highly creative. "I would like to have something very high because New York is very high. But I am a human and I must sleep, you know."
He chose the subway, he said, mostly for artistic reasons -- to get to know the city better, to feel its texture. But the practical reasons were also persuasive: he could not afford to keep a car here and, frankly, probably would have been too scared to drive one anyway.
So he has come to know and even love what can be experienced for the price of a MetroCard. "There was one time a family was making some break dance in the subway," he recalled. "I think this is crazy. There are also the other people who are making a show, and they do not even know it."
While making the art is difficult (Mr. Fortin has developed repetitive stress pains from folding the phone books), finding the raw material in New York is often more of a chore than he thought it would be.
Restaurants have balked at giving him paper matchbooks, perhaps a true sign of how bad the economy has become. Chinese fish-shop owners have refused to give him plastic bags. In Coney Island, he finally found a nice Nathan's employee who sneaked him a bag of plastic French-fry forks when her boss was not looking. "That was a nice meeting," he said. "Sometimes, it is not so nice. Sometimes it is hard."
The other day was no exception. He took the C train to Times Square to find some of the purple garbage bags used by the Times Square Business Improvement District, only to learn that they have, improbably, become hot tourist items.
"Can't let you have one," said James Avery, who works for the district. "I could get fired."
But then, perhaps warming to art, he led Mr. Fortin to an office, where a supervisor let him have five bags.
Jackpot.
"Today," he said, smiling broadly, "is the day of generosity."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jerome Fortin, an artist, scours the city for materials like ice-cream cup lids and phone books for his work. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)
