HEADLINE: Candidate Expands the Assault on Spending Limits 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: ALBUQUERQUE, Sept. 10 

 BODY:
It can be difficult enough for first-time candidates, informing voters who they are and what they stand for. Here in Albuquerque, the challenge for some is compounded by an unusual city charter statute that limits campaign spending on local elections.
 But as one of the seven mayoral candidates in a nonpartisan election next month, Rick Homans has won an early battle to remove the limits in a case that could reach the United States Supreme Court as the next big test of campaign spending as a protected form of free speech. 
 "I've made a very strong public commitment to ride this through," Mr. Homans said today in an interview. "It is not only an important policy issue at the local level, it is an important policy issue at the national level, and for me, a rare opportunity to be involved in the debate." 
With three weeks left in the race, Mr. Homans, 45, a businessman and political independent, is trailing the leaders. Three recent polls all show a pair of Democrats -- Martin Chavez, a former Albuquerque mayor, and Bob Schwartz, a former district attorney -- holding modest leads over a field that also includes Mayor Jim Baca, a Democrat seeking a second four-year term.
From Mr. Homans's perspective, his lagging behind was easy to explain. Fighting for news media and voter attention against better-known opponents, he said he had quickly learned that he could not adequately compete without spending more money to get his name and message before city voters.
The city charter allows mayoral candidates to spend up to twice the mayor's salary, for a current cap of $174,720. Mr. Homans viewed that as far too little "to even the playing field." So he took the matter into Federal District Court here, where Judge Martha A. Vazquez upheld the city's right to impose the spending limits by denying Mr. Homans an injunction against them. 
But last Thursday, an appeals court in Denver effectively overturned Judge Vazquez's decision, ruling that the city's spending limits violated the candidate's "core First Amendment right of political expression," a view that echoed the Supreme Court's decision in a 1976 case, Buckley v. Valeo, that equated campaign spending with free speech. The appellate ruling also served to invite the city and Mr. Homans back to the district court for a trial on the merits of his argument.
If Mr. Homans does return, legal experts say, his case has a strong chance to become the next vehicle for the Supreme Court to reconsider the scope of campaign spending limits because the 1976 ruling involved only limits for Congressional campaigns.
The court has not been asked to look at spending limits, for example, at the local level but now may be inclined to do so with other mayoral races featuring candidates spending huge amounts of money, like Richard J. Riordan, who spent $6 million in 1993 to become mayor of Los Angeles, and Michael R. Bloomberg, who has spent more than $20 million in the current New York City mayor's race.
"We think the Homans case is a very likely candidate to reach the Supreme Court," said Brenda Wright, a lawyer with the National Voting Rights Institute, a Boston organization that works to reduce the role of money in politics. "Now we have to see what happens where spending limits have been in place for 27 years. A record like that isn't available anywhere else."
Ms. Wright said while places had voluntary spending limits, Albuquerque was the only major city with mandatory standards. 
The potential for Albuquerque as a test case for the Supreme Court arises from evidence that suggests the spending limits have had an energizing effect on the city's mayoral elections. The lower court's ruling embraced a study by Anthony Gierzynski, a political scientist at the University of Vermont, who found that "democracy in Albuquerque is actually as healthy, if not healthier than in other cities due in part to Albuquerque's campaign finance regulations."
Mr. Gierzynski showed that with limits in place, a higher percentage of people voted over the years, compared with the results in cities of comparable size with no spending caps.
As a rationale for his appeal, Mr. Homans said spending limits worked to the detriment of lesser-known candidates. With limited exposure in seven-way debates, he said, he needed to generate enough coverage to raise his profile. "And that," he said, "takes money."
Mr. Homans has far surpassed his opponents, spending $487,000, more than twice his nearest competition, Mr. Baca, who has spent $241,000, according to spending reports filed last week. Mr. Chavez has spent $105,000 and Mr. Schwartz $20,000.
Even the attention he had generated in the news, Mr. Homans said, failed to help raise the issues most important to him, economic development and public safety.
"We looked through the clips of stories about my campaign," he said with a laugh. "About 95 percent of them dealt with the spending caps."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rick Homans, an Albuquerque mayoral candidate, center, with his wife, Jan, greeted Anthony Magi, left, on Friday. Mr. Homans says city law makes it hard for little-known candidates like him to be elected. (Kitty Clark Fritz/The Albuquerque Journal)

HEADLINE: The New Home Economics; 
All-Important Housing Market Softens at the Top End

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: LONGMONT, Colo. 

 BODY:
In a neighborhood on one side of Clover Basin Drive, here in this Denver suburb, nearly all the new homes are taken. Closely bunched production houses on small lots, they have drawn buyers like Ryan Bonino, a 25-year-old salesman of luxury cars, who was gratified to find something affordable in one of the nation's hottest markets. In April, flush with a $44,000 profit from selling his first house here after just a year, Mr. Bonino snapped up a two-story, three-bedroom frame home for $268,000.
 But in the neighborhood just across the street, custom-built $600,000 and $800,000 homes, with three-car garages, granite countertops and sprawling lawns, remain unsold. 
 Across this region, inventories of unsold high-end houses are rising and some sellers are having to trim their asking prices. "You can actually negotiate prices in today's market, and it hasn't been that way in five to seven years," said Stuart Wright, a real estate broker in nearby Boulder. 
In this and many other areas around the nation, prices for the most expensive homes are softening after a long run, while demand for more moderately priced housing remains firm.
Seldom has so much ridden on which way the housing market turns. As layoffs mount and businesses cut back on investment and the stock market falters, escalating home prices and continued homebuilding have become a central bulwark against recession.
"The only thing holding up the economy is housing and consumer spending," said Eric S. Belsky, executive director of the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University. "If house price declines stay confined to the high end, that may not have serious negative consequences, but if they start filtering down to the middle class, that's likely to take a big toll."
Robust home values, up 26 percent nationally over the five years through June, have helped prop up wavering consumer confidence and supported the spending that has kept the economy barely growing.
The housing market draws its continuing strength from low mortgage rates, an expanding population, rising incomes and, in a lot of areas, anti-sprawl measures limiting land for new homes. But in many places, these pillars no longer fully support prices in the upper range.
In Seattle, the number of million-dollar homes still for sale has risen by half over the last year while listings of middle-priced homes have shrunk. In California, homes in affluent towns lost value in the second quarter while more modest areas posted strong gains. In Texas, the largest price increases this year have come from towns with moderate housing costs, like Longview, Abilene and Sherman.
Across metropolitan New York, median home prices rose 10.5 percent in the last year, and 5 percent in the second quarter, according to the National Association of Realtors. But in Manhattan, the average sales price of luxury co-op apartments -- defined as two to four bedrooms on Park Avenue, Fifth Avenue or Central Park West -- fell 25 percent in the second quarter, to $2.05 million, according to Douglas Elliman, the real estate brokerage firm.
In the 1990's, the most expensive homes, now costing $750,000 and up, appreciated the most in many regions, as the wealthiest Americans had their income gains compounded by their stock market profits. Now, as the stock market has reversed, so have the upper reaches of the housing market. Many well-off professionals and executives, especially, have been stripped of their huge gains on stock option packages and investments.
Layoffs -- and fears of greater job cuts -- have also had an impact. Around Denver, job cuts and falling stock prices at large employers in the struggling telecommunications industry -- like Level 3 Communications -- have helped cool the housing market. While the official numbers, which include some lower-priced homes, are not as extreme, Jack O'Connor, a Denver broker, calculates that the inventory of the most expensive homes here now stands at 27 months, quadruple the level a year ago.
But, by and large, the market for moderately priced houses remains healthy: median existing-home prices nationally rose 6.4 percent for the year ended in June, according to the National Association of Realtors. Housing starts during July rose 2.8 percent over their June level, to their highest in a year and a half, the Commerce Department reported.
The reasons for the divergence are illustrated here in metropolitan Denver, one of the prime growth areas of the 1990's. In the late 1980's, it suffered from a severe glut of homes at all prices. Today, it has the highest median home prices of any metropolitan area outside the two coasts, according to the association of realtors.
Low mortgage rates are part of the favorable equation, as they are elsewhere. Population growth, stronger than expected nationally in part because of immigration, has been especially strong around Denver. And over the last several years, Colorado residents have had some of the biggest personal income gains in the nation.
At the same time, attempts to limit growth have curtailed the supply of houses, as residents fight to avoid sprawling tract homes and malls. While slow-growth rules here are some of the most extreme, such measures have proliferated in many areas, leaving land for new homes in shorter supply.
In addition, many Colorado lenders and builders have remained cautious despite the sizzling market. The overbuilding of the 1980's that left large speculative housing developments standing unoccupied was burned into their memories.
All these factors are present nationwide in some measure, and they are likely to keep most of the housing market from backsliding much, even if the economy enters a full-blown recession, many economists say. While the pace is sure to slow, "I think the fundamentals are still there for healthy home price appreciation," said David Lereah, the chief economist at the National Association of Realtors. 
Nonetheless, the softening at the high end of the market, if it persists, could have widespread consequences as affluent homeowners, already hit by stock market losses, experience a drop in the value of their homes and the equity they own. That could further chill consumers' spirits, particularly among the big spenders who played such a critical role in the boom of the late 1990's.
"If consumer confidence drops, they'll stop spending, then the economy is going to tumble, and that's a big concern for me," said Jim Cobb, owner of Cornerstone Homes, a home builder in Longmont.
Steven Weiting, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, contends that the appreciation in home values is sure to cool, since turns in the stock market usually lead to changes in housing prices. But he calls a collapse unlikely, noting that overall inventories of unsold houses remain low.
In July, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, affirmed the importance of rising home values. "As home ownership rises and as the market value of homes continues to rise, even in a period when stock prices are falling," he said, "we're observing a rather remarkable employment of that so-called home equity wealth in all sorts of household decisions."
Recent housing market gains and continued home building contrast sharply with steep cutbacks in business investment. Such spending plunged 14.6 percent in the second quarter, slowing overall economic growth to the most sluggish pace in eight years, a mere 0.2 percent annual rate.
In past slowdowns, housing has tended to lead the economy's fall. But the character of the current slowdown has made this time different, said Robert Van Order, the chief economist at Freddie Mac. In the early 1980's, he said, efforts by the Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, to squeeze inflation out of the economy by pushing interest rates up sharply sent the cost of mortgages soaring, crippling housing sales. During the recession and housing slowdown in the early 1990's, much of the problem was related to the poor financial footing of banks and savings and loans.
But the latest slowdown is happening largely on what he called the "real" side of the economy -- including manufacturing and investment in plant and equipment -- rather than on the financial side.
"The financial system is in pretty good shape," Mr. Van Order said.
In Denver, these trends have played out in dramatic fashion. By the late 1980's, the real estate market here was so depressed that builders were faced with more than a year's inventory of unsold homes, a result of rampant overbuilding financed by savings and loans, and the collapse of energy prices, which pulled a crucial support from the local economy.
But since then the turnaround has been so sharp that in two affluent suburbs north of downtown, Boulder and Longmont, prices soared 147 percent in the decade that ended in March, according to federal data.
Part of such appreciation comes from soaring demand. During the 1990's, Colorado's population gained almost 31 percent, more than double the nation's. Around Denver, people flocked to live within view of the Front Range of the Rockies. And during the two years ended in March, personal incomes in Colorado jumped 20.4 percent, the most of any state, compared with 13.4 percent nationwide.
On the supply side, efforts to limit growth have made it difficult for builders to keep up. Sales of new homes in Boulder County, which includes Boulder and Longmont, fell 45 percent during the first half of the year, compared with the period in 2000, according to the Genesis Group, a local research firm. That decline, despite a 15 percent gain in average existing-home prices over the last year in this county, came primarily because of growth controls that limited the supply of new building lots, the study found.
"There's no doubt growth caps increase the cost of housing," said Leona Stoecker, the mayor of Longmont. "It's basic economics 101 -- when there's a shortage of something, prices increase." New housing approvals here commonly take three years, and impact fees to offset the cost of roads, sewers and other infrastructure can top $20,000 a home.
At the same time, the area's lenders and builders have been more restrained than during past booms, learning their lessons from the busts that invariably followed. "If builders learned anything from that, it was to build to demand," said Pat Fisher, owner of Gallery Homes in Lafayette, Colo.
Over all, inventories of existing homes in the six counties of the Denver metropolitan area rose at the end of the second quarter to 3.4 months, compared with 2 months a year before. Inventories of new homes rose to 1.6 months, up from 1.3 months at the end of the year. 
The outlook for the high-end market is less encouraging. Builders had expected a continued influx of high-technology employees, flush with stock options, said Tom Hoyt, chief executive of McStain Enterprises, one of the area's largest independent builders. But the opposite happened, he says: not only has the influx halted, but some of those here have been laid off, and still more have stood by helplessly as their options became worthless.
"All of a sudden you've got a two- or three-year supply," Mr. Hoyt said, "and I don't think we know yet what the effect is going to be."

PERSON: Roger Starr 

HEADLINE: Roger Starr, New York Planning Official, Author and Editorial Writer, Is Dead at 83 

BYLINE:  By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Roger Starr, an outspoken thinker on urban affairs who blended a lifetime of intellectual analysis with hands-on public service and whose often provocative vision of his native New York City influenced public policy debates for decades, died yesterday in Easton, Pa. He was 83.
 Mr. Starr, who lived in Stroudsburg, Pa., suffered a debilitating stroke at the end of May and died of pneumonia, his family said. . 
 Although Mr. Starr's beliefs were passionate, they were always a work in progress. From his Trotskyite campus days, he evolved into a New Dealer, dedicated to slum clearance, public housing and urban renewal in the Robert Moses mold. 
But he eventually became disillusioned by what he viewed as the flawed execution of good intentions. He adopted a neoconservative viewpoint, extolling the free market and a tough-love code of social morality and individual responsibility.
So great were his shifts, said his son, Adam, that there was no one who was really a protege.
Mr. Starr's career took many forms. He took over his father's barge company, ran construction ventures, headed a nonprofit housing group and served three mayors. He wrote several books, numerous articles and, for 15 years, editorials for The New York Times. He also taught, gave speeches and talked to anyone who would listen. Many did, including those who disagreed.
Although his voice was heard over a span of issues and years, Mr. Starr is most vividly remembered for his 1976 proposal for "planned shrinkage." Citing New York's declining population, lost jobs, social problems, high taxes and stressed services, he urged the city to abandon depressed areas like the South Bronx for future redevelopment.
A furor erupted. Mayor Abraham D. Beame, whom he was serving as Housing and Development administrator, disavowed the idea. City Council members called it "inhuman," "racist" and "genocidal." Protesters disrupted his public appearances.
"Although my phrase "planned shrinkage" will run a poor second to "benign neglect" in the unappreciated phrases derby," he wrote, "it will remain the most prominent label in the file of my government service." 
That was hardly the first or last time that his prescriptions provoked opposition.
A legendary feud began in the early 1960's when he criticized "The Death and Life of Great American Cities" by Jane Jacobs, who famously advocated human-scale neighborhoods. Eventually she won on her home court, rallying West Villagers to block high-rise plans of the type favored by Mr. Starr. Usually collegial with debating partners, he said, "What a dear, sweet character she isn't." She in turn called him foolish.
Later Mr. Starr praised smaller-scale housing. Recalling such shifts, his son, Adam, said, "Sometimes we would drive past a Mitchell-Lama project, and he would say, 'Mea culpa, mea culpa.' "
Mr. Starr objected that cowardly politicians refused to raise rents to cover the costs, causing debts, subsidies and neglect. Likewise, he championed public housing for the working poor but lamented that it was spoiled when the courts forced it to keep misbehaving tenants.
Condemning the very rent controls he once enforced, he said that they had turned housing into a disaster. "Controls are an easy mistake to make," he confessed. "I know, because as a student of housing and a public official, I helped make it." 
Mr. Starr moved to Stroudsburg about 15 years ago, nudged by the co-op conversion of his Manhattan apartment and drawn to the country by his fondness for fly fishing. He is survived by his wife, the former Jody Ward Green. Other survivors are two sons by his first wife, the late Manya Garbat, known as Fifi: Adam of Westport, Conn., and Barnaby of Baltimore; two stepchildren, Douglas Green of Manhattan and Patricia Shaheen of Saddle River, N.J.; five grandchildren; and three step-grandchildren.
Born in Manhattan on April 16, 1918, Roger Starr was ahead of his time at an early age, when his mother started his schooling at second grade. Later at Yale -- in the class of 1939 with William Bundy and Cyrus R. Vance -- he became chairman of the literary review. But as a Jew, he was shunned by fraternities. His sympathies shone in his short stories about Kristallnacht and bias against blacks.
In a publicized challenge to military segregation, Mr. Starr offered in 1941 to enlist in a black regiment. The Army declined. Later in the war, he worked in the Office of Strategic Services in Burma and China.
An aspiring writer, Mr. Starr worked at CBS News. But in 1945 he was called to take over his father's company, Frederick Starr Contracting, which barged construction material, and stayed till 1974. Branching out, he won city approval for new construction methods and produced new, lighter concrete and the first precast beams for city schools.
His housing and planning role blossomed from 1958 to 1973 when he was executive director of the Citizens' Housing and Planning Council, a civic group.
Drawn into government, he joined a housing panel advising Mayor Robert F. Wagner, was appointed chairman of the Rent Guidelines Board by Mayor John V. Lindsay, then served Mayor Beame full time from 1974 to 1976, as a fiscal crisis unfolded.
"You can't know the sheer joy of finally having your ideas understood and valued, of being recognized at last as an outstanding citizen and leader," Mr. Starr said. "The glow lasted for, oh, four or five days."
Budget cuts, mass layoffs and looming bankruptcy frustrated the man with expansive ideas. Still, Mr. Starr rescued jeopardized projects like Manhattan Plaza and won extensions for tax abatements for residential renovations and incentives for construction, programs that endure today.
In his incarnation at The Times, from 1977 to 1992, Mr. Starr's domain was recommending stands on local issues and candidates. "He was exceptionally well tailored and always courtly," said Jack Rosenthal, a former editorial page editor and now president of The New York Times Foundation. "People loved arguing with him. But no matter how heated, all was jolly afterward."
His writing plumbed issues ranging from nuclear power to his fly-fishing hobby to three-cushion billiards, betraying an intimacy with local pool halls that was acquired on lunchtime excursions.
Mr. Starr taught at City University, New York University, the New School and Pratt Institute. His books included "The Living End" (Coward, 1966), "Urban Choices" (Penguin, 1968), "Housing and the Money Market" (Basic Books, 1975), and "America's Housing Challenge" (Farrar, Straus, 1977).
Painting a bleak future in "The Rise and Fall of New York City" (Basic Books, 1985), he warned that New York might be destined to diminish until it disappeared as one of the world's great cities. He deplored the "decline in civility" and the perpetuation of welfare "in a special class that does not work, never heard of working and is not expected to work."
"Thus, in the subways, the two worlds of New York collide: the working world that seems normal, and the never-working world of the criminals and the utterly helpless," he wrote. "When they meet in the subway, it raises the possibility that the entire system will come, bit by bit, to a stop."
Instead of stopping or shrinking, the city bounced back with unplanned growth, revitalizing even the South Bronx. But its revival stemmed at least in part to progress on Mr. Starr's issues: reduced crime and welfare and the imported work ethic of new immigrants.

HEADLINE: Nuclear Booty: More Smugglers Use Asia Route 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Sept. 10 

 BODY:
The police in Batumi, a Black Sea port in Georgia, heard a rumor in July that someone wanted to sell several pounds of high-grade uranium for $100,000. The most tantalizing aspect of the tip was that one of the sellers was reportedly a Georgia Army officer.
 All sorts of scoundrels have tried nuclear smuggling in recent years. Many are amateurs; most of what they try to peddle proves useless for making bombs. 
 But the possible involvement of an army officer gave the Batumi case a measure of deadly seriousness, beyond its status as another example of how the smuggling of nuclear material has shifted to Central Asia. 
On the morning of July 20, the local antiterrorist squad burst into a small hotel room near the port, just outside the Turkish border. They arrested four men, including an army captain named Shota Geladze. 
On the floor of the room, in a glass jar wrapped in plastic, sat nearly four pounds of enriched uranium 235, according to Revaz Chantladze, one of the police officers. The quantity was less than is usually required for a small atomic bomb. 
Subsequent analysis yielded differing opinions. A Western diplomat said the uranium probably had no value for bomb-making, but Georgian officials called it the third seizure in two years of uranium with potential weapons use. 
The appearance of a relatively large quantity of uranium on the black market in Georgia underscored American concerns that such trafficking has shifted from Europe to the Caucasus, Central Asia and Turkey. 
Washington has responded by sending millions of dollars' worth of detection equipment to several countries in the region. The Americans are also providing training for border guards to learn to spot illegal shipments of nuclear material, and they helped to improve security at nuclear plants and airports.
The region is the gateway from Russia, which has huge stocks of nuclear material, to countries that are in the market for weapons material. Two of them, Iran and Iraq, are trying to develop nuclear weapons; a third, Pakistan, is expanding its nuclear arsenal.
Few smuggling incidents involve material that could be used to make bombs, and intelligence officials say they know of no successful attempt at smuggling weapons-grade material. But they concede that the scope of smuggling remains uncertain.
The rising number of incidents and the strong belief that only a fraction of shipments are intercepted have raised the level of anxiety here. The worries are heightened by the slackness of border controls and the economic instability that has left customs officers vulnerable to bribes.
"The nuclear material tends to come from Russia, but once it gets outside, the region is pretty wide open," Gary Milhollin, director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control in Washington, said during a trip to the region to brief customs officials on suspected buyers.
The International Atomic Energy Agency provided new figures on Friday showing that the number of confirmed cases of nuclear smuggling had fallen in the rest of the world but had risen in Turkey, the Caucasus and Central Asia.
Only four of the 104 cases from 1993 to 1995 occurred in this region, the agency reported, but from 1996 to last month, 16 of the 72 cases worldwide occurred in the region. The data covered only three weapons-related elements -- uranium, plutonium and thorium -- and only incidents confirmed by the international agency.
Intelligence authorities said smugglers are seeking new routes out of Russia and find their paths easier across the southern flank. "There has, since the mid-1990's, been a shift of smuggling to the Middle East and Asia," Alex Schmid, head of antiterrorism for the United Nations, told a conference recently.
In the last eight years, there have been 104 attempts to smuggle nuclear material into Turkey, according to an internal report by the Turkish Atomic Energy Authority. Most cases, like those elsewhere, involved tiny amounts of radioactive material with no weapons uses. But officials at the authority said a handful were potentially more serious.
In September 1998, eight people were arrested for trying to smuggle nuclear material from Russia through Turkey to an unknown destination. The police seized about 10 pounds of uranium 235 and a tenth of an ounce of a plutonium mixture.
Yasar Ozal, director of Turkey's nuclear research center, said the plutonium and uranium were not weapons-grade material, but appeared to be fuel pellets. Nonetheless, he said, the appearance of plutonium on the black market was alarming.
In another case, a Turk was arrested at the Bulgarian border carrying a small amount of enriched uranium 235 in May 1999. Authorities said that the quality was high and that the material might have been a sample that he was trying to use to drum up a larger sale.
But Ismail Caliskan, director of Turkey's police unit fighting smuggling and organized crime, said the danger from nuclear smuggling had been exaggerated. Almost every incident, he said, involved amateur criminals trying to sell radioactive material with no weapons value. The only buyers, he said, are undercover policemen. 
Turkey illustrates the difficulty of monitoring borders. The country is slightly larger than Texas and has 120 border posts, including crossings to Iraq and Syria in the south, Bulgaria in the northwest and Georgia, Armenia and Iran in the east.
A senior customs official said only two border posts have systems to detect radioactive material, both donated by the United States. He asked that the locations not be identified, but said neither is at Habur, a busy crossing between Turkey and Iraq.
Locations without detection devices rely on visual inspections, something that can be difficult. A kilo of plutonium (2.2 pounds) is so dense it can be concealed in a container the size of a soft-drink can.
Some American detection equipment went to Uzbekistan, which has hundreds of miles of border in remote deserts and mountainous terrain. Border guards at three locations received van-sized detection units and 30 hand-held detectors far more powerful than Geiger counters.
Early last month, guards at a remote Uzbek post on the border with Turkmenistan stopped a sealed truck en route to Iran when one of the American-supplied devices went off, according to American officials.
The officials said they did not know what type of material the truck carried. They said the truck had come from Kazakhstan and passed undetected through the checkpoint at Gisht Kuprik on the Kazak border before being stopped in Alat.
Another American device, on the border between Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan, about 20 miles from Tashkent, the Uzbek capital, detected radioactive material in March 2000 in a truckload of scrap metal. Uzbek authorities said the truck was coming from Kazakhstan, bound for Pakistan with 10 briefcase-sized containers of radioactive material. The Uzbeks sent it back to Kazakhstan for analysis of the material and a criminal investigation. 
A Western diplomat said that when the Uzbeks stopped the vehicle, a second truck loaded with scrap turned and went back to Kazakhstan. 
What followed remains a bit of a mystery and an illustration of how regional rivalries can make it tougher to stop trafficking: The Uzbeks complained that the radioactive material disappeared in Kazakhstan and that no arrests were made. 
The Kazakhstan government has a good record on trying to curb nuclear-related smuggling. It worked closely with the United States to protect its Soviet-era nuclear facilities, and 1,300 pounds of weapons-grade uranium was removed from the country in 1994 by American officials.
But Western officials said they, too, were left in the dark about the outcome of the inquiry into the material on the scrap-metal truck. 
In Kazakhstan's first official explanation, Altynbek Sarsenbayev, assistant to the president for national security, denied that there were any briefcase-size containers. He said the problem arose because the scrap metal was contaminated with low-level radioactivity.

HEADLINE: Spoiling the Broth 

 BODY:
When Frank Flynn, a Columbia University professor of organizational behavior, drafted a fictitious letter to 240 New York restaurants, he did so in the hope of studying "vendor response to consumer complaints." The letter stated that he had been stricken with "extended nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and abdominal cramps" in each of the restaurants after a wedding anniversary dinner. Those symptoms were nothing compared with the headache Professor Flynn must have had last week when he realized how badly his research had gone awry. His letter caused a reign of terror in many of the city's top restaurants, as management tried to ferret out the culprits. If his subject had been culinary paranoia or perhaps the temper of the high-profile chef, the letter would have been perfectly crafted. 
 As it was, however, the restaurateurs were the ones who got to study organizational behavior. First came a formal apology from the dean of Columbia's business school, then a letter from Mr. Flynn in which he apologized and promised never to conduct such studies again. His academic fate is now being decided. Perhaps the simplest, as well as the most just, punishment would be to send the professor to work for a time in a few of those 240 kitchens. There is no name on the kitchen staff for the role Mr. Flynn would play -- the hierarchy doesn't reach that low -- but he would certainly learn a lot about vendor response to consumer complaints. 
 Restaurants are already feeling the gravity of this sodden economy, and the Flynn letter must have been as welcome as a power failure or a garbage haulers' strike. The situation calls to mind the Monty Python sketch about the restaurant patron who complains of a dirty fork, leading to the suicide of the entire wait and kitchen staff. For a brief moment last week, the culinary establishment of New York edged collectively toward the psychic precipice. All in all, it was a near thing for New York diners.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
Nikkei Plunge Has Investors On the Edge

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 11 

 BODY:
After the biggest plunge in a month pushed the Nikkei 225 stock index down 321 points on Monday, this popular economic barometer had long left behind "the Koizumi effect" -- the gains surrounding the emergence of Junichiro Koizumi as prime minister five months ago.
 After dropping 25 percent this year, the Nikkei in afternoon trading was up 108.59 points, or 1.1 percent, to 10,304.28, dancing above the 10,000 barrier, a level last seen in 1984. Still, the index could fall below the Dow Jones industrial average, a situation not seen since 1957, the opening days of Japan's economic boom. 
 With the Nikkei now pointed toward four-digit territory, few investors want to be reminded of the "bubble" era peak, on Dec. 29, 1989, when the index topped out at 39,915. 
In past drops, Japanese governments often intervened, especially at crucial times like the end of September -- the end of the half-year for companies and banks. But this time, Mr. Koizumi has said he will not step in.
"In the past, you had Japan's financial socialism kick in to keep up share prices," said Jesper Koll, chief economist for Merrill Lynch Japan. "This time they have made it very clear that if stock prices fall, so be it."
For years, Americans watched the Nikkei dispassionately. But today, interest is acute as billions of dollars flow in and out of Japanese markets.
From a marginal foreign participation of 4 percent of holdings a decade ago, foreigners held 19 percent of share values at the end of March, according to the Tokyo Stock Exchange. During the first half of this year, foreigners, hoping that Japan had bottomed out, pumped in a net $30 billion.
Now, although some Japanese equities are hitting 17-year lows, many foreign investors wonder where the bottom is. Suffering from what one American financial executive here calls "fear of regret," they are quietly selling.
"The U.S. investors are definitely on the sell," Garry Evans, chief strategist for HSBC Securities Japan Ltd., said Monday evening. "There is a feeling, 'Isn't it a bit late now?' "
Foreigners have also largely discounted the Koizumi phenomenon, recognizing that free market change to Japan's economy will come slowly, if at all.
"The honeymoon is basically over now," Marc Desmidt, director of Japanese equities for Merrill Lynch, said on Monday. "Koizumi needs to show his stuff, and walk his talk."
In the past, Japanese markets could blithely ignore foreign opinions. But, with foreigners accounting for half of all trades through July, that is no longer the case.
There is little Japanese interest in companies that often pay small or no dividends, ignore minority shareholder interests, and in many cases are not run primarily to make profits. Although the Japanese have some of the highest savings rates in the world, only 6 percent of the savings of the average Japanese household is invested in stocks, compared with more than 35 percent in America and Europe. American and European brokerage companies here are laying off workers, and Merrill Lynch is closing 6 of its 33 retail outlets in Japan.
"The Japanese are permanent sellers, and the market only goes up if foreigners buy," Andrew Smithers, a British economist and a Japan expert, said on a recent visit here. "Why should foreigners buy into an economy where shares are overpriced, where the economy is falling, and where the government doesn't know what to do about it?"
In recent weeks, Japan's government has been battered by numerous gloomy statistics: official unemployment rising to 5 percent, the gross domestic product dropping by an annualized rate of 3.2 percent, and the once vaunted trade surplus melting like butter.
This is likely to be a major topic of talks on Wednesday when Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill meets with Mr. Koizumi and others in Tokyo.
Mr. O'Neill's primary concern is expected to be the tottering state of many Japanese banks.
But damage is muted slightly by the fact that the Nikkei overstates the poor shape of Japan's stock markets. In April 2000, the Nikkei index was shuffled, dropping 30 "old economy" stocks, replacing them with 30 technology stocks. Today, technology shares account for about 37 percent of the Nikkei.
The perils of technology were illustrated on Monday, when NTT DoCoMo Inc., Japan's dominant cell phone company, dropped 5.4 percent on the news of disappointing subscriptions in August. Last Thursday, the Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest automaker, supplanted DoCoMo as Japan's most highly valued company.
While the public follows the Nikkei, most analysts follow the Tokyo stock price index, or Topix, a broader index, which fell Monday to a 33-month low. This year, the Topix is down 17.6 percent, or slightly worse than the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
However, with Japanese news media breathlessly reporting the latest drop, the Nikkei is firmly embedded in the popular consciousness. Mr. Koizumi cannot ignore the fact that the index has lost slightly more than 1 trillion yen, or one-quarter of its value, since May 7, when he confidently pledged a radical reform program for Japan's economy.
On Monday, after the Nikkei neared 10,000, Mr. Koizumi told reporters: "This is a severe situation, but U.S. share prices are also falling. We must watch developments carefully."
The chief secretary of his cabinet, Yasuo Fukuda, said Monday: "Personally, I doubt whether the current stock prices are reflecting the real situation of the Japanese economy."
But, across town, Taku Yamasaki, secretary general of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, said of Tokyo stock prices: "I think they reflect economic fundamentals."
Some analysts, like Mr. Desmidt, say the Nikkei would have to drop below 8,000 before banks would be seriously damaged. But the political pressure is mounting for the Koizumi government to stabilize the market by buying up shares.
"Most domestic investors know that the government will come in by the end of September," Robert Sasaki, managing director for derivatives for Bear Stearns in Tokyo, predicted Monday. "The government realizes that 10,000 is a huge line in the sand, so they will defend that line."

After a spectacular run-up in the late 1980's, the Nikkei is now, once again, near the same level as the Dow. HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Marshall Field's decides it's time for a big branding effort.

BYLINE:  By Allison Fass 

 BODY:
IN a new campaign meant to romanticize the experiences people can have at its department stores, Marshall Field's is beginning its first major branding effort since its parent, the Target Corporation, changed the names of its Dayton's and Hudson's stores to Marshall Field's. 
 The campaign, with billings estimated at $25 million to $35 million, was created by Arnold Worldwide in Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners unit of Havas Advertising. It began on Sunday and includes print, television and outdoor ads that carry the theme "The sheer joy of shopping," and revolve around enjoyable, personal and even moving situations that can occur at Marshall Field's. 
 Perhaps the emotional appeal will engage consumers as the souring economy leaves them anxious about where to shop and how to best spend their money. This is particularly important as August sales reflect that Americans are heading to discount chains rather than department or specialty stores. 
The Target Corporation was consistent with that pattern, with August sales for Marshall Field's department stores declining 4 percent from figures in the month a year earlier, while August same-store sales for its discount-oriented Target stores were up 3.9 percent. Similarly, Marshall Field's sales so far this year were down 6.3 percent, while same-store sales at Target were up 3.2 percent.
"This is the opportunity to strengthen our brand," said Katie Erickson, vice president for marketing and visual merchandising for Marshall Field's in Minneapolis. It is the chance for "anybody that knew Dayton's or anybody that knew Hudson's" to know Marshall Field's.
"It's not just about coming in our store and buying an outfit and leaving," she added. The ads show "what's important about our brand on an emotional level, not just a rational level."
The ads focus on different Marshall Field's shopping scenes and carry a title using the word "Experience." In one print ad, "Experience sick day," only one fitting room in a row has clothes draped on the door, illustrating a woman who goes shopping under the guise of being sick. In another print ad, "Experience fate," a young woman is shown gazing at a wedding dress.
In a television spot, "Experience fragrance," a woman leisurely leaves a Marshall Field's store and catches the attention of a blind man who turns his head as she walks by. A shoe department salesman carries a pair of shoes in a television ad, "Experience service," as he makes his way through an obstacle course including running through fields and jumping onto a freight train before arriving at a shoe department where a customer is waiting.
A more general branding spot shows a string of experiences as customers celebrate shopping at Marshall Field's; they are walking through the store, dancing and looking at merchandise, among other things. At different points, words on the screen say, "Experience impulse," "Experience chocolate," "Experience selection," "Experience service," "Experience love at first sight," "Experience delirium." A fourth TV spot explains "Project Imagine," the program through which Marshall Field's donates 5 percent of its income to community arts and cultural institutions.
The television spots carry upbeat, engaging music reminiscent of the music that became well known in Arnold's popular ads for Volkswagen of America.
The campaign seeks "to communicate that there's an experience worth having and you might want to try it out yourself," said Ron Lawner, chairman and chief creative officer at Arnold. It also aims to "touch" consumers, "inform them, give them a sense of the experience," he added. "That's what advertising does."
The strategy behind the campaign was based on research conducted by Arnold, with more than 75 women ages 25 to 49 from large markets like Chicago, Detroit and Minneapolis and smaller cities like Battle Creek, Mich., and Bismarck, N.D., which have Marshall Field's stores. In addition to small group and one-to-one interviews, the research also included women taking Arnold employees on tours of their favorite parts of Marshall Field's stores. Women were selected based on their "best guest" status for spending the most money at Marshall Field's, based on a loyalty program.
"When they talked about Marshall Field's, it was all about the experience and all the things they can do and feel at the store," said Kate Van Dam, senior account planner at Arnold. "When they talked about competitors, they talked about value, saving money, or they might talk about a specific style or fashion."
The print ads appear in the September issues of magazines like Vanity Fair and Vogue. In Chicago, Detroit and Minneapolis, there are ads in city magazines as well as outdoor ads. The TV spots will also appear regionally. Direct mail created in conjunction with an in-house team at Marshall Field's will also be part of the campaign.
Advertising for the three separate store chains was previously handled in-house and primarily focused on sales and special events.
Marshall Field's now operates 64 stores in eight states: Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, North Dakota, Ohio, South Dakota and Wisconsin. The Marshall Field's Web site, www.fields.com, which has been used by consumers nationwide, was updated in the spring.
"Shopping now isn't as pleasant as it used to be as a whole," said Kara Goodrich, senior vice president and creative director at Arnold. "One of the things that might be appealing to people about a department store like Marshall Field's is getting back to that peaceful, intimate, personal, quiet-almost shopping experience."
But is the Marshall Field's experience different from that of other department stores?
"I do think we heard over and over again customers have stories that Marshall Field's has gone out of its way to provide a huge extra measure of service to them," Ms. Goodrich said. "You'd have to go there to find out if it were true or not."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A new campaign created by Arnold Worldwide for Marshall Field's focuses on a variety of shopping scenes.

HEADLINE: U.S. Sues Morgan Stanley, Charging Sex Bias in a Firing 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
The federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed a sex-discrimination suit yesterday against Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, in what Cari M. Dominguez, the commission's chairwoman, said was its first action to contend that a major Wall Street firm did not treat female professionals fairly.
 In filing the suit in United States District Court in Manhattan, the commission took up the case of Allison K. Schieffelin, a high-paid bond saleswoman whom Morgan Stanley fired in October after she complained that she had been denied the additional pay and a promotion she had earned. 
 Ms. Dominguez said the commission thought that as many as 100 other women had been victims of similar discrimination within a single division of Morgan Stanley's investment bank since 1995. 
The appearance of Ms. Dominguez -- her first in New York since she was sworn in last month -- at a news conference to announce the suit signaled that Bush administration officials would enforce antidiscrimination laws for even the highest-paid workers. Some employment lawyers had questioned whether the government would go to court to fight for so fortunate a person as Ms. Schieffelin, who earned more than $1 million a year for several years.
"I came to New York today not only to thank Ms. Schieffelin for her courage but also to sound a wake-up call to all employers," Ms. Dominguez said. "This administration will not allow -- in any form, at any level or in any industry -- the existence of workplace barriers that operate to exclude on the basis of gender or any other impermissible personal characteristic."
Ms. Dominguez said Ms. Schieffelin's situation underlined a growing problem of employers' punishing workers for discrimination complaints. The commission's suit includes a contention that the firm retaliated against Ms. Schieffelin in a variety of ways, culminating in her dismissal on the ground of insubordination.
A spokesman for Morgan Stanley, Raymond O'Rourke, said that Ms. Schieffelin was fired after a confrontation with a supervisor in which she was "verbally abusive and physically threatening."
To prove that it did not discriminate against Ms. Schieffelin, he said, "we're fully prepared to go to court."
Wall Street firms generally try to avoid court trials, to minimize adverse publicity and the possibility that a jury will award a large amount in damages to plaintiffs. Lawyers for the commission and Ms. Schieffelin declined to say how much they hoped to receive in back pay and damages. 
The suit and Ms. Dominguez's remarks compounded Wall Street's considerable image problems. Recent lawsuits against two of the biggest American securities firms portrayed the brokerage business as hostile to female employees, but investment banks have cultivated the impression that they operate as meritocracies where performance is all that matters.
Lawyers for the commission said that statistics indicated otherwise. In 1998, the division in which Ms. Schieffelin worked, Morgan Stanley's institutional equities unit, had 50 managing directors; 3 were women. All the highest-paid employees in the division were men, the suit contends.
For her part, Ms. Schieffelin said, her sex was the only possible reason she was repeatedly told that she would not achieve her career-long ambition of becoming a Morgan Stanley managing director. A promotion would have meant she could earn "double, triple, quadruple what I was making," she said.
Ms. Schieffelin had worked at the firm for 14 years, since she obtained her M.B.A. degree at Northwestern University in 1986. She showed proficiency in selling convertible bonds, corporate debt securities that can be converted into shares of stock. Convertible bonds have become popular in recent years, and underwriting and trading them has become a lucrative business on Wall Street.
By all accounts, Ms. Schieffelin was a successful saleswoman, doing business with big institutional investors on the West Coast. Mr. O'Rourke said that she had been the firm's highest-paid convertible-bond salesperson.
To get to such a point, Ms. Schieffelin said in an interview yesterday, she made some big sacrifices. 
"I really made the choice not to have a family," said Ms. Schieffelin, 40, who is divorced. "I was going to L.A. every single week. I couldn't even have a goldfish."
She was such an enthusiastic employee, she said, that she almost immediately started helping Morgan Stanley recruit at Northwestern. Even now that she is looking for work at other firms, she said, she catches herself asking former clients about the deals "we" are doing -- meaning Morgan Stanley.
"I loved my job," she said. "I miss the action. I miss my clients."
Although high-ranking employees on Wall Street rarely speak ill of their firms for fear of losing their jobs or being blackballed in the industry, Ms. Schieffelin said she had not expected to be fired for complaining to the commission. Before she went outside the firm, she had her lawyer, Wayne N. Outten, write a letter to John J. Mack, then Morgan Stanley's president and now chief executive of Credit Suisse First Boston. 
"I really thought they were going to say, 'Gosh, we know Allie. This is somebody who has been a team player for all of her career,' " Ms. Schieffelin said.
Instead, she said, she almost immediately found herself frozen out, removed from important projects and receiving smaller allocations of bond offerings to sell to clients and sometimes worse prices for her clients' trades from Morgan Stanley traders.
She also contends that a managing director made unwanted sexual advances toward her.
But the crux of her complaint is financial.
"Morgan Stanley is a big, big company," she said, "and what they understand is money," adding that the amount the commission seeks from a jury "has got to be enough money to deter them from doing this again."
"If it doesn't cost them any money," Ms. Schieffelin said, "they won't change their practices."
Economic discrimination is a recurring complaint on Wall Street. Groups of female stockbrokers who sued Merrill Lynch & Company and the Smith Barney unit of Citigroup also contended that they had been victims of a pattern of discrimination in pay and promotions. Those firms settled the cases, which the commission did not get involved in, by setting up new procedures to resolve the disputes out of court.
Ms. Dominguez said that biased pay and promotion decisions on Wall Street were part of an industry culture that "often isolates and marginalizes women."
She deplored the practice of retaliating against women who assert their civil rights to be treated as equals in the workplace.
"It's been called kiss your Wall Street career goodbye," she said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Compromises Are Explored On Additional Tax Cuts
Leaders in both parties responded to the darkening economic outlook by exploring possible compromises on additional tax cuts, and the Democratic chairman of the Senate Budget Committee suggested that such a deal could involve the politically perilous step of tapping temporarily into the Social Security surplus.
 Pressure mounted on President Bush to drop his cautious approach to dealing with the weakening economy, much of it from within his own party. Page A1. 

Snag Looms Over China Trade Talks
A three-day conference that begins today in Geneva was supposed to tie up the loose ends for China's entry into the World Trade Organization. Instead, all eyes are on one big remaining obstacle: the squabble between the European Union and the United States over access to China's vast life insurance market. C2.

Qwest Plans to Cut 4,000 Jobs
Qwest Communications, the operator of large fiber optic and local telephone networks, said that it would eliminate 4,000 jobs by the beginning of next year, adding to the woes of the telecommunications industry. The company also reduced its spending and sales estimates. Investors, optimistic about more prudent capital expenditures, pushed shares of Qwest up $1.76, to $19.90. C6.

TV News Emphasis Shifts to Morning
The decision by CNN to lure the anchor Paula Zahn away from Fox News for a new morning program reflects the seismic shift that has occurred in television news, with the morning now the place to find the biggest stars and the viewers most desirable to advertisers. A1.

Stocks End Day Little Changed
The stock market rallied from early losses to finish the day little changed. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.34 point, to 9,605.51. The Nasdaq composite index rose 7.68 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,695.38, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index edged up 6.76 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,092.54. C9.

AOL Not in a Cable Bidding War Yet
AOL Time Warner's expression of interest in buying 40 percent of AT&T's 14 million cable subscribers does not necessarily signal a bidding war, experts said. News Analysis. C4.

YankeeNets Gets Its Own Channel
A year of battling in court and wooing investors spawned what YankeeNets coveted since it was formed two years ago: a cable television channel of its own, called the Yankees Entertainment and Sports network. D6.

Lernout Offers Plan for Revamping
Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products, the struggling software concern, filed a new restructuring plan and announced that it was talking to at least two potential buyers of its core activities. "We have filed a plan to reorganize a going concern," said the company's chief executive, Philippe Bodson. Under the new plan, the company would need $20 million to $25 million in cash to stay in business and would retain about 400 of its 571 workers. World Business, Section W.

Scottish Power to Take a Charge
Scottish Power said that it had miscalculated so badly in the California power shortages and the resulting wild swings in American energy prices that it would have to take a $300 million charge. World Business, Section W.

Investment Bank Merges Divisions
Credit Suisse First Boston's chief executive merged the bank's bond and stock divisions, naming one of his predecessor's top aides to manage a group of about 6,000 people. C4.

Economists Cut Growth Forecasts
Business economists lowered their forecasts for growth for 2001 and 2002 but most said the economy would not slide into recession. A separate report from the Federal Reserve showed that the level of consumer credit outstanding unexpectedly held steady in July. C16.

HEADLINE: The Politics of Panic 

 BODY:
The summer has barely ended, but President Bush and his Congressional allies are already frantically rewriting their script for the fall. This was supposed to be a season for Mr. Bush to talk about "values," not fiscal policy. But with a sinking economy, evanescing surplus and tottering budget, Republicans are going back to the drawing board. Some, like Trent Lott, the Senate minority leader, want to cut the capital gains tax. House Republicans are talking about broad spending cuts. The White House says Mr. Bush would listen to these and other ideas to revive the economy. There is a whiff of panic in the air, and panic can lead to bad policy. 
 That many Republicans are now rallying around a cut in the capital gains tax (from 20 to 15 percent) is a particular sign of desperation. After ramming through one of the most unfair tax cuts in history, one that targeted most of its benefits to the most wealthy taxpayers, the party is focusing on a new reduction that would lavish 80 percent of its benefit on the wealthiest 2 percent of taxpayers. A capital gains tax cut would not stimulate the economy in the short term, the most pressing economic need. While perhaps providing a quick infusion of revenue in the next year, as stockholders sold off shares to take advantage of the new rates, it would deepen the nation's long-term fiscal hole. The only thing to recommend it is that it would reward party fund-raisers and benefactors. 
 Mr. Bush and his economic advisers have until now resisted capital gains tax-cut proposals. During the campaign, Lawrence Lindsey, now the chief economic counselor, dismissed the idea as redolent of old Republican economic thinking, and not acceptable to the "compassionate conservative" philosophy of Mr. Bush. But that was then. Now the White House is saying it might be interested. It will be a hard sell politically, especially since the only way to pay for such a tax cut would be to siphon off even more of the Social Security revenues that Mr. Bush once said were inviolable.
To help Mr. Bush keep his promise not to touch Social Security funds, some Republicans are urging another bad idea: more budget cuts. Today the House will begin taking up a nutty scheme to "sequester" spending -- that is, cut spending -- in non-defense areas next year in order to avoid tapping Social Security money this year. This gimmick turns Keynesianism on its head. If an economic downturn invites a stimulative fiscal policy by cutting taxes, surely such an approach would be completely undermined by a parallel policy of cutting spending. Hard as a capital gains tax cut is to justify, it is even more unacceptable to finance it by cutting spending on health, children's nutrition and education -- the latter being the very priority that Mr. Bush set aside the week to promote in his new "values" agenda.
Democrats are saying privately that they might accept some sort of tax reduction provided the Bush administration is willing, in turn, to repeal part of the previously enacted tax cut that takes place several years from now. In theory, that may make sense. Democrats are also floating the idea of a tax cut that, this time, would go to lower-income taxpayers who got nothing out of the last package by giving them some sort of a credit for Social Security and Medicare taxes. One measure of Mr. Lott's eagerness for a capital gains tax cut is that yesterday he said he would consider adding the Democratic proposal to it.
Whatever happens, this is no time for cutting more taxes on the wealthy and cutting more spending on programs of vital importance to the most vulnerable Americans. Republicans are right about the need to rewrite their script. But the revisions they are clutching at now would make a bad plot even more implausible. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Report Cites Vulnerabilities Of Global Navigation System 

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 

 BODY:
The Global Positioning System which airlines plan to use to land flights in zero visibility, railroads want for avoiding train collisions and ships use to navigate shoals -- is vulnerable to interference and even "spoofing" by enemies, the Transportation Department said today.
 A report ordered by President Bill Clinton two years ago suggested that older technologies, which are more expensive and less precise but also more robust, needed to be maintained as a backups. 
 "There is a growing awareness within the transportation community that the safety and economic risks associated with loss or degradation of the G.P.S. signal have been underestimated," the report said. 
The receivers are also used by motorists, hikers and even surveyors, although for them failures would presumably not be potentially catastrophic. Banks and electric utilities also use the signals for precise time measurements.
The report did not rank the risks or say exactly what the government should do; instead the transportation secretary gave the Federal Aviation Administration, the Federal Railroad Administration and other agencies 60 days to report on how they would maintain safety. 
The G.P.S. system has tremendous potential for increasing operating efficiencies in aviation, helping planes fly more direct routes and land in low visibility in places that lack conventional instrument landing systems. By letting vehicles determine their positions and radio that information back to a central control point, it can help controllers get more use out resources like railroad tracks and runways. 
But the radio signals, which come from satellites, have a strength of less than one quadrillionth of a watt when they reach the receiver; a transmitter of only several watts can blank out large areas. Today's report said an adversary could broadcast a counterfeit signal that would confuse the receivers.
And in case of war, the satellites themselves might become targets, the report said.
The aviation agency's existing system costs about $100 million a year to maintain. That includes about 1,000 radio beacons, which pilots use to triangulate their positions; 1,200 instrument landing systems that guide planes to runways; and scores of radar stations, which controllers use to determine the position of planes. If the planes themselves knew with precision where they were, they could radio that information to the ground and make the radar obsolete.
At the agency, Steven Zaidman, the associate administrator for research and acquisitions, said that he had not yet read the report but that "it's clear that we're not going to get as much savings" as initially hoped.
The aviation administration will not face the decision about what to retire until 2010, Mr. Zaidman said, to give commercial and private planes time to equip themselves with G.P.S. receivers and to let the agency install equipment near airports that would augment the satellite signals, making the signal accurate enough for low-visibility landings.

HEADLINE: Dell Computer Is in the Catbird Seat, for Now 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

 BODY:
When Hewlett-Packard announced last week that it planned to join forces with Compaq Computer, creating a combined hardware and services company almost the size of I.B.M., its executives said it had contemplated leaving the personal computer business entirely.
 Gateway -- which ran insouciant ads last spring that said, "PC Price War . . .? Cool." -- has closed retail stores, begun a sharp pullback from international sales and announced thousands of layoffs. 
 While no single person can be blamed for the abrupt shift in the PC market, once highly profitable, much of the turmoil can be attributed to a brutal price-cutting campaign by one man: Michael S. Dell, the founder, chairman and chief executive of Dell Computer. His tactic of slashing prices in the middle of a market slump is something that only his company, which has done more to make its manufacturing processes nimble and efficient than any of its competitors, can afford. 
"The company is in a very good position to leverage its advantages to the hilt," said Ashok Kumar, an analyst with U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray.
Mr. Dell, 36, had revolutionized the industry before. He recognized early on that manufacturing could be structured around customers' needs instead of the one-size-fits-all approach that had existed in the industry. The company pioneered direct sales to business and consumers -- a sales channel that boomed with the advent of the World Wide Web. And he was also early to recognize that personal computers would become a commodity business like consumer electronics, and focused his company's efforts on squeezing costs out of the manufacturing process and passing the savings along to buyers.
The strategy has vaulted Dell to the top of the PC market, and brought Mr. Dell personal wealth of more than $16 billion.
Everyone is feeling the slump, but Dell can tolerate it better than most. In its second quarter, which ended Aug. 3, Dell announced that it had sold 19 percent more computers than in the period a year earlier, but sales measured in dollars were essentially flat, going to $7.61 billion this year from $7.67 billion last year. Dell lost $101 million in the latest second quarter because of one-time charges, but when those charges were excluded the company posted a profit of $433 million.
Dell is the biggest seller of PC's in the United States and worldwide, according to IDC, a market research firm, though it would be No. 2 to a combined Hewlett-Packard and Compaq. "The company was alone among the top vendors in growing shipments and market share as its rivals struggled to preserve volume and protect margins," an IDC report stated.
Dell has thinned the herd of PC makers before, said Tim Bajarin, an industry analyst in California; companies like AST and a host of smaller companies have found themselves unable to survive in a Dell world. "He's the Muhammed Ali of the industry," he said of Mr. Dell. "He floats like a butterfly and stings like a bee." The other companies cannot keep up, Mr. Bajarin said. "As new technologies come out he can put them in much faster than his competitors."
This shift to a commodity market, however, carries risks for consumers. Innovation, once the lifeblood of PC makers, becomes a luxury that the companies cannot afford. Research budgets shrink, and the role of innovator shifts to the companies at the core of the Windows-based PC market: the chip maker Intel and the operating system giant Microsoft. In that kind of environment, Mr. Bajarin said, Mr. Dell still wins. But the effect on consumers is less clear.
Lately even Dell has been focusing its attention where the money is in the industry, pushing the still-profitable sales of storage devices and powerful computers known as servers that are commonly used to store large databases and to house Web sites, as well as services.
The company's current tactics are familiar to many longtime observers of the quiet but fiercely competitive Mr. Dell. "He's the one calling the shots," said Andrew J. Neff, an analyst at Bear, Stearns. Mr. Neff spins a brief parable in which Mr. Dell asks his friends in the industry to go scuba diving with him. "Wait a minute, Michael," Mr. Neff imagines the friends saying. "Our tanks are only good for 30 minutes and your tank lasts about an hour. How long do you want to swim?"
"I don't know," replies the Mr. Dell of the story. "Forty-five minutes sounds about right." 
Mr. Dell himself, while soft spoken, has never hidden his passion for winning. A profile of him written in 1995 quoted a pep talk he once gave to employees in less circumspect days, in which he joked that his daughter's first words were, "Mommy . . . Daddy . . . Daddy, kill Compaq. Daddy, kill I.B.M. Daddy, kill Gateway."
The fact that Dell is still not the largest company competing in the dwindling PC market is a plus, Mr. Neff said. "He likes being No. 2 because it motivates his troops even more."
Yet the good times might not last, said Mr. Kumar, the analyst from U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray. Dell's greatest advantage is realized during lean times, when customers look for bargains and every manufacturer has to cut costs to the bone. When times are flush, parts are hard to get and expensive, which shaves some of Dell's advantage, he said.
"We are not going to stay in this weak economic environment for an infinite period of time -- it's a cyclical phenomenon," Mr. Kumar said. "What was a headwind for Dell a year or two ago with tight supply is now a tail wind -- and it could very well switch again."
Mr. Dell declined to be interviewed for this article. But last week while he was in Nashville for a board meeting, he spoke to a reporter for The Associated Press and said that the market confusion in the wake of the Helwett-Packard-Compaq news could only bolster the fortunes of his company. "We've found that when there's turmoil and confusion around us, that generally increased opportunities for us," Mr. Dell said, not mentioning just who had helped cause the turmoil and confusion.

HEADLINE: KEY LEADERS TALK OF POSSIBLE DEALS TO REVIVE ECONOMY 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL and RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 

 BODY:
Key figures in both parties responded to the darkening economic outlook today by exploring possible compromises on additional tax cuts, and the Democratic chairman of the Senate Budget Committee suggested that such a deal could involve the politically perilous step of tapping temporarily into the Social Security surplus.
 Pressure mounted on President Bush to drop his cautious approach to dealing with the weakening economy, much of it from within his own party. Republicans are voicing growing concern that the White House has underestimated public unease about the economy and the threat it poses to members of Congress up for re-election next year. 
 Confronted with polls showing that support for Republicans was eroding even before the government reported on Friday that the unemployment rate had surged, nervous Republicans moved on a variety of fronts. 
In the House, Republican leaders agreed tonight to take up legislation in committee on Tuesday that would require automatic spending cuts if any Social Security money was spent on other government programs in the current fiscal year. 
After accounting for the slowing economy and the tax cut signed into law by Mr. Bush in June, the Congressional Budget Office projected last month that the government would spend $9 billion of Social Security receipts in the fiscal year that ends Sept. 30. Both parties now expect that figure to be higher.
The White House sent a memorandum to all cabinet agencies today asking them to look for possible budget cuts as the administration develops tax and spending proposals for its next budget. 
In the Senate, Trent Lott of Mississippi, the minority leader, said he was open to an idea floated by Democrats for a tax cut for workers who had not qualified for the current rebate. Workers who do not make enough money to pay federal income taxes but who still pay the payroll taxes that finance Social Security and Medicare will not receive rebate checks this year.
Mr. Lott said he would like to see the idea linked to a reduction in the capital gains tax. 
"I would like to at least see how that would work, discuss it with Democrats," Mr. Lott said.
Mr. Bush, who met with the Australian prime minister this morning in Washington and then flew to Florida to promote his education bill, was silent on the economy today. 
His spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said Mr. Bush remained confident that actions already taken, including the tax rebates and the Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts, would put the economy back on track. At the same time, Mr. Fleischer said, Mr. Bush is "open-minded about possible other ideas."
Today, at Justina Elementary School in Jacksonville, Fla., Mr. Bush repeated his plea for the Senate to take up his education initiative, highlighting $900 million in new money for reading programs. He gave no hint of backing off on that financing, or anything else in his budget plan.
"One of my dreams is to make sure that schools understand and have the resources available for schools within schools," he said.
On Capitol Hill, Democrats and Republicans alike groped for ways to address the economic slowdown and the attendant political risks.
The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, hinted in an interview that he would be willing to consider using Social Security money to address the economic slowdown if Republicans were willing to scale back some elements of Mr. Bush's 10-year tax cut. But Mr. Conrad's approach was quickly dismissed by an aide to Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader.
In the interview, Mr. Conrad said Congress's response to the weakening economy should be "more fiscal stimulus in the short run, more fiscal discipline in the long run."
Asked if that meant a willingness to dip into the Social Security surplus -- a step that both parties have promised to avoid -- Mr. Conrad said the focus for now had to be on the economy, since the United States, Japan and Germany were all either in a recession or on the brink of one.
"What we really have to keep our eye on here is the economy," he said. "The critical thing is that you have fiscal discipline over time, that you're not taking Social Security and Medicare payroll tax money for other purposes over time."
In the short run, Mr Conrad said, more fiscal stimulus could be critical to keeping the economy from worsening. The details, he said, "could be worked out with Republicans."
Mr. Conrad said his position had been the same throughout this year's budget debate, but his language represented a clear shift in emphasis from the longstanding Democratic position that the Social Security surplus was sacrosanct. 
Mr. Conrad's views are not widely shared among Democrats. Tonight, a senior aide to Mr. Daschle was cool to Mr. Conrad's idea, saying, "Senator Daschle opposes using the Social Security surplus and believes that since the president rejected our budget approach and our short-term stimulus approach earlier this year, it is his responsibility to come forward with a plan."
In taking up the measure to cut spending across the board to repay any Social Security money spent for general government operations, Republicans in the House said they did not intend to be first to break their pledge.
"We'll send it over to the Senate," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, referring to the spending-cut legislation. "If Daschle is really worried about it, he can pick it up and pass it."
But Mr. Conrad's views are similar to the position taken by Mr. Bush, who has said he would consider using Social Security money if the economy lapsed into recession.
The flurry of tax plans and economic prescriptions come as Republicans in Congress are expressing frustration that Mr. Bush is not addressing the slowdown forcefully enough. 
Some Republicans are drawing a comparison to the midterm elections of 1982 when President Ronald Reagan told the nation to "stay the course" in a recession. House Republicans lost numerous seats in that election, but Mr. Reagan was re-elected in a landslide two years later.
Last week, on the same night that Mr. Bush was toasting the Mexican president at a state dinner, Congressional Republicans huddled at a dinner of their own on Capitol Hill that turned into a gripe session about Mr. Bush's passivity during his monthlong vacation. 
Republicans said the session began with a grim polling presentation from David Winston, a Republican consultant. The presentation showed that more people now believed that the nation was heading in the wrong direction than in the right one. Support for Congressional Republicans is slipping as next year's election approaches, the survey found.
Particularly worrisome to the Republicans was evidence that voters ages 55 to 64 were defecting from the party in large numbers, because of declines in the value of 401(k) plans that many people are counting on to finance their retirements.
Mr. Winston was followed by Nicholas Calio, Mr. Bush's Congressional liaison. Republicans said Mr. Calio gave a pep talk about the president's economic plan, telling the group that the Bush agenda -- tax cuts, trade promotion and an energy plan -- was geared toward economic growth.
Then a string of Republicans rose to express frustration with the economy, and in some cases irritation with Mr. Bush's long vacation in Texas. Several Republicans said that Representative J. D. Hayworth of Arizona complained that it was hard for Mr. Bush to get his message out if the White House lectern had a "Gone fishing" sign on it. Mr. Hayworth's office declined to comment.
Mr. Calio said today that the White House had heard those concerns. 
"We're talking to our members," he said. "We're listening, and we're doing some thinking ourselves." 
But Congressional Republicans continued to describe Mr. Bush and themselves as on different political timetables for 2002 and 2004; they said they could not afford to wait to take action on the economy and the budget situation.
