HEADLINE: CAMPAIGNING FOR MAYOR: MAYOR; 
Mayoral Candidates Crisscross City Seeking Last Few Votes

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS 

 BODY:
The six major candidates running to succeed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ranged across the city yesterday in the final burst of politicking before the polls open today.
 Dodging late summer downpours, the candidates hit neighborhoods where they thought they might be able to eek out just a few more votes. Crossing and crisscrossing the boroughs -- sometimes missing one anothers' campaigns by just minutes -- it seemed as though the six candidates were out to shake every hand in the city. 
 And shake hands they did, in Bay Ridge and Pelham Bay, in Stuyvesant Town and on the Lower East Side, in Staten Island and Flushing. Most ran late, racing to overcome traffic and, in one case, a computer glitch, but all managed to finish this last frantic lap around the city they hope to govern.

Fernando Ferrer
Fernando Ferrer, the Democratic mayoral candidate, went in search of blessings yesterday, both divine and secular.
In Williamsburg, Mr. Ferrer sat amid a clutch of black-robbed Satmar rabbis, who in turn gathered around Moshe Teitelbaum, the group's Grand Rebbe. The Grand Rebbe said a few words in Yiddish, and his translator, Rabbi David Niederman, turned to Mr. Ferrer to deliver the news. 
"You asked for a blessing, and he's giving you his blessing," Rabbi Niederman told Mr. Ferrer, who donned a yarmulke for the occasion. "You have the caliber to be the next mayor." 
The Rebbe's nod did not amount to an official endorsement, but a beaming Mr. Ferrer promised to make the most of it just the same. "I'm grateful, Rebbe; thank you so much," Mr. Ferrer said, rising from his seat. "I need one." 
And so the day unfolded, as Mr. Ferrer, seeking to become the city's first Latino mayor, skipped across the city in a final furious run of campaigning.
In a 13-hour stretch, Mr. Ferrer shook hands on the Upper West Side, spoke to a group of the Hispanic elderly in the East Village, took an endorsement from about 35 clergymen in East New York and then worked his way through Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens with former Representative Geraldine Ferraro.
As he wended his way around New York, Mr. Ferrer's voice sounded tired, and his eyes bore a weary look. But at every stop, he shook off his exhaustion and summoned a final bit of campaign fervor.
"If I look a little tired, it's because I am," Mr. Ferrer told a raucous gathering in Manhattan of 1199/S.E.I.U., the health workers' union. "But I got plenty of gas left in the tank. And when I needed a fill-up, I came right here to 43rd Street. Now I'm pumped up!" 
The crowd whooped and clapped. And when Mr. Ferrer finished, Tina Turner's "Simply The Best" began to boomed through the loudspeakers. 
As steadily as a drumbeat, Mr. Ferrer sounded the main theme of his campaign: the need to serve New Yorkers alienated by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and left behind after a decade's worth of economic growth. He reiterated his plea for expanded after-school programs, a commitment by the city to build new housing and for an end to racial profiling by the police. 
 DEXTER FILKINS

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Qwest to Cut 4,000 Jobs And Reduce Its Expenses

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
Qwest Communications, the operator of large fiber optic and local telephone networks, said yesterday that it would eliminate 4,000 jobs by the beginning of next year, adding to the woes of the telecommunications industry.
 Qwest's work force of 66,000 will be reduced 6 percent, with about a third of the cuts planned in or near Colorado, where Qwest is based, the company's chief executive, Joseph P. Nacchio, said. Slower economic growth in the western United States is one reason for Qwest's troubles, he said. 
 Qwest also reduced its spending and sales estimates. It expects revenue this year of $20.5 billion, down from earlier estimates of $21.3 billion to $21.5 billion. Next year, Qwest projects revenue to climb in the high single digits, down from earlier forecasts of a 14 percent to 15 percent increase. 
The company will cut spending by $300 million this year and $2 billion next year.
"In the last 30 days, we've seen more severe deterioration in the economy than almost anyone expected," Mr. Nacchio said in a conference call with investors.
The announcements initially unsettled investors in companies like Lucent Technologies, Nortel Networks and the Ciena Corporation, which sell equipment to Qwest. Communications equipment makers are already struggling with a steep decline in their revenue.
Qwest's move illustrates how the rapid expansion of communications networks in the late 90's has resulted in an excess of fiber optic capacity on these systems. Companies like Qwest that sell or lease capacity on their networks to large corporations are faced with plunging prices for that network space.
Fortunately for Qwest, it is more diversified than competitors that focus almost exclusively on selling bandwidth capacity. In addition to a 25,500-mile fiber optic network in North America, Qwest is the nation's fourth-largest long-distance phone company and one of the largest local phone companies with its purchase of U S West in 1999.
Investors responded enthusiastically to Qwest's announcements yesterday, pushing its shares up nearly 10 percent, or $1.76, to $19.90. Optimism over more prudent capital expenditures appeared to be the main reason. So far this year, Qwest's stock has declined 51 percent. 
"I'm glad that Qwest is finally becoming more conservative in its forward thinking," said F. Drake Johnstone, an analyst at Davenport & Company. "There was some valid concern recently that they were artificially inflating revenue."
Mr. Johnstone and telecommunications analysts from Morgan Stanley recently expressed concern over the way Qwest recognized nearly the entire amount of sales from 20-to-25-year leases upfront, instead of amortizing the amounts, effectively allowing the company to increase revenue on its balance sheet.
A Qwest spokesman, Tyler Gronbach, said that generally accepted accounting practices required the company to report revenue in such a way.
Another source of uncertainty for Qwest lies in the uneasy fortunes of Royal KPN, the largest phone company in the Netherlands. KPN, which is under pressure to reduce its debt, owns KPNQwest, a provider of broadband communications services in Europe, together with Qwest. 
In July, Qwest wrote down about $3 billion from its investment in KPNQwest as problems in European telecommunications and Internet industries worsened.
Over the weekend, KPN effectively ousted Paul Smits as chief executive after the company's share price had plunged more than 90 percent under his leadership. Page W1. 
In very heavy trading in Amsterdam yesterday, Royal KPN gained 10.5 percent, or 0.25 euro, to 2.63 euros, or $2.37. KPNQwest rose 7.1 percent, to 4.95 euros, or $4.45.
There is speculation that KPN may try to sell its stake in the jointly owned company. Any sale would largely depend on decisions made by Qwest because it has the right of first refusal to buy its Dutch partner's stake if KPN decides to leave the venture.
Qwest declined to comment yesterday on whether it had reached a decision to buy KPN's stake or allow it to sell to another party.

HEADLINE: A DAY OF TERROR: THE ECONOMY; 
A Tragedy Adds More Confusion To the Outlook For U.S. Economy

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The World Trade Center tragedy canceled all forecasts about the American economy. And whatever happens next in the United States, in turn, will inevitably affect the global economic outlook.
 Until yesterday, the economy's future -- whether it would revive or dip into recession -- rested on whether layoffs would inhibit consumer spending, whether business investment would revive, whether home construction and home prices would stay up. Now, what happens next to the American economy depends on how the public reacts to yesterday's terrorism, economists said. 
 The big issue, beyond the huge initial costs of repairing damage caused by the attack, centers on whether American consumers might stop spending until they know who is responsible for the assaults and whether they might happen again.
"Uncertainty causes people to seek information and suspend their judgment, and I think that will affect buying behavior initially," said Richard T. Curtin, director of consumer surveys at the University of Michigan. "People are going to be fearful of public places for a while, and they are going to stop going to car dealerships and malls. And that is likely to cause a decline in consumer spending."
In the past, cataclysmic events often affected the economy's direction. The Persian Gulf crisis, for instance, with its war jitters and higher oil prices, helped to bring on the 1990-1991 recession, while Pearl Harbor forged a national consensus to spend huge amounts of money to defeat Germany and Japan -- and the economy boomed. This cataclysm, however, is different: No one yet knows who the enemy is or what the group, or groups, may do next.
"I was in London when it was bombed in World War II, but I don't think I saw anything like this," said Peter L. Bernstein, a consultant and author. "You expected the blitz to happen in London, but you don't expect this sort of tragedy to happen in this country, in this magnitude, without being able to see an enemy."
That changes the economic debate. Preserving the budget surplus is now likely to fade as an issue, several economists said, as the government makes a priority of repairing the damage and increasing security. Replacing what was lost at the World Trade Center is likely to cost billions of dollars -- not only in new buildings, but in reopening or replacing the numerous companies whose personnel were injured or killed and whose records were destroyed.
Although the rebuilding of the Pentagon and of offices in southern Manhattan could lift both the New York and Washington economies, the amount spent -- in the low billions -- would have relatively little effect on the $10 trillion national economy. 
Beyond the physical damage, big segments of the economy are likely to be frozen for a few days or a week. Among those facing the largest losses are Wall Street firms, because the financial markets are closed. In addition, the airline industry faces tens of millions dollars in refunds to passengers unable to travel while aircraft were grounded. FedEx and United Parcel Service also were grounded yesterday.
In interviews with a dozen economists, most were reluctant to speak for the record about the economy on a day of such tragedy. "I feel like there is so much human tragedy, you do not want to be thinking analytically or rationally about this," said James Glassman, chief domestic economist for J. P. Morgan Chase. "But we know that soon we are going to have to think about the economy."
Mr. Glassman and a few other economists were optimistic. "This is going to make America, and the civilized world, be defiant," Mr. Glassman said. "People are going to see this as a threat to the civilized world, and good things are going to come out of it."
That was certainly the reaction to Pearl Harbor, on Dec. 7, 1941, a Sunday. Stock prices fell steeply at first but recovered as the nation mobilized. The recovery, however, is not likely to come as easily this time, Mr. Glassman said. "We are likely to be in shock and mourning for several weeks, and that means volatile markets and less consumption," he said.
The American economy has been weakening for a year. The gross domestic product barely grew in the second quarter, and in recent days, forecasters have been lowering their estimates of economic growth for the third quarter to an annual rate of less than 1 percent. The unemployment rate shot up to 4.9 percent in August from 4.5 percent in July -- a rise that shocked the markets. 
Before yesterday's tragedy, the Federal Reserve's policy makers were widely expected to lower interest rates at their October meeting for the eighth time this year. They may now step up that schedule. Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, was flying home from a meeting in Switzerland when the terrorists struck, and his plane was turned back. But the Fed issued a reassuring statement noting in effect that it would supply credit as needed.
The lower rates had helped to sustain consumer spending, but now mood and psychology will almost certainly become crucial, said Humphrey Taylor, chairman of Louis Harris & Associates, the polling firm. 
"I have no idea whether people will stop spending," he said. "I'm told by my wife that there is a zoo in the supermarket; people are buying up everything because they think the world is coming to an end. They could decide the economy is already weak and they should hunker down. Or they could rally round the flag, come together, and come out of this stronger and more united."

PERSON: Joseph S. Berliner 

HEADLINE: Joseph Berliner, 79, Professor and Author on Soviet Economy 

BYLINE:  By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Joseph S. Berliner, a longtime Brandeis University economics professor credited with helping spur changes in the Central Intelligence Agency's methods of appraising the Soviet economy, died on Sept. 2 at a Boston hospital. He was 79 and lived in Cambridge, Mass.
 The cause was complications after surgery, said Barney K. Schwalberg, a Brandeis colleague. 
 Dr. Berliner was one of the most influential of the early American experts on the Soviet economy after World War II.
In 1991 he was on a panel of nongovernmental experts on the Soviet economy created by the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence to review the C.I.A.'s estimates of Soviet economic growth and defense expenditures from 1970 to 1991. The Soviet Union was formally dissolved in December 1991. 
Dr. Berliner agreed with the panel's conclusions that the C.I.A.'s estimates of major Soviet economic statistics were not worse than those produced by independent scholars but that the agency's estimates of Soviet defense expenditures suffered from lack of contact with outside experts on that subject.
The panel's chairman, James R. Millar, professor of economics and international affairs at George Washington University, said the C.I.A. had made changes in its methods in response to the panel's findings, including increasing contacts with academia and other outside agencies, like the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the private research agency Plan Econ.
At Dr. Berliner's death he was a research associate at the Davis Center for Russian Studies at Harvard.
A native New Yorker, Joseph Scholom Berliner grew up in the Rockaway Beach section of Queens. He received bachelor's and master's degrees and his doctorate from Harvard and taught at George Washington and Syracuse Universities before moving to Brandeis, where he taught from 1963 to 1985. His books include "Factory and Manager in the U.S.S.R." (1957, Books on Demand), "The Innovation Decision in Soviet Industry (1976) and "Soviet Industry from Stalin to Gorbachev" (1988, Cornell University Press).
He is survived by his wife, Ann; two sons, Paul, of Evanston, Ill., and Carl, of Jerusalem; a daughter, Nancy Berliner of Manhattan; two sisters, Ruth Schargel of Delray Beach, Fla., and Edna Berkowitz of Phoenix; and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: A DAY OF TERROR: THE MARKETS; 
Stocks Tumble Abroad; Exchanges in New York Never Opened for the Day

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS and JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Financial markets plunged in two hemispheres before trading was halted yesterday after the attacks that destroyed the World Trade Center and damaged the Pentagon.
 American stock markets did not open and will remain closed today. It will be the first time that news has kept the New York Stock Exchange closed for two full days since the Great Depression. 
 The coordinated attacks caused traders to sell any assets that seemed at all risky. Stock prices in Europe plunged, as did those in Latin America before trading was halted. Gold and crude oil prices leaped as investors speculated that the attacks might be related to Mideast tensions. 
Stunned traders, some mourning friends who worked in the World Trade Center and are presumed dead, talked of their worries that the attack would further damage an already fragile world economy.
But there was little certainty, reflecting the fact that nothing like yesterday's coordinated terrorist attacks had ever been seen.
Trading did continue in currencies, and the dollar fell in value against the euro, the British pound and the Japanese yen. "There is a fear now that the U.S. is vulnerable in a way it never has been before," said Jeremy P. Fand, a foreign exchange strategist at UBS Warburg.
In Europe, the falls in major stock markets ranged from 4.6 percent in Spain to 8.5 percent in Germany. The German market had a small recovery from its lows before it closed, but there was no rebound in most European markets.
Still, some hoped those falls would be temporary. "The Americans have an incredible resilience," said David Donnelly, who runs a London-based hedge fund, Gordon House Asset Management. "They will come back from this hard and fast," he predicted, assuming that President Bush "is seen to be a real leader and takes extremely tough action."
The terrorist attacks came on a day when markets around the world were advancing, after the American market stabilized the day before. But they also came at a time when there was talk of the first global recession in a quarter century. No one was certain how the terrorism would affect markets and economies in coming months, but there was concern.
"The world was looking for the United States economy to recover later this year and help the global economy get back on its feet," said Michael Taylor, an economist with Merrill Lynch in London. "Suddenly, everything that seemed well established has been blown out of the water," he added.
American consumers have so far remained relatively optimistic as the economy has slowed, and there were concerns that they would pull back, further slowing the economy. "What's going to happen to the economy in the next 30 days?" asked one economist, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "Are you going to get on an airplane?"
But some recalled that market reactions to horrid news are often excessive. "It's a little early for a forecast on this," said Barton Biggs, the chief global strategist at Morgan Stanley, speaking from the company's offices in midtown. "We're probably getting an overreaction in Europe. Do I think this is going to change the world economy? No, I do not."
Charles Clough, a Boston-based money manager who runs Clough Capital, agreed. "It's an $11 trillion economy," he said. "My guess is that after an initial shock, there will not be a lot of effect on the economy or markets."
Even where trading continued, as in currencies, there was not much volume. "I think most people are stunned," said David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics in Essex, Conn. "I don't think people want to get in and take advantage" of the tragedy, he added. "It's too devastating to put into terms of profit and loss."
The first plane crash into the World Trade Center was at first seen by many as an accident, but it still caused American stock index futures, which were trading, to plunge. Futures on the Standard & Poor's 500 index, which were trading a little above 1,100, fell to as low as 1,066.
The major market for United States government bonds is through Cantor Fitzgerald, a brokerage firm based in the World Trade Center. "The Cantor screen went blank immediately," said Paul Devlin, a proprietary bond trader for Fuji Securities in New York. 
There was limited trading for a time through competitive systems, with bond prices rising as investors sought safety. But after the second plane hit the World Trade Center, said a trader who asked not to be named, he decided to stop providing prices at which his firm would trade. "I was not going to put our firm at risk at a time like this," he said. The Bond Market Association soon recommended that trading be halted, and last night said there would be no trading today.
After the first plane hit the World Trade Center, Richard Grasso, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, talked to Harvey Pitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and they agreed to delay the opening of stock trading. After the second plane hit the center, trading was canceled for the day by both the Big Board and Nasdaq. Other financial markets also canceled trading.
In an interview last night, Mr. Pitt said he hoped that trading would resume soon, but did not give a date. One issue, he said, was when it would be appropriate to trade after such devastation. The other was a practical one, concerning physical dislocations for many firms. "Our markets are very resilient," he said. "People are moving rapidly to get them reopened."
The New York Stock Exchange has suffered prolonged closures only twice in its history, at the beginning of World War I, from July 31 to Nov. 14, 1914, and from March 4 to March 14, 1933, when banks were closed to allow regulators time to determine which banks had failed.
On Friday, Nov. 22, 1963, the market closed early, at 2:07 p.m., after President John Kennedy was assassinated. By then, the Dow Jones industrial average had fallen 2.9 percent. The market remained closed on the following Monday, when the funeral was held, and rallied sharply when trading resumed the next day.
If there was a haven of strength in the markets yesterday, it was in oil. In London, the price of Brent crude for November delivery jumped to $28.87 a barrel, up $1.50. In Paris, the big winner was TotalElfFina, the French-Belgian oil company, whose share price rose almost 4 percent even as the overall French stock market plunged 7.4 percent.
Gold also got a boost. At the afternoon fixing in London, the price leaped $15.50 to $287 an ounce. 
The worst-hit stocks in many markets were airlines and insurance companies. British Airways fell 21 percent, while Lufthansa was down 14 percent. AXA, the large French insurance company, fell 12 percent on the expectation of large claims in the wake of the attacks.
While the dollar was weak against major currencies, falling to 119.20 yen from 121.04 the previous day, and seeing the euro rise to 91.5 cents from 89.8 cents, it strengthened against Latin American currencies. The Brazilian real fell to a record low of 2.66 to the dollar, up from 2.61, while the leading Brazilian stock index plunged 9.2 percent before trading was halted. The Mexican stock market was down 5.6 percent as the peso also weakened. All the major Latin markets were closed early.
In Argentina, whose currency is tied to the dollar, the leading stock market index fell 5.2 percent. Having recently received another rescue package from the International Monetary Fund, Argentina needs to attract foreign investors, and there was fear that a world suddenly hesitant to take risks would pull back.

HEADLINE: A DAY OF TERROR: THE FEDERAL RESERVE; 
The Financial World Is Left Reeling by Attack

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON and STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 

 BODY:
Concerned that the terrorist attack could ignite economic and financial problems in the United States and around the world, the government scrambled today to reassure markets and keep a global slowdown from becoming something worse.
 Within hours of the attacks in New York and Washington, the Federal Reserve issued a statement saying it was operating as normal and was making credit available to banks that might need it. 
 There was immediate speculation that the Fed would move soon, perhaps within days, to cut interest rates, as it has in the past when the markets and the economy have faced a crisis. The Fed has already cut rates seven times this year in an effort to bolster the economy.
Banks reported no major problems today, and the financial markets were closed, masking what could be considerable difficulties whenever they reopen. By mid-afternoon, regulators had decided, in consultation with the major markets and investment houses, to keep markets closed again on Wednesday and to review over the next 24 hours whether the markets could reopen on Thursday. 
Government officials and analysts said regulators were closely tracking a number of possible problems. They said they were concerned about a possible wave of selling in the financial markets and about the loss of computers, records and key personnel among investment firms with offices in the World Trade Center.
More broadly, they said, they were worried that the confusion and uncertainty generated by the attacks would put more pressure on the domestic and international economies.
Stock markets in Europe and Latin America fell sharply after the attack. The dollar fell sharply, and oil and gold prices surged. Those developments, if they continued, could ripple into the economy at a time when the United States -- and much of the rest of the world -- appears to be teetering on the brink of recession.
"This couldn't have come at a worse time from an economic point of view," said Robert E. Litan, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution, the research organization.
No one knows how the markets and the economy might react to the worst terrorist attack in the nation's history. Much could depend on how the markets respond when they eventually open. 
But even a sharp fall in the markets would not necessarily be a good indicator of the economy's path; the 1987 stock market crash, for example, never did lead to the recession that economists expected at the time.
Still, there was an undeniable air of crisis as economic policy makers, along with everyone else, worked through the shock of the attack and sought to keep the economic aftershocks from adding to the human toll of the day.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and Paul H. O'Neill, the Treasury secretary, were both out of the country at the time of the attack.
Mr. Greenspan was returning to Washington from Basel, Switzerland, where he had attended a meeting of the Bank for International Settlements, with William McDonough, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. 
Fed officials declined to comment on Mr. Greenspan's travel plans, but news agencies reported that his commercial flight to the United States had returned to Switzerland.
Dave Skidmore, a spokesman for the Fed, said that Mr. Greenspan is "working and in communication" with the vice chairman Roger W. Ferguson Jr. and other officials. 
Mr. Skidmore said the Fed system had encountered delays in processing checks because of the cancellation of airline flights, but that otherwise there were no major problems.
Mr. O'Neill was in Tokyo, where he was preparing for discussions with Japanese officials. Treasury officials said Mr. O'Neill would remain in Japan "until further notice." Late in the day, they issued a statement in his name saying: "Our nation's financial markets are strong and resilient. In the face of today's tragedy, the financial system functioned extraordinarily well, and I have every confidence that it will continue to do so in the days ahead." 
Beyond any short-term response to market conditions, government officials confronted the likelihood that various policies would have to be revisited. Should the economy weaken further, Congress would be more likely to put aside the bipartisan pledge not to touch any of the Social Security surplus and to use some of that money to stimulate the economy through further tax cuts.
Despite the absence from Washington of Mr. Greenspan and Mr. O'Neill, government officials said there was close coordination throughout the day among the major regulatory agencies, including the Fed, the Treasury, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
While most of official Washington was evacuating its offices, senior officials activated an interagency committee that is formed whenever there is a crisis. The group, an outgrowth of the stock crash of 1987, is known as the President's Working Group on Financial Markets. It consists of officials from the Fed, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Treasury and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
Members of the group spent the day juggling calls from trading exchanges and investment houses, and from other regulators concerned about the effects of the day's events. They also consulted with foreign markets which could become particularly volatile in the coming days.
At the Fed, Mr. Ferguson, the vice chairman, was the only board member in Washington. He held a conference call late this morning with many of the presidents of the Federal Reserve banks around the country.
In Switzerland, Mr. McDonough, who oversees the Fed's monitoring of the financial markets, spoke by phone with Wim Duisenberg, the head of the European Central Bank, and held 10 phone conversations with regulators in Washington and New York. The Fed's money transfer network -- the central nervous system of the financial markets -- operated normally, Mr. McDonough said.
"It is clear that the normal financial system in the U.S. has held up extraordinarily well," he said. "I think the central banking apparatus and the market apparatus knows how to function."
Officials on the interagency committee, however, identified a number of concerns involving the economy and stock exchanges that needed to be addressed.
Would the day's events shatter confidence in an already shaky market and lead to unacceptably volatile trading? Did the system have enough liquidity in the form of easy credit to assure that major houses would not buckle? And how would Wall Street be able to cope with the devastating destruction of the World Trade Center, which houses many crucial market players, including some offices of Morgan Stanley and Deutsche Bank.
By midday it became clear, officials said, that the stock and futures exchanges would need at least a second day to adjust, absorb the tragedy and assess when they might be ready to reopen.
"The markets do best when there is a free flow of information and people are fully informed," said Harvey Pitt, the new chairman of the S.E.C.. "One of the difficulties is that what happened just occurred. And if one wants people to make decisions that are based on all the information that's important."
Mr. Pitt said that executives on Wall Street and officials in Washington agreed that the needs of investors to have access to the markets were outweighed by the tragic circumstances, as well as concerns about the ability of the exchanges to get back on their feet so quickly.
"In a free market we do not want to unduly tie up the right of people to trade," he said. "But at a minimum, because of the tragedy and for regulatory reasons, it makes sense for people to take a step back and reach conclusions about the market. While I would not dictate to the markets what they should do, there is a consensus that tomorrow it would be inappropriate to trade."
Mr. Pitt said that his conversations with the exchanges and investment houses made it clear that "notwithstanding the incredible amount of damage, there are a variety of fail-safe mechanisms," like backup record-keeping operations, that will enable trading to resume. 
He said that on Wednesday, the exchanges -- in consultation with their members and with Washington officials -- would reassess when the markets should reopen.
Officials were only beginning to grapple with the long-term consequences. The mayor of Washington, Anthony A. Williams, said he was considering asking the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to postpone their annual meetings later this month. The meetings were expected to attract tens of thousands of protesters, along with 12 heads of state and 15,000 delegates from around the world.

HEADLINE: A DAY OF TERROR: THE AIRLINES; 
For the First Time, the Nation's Entire Airspace Is Shut Down

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Minutes after two commercial jets slammed into the World Trade Center towers yesterday, the Federal Aviation Administration shut down the airspace over the United States to commercial traffic, the first time the government has taken such a drastic step. 
 All planes on the ground were immediately barred from taking off. Those in the air were given the option of continuing to their intended destinations or diverting to the nearest airport. Most airlines ordered their planes to land as soon as possible, placing thousands of passengers far away from where they intended to land. 
 Canadian officials quickly followed the F.A.A.'s lead, halting all commercial air departures from that country. The move cut off North America from a global economy that is increasingly lubricated by air travel. 
Late yesterday the F.A.A. said that the skies were clear and that air service would resume today at noon "at the earliest." 
The longer the grounding lasts, airline executives and aviation experts said yesterday, the harder it will be to get the airlines' complex networks of aircraft and crews back in sync. 
Airline officials were reluctant to speak for the record yesterday, citing a prohibition imposed on them by the F.B.I. But in the aftermath of yesterday's crashes, some executives worried about the damage the industry would incur at a time it is already suffering one of its worst business downturns. 
"How many people are going to want to get on an airplane after what they saw today?" asked one airline executive, insisting on anonymity. 
Some 4,000 to 4,500 airplanes were in the sky yesterday morning, according to the F.A.A. Hundreds more were on the ground waiting to take off. Parking the country's entire fleet of jets -- including those of cargo carriers like FedEx and United Parcel Service -- presented a logistical problem that airports and airlines had never before faced. 
"The ripple effect of this is amazing," said Dan McKinnon, president of North American Airlines, a charter company that operates out of Kennedy International Airport. "The parking space at all the various airports is going to be jammed. It's going to have a tremendous impact." 
Commercial jets are so expensive that airlines try to keep them in the air, earning money, as much as possible. Pilots and flight attendants are scheduled in concert with regulations limiting the number of hours that they can work without rest. 
Yesterday, many planes were forced to land in cities where their airline does not usually fly. There were no dedicated ground crews to serve them and no ready lists of hotels to house their crews and passengers. 
"The longer you are down, the more complicated it is going to be" to get back in the air, said one airline executive who insisted on anonymity. "Even right now it is more complicated. We have planes and people in the wrong place and crews that can't fly them because they have been on duty too long." 
For example, some of American Airlines' trans-Atlantic flights landed in Gander, Newfoundland, and Halifax, Nova Scotia. A US Airways flight bound for Seattle from Philadelphia landed at tiny Willard Airport in Illinois.
Continental Airlines said that more than 100 of its flights were diverted to alternate airports yesterday. Its flight from Hong Kong to Newark turned around over the Pacific and returned to Hong Kong. 
Many foreign carriers, like Air France and Lufthansa, also instructed flights bound for the United States to return to their departure airports. 
Many domestic airline employees, like most of the country, were in the dark yesterday about how and when air travel would resume. Airline call centers and information lines were busy, but there was not much information to share.
"As of now, we don't have a clue when and how the company is going to get things started again," said Sam Mayer, a spokesman for the Allied Pilots Association, which represents American's 11,000 pilots. "We have a lot of crews that are trapped in hotel rooms in many places. We are trying to take care of them." 
United Airlines and American also had to cope with the difficult job of notifying the families of passengers killed in the four plane crashes and helping authorities sort out what happened. But the freeze on air travel was hampering both their efforts to get people to the crash scenes. 
United announced that it was offering the families of victims on its flights $25,000 each to meet their immediate needs. It also said that it was sending people to Johnstown, Pa., and Manhattan, the sites of its two crashes. American said that it would also offer $25,000 payments to victims' families. 
All the airlines are required to refund the tickets of passengers who were unable to fly yesterday, said Terry Trippler, a travel agent who writes travel commentaries for the Web site OneTravel.com. Mr. Trippler said the requirement stemmed from the force majeure clause of ticket contracts, which went into effect with the nationwide grounding.
The refunds, the additional costs of caring for inconvenienced passengers and the loss of revenue as a result of the suspended flights will take a significant bite out of airline earnings at a time when most of the major airlines are already hurting. Only last week, American announced that it would lose substantially more money in the current quarter than it did during the second quarter. 
One airline executive who insisted on anonymity said the industry's woes were well illustrated by the relatively small number of passengers on the flights that crashed. The widebody 767 aircraft lost by United and American can hold up to about 250 passengers depending on the model and seating configuration; there were 56 and 81 passengers, respectively, on the two planes.
"It's really going to be a devastatingly tough time for the airlines," said David S. Stempler, the president of the Air Travelers Association, a passenger advocacy group. "This is going to be a big impediment. People are going to come up with a lot of reasons not to fly."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
ANIXTER REDUCES SALESAND PROFIT FORECASTS FOR YEAR

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Anixter International Inc., which makes communications wire and cables, reduced sales and profit forecasts for the rest of this year and said it would cut 14 percent of its work force and close some warehouses. The company, which is based in Skokie, Ill., said it expected third-quarter profit, excluding some costs, of 18 cents to 20 cents a share. The company was expected to earn 50 cents by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Anixter cited slowing economic growth and fewer sales to telecommunications and technology companies. Customers are spending less, especially on expensive projects, Robert Grubbs, the chief executive, said in the statement. Anixter employs 5,000 to 6,000 people, the chief financial officer, Dennis Letham, said.

HEADLINE: The War Against America; 
The National Defense

 BODY:
As the nation assays the horrific human and physical losses of yesterday's brutally efficient terrorist attacks, it must also begin the urgent work of determining how an open and democratic society can better defend itself against a threat that conventional armies and weapons cannot defeat. 
 Terrorism is not new, but the scale and audacity of the attacks in New York and Washington make it obvious that familiar defensive strategies are inadequate and that the fight against terror must move from the periphery to the center of American national security planning and operations. An unconventional and frightening assault on the American homeland has commenced. The American people and their leaders must mobilize the resources to meet it. 
 This cannot be just another moment when the president declares that the United States is unbreakable, when American military forces strike back ineffectually and when airport security is tightened for a month or two. It must be the occasion for a fundamental reassessment of intelligence and defense activities. There must be an exacting examination of how the country can face this threat without sacrificing its liberties. 
The best defense against terrorism is good, timely intelligence. The Central Intelligence Agency and other organizations have enjoyed some quiet victories, but much more must be done to try to infiltrate terrorist groups and to track their activities and communications. No one suggests this is easy or inexpensive work, but for the nearly $30 billion that Washington spends on spying, the nation should know more about terror networks and their plots. If more money can be usefully invested in these efforts, it can be provided by Congress.
When retaliation is warranted, as it will be in this case once the organizers have been identified, Washington needs light but lethal weapons to attack terrorist compounds in remote locations. Cruise missiles can be effective, but even more accurate weapons may be needed that can be used in coordination with enhanced intelligence information.
When Washington has prepared to act in the past it has often been stymied by faint-hearted allies. Some of America's closest friends have found it more useful to do business with countries that have either supported terrorists on their soil, been indifferent to them or been too afraid to go after them. America must let its economic partners and allies know that they can no longer stay on the sidelines of this global conflict.
While the United States must retain its conventional and nuclear war-fighting machinery, the government needs to consider a reallocation of resources to homeland defenses against unorthodox threats. That was the largely ignored recommendation of a national commission headed by former Senators Gary Hart and Warren Rudman that early this year noted that the relative invulnerability of the nation to catastrophic attack could soon end because of terrorist threats. 
When all that suicidal terrorists need to crumble the twin towers of the World Trade center are airplane tickets from Boston to Los Angeles, it seems reasonable to wonder again why a missile shield should be Washington's highest priority.
Tightened airport security seems such a painfully obvious way to enhance homeland security after yesterday's strikes, all of which used hijacked commercial airliners as deadly weapons. A nation with the resources and technological skills of the United States can develop detection systems that are far more sophisticated than those normally in use today. Indeed, there are already machines that can detect plastic explosives and other non-metallic devices, but they have been installed in only a few airports because they are expensive and deemed an inconvenience. 
Americans must rethink how to safeguard the country without bartering away the rights and privileges of the free society that we are defending. The temptation will be great in the days ahead to write draconian new laws that give law enforcement agencies -- or even military forces -- a right to undermine the civil liberties that shape the character of the United States. President Bush and Congress must carefully balance the need for heightened security with the need to protect the constitutional rights of Americans. That includes Americans of Islamic descent, who could now easily became the target for another period of American xenophobia and ethnic discrimination. 
Terrorism is a global threat. Part of the challenge for the United States is to recognize that the roots of terrorism lie in economic and political problems in large parts of the world. The end of the cold war has brought a resurgence of ethnic hatreds that were often stilled by the superpower conflicts between East and West.
The United States must therefore be adroit as well as strong. It will not be easy to address religious fanaticism or the anger among those left behind by globalization. The distaste of Western civilization and cultural values that fuels terrorism is difficult to overcome.
Americans have long known that these resentments existed. The nation must now recognize and address the fact that hatred has turned into a malignant threat that can destabilize the underpinnings of the world economy and civil society. The World Trade Center was not just a symbol of American prosperity. It was an economic nerve center. 
As horrible as it is to imagine, the United States must also consider a future in which the assaults carried out yesterday may be overshadowed by even more lethal nuclear, biological or chemical attacks by terrorists. We have long known that these dangers could be part of our future. It is now clear they may be nearer than most people thought. A concerted national effort to remake the nation's defenses must begin immediately.

HEADLINE: A DAY OF TERROR: THE VIEW FROM THE PACIFIC; 
Markets Slide in Japan, New Zealand and Australia While Others Don't Open

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 12 

 BODY:
The financial world had its first chance today to react in dollars and cents to the terrorist attacks in the United States as markets in some Asian and Pacific Rim countries opened for trading and braced for turmoil. Others decided to close for the day and watch and wait.
 The trend in early trading became apparent swiftly. Each market that opened sank precipitously in the first few minutes. 
 A deluge of sell orders choked the Tokyo Stock Exchange, delaying the opening, and when trading finally began, the benchmark Nikkei 225 index plunged by nearly 6 percent, plumbing depths well below the psychologically important 10,000 level; at the midday break, the market was down 5 percent. The broader Topix also fell sharply.
The disorderly start to the day came despite an early-morning announcement by the governor of the Bank of Japan, Masaru Hayami, that the central bank would take steps to keep money flowing smoothly, to maintain stability in Japan's financial markets and to deal with any disruptions in settling transactions. 
In New Zealand, the first market to begin the trading day, stocks plunged across the board at the opening, which had been delayed one hour by officials, who hoped to maintain orderly trading. The benchmark index fell by more than 5 percent in minutes before stabilizing at a loss of roughly 4.75 percent.
New Zealand's exchange lists few of what analysts thought were the most vulnerable stocks, like banks and airlines; Class B shares in Air New Zealand, the country's main airline, which has been in deep financial trouble for months, plunged 18 percent in early trading.
"We recognize the difficult position we were in," as the first exchange to open, said Bill Foster, managing director of the New Zealand Stock Exchange. But after consulting with markets in neighboring nations, Mr. Foster said, the exchange decided that the need for an open exchange to provide liquidity and market clearing was paramount.
Australia's market followed an hour later and did much the same, falling about 3 percent in the opening minutes; by midday, the losses were about 3.75 percent. Japan's markets were next to open.
Markets in Taiwan, Thailand and Malaysia decided not to open for the day. South Korea delayed its opening by three hours, to noon.
Currency markets were much calmer as trading began in Asia, with the dollar roughly steady against the yen. 
Soon after reports of the attacks on New York and Washington reached Asia, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill canceled two days of meetings with Japanese financial officials, cut short his Asian tour and headed home to the United States.
With Mr. O'Neill's mission to Asia cut short, the spotlight has abruptly swung away from what had been seen in Washington as one of the most pressing threats to global economic recovery, the huge bad-debt problems weighing down the Japanese banking system.

HEADLINE: Porsche Reports 18% Increase in Earnings 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: STUTTGART, Germany, Sept. 11 

 BODY:
Porsche's fiscal full-year earnings rose 18 percent on demand for the new 911 Turbo and Boxster sports cars. The current-year outlook is "positive," said the company, which has the highest profit margin among carmakers. 
 Pretax profit was more than 1 billion deutsche marks ($459.8 million) in the period ended July 31, compared with 848.5 million marks a year earlier. Sales rose 20 percent, to 8.5 billion marks. 
 The carmaker is increasing profit and sales, as are competitors Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G. and DaimlerChrysler A.G.'s Mercedes-Benz unit, even in the face of economic slowdowns in their biggest markets, the United States and Germany. Porsche's new 911 Turbo costs 240,000 deutsche marks.
The company's pretax profit margin was 12 percent in fiscal 2001, the highest of any carmaker, and about the same as the year earlier even though the company has been investing in a new model, the Cayenne sport utility vehicle, and a factory to build it in Germany.
The carmaker said unit sales rose 12 percent, to 54,586 vehicles in the last fiscal year.

HEADLINE: A DAY OF TERROR: THE MILITANT; 
America the Vulnerable Meets a Ruthless Enemy

BYLINE:  By JOHN F. BURNS 

 BODY:
America the vulnerable.
 Since the end of the cold war in the early 1990's, there have been two Americas, existing side by side: the America that is the world's only superpower, dwarfing every other nation in its economic and military might, and the America that learned in one deathly hour on Tuesday that no amount of power can provide protection against an enemy with limited means but a ruthless determination. 
 For years that vulnerability has been a concern of defense experts in the Pentagon and elsewhere who have studied what some have called "asymmetric warfare" -- a 21st-century phrase for a concept that has been around in warfare since David and Goliath and has found its most menacing expression in the modern world in the suicide bomber.
But it has also been studied, and celebrated, by many of the terrorist groups that will now be on the list of suspects in the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.
One of those certain to be high on that list, Osama bin Laden, has made America's helplessness in the face of terrorism a rallying cry, one he has used repeatedly to taunt the United States and to draw new recruits to his ranks of suicide bombers. People close to Mr. bin Laden in Afghanistan, where he lives, today denied responsibility for the attacks. 
The theme of American helplessness, applied as often to Israel as to the United States, is common among the leaders of Islamic militant groups like Mr. bin Laden's Al Qaeda, as well as two groups that operate in the Palestinian territories, Hamas and Islamic Jihad, and the Iran-backed Hezbollah, which operates from Lebanon.
Although investigators may well absolve these groups of the New York and Washington attacks, there is little doubt that the officials will be examining the threats that the leaders have issued against the United States. None of the threats is likely to draw more attention than what Mr. bin Laden had to say about America's susceptibility to terrorism in a two-hour videotape delivered to a Kuwaiti newspaper this summer.
On the tape, which proliferated rapidly on Islamic Web sites and in mosques and bazaars across the Muslim world, Mr. bin Laden seemed to gloat as he spoke in Arabic of future attacks on American targets that he said would dwarf those he has directed in the past. "With small capabilities, and with our faith, we can defeat the greatest military power of modern times," he said at one point. "America is much weaker than it appears."
At one point, the Saudi Arabian-born Mr. bin Laden seemed to hint at a suicide attack in the United States. Over pictures of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the Egyptian-born Muslim cleric who is serving a life sentence in the United States for his role in the 1993 World Trade Center bombing, Mr. bin Laden described the cleric as "a hostage in an American jail." He added, "We hear he is sick, and that the Americans are treating him badly." Then, addressing his followers, he shifted straight into an exhortation to martyrdom. "You will not die needlessly," he said. "Your lives are in the hands of God." 
Since the tape surfaced in June, there have been other hints that a new bin Laden attack might be imminent. Abdel Bari Atwan, editor in chief of Al Quds al Arabi, an Arabic-language newspaper published in London that has kept a close watch on Mr. bin Laden and his pronouncements, said today in an interview with the BBC that Islamic militants in touch with the newspaper had hinted that a major attack was under preparation, without giving any hint of when or where.
Elsewhere on the tape, Mr. bin Laden called on his followers to prepare new suicide attacks to avenge Palestinians who have been killed in the past year's violence with Israel, Without specifying whether those attacks would be mounted against Israeli targets or elsewhere. 
At first, when the bin Laden tape surfaced it attracted only passing attention, partly because large passages were spliced from earlier bin Laden interviews and tapes.
But intelligence officials in Washington see it as the fullest exposition yet of the bin Laden strategy, and a rough road map to where Al Qaeda, his group, might be headed. 
One of the characteristics that has set Mr. bin Laden aside among terrorist leaders has been the way he has coupled the furtiveness inherent in his deadly trade with warnings that new attacks may be in hand.
On several occasions, he has done this by releasing tapes or interviews alluding to new attacks shortly before they have been carried out.
He did this with a tape that surfaced in the Middle East shortly before two Arab-speaking suicide bombers in a fiberglass skiff attacked the American destroyer Cole last October in Aden harbor in Yemen, killing 17 American sailors. In the latest tape, he promised that the Cole attack was only a preliminary to new strikes. Although recent weeks have seen the State Department issue a flurry of alerts, and temporarily close several embassies considered possible targets, experts were not convinced that the tape presaged a major strike, partly because much of it had been taken from tapes made as much as three years ago.
On the tape, Mr. bin Laden read a chilling poem with themes that have a powerful resonance among Muslims with the grievances against America.
Principal among these grievances is Israel, and the support it draws from the United States -- a shift in emphasis, according to intelligence experts. In the past, Mr. bin Laden, one of more than 50 children of a Yemeni-born migrant who made a vast fortune building roads and palaces in Saudi Arabia, has made his principal obsession driving American troops from the Arabian peninsula, site of Mecca and Medina, Islam's holiest sites.
But this time, "purifying" the holy places seemed to take second place behind supporting Palestinians. Over scenes of some of the harshest incidents, like footage of a young Palestinian boy shot in his father's arms as they sought shelter from crossfire in Gaza, Mr. bin Laden urges the killing of Americans and Jews: "We will see again Saladin carrying his sword, with the blood of unbelievers dripping from it."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
NEIMAN MARCUS REPORTS$20.6 MILLION LOSS

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 The Neiman Marcus Group Inc. posted a $20.6 million fourth-quarter loss yesterday, in contrast to a year-earlier profit, and said its first-quarter same-store sales would suffer because of the soft economy. The Dallas-based retailer, which operates Neiman Marcus and Bergdorf Goodman luxury stores, said that because of the economic environment, it expects first-quarter same-store sales, or sales at stores open at least one year, to fall 1 percent to 3 percent, while September same-store sales could slip below that rate. Neiman Marcus said its loss for the quarter, which ended July 28, was $20.6 million, or 44 cents a share, in contrast to a profit of $10.1 million, or 21 cents a diluted share, a year ago.

HEADLINE: A DAY OF TERROR: THE VICTIMS; 
Companies Scrambling to Find Those Who Survived, and Didn't

BYLINE:  By JOHN KIFNER and AMY WALDMAN

 BODY:
The businesses whose presence in the World Trade Center seemed to symbolize economic potency scrambled last night to find thousands of employees feared lost in the ruins. 
 Banks, law firms, insurance companies and investment houses set up special phone lines or posted notices on their Web sites, asking employees to call in. Each call brought relief; each hour of silence, dread. 
 Officials at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the largest tenant at the center with more than one million square feet, set up a command center and a special telephone line to try to trace the 3,500 employees who worked at the trade center. Two thousand of them worked on mid
range floors of 2 World Trade Center, one of the buildings that collapsed.
Company officials would not discuss any casualties last night. 
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey occupied about a dozen high floors in 1 World Trade Center, with an estimated 1,400 employees. Among those who had not been heard from at 10 last night were the executive director, Neil D. Levin; and its director of public safety, Fred Morrone, an official said. 
Marsh & McLennan Companies had about 1,700 employees on floors 93 through 100 of 1 World Trade Center. A notice on their Web site asked all World Trade Center employees to call a special phone number immediately. 
The Aon Corporation, the world's second largest insurance brokerage firm, had about 1,100 employees on floors 92 and 98 through 105. A spokesman, Stephen Ban, said last night, "We are literally contacting them one employee at a time." 
There was some good news. The law firm of Sidley, Austin, Brown & Wood said on its Web site that while its office in the center had been destroyed, preliminary information indicated there had been no casualties.
Jeff Lanka, a computer programmer for Bridge Information Systems, who walked down from the 58th floor of 1 World Trade Center, said that all but 2 of about 200 employees who worked in the building had been accounted for, and those two had probably not been in the building when the plane hit.
More ominous was the silence from Cantor Fitzgerald & Company, the leading brokerage firm in trading Treasury bonds, which was based on the upper floors of 1 World Trade Center. Its screens, found in many firms that trade Treasury bonds, went blank right after the plane hit the building.

HEADLINE: PLUS: CYCLING; 
Julich Joins Ullrich's Telekom Team

 BODY:
The American Bobby Julich signed a two-year contract with Deutsche Telekom, the German team announced yesterday.
 Julich, 29, Lance Armstrong's former teammate, finished third over all in the 1998 Tour de France. He then left the United States Postal team for Credit Agricole of France. Julich, who appears to be recovering his best form after a string of injuries, becomes the second former U.S. Postal rider to join Deutsche Telekom. The first was Kevin Livingston. 
 The Deutsche Telekom leader, Jan Ullrich of Germany, won the Tour de France in 1997 and has finished second three times - to the Italian Marco Pantani in 1998 and Armstrong the last two years. (Reuters)

ZABEL WINS STAGE 4 IN TOUR OF SPAIN: Erik Zabel of Germany won the fourth stage of cycling's Tour of Spain from Leon to Gijon, edging Oscar Freire of Spain in a sprint finish for his third consecutive stage victory.
 Santiago Botero of Colombia took the race leader's gold jersey from David Millar of Britain after a crash near the finish split the field. Botero now leads Millar by four seconds, with Pedro Horrillo of Spain another seven seconds back in third place.
 Tomorrow's fifth stage takes the riders into the mountains for the first time on a 101-mile journey from Gijon to Lagos de Covadonga. The race concludes Sept. 30 in Madrid. (Bloomberg News)

ITALIAN CYCLISTS BANNED FOR DRUGS: The Italian cyclists Dario Frigo and Marco Magnani were banned fro the sport for six months for possessing performance-enhancing durgs, the Italian cycling federation said yesterday.
 The police seized banned substances from their hotel rooms in an overnight raid at the Tour of Italy in June. Frigo, 27, second in the race at the time, was dismissed by his Fassa Bortolo team and later admitted taking banned drugs. Their suspensions come as the sport seeks to clean up its image following three years of revelations about drug taking by leading cyclists. This year's Tour de France produced just one drug-test failure among 189 riders.
 Frigo is unemployed, and Magnami rides for Alexia Alluminio, and Italian team. Four other Italian riders - Matteo Carrara and Renzo Mazoleni of Team Colpack-Astro, Daniele De Paoli of Mercatone Uno-Stream TV and Gabriele Massaglia of Lampre-Daikin - are under investigation on suspicion of possessing banned drugs, but their cases were postponed. No date has been set for a new hearing.
 Michele Ferrari, the Italian doctor who has worked with the Tour de France winner Lance Armstrong, awaits a Sept. 21 hearing. He is accused of procuring and supplying banned substances to cyclists. (Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: Italy and Rest of Europe Differ on Rome Leader 

BYLINE:  By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

DATELINE: ROME, Sept. 11 

 BODY:
One of the first laws proposed after Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi took office would change how certain white collar crimes are prosecuted in a way almost certain to benefit the country's most famous defendant: Mr. Berlusconi.
 Of course, the prime minister, Italy's richest man, who has three accounting fraud cases pending against him, has never exactly been paralyzed by a preoccupation with appearances. 
 He owns much of the news media that cover his government, as well as the polling company that shows him with an unprecedented 70 percent approval rating. One of his lawyers is the member of Parliament who, as he puts it, "explained" the corporate crime legislation, expected to become law, to the parliamentary committee.
In the three months since Mr. Berlusconi took office, his effect on Italian political life has been outsized. He has not only quieted the uproar that followed police brutality during the Group of 8 meetings in Genoa, but has also used the violence and isolated incidents of terrorism in Italy recently to marshal support for his tough law-and-order agenda. 
Tonight, his minister of reforms, Umberto Bossi, of the rightist Northern League, suggested that the terrorist attacks on the United States had proven the Berlusconi government right in its more authoritarian line. "One could sense that terrorism was coming back," he said.
Mr. Berlusconi has also signaled his intention to engineer a series of fundamental legal and social changes -- adding criminal penalties for illegal immigration for the first time, for instance, and financing private schools in a way that is now unconstitutional.
In a Europe governed mainly by the center-left, Mr. Berlusconi's moves have caused a stir. There is suspicion of his methods, and there is concern about his mingling of political and business interests.
"He's very authoritarian, and that's creating a lot of problems for Italy," said Gert Weisskirchen, foreign policy spokesman for legislators from the Social Democratic Party of Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany. 
"The whole European style of democracy demands a clear separation of political power from the power of the media, but he's thrown out that rule, and put the whole framework of Italian democracy in danger."
James Walston, a professor of political science at the American University of Rome, said, "The rest of Europe is extremely worried, but not quite sure how to respond and hesitant to criticize too forcefully after their experience with Haider," the far-right Austrian Jorg Haider. 
Last year the European Union imposed sanctions on Austria after Mr. Haider's party joined the government, but the effort backfired, uniting humiliated Austrians against what they saw as their meddling neighbors.
Italians are already hunkering down in the face of foreign criticism.
Such references as a recent one in the British daily The Guardian, calling Mr. Berlusconi and his ministers "Italy's telegenic ancient mariner and his 'post-Fascist' crew," are being written off as anti-Italian. "People using that language are the victim of some prejudice," said Marcello Pera, the well-spoken president of the Senate, who is a member of Mr. Berlusconi's party, Forza Italia. 
Mr. Pera said Italians were willing to wait and see what the government actually does rather than being upset by rumors and slurs.
Mr. Berlusconi, meanwhile, is working mostly from off stage, leaving his deputies to float various proposals and sometimes to take the blame for them. He himself appears in public only rarely, exuding confidence and repeatedly referring to himself as Italy's paterfamilias.
Alessandra Mussolini, the granddaughter of the former Fascist dictator, who is outspoken on women's issues, says nobody minds.
"You know, people want the father," she said. "Yes! So Berlusconi is doing well."
Elsewhere in Europe, Mr. Berlusconi's apparently casual view of civil liberties has been seen as another unhappy reminder of why even Mr. Bossi, the formerly separatist Northern League leader, referred to Mr. Berlusconi as "Berluskaiser" back in 1994, the last time they were political partners.
But the prime minister seems to be relishing the opportunity to take a tough line. Last week, he announced that it was his duty, "as a good father of the family," to protect "holy" Rome from unruly demonstrators during a coming conference on global hunger.
This plan to move a planned world food summit meeting outside Rome reneged on a longstanding commitment to the Food and Agriculture Organization in Rome. But it was barely criticized inside Italy after Mr. Berlusconi said he would not allow a repetition of the anti-globalization protests in Genoa in July. He said he made the decision only after considering public opinion -- as measured by a survey conducted by his own polling company.
Later, one of Mr. Berlusconi's ministers explained that the plan was not only to move the meeting, but also to ban all demonstrations in the city while the meeting was going on.
Yet in Italy, the only forceful condemnation of the plan came from another member of Mr. Berlusconi's center-right coalition, who pointed out that the government could not suspend Italy's constitutional right to protest -- a scolding that ended the matter.
Much of the Italian public, though, remains not only outrage-free but openly admiring of even Mr. Berlusconi's conflicts of interest, which strike a lot of people as both irrelevant to them and a tribute to their top man's acumen.
Even the left, battered in the election in May, seems remarkably favorable to the new government.
In an interview, Francesco Rutelli, the opposition leader who lost to Mr. Berlusconi in the election, leaned back, crossed his foot -- sockless in a pair of blue suede loafers -- over his knee, and said he had seen nothing that concerned him.
"I don't think there's any authoritarian trend," he said.
"There are some worries, but if you ask people in a riot if they're in favor of the police or thugs, they'll say the police. And people do see immigrants as a bigger threat now."
Perhaps having lived through real authoritarianism, older Italians are less inclined than other Europeans to throw that word around. Certainly, they are used to living and thriving with a variety of governments and even, for long spells, no government.
Still, not everyone in the opposition is relaxed.
"He already has half the TV market, some print, plus book publishing houses, which makes it hard for us to speak to public opinion," said the former prime minister Massimo D'Alema. "If the mayor awarded himself the city's garbage collecting contract, he'd be arrested, but here we have all the political power, the economic power and the media power held by one person for the first time in a Western democracy."
Mr. D'Alema is also worried about the law on corporate crimes, passed by the lower house of Parliament but not yet by the Senate, which seems to benefit Mr. Berlusconi. It lowers the penalties for accounting fraud and raises the bar for prosecutors by forcing them to prove not only wrongdoing but also damage.
Even Gaetano Pecorella, Mr. Berlusconi's lawyer and the legislator who explained the proposed legislation in parliamentary committee, said it would probably help his client.
"The opposition has argued that this law was passed in order to favor Berlusconi," Mr. Pecorella said in a phone interview.
"This is, of course, not why the law was passed by Parliament," he said, "but it is true that a judge could, according to the new law, decide that since there is no clear damage done, these cases could be closed."
Mr. Berlusconi has also used the handful of bombs that have gone off around the country since the Genoa meeting to consolidate his political position. None of the bombs caused serious injury. After today's terrorist attacks in the United States, the government position is that it was ahead of the curve.
In a recent interview, Carlo Taormina, the under secretary of the interior and yet another Berlusconi lawyer -- better known for defending the former SS captain Erich Priebke for his role in the slaughter of hundreds of civilians outside Rome in 1944 -- said he saw the possible resurgence of terrorism in Italy as a real threat.
He said that "in the last years the climate has been somewhat lax" in monitoring potential terrorists, adding, "Organizations protesting against the state were not sufficiently controlled." He described the Genoa episode as "a call to arms" for terrorists, and added, "That's understood by the police and the security force."

HEADLINE: A DAY OF TERROR: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
Awaiting the Aftershocks

BYLINE:  By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 

 BODY:
Today's devastating and astonishingly well-coordinated attacks on the World Trade Center towers in New York and on the Pentagon outside of Washington plunged the nation into a warlike struggle against an enemy that will be hard to identify with certainty and hard to punish with precision.
 The whole nation -- to a degree the whole world -- shook as hijacked airliners plunged into buildings that symbolize the financial and military might of the United States. The sense of security and self-confidence that Americans take as their birthright suffered a grievous blow, from which recovery will be slow. The aftershocks will be nearly as bad, as hundreds and possibly thousands of people discover that friends or relatives died awful, fiery deaths. 
 Scenes of chaos and destruction evocative of the nightmare world of Hieronymus Bosch, with smoke and debris blotting out the sun, were carried by television into homes and workplaces across the nation. Echoing Franklin D. Roosevelt's description of the attack on Pearl Harbor as an event "which will live in infamy," Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, a Republican, spoke of "an incredible outrage" and Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York, a Democrat, spoke of "a dastardly attack." 
But mere words were inadequate vessels to contain the sense of shock and horror that people felt.
As Washington struggled to regain a sense of equilibrium, with warplanes and heavily armed helicopters crossing overhead, past and present national security officials earnestly debated the possibility of a Congressional declaration of war -- but against precisely whom, and in what exact circumstances? Warships were maneuvering to protect New York and Washington. The North American Air Defense Command, which had seemed to many a relic of the cold war, adopted a posture of heightened alert and suddenly seemed relevant.
Disappointing some of his political advisers and allies, who felt he should have returned to Washington at once from a trip to Florida to symbolize that the government was functioning, President Bush headed instead to Offutt Air Force Base near Omaha, where a more secure command post was available. At the height of the Cuban missile crisis, when the sense of danger was just as palpable, John F. Kennedy stayed in Washington.
The president flew back to Washington tonight, escorted by F-15 and F-16 fighters, as leaders of both parties closed ranks behind him with pledges of support and a stirring rendition of "God Bless America." In a brief, earnest televised speech, he said the day had taken "thousands of lives" and generated "a quiet, unyielding anger" in the nation. He promised that those who harbored terrorists would be treated as harshly as the terrorists themselves.
For Mr. Bush the attacks constituted a threat and an opportunity. A minority president, just a few months into his term, derided by many as intellectually inadequate for his job, he is likely to be judged, at least in the months ahead, on whether he can take command and act decisively.
Will he prove to be a Jimmy Carter, whose presidency was poisoned by his inability to resolve the Iranian hostage crisis? Or will he enhance his reputation, as Ronald Reagan did after the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger and as Bill Clinton did after the Oklahoma City bombing?
Samuel Popkin, a political scientist at the University of California at San Diego, who worked in the presidential campaign of Al Gore, said:"Many Americans have come to consider politics irrelevant in recent years. Now politicians matter again, and the president, in his role as commander in chief, becomes our focal point."
In a statement made at an air base in Louisiana, Mr. Bush said that "the resolve of our great nation is being tested" and pledged that the test would be met. He is being tested as well, far more severely than ever before.
Senator John McCain of Arizona, Mr. Bush's sometime Republican rival, said that he was confident the culprits would be caught and severely punished and that the president would "ensure something like this will never happen again." Together, the two men's comments set the bar very high -- perhaps too high.
No doubt the public will rise to the challenge as best it can; many of those in the buildings hit today reacted with almost supernatural calm. But Mr. Bush alone must decide how to retaliate and against whom, and he will be operating in a murky area. 
"This went far beyond anything we had expected," a senior intelligence official conceded. "We're better than we used to be at monitoring terrorist activities, but today makes it obvious we are not nearly good enough."
It follows, then, that preventing another attack will be very difficult. And while it is evidently easier to identify malefactors after an attack than it is to predict their activities, many experts cautioned against assuming, for example, that today's attacks were the handiwork of Osama bin Laden.
Even if Washington concludes that his organization or some other foreign terrorist group was responsible, devising an appropriate response will present a number of complications. For one thing, bombs and rockets tend to kill the innocent as well as the guilty. As a Democratic senator said, "You're likely to bomb a city or a village with 100 terrorists and end up with 400 or 500 when the warplanes have flown away."
Some strategists suggested that Mr. Bush might mount a ground attack on bin Laden's headquarters, which are believed to be somewhere in Afghanistan, much as Woodrow Wilson sent American troops into Mexico before World War I to capture Pancho Villa dead or alive. But they did not get him. And Afghanistan has proved resistant, throughout its history, to foreign forces trying to operate there.
If the United States develops solid evidence that any country aided the perpetrators of today's attacks, said Richard C. Holbrooke, ambassador to the United Nations under the Clinton administration, a declaration of war against that country might be appropriate and retaliation against it should certainly be undertaken in short order.
Another consideration is the attitude of the Middle Eastern oil states to any retaliatory attack by the United States, which remains uncertain.
Many Americans, particularly those old enough to remember Dec. 7, 1941, compared today's events to the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. But then, after the first few minutes of confusion it was evident that the planes were Japanese -- they had military markings on their wings, instead of airline names on their fuselages, as was the case today. Militarily daring as the Doolittle raid on Tokyo months later may have been, there was no doubt that it hit the right target.
This was Pearl Harbor redux without the face of an enemy. In today's more anomalous situation, Mr. Bush is likely to avail himself more fully than he has to date of the knowledge, experience and prestige of his secretary of state, retired Gen. Colin L. Powell. The president "needs Colin like he's never needed him before," an administration official said.
It appears possible that the attacks will undercut Mr. Bush's campaign for a missile defense shield by suggesting that such a shield would concentrate American resources on seeking protection against the wrong kind of threat. People who wish the United States ill "don't need missiles to do this country harm," Professor Popkin argued, "and we saw that clearly this morning."
On the other hand, the attacks might persuade the American public that everything possible should be done, no matter what the cost, to protect the nation in any way possible.
It will be up to Mr. Bush to make that case. If he makes it well, it will be harder for the Democrats to mount a partisan assault on his plan.
It will be up to Mr. Bush as well, perhaps even more important, to keep the country from entering a kind of psychic bomb shelter, reluctant to make decisions, take chances, even to fly from one city to another after the four hijackings involved in today's campaign of terror. One of the most important contributions to Londoners' morale during the Battle of Britain was made by King George VI, who calmly toured the city despite the blitz.
Inevitably, the attacks will make daily life in the United States more complicated. Security will be tightened at private buildings and federal offices. Airport checks will be stricter and more frequent, requiring passengers to arrive earlier. In general, it will be harder to get about.
At past moments of national tension, like the Communist challenge following World War II, civil liberties have come under pressure. Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, warned today that "if we alter our basic freedoms, our civil liberties, change the way we function as a democratic society, then we will have lost the war before it has begun in earnest."
And what of the nation's economy, the main preoccupation of Washington, the president and much of the nation until this morning? Although the stock market remained closed today, Karen P. Hughes, Mr. Bush's counselor, was at pains to state at a briefing this afternoon that the rest of the economic system functioned normally. But it was by no definition a normal day, and sooner or later its hellish events are bound to affect the economy in some way -- probably not for the better.
